description:
Bottom line: go here for brunch!

What to get: the butter cake (OMG), grapefruit brulee (the carmelization makes it very unique), park tavern salad (goddess dressing is delicious), crispy polenta cakes (nice take on eggs benedict).

Ambiance: trendy casual, lively and a bit noisy. Bright, large open room.

Service: outstanding, super helpful and quick with the food and drink refills.
author: K R.

description:
Large, nice looking restaurant right on Washington Square Park.  We came here for an early brunch on a Saturday.  We had:
- Marlowe deviled eggs (5/5) - Excellent as usual.  I could eat a whole meal of these.
- Croquettes (5/5) - Basically battered and deep fried muffin balls with an excellent crunchy exterior and moist center.  Really delicious, especially with the dipping sauces.  They're massive, too.  We had three between the two of us.
- Entrees: polenta cakes and corned beef hash (3/5) - These were fine but not memorable.  The appetizers were much tastier.
author: Simon L.

description:
I cannot believe this took me so long to write a review, I think it is because I live so close by and love this place (or want to love this place). I have been here and had a decent experience a few times for brunch, and definitely countless times for drinks but the last few dinners I had were very off-putting. The waiter did what he could to rectify the situation, which we appreciated but the food was sub-par at best. I was super disappointed to get my steak, which was cold and seemed as if it has been sitting out forever accompanied with some basic veggies that were not too hot either. My friend ordered the steak as well and also had to send his back, he got it medium which was also cold? I was so confused and for what they charge for a steak dinner I definitely expect to at a minimum enjoy it but in this case it was hardly edible and very bland and extremely hard and chewy. 

The waiter did not offer any discount or compensation for the awful dining experience but he was very awesome, polite and charming so he did the best to make us have a enjoyable dinner for the most part. 

Would love to come back but can't justify spending the $ when it is so unreliable.

Brightside:The bartenders are phenomenal people and the deviled eggs are to die for, I will miss that. :(
author: Ellie J.

description:
Popped in here last summer for a drink after putting our name down at a local pizza place.

It's quite an intimate, romantic place, despite the high volume of passers through. As many have said before, large parties are the most intimate.

We sat at the bar in the middle of the room, and our server took my order surprisingly soon after we sat down. 

I just ordered a McLaren and closed out. The drink was made in a decent amount of time, and it was deliciously refreshing. 

I loved the interior, including the copper table tops. 

The employees seemed to work well under pressure. I would describe them as efficient and polite. 

If I ever live in the Bay Area again, I would like to return to try the food. This place is just my type: bougie, but not so trendy that it would quickly go out of style.
author: Colby D.

description: I love this place, came last year. Deviled eggs are pricey but worth it. Shrimp and grits was wonderful, I was daring and added an over medium egg on top! Going tomorrow will post updated pics. I've never been let down here before so I know it will be amazing!
author: Ashley B.

description:
My husband surprised me and brought me here for my 30th birthday dinner! It seriously couldn't have been better. We were seated in this 2 person corner booth that overlooked the restaurant; the space is definitely hip and happening but the sound is not overbearing or annoying at all. 

I love the open kitchen aspect and the bar area is a place that I would happily grab an after dinner drink and snack. 

The restaurant was celebrating their own 7th birthday with a special menu that was a DEAL! My husband and I both got the deal that included 4 courses (1st - champagne & deviled egg, 2nd - choice of salad, 3rd - poulet noir (roasted king bird) & 4th - carrot cake). It was all freaking incredible. i don't even like deviled eggs and I could've eaten an entire platter of these. My main dish was served beautifully and SO yummy. I couldn't even finish half of it but I definitely enjoyed what I did it. And the carrot cake was incredible; perfect amount of sweet and savory. 

The service was amazing as well. We were greeted so well, allowed to check out the menu and didn't felt rushed one time during the night. Our server was so nice and gracious in how she treated us, which made the experience even more delightful. I can NOT say enough good things about this place. If you get the chance, come here! You will definitely not regret it. Thanks Park Tavern for definitely being the "icing" on the top of my birthday cake.
author: Bethany M.

description:
Park Tavern is having a renaissance. After 7 years in the city it's back to its old ways of impressive eats, inventive cocktails and exquisite service. Welcome back. For the record, I'm not saying it really went anywhere but, something has changed and it's the way I remember it from the early days...just fabulous. 

In a recent visit with a large group of coworkers we had an unbelievable evening. From the attentive service to the killer menu, it was truly a night to remember. My first cocktail was a perfectly poured martini and set the tone for the multiple dishes that graced our table. 

The unmissable dishes are below. 

The Poulet Noir - blackened chicken on a cast iron pan and trumpet mushrooms. No joke, this might be the best piece of chicken I've ever eaten. DO NOT miss this. 

Deviled eggs are still KILLIN it. 

The whole roasted trout. Cooked to mid rare and perfection. 

I could go on and on about the evening and food that we continued to order but, it's something you need to experience for yourself. Bravo!
author: Benjamin F.

description:
Dear Park Tavern, 

Take my money. Take all of it! My past two visits have been nothing short of amazing thanks to some stellar food and even better service. It's safe to say that we loved every single minute spent within this cozy SF staple.

I have two pieces of advice for you first timers when ordering:

1. If you see the whole roasted chicken on the menu, order it. Seriously, it's incredible. I know, I know, you always hear "don't order chicken at restaurants" but this bird is the exception to the rule. Rules are meant to be broken and this chicken will make you question these "rules," which were certainly were written by diners unfamiliar with Park Tavern and their ability to cook chicken correctly. 

2. The pork chop cooked how the chef recommends is just my speed. Juicy and plated beautifully, this pork chop has been revisiting me in my sleep. Yes, this chop is what my dreams are made of and I'm struggling to find something to compete with this perfectly prepared pork in San Diego. Soooo... how long will SF to SD delivery take? 10 hours? Worth the wait! 

One final note is to keep an eye on the restaurant floor for a speedy, little, blonde, Kiwi, bussing tables, running food and chatting it up with diners. This hard-working beauty is the owner, not afraid to roll up her sleeves, get her hands dirty, and aim to please. Other SF restaurant owners take notes... she's got the restaurant/service game nailed. 

Thanks Park Tavern!
author: Brad B.

description:
I think most cities probably have a Park Tavern, Tavern at The Park, Tavern in The Park, or some sort of variation of this title. Don't let the generic name fool you though, this place is far from an average experience. Between the food, cocktails and service I can't really think of a restaurant in San Francisco I've enjoyed more. 

A few of my highlights include the Deviled Eggs, Demons on Horseback, Kobe Beef Tartare, and the Marlowe Burger. Honestly though, I was here with a big group of coworkers who weren't shy about sharing so the meal was really just a blur of amazing bites for our over 2hr long dinner. For that reason, I can't be much help on one thing you must order. 

The whole meal was met with impeccable service from every bit of staff who even came close to our table. The owner? She was on the front lines hustling to greet just about every single person who walked through the doors. It was really impressive and a testament to all the amazing service feedback they've already gotten. 

If you're in San Francisco and need a safe bet for a dinner of any occasion, don't let the simple name scare you away. This spot is a sure thing.
author: Danny W.

description: Yes was actually pleasantly surprised. The staff was great and the food was yummy. Was pricey but the ambiante is nice and expected. Had the trout that melted in my mouth and others had the steak and the ravioli. All amazing all around.
author: Viji V.

description:
Came here with a late reservation Saturday night.

We got the fries, melon salad, waygu jerky, and the deviled eggs as appetizers.

The fries and the deviled eggs are a MUST! the Waygu jerky is a big skip.. it's pretty chewy and dry.

I got the pork chop, which was a little on the fatty side. Our table was kind of in this dark corner, so it was hard to see the food and cut out the fat. I was constantly spitting some of it out.

But overall, I enjoyed everything here.
author: Jessica S.

description: Pretty much everything about Park Tavern is excellent. The decor is rustic and dark, in a classic timeless way. The menu has something for everyone. The Marlowe burger is always delicious, and we recently tried the ravioli which was great. Both are reasonably priced (~$20). I love that when you order something like a burger here, you get the meal and they don't nickel and dime you for fries or charge you $2 for cheese like other "nice" restaurants. In addition to the food, the service is exceptional. The servers are all really well-verses in both food and wine. It's team service, which means things come quick, and you don't even have to ask for water, the bill, etc. We live right down the street from Park Tavern, and it has now become our go-to spot for any kind of celebration.
author: Christian S.

description:
My favorite place in my neighborhood, period. No photos necessary. Going there is like foreplay. 

Oops, sorry to mix metaphors. 

What I meant is that the kitchen and wait-staff do everything right, treat my guests and myself -- and everyone who walks in the door -- like VIP's.

And you don't want the experience to end . . .

p.s. Tell me a better patio in the city! Park view. White table cloth. Heat lamps.
author: Paul A.

description:
We started with the PT fries which are truffle garlic fries and on the side is a soft boiled egg topped with caviar to dip. It was yum, but after I tried it once I won't order again. Next we had lemon chips with burrata. Wow they gave us a lot of cheese! Thank you Park Tavern for serving an appropriate amount of burrata! They give you a generous portion. As far as the dish as a whole, there were a lot of flavors going on. Too much for me. The lemon chips + burrata and the topping on the burrata + the herbs...it was a lot. 

Service-- I would never come here on their busy nights because when we came it wasnt busy and the service was very slow.
author: Katie C.

description:
My wife and I have been looking for a celebratory restaurant for us in the city. We may have found it. I was recommended to this place by someone from work and then every single person I told that I was coming here became very excited and said how amazing it was. I had high expectations. This place did not disappoint. 

The ambience is spectacular. It's up scale but still relaxed. You can easily dress up very nice for this spot or, wear something casual. It's got a great mix and I love a good restaurant with great ambience. 

This place has some spectacular drink offerings. Very unique flavorings to their mixed drinks and I was impressed at the very reasonable price. 

All the food looked amazing that I saw come out. That being said, the deviled eggs are out of this world. Seriously, you think it's just deviled eggs but they are wonderful. Probably the best I've ever had. 

My wife got the Cornish Game Hen and it was HUGE and delicious! I got the steak frites and it was fantastic as well. 

We'll definitely be back as we need to work our way more through the menu. 

If you want a spot for date night, work dinner or to take friends visiting from out of town, this spot is for you.
author: Matt M.

description: Amazing cocktail called the Piña Thomasa! I ordered two! It tastes like pineapple and slightly coconut flavored. It was super frothy with green flakes at the top, all my friends tried it and loved it. Some even ordered the same drink lol it even came with three blueberries preserved like Maraschino cherries, it was delicious! If you don't know what drink to get at the bar here, I say give this one a shot.
author: Alejandra A.

description:
Would recommend: deviled eggs and challah 
A perfect Sunday morning brunch spot. We ordered the deviled eggs and challah which were to die for! The challah is a lot more delicious than it looks, I had to restrain myself from making two orders. For my main I ordered the beef hash--it was ok, but definitely not something I would get again.
author: Rene C.

description:
3.5 Stars

What a fancy dancy breakfast joint when they have a place holder for the bacon. Hahaha

Sunday morning brunch with my Bestest and we ordered the following:

- Oatmeal walnut raisin pancakes ($13) = with strawberries and maple syrup. A little on the dry side.

- Cast iron baked farm eggs ($15) = with kale, shiitake, ham, and cheese. This was better than the pancakes. 

- Their "special" = poached eggs, arugula, and panisse. 

- Sides of bacon.

Good brunch, felt like we were eating for 3 ppl. Too bad, the service was slow and unfriendly.
author: Owie N.

description: Fancy, artisan, American are 3 words that come to mind when I think of Park Tavern.  The food was delicious and the atmosphere was like a beautiful updated farmhouse or something.  Crispy lemon chips sounded crazy, but were crazy delicious.  Marlowe burger was fantastic and the Poulet Noir is an entire chicken for those that don't speak french.  YUM!
author: Thomas J.

description:
This was my B-day party dinner and I'm not sure what happened but our waiter was always MIA and the food was not great, some dishes flat out were terrible but unfortunately we could not even send them back because he wasn't around.  We had a nice table by the window, so there was that. 

We started with the burrata and lemon chips.  The chips were bitter, there wasn't much burrata on the plate.  

The brussel sprout chips were OK, but nothing special. 

The deviled eggs were good, but again nothing impressive, it's like the chef was missing.

The duck was the worst offender, it was dry, overcooked and tough, it was one of the worse duck dishes I've ever had.  The polenta was dry as well, there was no flavor or sauce on the plate, but we were hungry and our waiter was nowhere to be found even though he was obviously getting a nice tip since it would be automatically added to the bill. 

The burger was OK, but again lacked flavor and anything special.  This is one of their specialties and again it fell flat.  

All and all we had a good time because it was a party and our wine and cake made the night sweeter.
author: Inga W.

description:
A little sultry, a little sleek, a little old school, a little trendy; Park Tavern combines a little bit of every good vibe and packs them into a place with a feel all its own.

It's actually quite unassuming from the outside, with simple lettering and a darker facade. Inside it's a lighter shade and straightforward decor that is all professional; a nod to the old school spots in SF that served your parents' generation--the parents that didn't go to Woodstock.

Located right there on the border of Washington Square park (and around the corner from a truffle spot that has my heart) it's a great piece of real estate with a view appreciated from big front windows.

I arrived with a reservation for 10:15am for brunch. Yes, they take reservations! Yes, they do brunch! It was almost empty, so we were lucky enough to snag a seat by one of those windows. 

The brunch menu is pretty simple. Some savories, some sweets, some starters. I had a really tremendous starter--the grapefruit brulee. It's exactly what it sounds like: thick slices of grapefruit covered in a light coat of sugar, then burned (hence the brulee) until lightly caramelized, and dressed with slivers of mint. The crispy, sweet shell paired with the citric bitter burst of grapefruit and cool minty aftertaste was a workout for my tastebuds, and they were invigorated.

I went with cast iron baked eggs, which was a bed of greens, topped with copious amounts of cheese and two eggs, baked to perfection. Simple ingredients but made in a way that felt new. 

I was able to try pancakes, and these massive beasts are good. One slight misstep--one of the pancakes on the bottom of the stack was clearly underdone with raw batter in the middle. Just give yours a quick slice to check, I'm sure they would fix it, if this is more than a one-off problem.

At the end of the meal, I realized the magic that Park Tavern has. As a fella who likes to explore new city cuisine, I really dug it. I was also there with a 70-year-old who has his routines and doesn't like fancy new stuff. He loved it to. New school. Old school. All rolled into one.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
The deviled egg, burrata and lemon chips, and the brussels were delicious. Apps are on point! Seriously though the burrata and lemon chips...mmm.

I enjoyed the wine and atmosphere.. a little dim so the table next to us was making out the whole time but romantic vibes so I get it. 

Service was great.. the server did try to bus a plate that had food on it still which I found odd but we caught her and she set it back down. 

The fish with the peas & the veggies on the Poulet Noir were bland but maybe I just should've ordered something else. The burgers were well received at our table and who doesn't love french fries!!
author: Natalie S.

description:
If I could give Park Tavern 10 stars I would.

We got a recommendation for a few dinning spots in the City. I will be honest to say, we ended up at Park Tavern because they had reservations available. Our reservations were at 6:30 on a Sunday evening and scored with parking across the street next to the park. We mentioned we were having dinner to celebration our anniversary. They seated us at a cozy corner booth. Our waiter, Michael brought us a couple glasses of complementary champagne and wished us a lovely anniversary. So nice.
Fast forward. Michael provided the best service. Seriously. He was timely, very professional, super friendly and gave superb recommendations. He did underestimate how much we can put down though. Haha.
We had the French fries and Brussels sprouts for appetizers. I had the Halibut that was served with some type of mashed potato and veggies. We also had a steak dish. Both were delicious and perfectly prepared. I even ate the skin on the fish.
Amazing dinning experience. We will be back!!
author: Jaime C.

description:
Ahhhh the memories......

I grew up around the corner from this joint on filbert, wonderful memories of my life in NB.  This particular location was once a funriture store called Figone furniture, was there for 40+ years. 

Too bed it still isn't a furniture store. 

Went last night with friends from out of town, almost all of North Beach was crowded, crazy night. Of course, had to do valet, that's cool. Love the interior of the place but WOW was it loud - at 9:30 p.m.!   Not only was the lousy background music too loud, and probably because of it, the crowd noise was like a five alarm fire.  I typically don't mind such lively environments, maybe my prior research on the place put me in the negative.

What I noticed from the online menu, it isn't very large and it is very expensive.  But alas, sometimes you get what you pay for, right?  Here... No.

Though the food was ok/good, it wasn't $16 for a cup/bowl of soup or $19 for some sloppy "raviolo" (wtf is that anyway ?!?!) good.  

The waiter was disinterested from the minute we sat down. I get it, it was late, but hey, the place is open, lose the jitter and cope. 

5 stars for the hood, the memories and the decor. 1 star for price, choice and noise. 

Too bad it still isn't a furniture store. 

Ya feel me ??
author: Johnny L.

description: Food is meh. Mediocre at best. Service is typical cold demeanor and dismissive San Francisco. Our guests from Italy brought two bottles of wine not knowing their corkage fee to be surprised that they charged us $45 each bottle, so $90 to have our two bottles opened. Ok. Maybe that makes sense to you, but I don't see the logic in charging that much. I've never seen more than $25 corkage fee to be honest and that's for even 4 Star fine dining restaurants.
author: Bridgette P.

description:
I have this place as a stop on my walking tour when friends visit. The drinks are great, the food is also great, but the portions are small.

I realize there is this "thing" with charging higher prices and giving smaller portions of really high quality food. However, I wouldn't put Park Tavern in the 3 Star Michelin category, so I docked a star for that. 

I'd highly recommend the deep fried fritters. Those things are delicious. Pro Tip: eat them for dessert instead of a starter. 

Overall I'm a fan of this place for a drink stop and an appetizer. I just don't love having a full meal where where I need to eat again afterwards.
author: Willard J.

description:
Sometimes it feels like you have to travel far for a place to feel magical. Not here. Here, I found the mix of near and extraordinary.

Commenting only on the bar, where I was seated this past Sunday evening.

Had a great bar-date here. Even if the date itself had gone sour, this would be my new go-to in SF. The space is wide, the lighting is soft, and the bar only occupies a fraction of the overall space, so it doesn't feel like everyone's conversation is rebounding against a nearby back wall. You can easily listen/be heard.

The GM, Morgan, was stoked when he checked in on me while my date went to the bathroom, and I told him I thought things were going well. Morgan--thank you for swinging by later and hooking us up with amaros to cap off the night. It was a really nice touch/assist.

Really enjoyed my interactions with the bartender, and other patrons as well. Strangely enough, I met/shook hands with a stranger in the bathroom (post-handwashing), which eventually led to an introduction to the owner (uh?).

Oh, and the drinks and food speak for themselves. They certainly weren't forgettable (The McLaren was refreshing and the deviled eggs were rich!). But I feel like the most special dining experiences mean you don't even remember the food, you know?
author: James Y.

description: Been here twice, people I came with have been more often and we all agree, it does not disappoint! Hands down the best weekend brunch in the city! I went for sweet but those who had savory dishes were saying how good their food was too! For starters the challah bread and avocado toast are super yummy - seriously the challah is DIVINE! The French toast was OK, I've had better but the pancakes are crazy, drop down amazing good! Coffee is very strong so be mindful of that. We were served by Nanette and she was awesome! Thank you Nanette, we had a great time!
author: Lily R.

description:
Two of my friends and I arrived on Saturday, July 29 fully intending on trying nearly every dish and drink on the brunch menu. The hosts were very pleasant and accommodated us immediately even though we were 20 minutes late for our reservation. 

We ordered cocktails and began to debate which dishes to start with when we were approached by our server. I asked a question about the smoked deviled egg on the menu, which he informed me consists of only HALF an egg for $3. When I expressed my shock and amusement at the price for a half egg, the server immediately became argumentative and told me that "there are other places to eat in the city," and essentially told us that we could take our money elsewhere. 

To this day, I am not sure what elicited his response. My friends and I, a group of young, diverse professionals (who had already ordered over $40 in drinks alone), were incredibly offended and chose to leave rather than subject ourselves to further insult. A manager did apologize once we got up to leave, but the experience left a bitter taste in my mouth. For a restaurant in a diverse city, that sells half a deviled egg for $3, you would think the servers would treat guests with respect. I was very disappointed in my experience and am not sure if I will return.
author: Akasha P.

description: This place is the beat! Originally came this way for Mama's but they had over a 90 minute wait, decided to come here instead. The food was excellent, we had the Smoked Trout Benedict and the Chorizo and Eggs. Both fantastic, we also had a Hummingbird each which was a great drink to start the day. Our waiter checked in constantly and suggested other places in the city since we were visiting.
author: Carrie B.

description: Best of the best  i really enjoyed my brunch there food was fresh tasty outstanding and great service thank you
author: Jiiji S.

description: Went here for lunch a few weeks ago and had the best experience.  Service really makes a difference.  Our server was Ninnette and she was just the best.  We went for my birthday and gave me the royal treatment and top my lunch off with a glass of bubbles.  Food and service was amazing.  From everything we ordered the deviled eggs and avocado toast was my favorite.  We will definitely go back and definitely ask for Ninnette again because she made our lunch 10 times better!  Thank you!!
author: Tanuja S.

description: Delicious breakfast with great service! Everything looked good on the menu and I had a hard time deciding. My table started with the jam and baguette. Very simple but very good! The jams were excellent, strawberry was my favorite. I decided to try to try the challah toast with cinnamon sugar and smoked deviled eggs. Both were really good but especially the challah toast. Sometimes the simple stuff is the best! I appreciated that they had almond milk for my coffee too. I'd definitely come back.
author: Kiki H.

description: I have to agree with the other reviewers that the whole chicken was amazing.  We also got the rib-eye and that was equally amazing.  Jason was our server and he did a great job attending to us with the drink orders and appetizers.    I can't wait to go back
author: Seth T.

description:
I am blown away by the food, staff and especially management at Park Tavern. The manager Morgan is funny, witty, and very attentive. You can tell the service is top priority at this restaurant. 

The food portions are quiet big. The duck was amazing and the devils egg were so so so good. Morgan and the staff kept checking on us and made sure we were having a great time. It was one of the best dining experiences I have had in SF.

I also love the oatmeal cookie. I am a big dessert fan and the oatmeal cookie is one of the best desserts in SF! If you like oatmeal cookie, this dessert is a MUST. 

I can't wait to go back.
author: Tina L.

description:
Park Tavern is a favorite for brunch with its brasserie experience that adds to the European vacation vibe of hanging out in Washington Square Park.

Start with a cocktail. From a classic negroni to a smoky Sutro Heights or the refreshing McLaren - Hendriks gin, cucumber, lemon, and ginger beer. Then move on to the "can't stop eating it" deviled eggs. They're incredibly addictive and a perfect bite of rich and creamy egg yolks, salty bacon, and spicy pickled jalapeno. The crispy Brussels sprouts, a staple at Marlowe, is a great sharing dish. Crispy lemon chips with burrata are a fun take on a classic.

The Marlowe burger is quite the classic but there are other good choices too. The seared halibut with sticky rice and bernaise sauce is a good choice if you're opting for a lighter meal. My fish was slightly overcooked but well-seasoned and I appreciated the contrast between the rich bernaise against the fresh spring peas and cherry tomatoes. The proud roast chicken that stands tall on the plate is a pretty impressive dish, as it is delicious too.

Service is lovely and attentive. Couple that with the relaxed vibe, Park Tavern makes for a lovely spot to dine be it seating outside for a sunny weekend brunch or a cozy weekday dinner.
author: Jon L.

description:
I'd say 3.5 / weak 4 - bit heavy for my taste but overall had a pleasant experience!

Venue / Service: came here for brunch on a Saturday afternoon with a reservation.  Service was fine, though for some reason it took them a very long time to bring out a tea that I had ordered.  Venue was a bit dark because of all the black wood accents inside so it kinda felt depressed inside.

Food: we shared the first two dishes and then ordered our own dish; all together it ended up being a bit much for me.  Might want to consider just one shared dish and then your own entree if you have a smaller stomach, given most of the dishes tend to be on the rich side...

-- Avocado toast (whole wheat sourdough, chile, lemon, sea salt)($10) - recommended by the staff.  Good amount of avocado vs. rest of the toast (sometimes there is not enough or way too much) and the chile gave it a nice flavor, especially since I think avocado is generally bland.
  
-- Smoked Deviled Egg (bacon, pickled jalapeno, chive)($3) - Recommended by the staff.  They give you quite a lot of filling, placing it between a one- or two-bite dish.  Bacon added a nice smokiness and the jalapeno gave a good kick.  

-- Cast Iron Baked Farm Eggs (sauteed kale and shiitake, jamon Serrano and Gruyere cheese)($15) - very filling, especially when you are talking about a nice, runny yolk and LOTS of cheese (maybe a bit too much cheese).  At least there was a decent amount of kale such that you felt slightly better about yourself after.  Kinda wish they incorporated the jamon Serrano into the cheese/kale/mushroom mixture rather than just sprinkle it on top... though I ended up brushing most of it to the side since it was super salty.  I was so full that I pretty much scrapped the cheese to the side and ate the egg and veggies mostly.

Our meal came out to around $25-30 for the food (we didn't order drinks or dessert).  Seems quite reasonable given the portion and richness of the food.

Between here and Marlowe, I tend to lean toward Marlowe- maybe it's because Marlowe has a brighter interior or maybe it's that I feel like Marlowe offers a few lighter options meal-wise and didn't feel so heavy after eating there.  Nevertheless, I still think Park Tavern is definitely worth a try as a solid brunch option.
author: Audrey H.

description: This restaurant is a great staple of San Francisco. When you don't know where else to go, this place is a crowd pleaser. Nothing to knock your socks off, but good food, fun atmosphere.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
Two of friends and I had dinner at Park Tavern last night.

For appetizer side dish of Brussels Sprouts, bacon wrapped shrimp and the Kobe beef tar tar. These dishes were all exceptional in portion size, presentation and flavor. 

For Entrees: two of us had Steak Frites and one had the Duck. I'm not a huge fan of Duck but my friend said it was excellent. The Steak Frites is where Park Tavern fell down for both my friend and I. The fries were crispy and soggy and we both thought that they were treated like a cheap plate filler. Even the plate design was odd - sort of like a cross between a bowl and a platter, with made the steak impossible to cut efficiently. I ordered my steak medium rare and it came out mostly rare and unevenly cooked. My friend's steak was cooked appropriately. This right here is the issue: inconsistency. Not enough to stop me from going back if I'm in the neighborhood - because this is pretty solidly a 4-start restaurant. Yet, for $80 per head (with one person not drinking), you expect the food above all else to be perfect. 

MISC: The waiter disappeared once toward the end of the meal. The bar does not carry Southern Comfort. The managers seem uptight. Our waiter was super-pleasant and knowledgable about which wines are paired best with the entrees (he paired a perfect selection with the duck). 

Finally, the "Summer Birthday Cake" was excellent. It was refrigerated perfectly - not ridiculously cold and not warm either. The cake was perfection - so our dining experience ended on a positive note.
author: Bulldog W.

description:
Perfect setting for brunches and dinners -- whether it's with a date or a group. I dined here recently for a company holiday dinner and had a great experience. Excellent service and cozy interior, especially during the holidays. The restaurant is located right in front of Washington Square Park, great location for a pre or post meal walk. 

Park Tavern is an 'upscale' American tavern, featuring a menu that rotates seasonally with a few items that remain year-round. They also have a solid lineup on cocktails.

What we ordered:

- PT Fries with truffle oil: You dip it in a soft boiled egg mix with caviar. Fries were crispy with a strong truffle flavor.  So good!

- Brussels Sprouts Chips: I thought it was okay. Too salty and oily.

- Smoked Deviled Eggs: Topped with pickled jalepenos and bacon. One of my favorite deviled eggs ever. 

- Demons on Horseback: Lardo-wrapped smoked prawns. I thought they put a little too much remoulade. Still great nonetheless.

- Crispy Pork Belly with forbidden rice, onion marmalade, and pickled mustard seeds: One of the favorite appetizers of the group. 

- Peppered Tombo Tuna with yukon potatoes, pole beans, olives, salmoriglio and radish: The tuna was cooked medium-rare and cut into large pieces. Not a huge hit, but the fresh tuna was a great balance with all the rich, heavy appetizers I had prior.

- Poulet Rouge: Wow, this dish is a like a mini rotisserie chicken served on a plate. It's kind of messy, because you have to dig into the chicken and carve out your own pieces. It takes up to 30 minutes to prepare, which is likely why all our entrees came out a little late. Fitting dish to meet a huge appetite. 

- Wood Fired Pork Chops: I didn't get to try this dish, but the portions looked huge. 

- December 'Birthday' Cake: Think pumpkin carrot cake with cream cheese frosting. The slice was served with a candle, though we weren't celebrating any birthdays. We all shared this since we were stuffed. The cake was gone in minutes.

Overall solid spot for locals. Highly recommend.
author: Helen C.

description:
My husband and I had dinner here tonight. The restaurant is celebrating their 7th anniversary and offered a Prix Fixe meal. We selected the chicken and steak dishes which were delicious. The shrimp appetizer included 6 scrumptious shrimp (a meal in and of itself). The salad was excessively dressed. The cream brûlée was coffee flavored, not the traditional presentation. The strawberry cake was light and tasty.

Unfortunately, the music was so loud that my husband and I could barely hear each other and we were seated right next to each other. It became progressively louder as we were eating, to the point that I had to take Advil for the headache I developed due to the volume. We were so relieved when our meal was over and we could get out of the restaurant to feel fresh air and get away from the loud music! We will not be returning anytime soon.
author: Linda F.

description:
We came here while on a business trip in SF - we wanted to get away from the JPM craziness. I really enjoyed the experience!

We started with drinks at the bar - they had a great negroni! To start, I had a deviled egg - it was wonderful. As a table, we shared the burrata with the fried lemon chips and the brussels chips. Both were amazing! I didn't know what to expect with the lemon chips and really enjoyed the app.

I ordered the chicken, which was a full chicken! It was amazing but you could split with at least 2 people. The twice baked potato was slightly underwhelming. 

Would for sure come back if I'm ever back in SF.
author: Teagan R.

description: Great customer service. Management reached out to apologize for the inconvenience and I am very satisfied with the care they extend to their customers.
author: Kimberly D.

description:
Reservations for brunch? Check. 

Do you really need to know anything else? I don't think so, but the chic interior, comfortable booths, nice location next to Washington park, escape from the line at Mama's, and the poached egg with crispy polenta, mushrooms, with truffle salsa were also on point. I loved my dish. They were also very accommodating and could take out meat from some of their other dishes (ie. Shrimp and grits and baked eggs). My friend enjoyed her chorizo and eggs. The menu was not huge but everything looked delicious.
author: Susan W.

description:
Wow, this place is good !!!! We had just finished coming off of Alcatraz island tour on a Sunday morning and we were looking for a brunch spot and we walked to north beach neighborhood and the place we were originally going to go had a very long line out the door so we kept walking and decided to go in. The place was very busy it was prime brunch time but we were able to score a place for 2 in this long big communal table by the bar, we got very lucky!

Food
- started off with some bellinis
- shrimp and grits- no words can describe this dish, the portion was great and it was so good it left me wanting more. The shrimp was perfectly cooked and the grits with the bacon and the cheese was scrumptious, the sauce was finger lickin' good !!! 
- Chorizo and eggs- it also came with country style potatoes, good dish, not as heavy as it sounds.
- French Toast- It came with a blueberry fruit compote and mascarpone, it was perfectly balanced and delicious. It was the perfect way to end brunch.

If your visiting SF or your a local and haven't visited this place do yourself a flavor and go. You won't be disappointed!!!
author: Danisbel C.

description:
Came here for brunch because there was a long wait at Mama's on Washington Square. We made the right decision! 

A modern and chic restaurant with attentive and professional service. I ordered the salmon egg Benedict and cream cheese danish.
Salmon egg Benedict: fresh salmon with flavorful eggs. The salmon was just right. Neither fishy nor overly seasoned. 
Cream cheese danish: flakey and creamy!
author: Cynthia W.

description:
Can't believe I'm saying this but lately I've been over brunch, it just doesn't excite me as much as it used to and I haven't had any absolutely amazing brunches lately.

Well park tavern just helped me get back in to the groove and I thought it was actually one of the best brunches I've had in a very long time!

Their menu is pretty simple which I love. Def more sweets than savories. Prices are very reasonable. 

I had been wanting to try their brunch for a while bc their lunch and dinner menu didn't seem to have too many options I would like.

The inside is beautiful and spacious I love the lighting and the cabin like decor! Very cozy! 

What we got: Avocado Toast: so I'm not one to order avocado toast at brunch just bc I'm kind of against paying $$ for something I can easily make at home and it's usually just as if not better. Well the one here was amazing. It had the perfect combo of toasted garlic, chili and sea salt aka perfection. Plus they use a whole wheat sourdough!! 

Deviled eggs: these seem to be a highlight on their both brunch and dinner menu. I thought it was done well but not amazing but I did like the pickled jalapeño. It's $3 for one piece which I've seen is standard at most places .

Chorizo and eggs: I only had a few bites of this from my dining partners plate and thought it was really good and I don't even like Chorizo. It wasn't greasy or too heavy and the potatoes mixed in were yummy. 

Oatmeal Raisin Pancake: OMG so so good! We got one instead of a whole order bc we were pretty stuffed but like I said omg so good. It's perfect esp if you love cinnamon like I do. The raisins inside the pancake are perfect it's fluffy soft and just the best way to end the meal. I love that they had the option to order just one bc I think I'd feel pretty guilty eating a whole plate.

The service was wonderful and all the staff were very nice on a bright and early Saturday morning. I'm so glad I went and can't wait to come back soon
author: Hetal P.

description:
My wife and I went to dinner here on Friday, 04/20. We were very disappointed.

With tip, we paid $165. That was for 2 glasses of wine , 1 appetizer, and 2 courses. 

Steak- not even usda prime. For $37? Would be surprised if it was even usda choice. 
 

Waitress picked up our signed check before we left -- so rude. 

Waste of money
author: Ben G.

description:
I had brunch at Park Tavern yesterday with two friends.

Made a reservation with Open Table - so awesome because I hate waiting and brunch places in SF are known to have horrendous wait times/lines. Definitely kudos from me for Park Tavern to offer reservations!!

Love the decor. A little dark inside but very cozy with comfortable booths and wood tables. It's packed tightly but a pretty decent size restaurant for SF. Service was good and we were pretty quickly greeted and asked about drinks shortly after being seated.

We got the following brunch dishes:
- Crispy polenta cakes (mushrooms, poached eggs, arugula, truffle salsa verde): I could immediately smell the truffle when the dish arrived. The polenta was perfectly cooked and seasoned! The egg was well cooked and really worked well with the mushrooms, arugula and polenta. A+ dish!!

- Cast iron baked farm eggs (sautéed kale and shittake, ham, and gruyere cheese): This dish was good but not great because it felt like a side dish. Tasty but salty!Almost like a cheesy artichoke dip you would have at a friends house. It was tasty but not sure as an entree. My friend asked for more bread in order to keep eating it..

- Smoker trout benedict (poached egg and focaccia): tasty! My friend seemed to really enjoy it. 

We also ordered the ice cream sandwiches for dessert. Two cookie sandwiches for $10. Not bad and pretty good but not worth the $. Good way to end the meal.

All in all, not bad and I will be back. Good place to enjoy some good food and company. I want to try the Marlowe burger one day! Maybe I'll make a reservation for dinner in the future.
author: Cicely T.

description:
3.5 stars.

Not sure if I was too full from my late night dinner but it didn't hit the spot quite as I was expecting. We tried the Marlowe burger but my friend went the next day, and the original one was much better at Marlowe apparently.  It was good but not the best burger I have ever had. Their fries were definitely delicious.  The smoked deviled egg was good but not AMAZING as everyone claims it to be. 

Staff was friendly. Venue had a dark sexy feel to it. Perfect for group brunches or events to celebrate. 

Cute spot across from Washington Square Park to enjoy a Sunday Brunch!
author: Kathy D.

description:
Went here for a work event.  First time here and was pleasantly surprised.   The food tasted great and the service was attentive.  The only draw back was that they forgot one drink order and as one of the waiters was delivering the shrimp appetizer he tilted the plate a bit too much as he was placing it on the table.  Some of the shrimp and other bits of the appetizer slid off the plate and fell on the table.  They took the appetizer back.  I'm not sure if they just placed the same food back on the plate but they brought the appetizer back out re plated in under 2 mins.  :/  I know as my table was watching the cook staff as they have an open kitchen.  perhaps they re cooked it really really really  fast.  :/  I would hate to know that they took the food that fell on the table and just re plated it.

Other than what I mentioned above all was well.

I had the roasted bone marrow appetizer.  It was rich.  I had the roast duck.  It was cooked perfectly.   I had the twice baked potatoes.  It was good.  I thought the potatoes would be a whole potato but it was more like sliced potatoes covered in cheese. 

I would give this place 3.5 stars if I could.  But 3 stars for now.
author: Guest U.

description:
Give me brunch or give me death...

It never ceases to amaze me, that once I thought I found the best brunch on earth, I find a better one, within a short few months.

I have a friend that shares my affection for brunch and I'm sure I have many more, but this one in specific, we only meet for brunch 2-3 times a year. It's a beautiful thing and leaves us both in a sweet spot until the next breakfast moment. 

I have now found my favorite local go-to brekkie spot, where you don't usually have to wait an hour or two hours in line, especially if you make a reservation beforehand. 

Soy lattes were on point. Between the four breakfast dishes we ordered (one for the sleeping beaux at home), they were all on point as well. Cask Iron Baked Eggs with gruyere, greens and other goodness, Poached Eggs over Polenta cakes with spinach, seasoned and sautéed mushrooms, a buttermilk pancake (that dropped out of some fluffy heaven above) and the Chorizo and Eggs. Yum! I'm so crazy over their brunch, I'm getting hungry thinking about it right now! I love it when the people in the kitchen use more than salt and pepper! It's a delicious mouthwatering flavorful treat!

The service was outstanding, from the beginning to end with their attentive team work and polite demeanor. My friend made a slight side comment about my birthday celebration and they brought out a Kouign Amman (they called a butter and sugar pastry) without anyone asking, with a candle lit on top.  

I was fully impressed. The food. The service. The pristine atmosphere with hipster decor. I'll return for sure.
author: Cassandra E.

description:
This restaurant is the "real deal". Went after having a great experience at Marlowe(same ownership). Like Marlowe reserve well in advance. The atmosphere is electric, high energy. The service is professional, a well-oiled machine. Like Marlowe, we started with deviled eggs. Spicy with a strip of bacon atop the pesto topping Great mixed greens salad. Park Tavern's menu offers a choice for every taste. 
Their rendition of Poulet "viert" (sp) is a large Cornish game hen grilled over open flame presented on a cone dish surrounded by new potatoes and fennel cooked in the hen's juices. Outstanding. Can easily be shared. Halibut with peas was also a dish that came out perfect. Good cocktails and plenty of wine options. This is a Top 100 that lives up to it's reputation.
author: Alan P.

description: The atmosphere & dining experience is one you cannot miss of your in San Francisco . It's a casual attire w/ amazing food selections . I chose the hen /chicken which takes up to 30 minutes to cook . It was well worth it & large enough to share between two people . I would definitely recommend stoping here for a bite if your looking for something to eat in the bay .
author: Adam M.

description: This place is great.  It's a modern and chic restaurant.  We came here on a Saturday dinner.  My cousin made reservation ahead of time so we didn't have to wait.  Parking is hard to find in this area but there was valet parking.  I ordered piglet rouge and it was delicious.  They have a good selection of cocktails too.
author: Amy D.

description: Crispy Polenta breakfast is one of the best things have ever eaten in my life. Poached egg on top breaks open and runs yolk all over the polenta and mushrooms are waiting for you under bed of arugula topped with parmesan cheese flakes. Delicious.  Shrimp & Grits, Chorizo & eggs, coffee cake, deviled eggs...all excellent. Saw the huckleberry fritters at a table next to us and wish had ordered that as well...next time.
author: Julie F.

description:
It was a lovely dinner at Park Tavern. 
For starter, I had the Heirloom Tomato Salad. The coconut cream in the salad was a unique touch and indeed flavorful. 
For entree, I chose the Petrale Sole. It was cooked to perfection, served with satisfying sticky rice, garnished with fresh watercress and sweet cherry tomatoes. Absolutely delicious! 
For dessert, the chocolate and  hazelnut cake topped with coffee ice cream was heavenly! 
With all that said, the highlight of the dinner was the exceptional service! "Aura," was so attentive, very efficient, and extremely intuitive! Her impeccable service was undeniable!
author: Malu D.

description: Stopped in while visiting North Beach when a friend was in town. Burgers and cocktails and wine. Nice spot with a great bar. Bartender was handy on some places to go as well.
author: Tyler M.

description:
We had brunch and it was delicious.  

Buttermilk pancakes,  avocado toast, shrimp and grits,  and trout Benedict.  

The place is very nice and elegant as well. Server and staff all friendly. 

We're originally wanted to go to Mama's across the street but the line was extremely long and we came right when it was open but walked past this place and was like ok let's go here.
author: Marie C.

description: Avocado toast and deviled eggs are a must!!! I'm not a big fan of waiting in line when it comes to food. One great thing I love about Park Tavern, is that they take brunch reservations. Perfect for when I'm entertaining on a schedule. The food is always A+, and it's right in North Beach with lots to do before or after.
author: Ali R.

description:
As other reviews have called out, bougy SF brunch spot pretty much sums this place up. I came here for a friends bday and shared an avocado toast and shrimp & grits with my bf. The toast was tasty but pretty small for $10. The shrimp and grits had lots of shrimps on it but I felt the flavoring was too salty. It's overall a pretty heavy dish.

Valet parking is $12 -not cheap!! Parking is hard in the area so do yourself a favor and uber/lyft.

This wouldn't be my top choice for brunch but it's pretty nice that you can actually make reservations so I might come back for another occasion.
author: Sophia H.

description:
Very pleasantly surprised by the brunch here.

Avocado toast is a must. Toast is perfectly crisped and tastes sweet with a hint of butter. Avocado is laid on top perfectly. Dish was very pricey for what it is.
Marlowe burger was fantastic. I ordered the patty medium and it was perfectly juicy. Everything just went really well together, hard to describe. Fries were a little cold but went well with the horseradish aioli. Horseradish aioli had just the right amount of horseradish because it didn't give the nose burning sensation regardless of how much you ate.
Cast iron baked farm eggs was surprisingly delicious. Eggs are a bit runny and went well with the shittake and kale. 

Overall, I loved all three dishes that I tried and would definitely come back.
author: Edward W.

description:
Went here for celebration dinner, the food was amazing! Truffle fries are to die for, and those lemon chips with burrata  
Best of all...our server, Davis, was so awesome! 10/10 would definitely come back for dinner here, drinks and food were all amazing!
author: Marisa W.

description:
I came here for brunch with a couple friends and was really underwhelmed by the food and the prices. However, the brunch vibe and the atmosphere are great. If you're looking for an average brunch spot next to Washington Square Park, its worth popping into Park Tavern. 

[Brunch]
My friend's water was dirty, so she had to ask for a new one. I ordered the baked eggs ($15), and I sampled my friend's burger. My baked eggs looked amazing, but the cheese really made the dish unbearably salty and there was way too much kale in the dish. I wish there were a couple more eggs or something to balance out the amount of cheese I ate in the dish. I tried the burger as well. Comparatively, the burger over at NOPA is 5x better. The fries were a bit sad and limp. 

[Drinks]
The grapefruit mimosa I had was average, nothing special. ($10) 

[Service]
We went at 1:45pm and the kitchen for brunch closes at 2:15pm. Service was great and the food came out really fast.

Overall, I would give Park Tavern a try, but I wouldn't make it a go to.
author: Alice Z.

description:
Cannot believe in my 6 years in SF that I had never been here. Their avocado toast is a blessing on earth and the bellinis are delicious. Three bellinis later and we were feeling great...

My friend had the challah bread and a deviled egg. I think I recall her anything they were both good.

Park tavern will always be recommended whenever friends ask where we should go.
author: Alyssa H.

description:
Really enjoyed this lively neighborhood gem.  We had a few starters and entrees.

The lemon chips-probably the most unique items ever.  So crispy and the cheese just makes them so good

Deviled eggs-these were ok.  Anything with bacon on it is not bad, right?

Steak and fries-meat was a good cut, not too large and seasoned lightly.  The fries were crisp and flavorful

Octopus-one of the best items on the menu, hands down

Chocolate torte-good sharing portion paired with after dinner port

Overall, very good.  The service was phenomenal....our server was so helpful and friendly.  She went above and beyond in a very busy and frenetic environment. 

We do recommend Park Tavern!
author: Terry L.

description: I've been here twice, brunch and dinner. Both meals were excellent, great service, delicious drinks!  If you want to make sure you get a table, make reservations in advance!
author: Whitney C.

description: I went here a few months ago on a date. We order drinks, appetizers and entrees. Our drinks came, apps came and then we ordered another round of drinks. We were waiting over an hour for our entrees. We wanted to check in with our server to see how much longer it would be but he was no where to be found. We were sitting outside so it's not like other staff was walking past. Finally he came outside to take orders for another table and we flagged him down. He definitely was avoiding us because he knew it was taking so long. He brought over the manager and he apologized for the long wait saying the kitchen was backed up and said that our entrees would be at shortly. At this point it was too late, we had a comedy show we had to go to and it had been over an hour and 45 minutes that we spent. The manager took the entrees off our bill and gave a us a $50 gift card. Honestly, our experience there wasn't great so that gift card is still sitting in my junk drawer.
author: Angela L.

description:
Family birthday night at PT was great. Our table was ready when we arrived, service was prompt (our waiter did forget something but then brought it out gratis) and food was creative and delicious. 

We started with PT fries, Brussels Sprout chips and deviled eggs. The forgotten Firecracker prawns were brought out a little after our mains, which we were eating family style, and I'm glad they arrived, excellent!

We shared duck, octopus and chicken, all were prepared well and we really enjoyed the different flavors. We didn't order dessert but a slice of birthday cake showed up for our daughter. 

I hadn't come here since it was Moose's, it was a great choice my daughter made to celebrate her day.
author: Susan K.

description:
Just had dinner here, earlier this evening. (Our party was for 8 people)

We each ordered an entree and had cocktails. Cocktails were fine and tasty. Again, nothing special for an expensive Christmas Dinner. My grandmother flew in and took us out to dinner. We we're expecting top tier service, care and attention. 

We were seated 15minutes late but the male host brought two free bar appetizers over which greatly made up for it! Thanks! 

Note that I've been a customer and fan of Park Tavern for over two years. However...something has changed in the last few months! Whether it's management, service, or the food, something needs to improve!

We ordered: 
- The Bar Steak ($34+) was just ok. Simple cut of meat and cooked fine (medium-well). Would order again but it's not a $30 plate. Should be $22-$25 range based on size, taste and overall simplicity/blandness. Would be nice if it had some greens, potatoes or a simple side. Tallow fries (jush blah) were there but nothing special. 

- The Marlowe Burger ($16) was nothing special. For a $16 dollar burger the price is fine. The serving size is kind of a joke though...It's like a nibble of food. Comes with bacon and a side of frites. 

- Pan Seared Halibut ($33) would never order again! It's too messy of a plate. The farrow and beets just don't go and it's not "fresh daily" tasting, sorry! Was overcooked, gritty and dry. Was greatly lacking in flavor. 


The Atmosphere: 
 
+ American upscale food that's now proven to be a miss. Hope it improves.

+ Great for a night on the town, not great for a large party looking to actually have a conversation w/ one another. 

+ Neat and authentic ambiance. The displays are simple and understated. Not fancy, just simple. 

- The table was "not a perfect table" and was in the middle of the dinning room x bar. Had a walkway divider but was noisy, uncomfortable and the lighting was horrible. Two other tables had to shine light onto their menu's just to read. 

- The servers weren't engaging, kind or at all interested in top tier service. It wasn't that they were overwhelmed with our group size, it was just that they were literally uninterested in entertaining/ serving. 


The worst: 

- Note that I made a reservation on Thursday of last week with a lovely male host who got us our perfect time slot for 7:15PM. He was the same host who sent over the free appetizers, thank you! 

I cancelled the next day as we thought our whole party wouldn't be able to attend. 

When cancelling the horrible experience began. Can't recall the female hostess's name but I want to say it was Adriana. Any who... it started with an A. 

Over the weekend, trying to re-book I got her at every call. She was snippy, rude, pretentious and overall just very unpleasant. I honestly have no idea how she works in customer service and as the face of a business. My father owned two renowned restaurants and I grew up in the industry.

Her tone was sharp and she had the nerve to address me as "hun". First off, I was giving her my credit card, for a party of 8. I've dined at Park Tavern numerous times and it had never been unpleasant until now. 


I really hope that the service improves. Overall Park Tavern is an OK place to eat that I would recommend to someone wanting an average experience.
author: Clara D.

description: Came here for dinner on a Tuesday night. I have dined several times here in the past but this place seems to have lost its luster. Wait staff seemed understaffed, forgetting our wine order. Food came out a combination of overcooked (steak frits) and under cooked (prawns). Was disappointed enough to skip dessert. Too many other good restaurants in walking distance to give this place another chance.
author: Maxwell M.

description: The ambiance and decor was beautiful. Very dark and intimate and a lot of interesting details on the wall. We waited 20 minutes for our reservation but the hostess sat us at a small table so we didn't have to wait in the doorway. After the party next to us left, they moved the tables together and we sat more comfortably. The food was interesting and tasty. We had the Tasmanian Trout and Twice Baked Potato side. Pricey, small portions, but very good.
author: Megan H.

description:
I've been to Park Tavern twice - once for dinner and once for brunch. I love the location, and it is a welcome change from the endless Italian food in north beach. 

The service is quite good, the staff is knowledgeable and friendly and they have a good wine list. 

I only have pictures from a recent brunch. My boyfriend and I stepped in right when they opened, their reservations were booked but luckily we were able to sit at the bar. We started with avocado toast (outstanding!) which had a garlic chili oil sprinkled on top. I was pleased that the toast was crisp and not soggy from the avocado. My boyfriend had the egg skillet, which was very cheesy and he liked it a lot. I ordered the walnut and raisin oatmeal pancakes but was served buttermilk pancakes (our waiter apologized and I enjoyed the pancakes nonetheless). 

We had dinner here a few months ago for my birthday. I had duck with a cherry glaze and my boyfriend had a pork chop. Both were cooked perfectly and served with tasty and interesting sides. 

Overall, highly recommend for a nice date night or occasion in North Beach! Be sure to make a reservation as it is almost always packed!
author: Kim A.

description: We are at Park Tavern for a drink and ordered right away. Before the drink arrived the manager who also greeted us brought over a bite - their delicious deviled eggs! It was such a wonderful gesture! Thanks!!! My sister and I always stop in at Park Tavern - either for drinks and apps or dinner. Highly recommend!
author: Sherri N.

description: Very special and you can make a reservation before you go. Have really enjoyed the food and will come again.
author: Willy L.

description: Reliable and yummy food; always super accommodating to large party reservations, especially for brunch! There are few other places where you can do this in SF. The breton cake, avocado toast, and smoked trout benedict are incredible as are the servers/hosts.
author: R D.

description: My wife and I ate here last night with good friends that had never made it to Park Tavern. After dinner they were already figuring out their schedule to make it back. Our outstanding starters included the amazing deviled eggs topped with bacon (yes everything IS better with bacon) and roasted Brussel sprouts. My friend then had the Marlow burger quoted as one of the best he has ever had. His wife loved her mussels in the freshly made red sauce and my wife's pork chop was excellent. Even with the solid reviews nothing beat my individual roasted chicken in its special roaster surrounded by trumpet mushrooms and yellow/green squash. While we have enjoyed Park Tavern before I guarantee we will be returning again soon.
author: Timothy P.

description: This place has wonderful atmosphere - great soul. Maybe it's because it was Moose's forever but the vibe is legit. The bartender was great too. Yummy drinks and good feel at the bar. The food was very good - devils on horseback stood out as did the seafood grill. The deviled eggs were good but being from Texas I've had a few good deviled eggs in my lifetime. The sole was good but the potion was very small. The service was okay, not great. It took forever to get out check. But all in all really good experience and I'll definitely be back.
author: leslie g.

description: Great location on Washington Square, fast and friendly service and really good eats!  Drinks are great and the bar is fun.
author: Quinn B.

description:
Update: Christina, the hostess, is so kind and always find us a place to sit. She is so nice!

Also James, the waiter, serves us all the time. He's very courteous professional and nice to talk to. A real pleasure. 


Hands down the best brunch restaurant in San Francisco. Super nice staff. Wait staff is very quick and courteous. Oliver, the host, is very welcoming and always has some fun small chat. 

Food is incredible. Avocado and Shrimp Toast, pancakes, deviled eggs, caesar salad and the Marlowe burger. All excellent.  

Keep up the great work Park Tavern!
author: scott o.

description:
We had a dinner date night here.

- PT Fries: standard french fires with a fancy-ish dip for $15.
- Spanish Octopus: Not bad tasting, but you don't get much octopus (it's mostly the veggies), $30.
- Tombo Tuna: Highly recommended by the waiter, but really... it was rather plain and bland.

The overall impression we had was overrated and meh. It's priced like a Michelin place (SF has several excellent ones!), but the service was lackadaisical and the quality wasn't there. The food didn't taste particularly bad, but it was rather expensive, bland, and just... not that tasty or dynamic or whatever adjective you want to use. Meh.
author: C B.

description: I've been twice.  Once for brunch.  Delicious!!! Once for a glass of wine and "bites" (in between lunch and dinner service).  Brussels sprout chips are amazing.  Deviled egg is fantastic.
author: Kat C.

description:
Update 7/28/18: I'm pleasantly surprised that the manager reached out to me and was willing to make things right. This is a hallmark of any good business and I appreciate the kind gesture. If I should be in the area again I'd definitely give them another chance.

7/27/18: Our waitress appeared to be stoned, kept us waiting for a while before she finally came to take our orders, all while the meter's running. Waited over 40 minutes wondering why our food wasn't being served yet when customers who arrived after us got their breakfasts before us. Waitress claims they lost our order, no sincere apology; brings us a lame danish to compensate for the time and money wasted. Food was way too salty and nothing special. Won't be coming back.
author: Miss T.

description:
Great bartenders!  The menu is nothing exciting. What we did order  was so salty. I for the impression that they only care about famous customers and not
 neighborhood customers who may or may not come back.
author: Victoria M.

description:
TLDR - Great spot for a nicer occasion. Food is good but pricey and not impressive, made up for by great service and ambiance 

Make reservations in advance! I made mine 2 weeks in advance for a Saturday for 3 people and most of the normal dinner times were already taken. The restaurant was busy when we got there at 6:30 and stayed consistently busy until 8:30 when we left. Definitely would recommend snagging a reservation if you can, especially for weekends. 

Ambiance here is on the nicer casual end. Great service - very attentive but not overly so that you'd find it to be intrusive, basically what you'd expect from a nice restaurant.

Food here is good but wasn't really wow-worthy. Nothing super unique or creative. If you plan on getting whatever Poulet they have (rouge, noir, vert), make sure you tell your waiter early since it takes 30 min to prepare. Prices are on the higher end (~$30 an entree), and while the food was still good, it didn't impress me enough for a return visit. I'd come back or recommend for the overall atmosphere but not so much for the food. 

* POULET ROUGE ($32) - 4/5
[roasted peppers, toybox eggplant, ceci beans]
If you're really hungry, the chicken is probably your best bet here. It's literally a whole chicken sitting upright in a bed of veggies. The chicken was tender and juicy, and the skin was crispy and fatty, but aside from the presentation, I didn't find the dish to be particularly special. Flavor was simple and I would've preferred the veggies sitting in less of a pool of oil. 

* BEEF TARTARE ($19) - 4/5
[smoked bone marrow, quail egg, crostini]
Beef was fresh. Loved the bone marrow! The fattiness paired really well with the raw meat and gave it a richness and a nice, smoky flavor.
author: Jessie L.

description:
I used to frequent Park Tavern often. Brunch is greater than Dinner.

Brunch- deviled eggs, avocado toast, another sweet toast with date paste, amazing stuffed blueberry French toast, poached eggs over polenta cakes.

DRINKS- the boozy smoothie. so good I had to recreate with my blender at home.

Dinner not so much- I always end up with the burger bc I can't decide. I had the fries with the soft egg to dip, and even though it looked very fancy, it was just average. 

Now, in terms of service, the waitress here was so rude to my GF. My friend wore an off the shoulder shirt, and the waitress, after she seated us, told my friend "your shirt is off your shoulder. Shouldn't you fix it?" with the snottiest attitude. My friend and I were shocked and didn't say anything, but lady if you're reading- you are a huge B and wish you could rock an off-the-shoulder top. Haven't been back to this place since.
author: Mariam P.

description:
Park Tavern looks extremely trendy for brunch. I came here with a group that made reservations which definitely seems like the must do thing here because the place was packed. I was impressed at how trendy the whole place looked and all the yuppies. As I was reading the menu I noticed that they also sell the Marlowe burger and I realized that they might be a part of the same restaurant group which is cool. 

I had the smoked trout benedict here. I was looking for something on the lighter side, but they in general have a pretty heavy brunch menu - lots of cheese, cream, etc. So definitely not a place you go light for. In general, the trout benedict was okay. The horseradish cream was a little strong for my liking, and the choice of using foccacia as the base of a "benedict" was interesting though mis executed as the base was pretty soggy. In general, while each unique component was okay, the combination really left more to be desired. 

Final price was $20+ ish which is to be expected for brunch, though I'm not sure it was worth my money.
author: Jasmine X.

description: Awesome chilled out atmosphere, tasty food, and great servers. Great for kids because it's loud.
author: Kathleen W.

description:
Hosted my birthday dinner here this past weekend, was seated the second we got there even though we didn't have all 14 of our party present. 

Started off with the pork belly which I highly recommended! I had never had pickled mustards seeds and it cut through the fattyness of the pork belly. Super yummy! 

Shared the lamb and steak with the fiancé and boy the lamb was so damn good!!!!! The chrizo, the roasted veggies, the delicious lamb! My mouth is watering just thinking about the dinner. The steak was okay my fiancé loved it but my lamb had so much flavor that the steak didn't match the flavor punch the lamb provided.  

The service was great and the restaurant itself was so pretty. Would totally come back to enjoy more drinks and apps.
author: Tamar B.

description:
Burgers to die for, but those Deviled Eggs!

I usually stop here when I am craving an awesome burger, a good drink and a good conversation with my bartender. I sit at the bar, let the bartender tell me what is good and then order my drink and burger as I always do! But this time, Jeff, our bartender was very persuasive and convincing when it came to appetizers and later with the desert, but first thing first! As we were chatting, Jeff made it clear that he was high on the Deviled Eggs, but as I was sipping on the wonderful martini that he mixed for me, I decided to try the Pancetta Wrapped Figs which he also recommended! He, to his credit, did not take no for an answer and offered me a complementary order of the Deviled Eggs, and man oh man! Was I appreciative that he did! These things are so flavorful and addictive! Perfect snack with most cocktails! I am hooked! Read more about them here: http://goo.gl/hMP1i4 

The Pancetta Wrapped Figs are so full of wonderful flavors that no matter how hard I tried, I would be doing them a disservice here, so I won't try! But if you like figs, give them a try, you won't be sorry.

The burgers and the fries ............. ahhh! Heavenly! 

Let me stop talking about them before I get hungry again, but let me just say that these burgers, and fries, should make to the top 5 best San Francisco burgers year after year! Believe me, this comes from a man who has had his share of burgers in life!

Last but not least, the Ice Cream Sandwiches! I do NOT care for cookies! These cookies though ... they were just perfect with the ice cream or gelato they were hugging! Jeff scored again! I am hooked on the ice cream sandwiches too!
author: Afshin A.

description: We really enjoyed the goat cheese levain (with more salad than we expected), the brown butter brussel sprouts, the ricotta and tomato ravioli, the chocolate icing "birthday cake," and the Summer Bubbles cocktail with lime and mint!
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Our original intention was to have brunch up the road at Mama's by the line was so long, ridiculously long that we weren't willing to wait the hour and a half it would take for brunch. 
We stumbled upon this trendy, classy restaurant with friendly staff and were amazed. I ordered a mimosa with grapefruit juice and the polenta cakes with poached eggs and can honestly admit that I haven't had such a good breakfast meal.. maybe ever. Jokes but it was spectacular- every bite was savored. The portions caution on the small side but are filling so both my husband and I were satisfied with our choices. They make a good cappuccino and the skillet was a great choice, too. SF prices are to be expected but the food cane quickly and service was spot on! Would highly recommend it *****
author: Kate S.

description: The brunch was fabulous and the service was outstanding.  Try the smoked trout with hollandaise sauce
author: Richard L.

description: Went for graduation brunch, food good service,lame, extremely lame,  it was like we get a automatic gratuity, so who cares.  Besides alot of small things,  the most irritating thing was for the apps about half the table of 11 ordered apps, they just come over are put them in the middle of the table and left , even if we wanted to share there were no side plates. When the entrees came felt like I was at dennys, raffling off the foid,, "WHO HAD THE BENEDICT?,  WHO HAD THIS," OR THEY WOULD JUST PUT THE WRONG DISH IN FRnOT OF SOMEONE, kind of sad.  There were other things but come on, do it RIGHT, at least act like you care. The entire time we were there no one asked how everything was. Once, after about a hour they asked if anyone else needed a drink.  Just lame.  3 stars is very kind.
author: James H.

description: I came here for brunch and the food was excellent. I had the smoked trout Benedict. Portions were small but the flavors were amazing. The pancakes though were HUGE and delicious. Service was excellent as well. However the main entrees took a while to come out but it wasn't a huge issue for me. The ambiance was also nice. Parking is difficult around here but there's valet for $12. I'm definitely coming back for the delicious food.
author: Holly L.

description:
I've dined here twice for dinner over the last year, and experienced top-notch food, drinks, service, and ambience each time. 

Park Tavern rotates seasonal menus and many of its entrees are thus ever-changing. None of the entrees I had last night, for example, were on the menu in January over a year ago. There are staples, like the poulet rouge, pork chop, steak, marlowe burger, and appetizers that stay fixed, however.

Favorite appetizers are the brussel sprout chips, smoked deviled eggs, and pork belly. The brussel sprout chips are generously salted and oiled, then roasted to crisps. The pork belly, while fatty and flavorful in and of itself, is served with an amazing black "forbidden rice" and caramelized onions for an incredibly flavorful and textural bite. We split the black miso cod for our entree, which was tasty, but not quite extraordinary. The cocktails, in addition, are all well-mixed and satisfying.

Last night, we had an unfortunate situation in which an elderly lady sitting at the table next to us suddenly began screaming at us, complaining about the volume of our conversation. We had not been talking above normal table volume and were completely surprised by her reaction. She continued on in an extremely rude fashion, even invoking racial slurs. The hostess moved us immediately and apologized profusely. The assistant general manager and even our server did as well, and noted that she had been incredibly rude to everyone the entire night. After learning a bit more about what transpired, the assistant GM asked them to leave. Everyone was incredibly apologetic and good to us the rest of the night, even bringing us some champagne. As if I wasn't already impressed by the service, this instance truly proved how well-run and managed this restaurant is. We'll be back!
author: Tim X.

description:
I've been here twice now and decided it's extremely mediocre in terms of food. Great atmosphere and drinks but the food is a bit bland for my liking.  We had the sea bass which came highly recommended by our server as his fave thing on the menu. Roasted fish with crispy skin covered with some pretty bland cream sauce and a bunch of beats. Wasn't impressed. The house salad looks like it could be a decent Cesar but it's a bland overly creamy dressing. Could have been an off night, maybe it's not a place for fish. 

I'll add that the first time I came here i had a better meal - the roast chicken was tasty. 

The beef jerky appetizer was, in the way of beef jerky, the best beef jerky I've ever had. And the lemon chips appetizer was pretty good.  

All in all for a $125 meal I would expect more. (That's one entree, 2 appetizer, 4 drinks)

No complaints about the service, they were great.
author: Evan S.

description: The avocado toast was the best I've had. It has a light lemon and oil on it that hit the spot. The potatoes were served crispy and tasted delicious.
author: Gina N.

description:
3.5 Stars granted here. Great location in North Beach across from the park, well done on the furnishings and interior and great wait staff. The only aspect lacking, and only slightly, was the quality of the food. While some of the food items were great, some were off. The deviled eggs and brussel sprouts were well made with clear evidence of them being well thought out and designed. The egg appetizer had a nicely hard boiled half egg with a perfectly cooked thick cut bacon portion and a well seasoned yoke mixture. The brussel sprouts were deep fried leaves and were well seasoned also, but was a rather small group of leaves served in a fairly large dish. The mixed green salad with avocado was also well done though some leaves were a bit awkwardly large. For main entrees, we had the steak, shrimp and poulet rouge. This is where the meal turned in the other direction. The steak appeared a bit overcooked. The poulet rouge was a full game hen and thus a large portion, but the accompanying sauce made the bottom of the dish look soup-like with large portions of sliced zucchini and squash. The disappointing aspect was that the hen was clearly overcooked and thus dry unfortunately. The skin remained tough despite having clear char-marks throughout. 

My remedy would be to sous vide the hen at a lower temp for a longer cook time to soften the skin, and then broil at 400 to crisp the skin and finish with poured hot butter spooned in a pan. More work for sure, but the end result should be pleasing. I would also recommend they experiment with a blanc-cream sauce to stand against the sour (but fine) flavor residing in the squash slices.

For dessert, the birthday cake looked very colorful, but also looked very heavy. The crème brulee had a nice caramel flavor but was a surprisingly small portion (served in a tea cup sized dish).
