None of the dish portions were big and I wasn't full.. Actually I was still hungry. Eek. I should have also gotten the pancakes in that picture..

Park Tavern gives off a dinner + drinks vibe instead of the classic early / late morning weekend feeling you get at Kitchen Story or Plow. But we weren't sitting at the regular tables so it could have felt different sitting somewhere else. Maybe I'll come by for dinner..It's undecided.
author: Ingrid C.

description: Bustling, warm restaurant on Washington Square Park. Good food, great burgers, great service and ambiance. Very friendly place and festive, vibrant ambiance while still being able to have a conversation. Food is consistently good. Not the very best in town, but consistent good quality. I've been there four times in a year and there are lots of choices in SF.
author: Audrey M.

description:
Overall: 4.8/5
--------------

Food - 5/5
1) Shrimp and Grits - 5/5

Service - 4/5

Cleanliness - 5/5

Location - 5/5

Experience - 5/5

------------------
Wait time: 0 mins (brunch, weekday)
author: John V.

description: Great location right next to the park (and good backup if you don't want to wait 2 hours for Mama's). Great food for every meal. I love their public seating area which means you can get in with 2 people very fast most of the time.
author: John J.

description:
Can't say much for the food (was actually looking forward to trying superb sounding menu options), but the hostesses were rude...which is a no no for me. 

I made an opentable reservation, making a note that it was a birthday dinner and we would like a nice table. There was a window seat available, but we were told (with plenty of snarky attitude) we wouldn't be able to sit there. Frankly ruined the beginning of our evening and we chose to go somewhere else with more professional and accommodating service. Maybe my own shortsightedness in arranging a special occasion meal at a "tavern."

Note: inside is loud if you prefer a quieter place to converse.
author: Aerin Y.

description:
Park Tavern is a solid addition to North Beach. I went here for brunch and immediately loved the open yet dark space that leads you to the bar/dining room .

Had the Hummingbird cocktail - $9 (St Germaine, Champagne, Grapefruit), and the "Marlowe" burger/fries ($16)-was superb. Our friends had the Pan-Fried Corned Beef Hash ($16) and the Cast Iron Baked Farm Eggs ($15). We ended up trying everyone's entrees and I found them all solid.

Albeit being busy (we made reservations 2 weeks ahead), our service was still good.

Overall, I would come back here again for dinner, as well. Park Tavern seems to be the restaurant for any occasion -a date, a group meal with friends, a work dinner, etc. !
author: Veronica S.

description:
Food tasted great ... I had the Marlowe burger which was melt in your mouth, aioli & bacon goodness, but not too big...hummingbird cocktail which tasted grapefruit with a raspberry refreshing but felt strong alcohol-wise, coffee which comes with sugar cubes & coffee cake which had hints of cherry in it.

Waiters were super nice

The one thing I don't get is why they lost my reservation..I had made it on Open Table the night before... Now granted accidents? Do happen but well I could have always just sat by the bar but if you really need to get seated then....either Open Table or Park Tavern decided to cancel my reservation 45 minutes before I got seated . ( I received an e-mail).
author: Andrea V.

description: I was last here two years ago and had a great experience. Last night, however, was different. While the atmosphere and vibe were both still great, the service was poor. I was dining alone and felt rushed by my server. Once I made it clear that I was not in a hurry, his timing and attention were spotty. I also received my appetizer about five minutes before my cocktail, which was not very cold. The deviled eggs were amazing. I ordered the pork as an entree, and only after I ordered did my server tell me the restaurant was out of me selection (at 6:45 with a half-full restaurant). The steak and Brussels sprouts were fine but nothing special. The cake was spectacular.
author: Bruce M.

description:
After a long day of discovery in San Francisco, we wanted a place that seemed cool enough to be an experience, but not too stuffy. Enter Park Tavern. 
It's beautiful. There is nothing tavern-ey about this place - it's modern with low lighting, lots of wood, a vibrant bar scene and a great cocktail list. 
The food is excellent here. Trendy San Francisco dwellers mix with out of towners who have found there way to a bowl of lemon chips with burrata, delicious roasted bone marrow and entrees like halibut, grilled octopus and wagyu steak. Everything's on the menu seems well considered and beautifully crafted. This is a place that values its food, with the right amount of fanciness that doesn't ever seem to breach into pretension. 
Be aware though, it's loud. Girls at happy hour drinks and apps, groups of work colleagues and 3rd dates make the noise swell and echo heavily in here. To counteract, just get talking to the table next to you and add to the ambience. Loud is better when it's you being loud.
author: Jay H.

description:
Five star vibe and people!

Two star price to performance ratio.

Average: 3.5 but Yelp doesn't do halves.

Fun, go here and enjoy.  Challah bread cinnamon toast was excellent, but two miserly slices?  For 7$ ?

14$ pancakes and eggs...lol.

They blew the poached egg ( not runny).

Good beer:)
author: Joe H.

description:
Met up Rodney H, Bobby L & Peter L this past Tues. Started at the bar. Drinks are good. Nice and stiff just the way I like them! For drinks, we tried:

Mclaren: Hendrick's gin, cucumber, lemon & ginger beer ($13)
This was kind of like alcoholic spa water. Not my fav since it was so light, but it had a refreshing quality to it.

PT old fashioned: Old overholt rye, cherry, bitters ($12)
My favorite cocktail of the night! It was dark and strong.

Country lawyer: Knob creek bourbon, zucca amaro, vermouth & bitters ($13)
Even though it was dark and boozy it was just a touch too sweet for me.

Duboce: Bank note scotch, yellow chartreuse, benedictine & bitters ($12)
A very pretty cocktail. 

Now onto the food! Between the four of us, it took us a while to pinpoint what we wanted. We finally settled on the following. 

Smoked deviled eggs: bacon, pickled jalapeno & chive ($2 ea)
Best deviled eggs ever! The bacon, jalapeno and chive just elevated the eggs. If I were coming back for a snack at the bar, I'd come back for this! Sooo good!

PT fries: truffle, soft cooked egg, caviar ($14)
Omg! These were amazing! Probably one of the best versions of truffle fries that I've had. The fries were crispy but soft in the center. And dipped in the egg and caviar or truffle dip?! I was in heaven!

Wagyu beef jerky ($7)
I didn't care for this. I typically like my beef jerky softer, so this wasn't my fav.

Braised lamb tongue: french fingerling potatoes, mustard greens, soft cooked hen egg & horseradish ($14)
I picked this dish since I love tongue! The tongue was soft but I wanted something crunchy on the dish to give it texture. Everything on the plate had a rather mushy texture.

Grass fed ribeye: potato puree, baby carrots, cipollinis, blue lake beans, arugula & chimichurri ($38)
The steak was cooked perfectly!

Poulet vert: fines herbs, french fingerlings, thumbelina carrots, baby leeks & mustard jus ($29)
This was as beautiful as it was delicious! The hen was super moist and juicy! I was actually expecting the hen to be larger, but it's a good size for one or for sharing. 

Venison carpaccio: classic angus beef tartare, capers & crispy bone marrow ($18)
The tartare was excellent! We got this a little later so I only took a bite. I didn't realize there was crispy bone marrow until after dinner when I was looking over the menu! So bummed since I didn't try the fried marrow! 

The rest of the dishes I don't recall too well. A few drinks and lots of coursed plates can do that to me from time to time, but we also got:
-Grilled pork chop: cranberry bean & sweet pepper ragout, preserved tomato, red mustard & peppadew ($27)
-Wood oven roasted beets: agrodolce goat cheese & breadcrumbs ($8)
-Brown butter brussels sprouts: parmesan & chili flakes ($8)

Since it was Bobby's birthday and we were celebrating, our server gave us a free dessert! We got the birthday cake since it was fitting and also ordered the creme brulee. The July's birthday cake ($9) with James vanilla & strawberry creme cake, mixed berry compote & cream cheese frosting was light and fluffy and not too sweet. The Tcho chocolate creme brulee ($8) with chocolate biscotti, chili, lemon zest & sea salt wasn't really my cup of tea since it mixed sweet and salty, but everyone else loved it!

After the meal, we were all talking about how great the Deviled eggs and PT fries were. Everyone loved them! I'd definitely come back just for those dishes! Add the Poulet vert and that may just be the perfect meal!
author: Elena N.

description:
2 stars for the service, 4 for the food. 

It was a beautiful day out and my group was looking to grab a quick brunch after walking around, so we decided to go to Park Tavern when we saw a fairly busy restaurant with several outdoor tables available. 

We were seated quickly by the hostess but that's where the great service stopped. Our waiter had to have been one of the rudest, snobbiest people I have encountered in the customer service industry. One member of our party asked him what types of coffee was served. This apparently was a dumb question as he replied, "Excuse me? What do you MEAN what kind of coffee??" We also inquired on what type of chorizo (Spanish or Mexican style) was in the chorizo & egg scramble and, again, we were met with attitude. He did not offer to ask the chef and instead acted as if we had no idea what we were talking about. His tone was so dismissive and borderline condescending.

Fortunately the food came pretty quickly. I got the cast iron baked eggs with gruyere cheese and jamon serrano (thinly sliced ham). It was delicious but there was a little too much spinach and not enough egg. The jamon was also measly. Another member got the pancakes which were HUGE - stack of 3, each the size of a large plate... but they were just pancakes. 

All in all, not too impressed. I'm sure there are better places in the area for brunch, or maybe my experience was just overshadowed by our sassy waiter.
author: Margaret Z.

description: I guess I had higher expectations based on the reviews here.  I think the food is overpriced for the quality. That said, I had the Spanish Octopus and the actual octopus was really good, but can't say that for the rest of the dish.  Good ambiance and location though.
author: Richard L.

description:
We came here for brunch on a rainy Sunday right at 10AM for the first seating and we were so glad that we made reservations since the place was already filling up pretty quickly within the first 15 minutes of opening. 

Our server quickly came over and offered water and took drink orders. We ordered a couple of cocktails - like Park Tavern's sister restaurants, most of the cocktails sounded and tasted delicious. I also love how the house coffee comes in a Le Creuset mug. 

We ordered the Huckleberry fritters to start and they were so delicious! They were piping hot when they made it to our table and perfectly crispy on the outside while nice and dense on the insides. For entrees we opted for the Corned Beef Hash, Shrimp and Grits, French Toast, and Polenta Cakes. Everything was delicious, I love the crispiness of my polenta cakes with the runny egg, the shrimp and grits was a bit too heavy for my taste, but still impressive. 

Service was great throughout our meal, the only thing that bothered me was the spacing of the tables, it seemed like they really tried to squeeze as many seats as possible into the seating area, and it made it uncomfortable to slide in and out of the booths and walk in the restaurant to use the restroom, etc.
author: Elizabeth C.

description: Better than your average Tavern! Pricey but so worth it because the flavors are complex and adventurous...sometimes subtle but still rich in flavor. The deviled eggs had an higher yolk to white ratio than usual which is one of the reasons I loved it. It was topped with jalapenos and bacon, so it was not only well seasoned but also had a kick. Never had smoke prawns before and they were delicious. Well balanced with cucumber and avocado. The sea bass was poached with unique mushrooms and delicately seasoned. Only minor issue was the chicken satay which was little bland and under cooked. Look forward to returning and trying the brunch. Not really a brunch person but hope to be converted.
author: And H.

description:
Stopped by here for drinks during a business trip.

I am a fan of the nice ambiance of the entire joint.  The menu looks robust and the drink selection is solid.  They have some decent cocktails and a nice variety of other selections.  

One plus was grabbing one of the tables outside.  The heat lamps for those chilly SF nights were a nice plus.  This is a good place to gather with friends and work colleagues as well.
author: Kevin W.

description: This place is the place to be if you want the valet to treat your car like trash. I'm posting a photo-- I've never seen such huge curb rash in my entire life, it's almost 1/4 of the wheel.   I am never coming back here until they get a proper valet service. God only knows what else they're doing to the cars while you're inside trying to have a nice night out.
author: pete h.

description:
I can honestly count the number of times I've had a memorable service experience (for the right reasons) in San Francisco on one hand.

I just want to give big kudos to the staff here who went above and beyond starting with the host who thanked me for speaking up when I asked to move tables (I hate myself a little for that, but my date is tall and we were crammed next to each other on the corner of a booth) and offered to check my coat.

We ordered the side of brussels, deviled eggs, harvest salad, short rib and flank steak. They were all delicious and cooked perfectly, except for the salad which was a bit bland and forgettable. Also we asked for bread and the server forgot, but everything else was on point.
author: Christine M.

description: I love to sit at the bar and order a Marlowe burger l here and I have to say, the Marlowe burger here is better than at marlowes! Reservations are relatively easy to get here and also walk ins are welcome. If you're in a rush, sit at the bar where they serve the full menu. I love the location right across the street from Washington square park. The ambiance of the restaurant takes me back in time a bit. I think it's pretty popular with the touristy crowd. You'll see lots of people pretty dressed up for dinner at least for SF standards but I've always also felt right at home in casual wear.
author: Yin H.

description:
We celebrated our anniversary here last weekend and had one of the best dinners we have ever had in SF. Service was top notch and the food was exquisite. 

My boyfriend had never been here before so I thought this would be a great spot for a special evening. I made a table reservation for us via OpenTable and added in the notes that we wanted to be seated near the windows in front if possible. First, I had to call last minute and request that the reservation be increased from 2 to 4 people which they were able to accommodate.  When we were seated, we were not able to be sat near the window so they brought each of us a glass of sparkling wine to make up for it. They also asked about our anniversary which was very kind. 

We started with the brussel sprout chips and deviled eggs. Both were very good starters but the chips were pretty greasy but but were also really tasty.

For the mains - We ordered 2 salmons, the bar steak and a salad nicoise. The salmon was cooked perfectly and was on top of a sort of creamed corn. Absolutely divine. The steak was also cooked perfectly medium rare, very juicy and tender. Everything was scrumptious!

For dessert we ordered the pumpkin spice cake which they brought out with a candle, which again was very sweet of them. the cake was moist and delectable.

I will continue to go back to Park Tavern and will recommend it to all my friends. Delicious food and excellent customer service.

Keep up the great work guys!
author: Ladan G.

description:
I came to Park Tavern just after it opened a few years ago, and I remember it being good but I wasn't so impressed by it. This last experience I had for brunch was great and I can't wait to go back again soon. 

My friends and I went family style which is a great way to go - I love trying a little bit of everything. This is how I would rank the dishes we had:
- avocado toast: creamy and savory 
- polenta cakes with mushrooms: the polenta is a great balance against the mushrooms
- burger: rich and heavy so probably a better sharing dish
- deviled eggs

This is not to say the deviled eggs weren't so so good. It's just that the avocado toast was so excellent. 

I would definitely recommend making a reservation. We were a party of 6 and were seated without a problem but every party that walked in that morning were looking at anything from a 30 min to 1.5 hour wait.
author: Wendy L.

description: So so good. Just had brunch here and absolutely loved the Trout Benedict. The restaurant is super swanky. I love the ambiance. The service is excellent. Highly recommended!
author: A B.

description: Excellent find after seeing the line at Mamas house.  Definitely a fancier take on breakfast, but well worth it!
author: Tara And Sean W.

description: Great service. Walked in without a reservation and was sat right away. Great food. Loved the bone marrow. Highly recommend.
author: Wayne U.

description: Mother's Day dinner.  Early arrival.  Seated right away.  Had to ask a wait person to put down the window curtain as the sun was shining right into my eyes.  Still ok.  Ordered simple drinks.  They came.  Ordered appetizers and dinner.   Finished our drinks.  The entree arrives.  I am surprised and ask the wait staff what happened to the appetizers.  As I am speaking the appetizers arrive.  Try to put all the serving dishes on a very small table.  Decide to start with the entrees so the food doesn't get cold.  My steak knife won't cut the meat. The serrated edge is worn down smooth. My dinner knife won't cut the steak.   Ask the wait staff for another knife.  Wait.  She returns.  First substitute knife is as dull as the first.  I ask for another.  3rd knife is the charm.  Waiter comes and says I am so sorry about this (all the food arriving at once). I'll bring a complimentary drink.  We say ok.  Food is excellent.   Then they comp us a dessert instead of asking if we wanted to the dessert menu.  My son ordered the dessert he wanted.  By this time the dining experience was quite flawed.  So, go to Park Tavern to taste the food, but sit at the bar where you should get better service.
author: Judith I.

description:
The deviled egg renaissance of SF?  It all started here.  Jennifer Puccio is a true pioneer.  She took a mundane & pedestrian item & tweaked it a gourmet twist, & now they are on practically every menu in town.  This is no exaggeration.  Alta CA, Prospect, Bix, Fog City, The Brixton, Bocadillos, Hog & Rocks, and Sauce, just to name a few.  Chiarello offers his own version using quail eggs & Serrano ham @ Coqueta.  Even venues that are not full service restaurants like 20 Spot & Craftsman & Wolves sport them on their menus.

But it wasn't until Puccio's version that people started thinking about them, talking about them, & waiting 6 weeks for a reservation (or over an hour for a seat at the bar), just to have them.

Something I have every time I'm here?  The Park Tavern French Fries.  Fries that you dip into a creamy, soft cooked egg w caviar & truffle.  A must order.  The greatness doesn't end there.  The poulet noir is also a must order.  Stunningly presented whole chicken...just do it.  The brussels sprout chips, the gnocchi, the pork chop...basically PT just crushes it.  

The bartenders are artisans that make classic or contemporary cocktails to perfection.  

All of this & a 5 star brunch too.

5 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
I really enjoyed my experience at Park Tavern, which was an unintended consequence of the ridiculously long line at Mama's across the street (sorry PT, the truth hurts). Given I had just completed the San Francisco Half Marathon that morning, I was not going to wait long to refuel this temple of mine, and so we had to quickly look for an alternative in the area. There was no visible line at Park Tavern so this is where we ended up! If you're familiar with the North Beach square then it goes without saying that Parking is a nightmare! Park Tavern offers valet parking for $12 ($15 if you're a good citizen and tip the valet) and though paying for parking may result in one less mimosa afforded, it sure saves you a good 30 minutes and a headache of circling to look for a space... and the follow on tight parallel parking you will endure otherwise. 

Well the absence of a visible line fooled us! It was still a 25 minute wait to be seated. However, we learned they do take reservations (something to consider if heading in around brunch time). Thank goodness for the other post SF Marathon finishers eating there as well, otherwise I would have felt like a slob entering in running clothes and a baseball cap :/ It is an upscale establishment, large seating area and every table full with good looking and well dressed brunchers... clearly lots of dates going on. 

Our server was outstanding... on top of our table, friendly, and humored us with the all the food we ordered. 

Mind you, this was 2 people eating at a table fit for 2 plates: 

Deviled Egg: SO GOOD! I've never had a deviled egg with bacon on it. Genius idea! A small sliver of jalapeño to add just enough kick. One order is actually half of an egg... keep that in mind if sharing. 

Challah Toast: Should be a dessert but we ate it before our meal. Thick Texas toast covered in butter, cinnamon, and sugar. Who doesn't love Challah toast? While it was yummy, it doesn't compare to Trouble Coffee's challah. I thought it could've used a dash more of everything, but I wouldn't hesitate to eat it again should it arrive in front of me. 

Smoked Salmon Benedict: A larger than usual benedict, served over focaccia rather than an English Muffin. PT was not stingy with the smoked salmon either! Capers added just enough to the overall taste and the eggs were cooked perfectly! There are no sides to this dish - it is solely the benedict. Keep that in mind as its unusual to eat benedict without potatoes or some other side dish. It was large enough that you don't need a side in my opinion. 

Corned Beef Hash: Per my brunch date, the dish was very good. He felt like he was chewing on real meat as opposed to hash out of a can. The kale was a nice add to the dish. 

Cherry French Toast: What a great way to end a brunch - with the warm, soft, chewy, sweetness of the PT French Toast. Cherries, syrup, mascarpone cheese... a delight for your tastebuds! 

Classic mimosa: No brunch is done justly without a mimosa. A perfect ratio of sparkling wine to OJ... it's the simple things in life :)
author: Krystal A.

description:
"YOU'RE SO HOT!" Those were the words my buddy James dared me to write on the check as we left, for our gorgeous waitress. 

And when someone says "I dare you," I'm all in since I feel that my honor is at stake.

Came here for lunch and had the banana-coconut fritters, crab toast, corned beef hash, and burger.

The fritters were undercooked and James said they were "burnt," so we sent them back. I was hesitant though since I didn't want to draw more attention to use, since both of us couldn't help but notice that our waitress was stunning.

And you know me, around stunning women, I turn into a mime. Silent. Nervous. Stumbling around. Can't find my way out of an invisible box....

After we told her about the terrible fritters, she was great and took it off our bill, as James, who has enough confidence and swagger to fill the whole restaurant got her name.

She had no interest in me whatsoever, and honestly, I could have been wearing a chicken outfit and clucking and she still wouldn't have noticed I was there.

The crab toast was soggy, and had more water than mayonnaise. It also tasted like canned crab, though I'm sure it's not (or at least I hope it's not for $16).

The corned beef hash was hearty and flavorful, but I would have liked less arugula. It's not a salad after all. And the burger was surprisingly good too. James couldn't stop raving about the aioli. He could have cared less about the burger, he just wanted the aioli with fries. He's easy to please that way.

The waitress (who I won't embarrass by writing her name) was a good waitress and split the burger and fries for us so that we could share the dishes.

My only complaint was the crab toast, fritters, and 53 minute wait to get our burger and hash. Luckily, she was so gorgeous that I almost forgot the time (notice I said almost), cause it took forever to get our food. Hence the 4 stars.

We also tried the TCHO creme brûlée because she recommend it. And in my eyes, she could have recommended anchovy creme brûlée and I would have bought it.

Anyways, after James dared me, I wrote the note on the bill gave her a 23% tip, and ran like a track star out of the restaurant as James walked out casually, laughing behind me.

P.S I didn't leave my # because knowing my luck she would have called me and asked for James LOL
author: Jack R.

description:
Delicious Sunday Brunch option!
It was packed at 11:30 on a Sunday, but we were lucky to snag the last 2 seats at the bar (open seating).

Get: 
- The grapefruit mimosa! I watched the bartender make it, and it was the perfect ratio of juice to champagne (just a splash of juice, obvi)
- The deviled eggs. A little pricey at $2.50 a pop, but so delicious... and topped perfectly with of bite of bacon and jalapeno
- The polenta cakes. A little heavy handed w/ the truffle oil, but still the perfect combination of crispy polenta, runny poached egg, sauteed mushrooms, and peppery arugula. Absolutely amazing!
- The chorizo and eggs. Scrambled eggs w/ chorizo and tomatoes. The BF really enjoyed this dish - I thought the eggs were done well as well!!

Try to make reservations if you're coming for brunch! You won't regret it.
author: Michelle L.

description: Phenomenal tastes!! To name a few, the deviled eggs, fig dish, cheeseburger with a horseradish aioli sauce and a real fav is the brussel sprout chips!!! The venue itself is beautiful, great atmosphere and the service is fantastic!!! A wonderful place to eat & share time with friends and family!!
author: Mindy N.

description: Park Tavern is one of my local favorites. The deviled eggs, devils on horseback, and Brussels sprout chips are great starters. The Poulet Rouge is fantastic and I also like the Spanish octopus and the burger. The cocktails are also delicious. This is a great upscale Friday or Saturday night spot to go with friends. I've never had brunch here but I've heard great things. My only complaint is that the service can be a little slow but I'll definitely be back!
author: Caitlin M.

description:
Amongst the sea of the typical and traditional Italian options, Park Tavern sticks out like a sore thumb. We stopped by for brunch the other day after making our reservations through Open Table and while doing so we'd requested window seating.  Lo and behold, upon arriving we were lead to a window table just like we had asked - surely an indicator of fantastic, detail oriented service. 

The restaurant was decked out with Christmas decorations adding some festivity to the ambiance. We sat next to a very large, plush black and white houndstooth wreath. Very chic. The patrons, sophisticated, older. 

When we lived next door to Marlowe on Townsend, my husband would grab a Marlowe burger for lunch quite frequently so he skipped the burger this time and opted for something new, the hash. I had the poached eggs and crispy polenta cakes which was exactly texture and flavors I was wanting; earthy, velvety with a crunch and the bitterness from the small bed of arugula and mushrooms. We also had the Breton butter cake which was reminiscent of a Kouign Amann minus the sweet, glazed top. The buttercake, I'd probably skip next time. 

Service was quick and no-fussed, just how I like it.
author: Esther A.

description:
We were on our way to Mama's and ended up hear because the lineup for Mama's was insanely long. I thought overall Park Tavern's was a decent joint. We ordered a lot of food for two people:
Deviled eggs: 3/5
Avocado toast: 4/5 (super simple but tasty)
Oatmeal pancakes: 5/5 
Spinach omelette: 3/5
Deep fried muffin balls: 2/5 

The last items was not a good idea considering how rich and heavy it was. Taking a bite out of that was pretty much like drinking the oil from the deep fryer.
author: Kunny M.

description: This restaurant is the best! The service and the food is more than 5 stars. I came here with my husband and my parents, and we each ordered different entrees and shared it. Such a fun and great time.
author: Melissa B.

description:
Loved this place 
The shrimp toast is awesome and the deviled eggs ...I couldn't eat anymore so I skipped the burger but the table next to me ordered so I'll be back 
The waiter I had was so personable and kind !!!
His name is Matthew awesome service !!!
The dude ROCKS !!!!
author: Darryl M.

description:
Top-5 brunch in SF in my opinion. Get a reservation to make things easier. 

Try the corned beef hash, you won't be disappointed. Buddy had the shrimp and grits which were solid, and the baked eggs were a cool dish. The avocado toast is a must, and try the berries and cream for dessert. Bloody Mary is legit too.
author: Count C.

description: Great food and drinks! Also the location is good if you like to walk around North beach neighborhood. however these restaurants put the tables so close by each other that you can hear others conversation!
author: Ichi Y.

description: The Wood-fired pork chop is a generous portion (you could possibly share it with 2, but it's so tasty, perhaps not, hehe). But seriously, this chop is delicious in many ways. The skin is crisp and has a layer of fatty goodness underneath, and the meat is juicy. Though the dish itself is incredibly rich, the pickled medallion onions and greens provide the acidic bite to keep you in the game. GET THE PORK CHOP! You'll enjoy it. PS: the ambiance here is pretty chill too. Good place to enjoy with friends.
author: Chase B.

description: I have fond memories of this place since it was one our early dates that my fiancé had planned.  That was the first time I had been for dinner and it was years ago.  Now fast forward a few years, and my friends planned a brunch here for my bachelorette, and it brought back a lot of memories!  For brunch I ordered the smoked salmon benedict, which was really well done and delicious.  I'm not usually a big fan of devil's eggs, but given all the rave reviews of them maybe I should have ordered that as well.  Really solid food, just like Marlowe!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
As much as I love to sample the restaurants of the Bay Area, I rarely get out to try the brunch offerings. Who wants to wait in line for an hour to eat, right? That said, as I've been on something of a brunch kick lately, and after hearing so many great things about Park Tavern, especially the drinks, my girlfriend and I decided to grab a late brunch here. Luckily, as it was around 1 pm, there was no wait for seating at the communal dining table.

We did had to wait a bit longer than I would have liked to get our food orders taken, but our server was extremely apologetic and the rest of our dining experience was first rate. When my girlfriend, who doesn't like walnuts, decided to take a chance on the oatmeal walnut raisin pancakes and didn't like them, our server happily offered to take the item off the bill and allowed her to order something else.

Now onto the important stuff: the food here was amazing! The smoked deviled eggs were quite tasty and the avocado toast may just have been the best take on the dish that I've had the pleasure of trying. The highlight of my meal, though, was the shrimp and grits! The seasoning of the shrimp here was quite unique; add to that some well-prepared grits and you get the makings of an absolutely delicious meal!  

I paired all this food with the Double Issac, a tequilla-based cocktail, which was very refreshing. My girlfriend got the boozy smoothie that combines bourbon, banana, espresso and vanilla ice cream. I wasn't expecting it to be served in a champagne coupe, but I was pleasantly surprised by how well-balanced all the ingredients were. I'll definitely be back to explore more of the food and drink menu here.
author: Rodney G.

description:
I have always wanted to try this place and I'm happy that I did. That being said, I didn't have any foodie-experience that would cause me to come running back. I feel like this place is trendy and Instagram'able, thus making it very popular among the 20-somethings of San Francisco.

I will give them a major thumbs up for the bottomless coffee, which was greatly appreciated. Another major thumbs up for their honesty in telling my friends that the "pitchers" of mimosas were meant for about two people (i.e., not worth the money). The servers were also VERY patient while we waited for our entire party to arrive.

I probably had the healthiest brunch I have ever had. Usually, I don't equate diets and brunch, but if you're on a diet, this is definitely the place to brunch. If you try this place, try the Cast Iron-Baked Farm Eggs! For the first time after a brunch, I didn't feel tired and weighted-down. 

That being said, Park Tavern has its healthy options (Avocado Toast, anyone) and its unhealthy options (the typical pancakes and french toast).

I don't have any complaints whatsoever. I just wasn't ready to tweet about the experience. I did, however, Instagram my food, so that counts for something, right?
author: Gabriela K.

description:
Park Tavern was an okay experience, but for the price, I wanted it to be better

Pros: 
-the Brussel sprout chips appetizer was GREAT (highly recommend)
- if you sit outdoors, they provide a warm blanket for you in addition to heat lamps which was nice
-the whiskey cocktails were made well.

Cons:
- overall, food was mediocre at best. Significantly overpriced.
- not many vegetarian or vegan options.
- the wait for food was OVER an hour... On a Sunday night... For a party of 2.

Overall, not a bad experience, but with hundreds of foodie options in SF... I'd go elsewhere.
author: Tara G.

description: We celebrated a family member's special birthday in the Eden Room last night.  The Park Tavern exceeded our expectations.  With the lovely decor, which included mercury votives scattered throughout, along with perfect lighting and bar set-up, we could not have asked for a more beautiful place to have a family celebration.  The wonderful staff was attentive, flexible, personable and professional and ensured a memorable evening.  The menu selections were delicious too.  Highly recommend the Eden Room for your next party.
author: Nancy H.

description: I really liked this place - great service, well paced and expertly executed.  Great wine list, great cocktails and a thorough menu.
author: Michelle N.

description:
Maaannn, this place is swank. It's swank with its food to back it. I went with a couple of friends for a birthday brunch and it was totally worth it. We reserved for 10:15 on a Sunday morning and we were seated at 10. They were automatic with the water, which was great, and the morning drinks came right after. Their Irish Breakfast was STRONG, so make sure you have some food in you before drinking the whole thing. We ordered the buttermilk pancakes, 4 deviled eggs, the huckleberry fritters, the salmon benedict, the corned hash, the polenta cakes, and the farmed eggs. 

1: the deviled eggs are as great as they are hyped up to be.
2. the huckleberry fritters were crispy on the outside, soft and moist on the inside, with huckleberry and cream dipping sauces.
3. the buttermilk pancakes were ok.
4. the salmon benedict was a bit on the salty side, but very filling.
5. the hash was good and flavorful.
6. the polenta cakes were surprisingly refreshing with a slightly crisp bottom. they came with a bed of mushrooms which made the whole dish amazing.
7. the farmed eggs were ok.

Since it was a birthday thing for 2 in the group, our server gave us a chocolate cheesecake and an angel food cake slice on the house! 

I was extremely full and satisfied with everything from food to service to presentation and everything in between. I can't wait to try their dinner next time!
author: Pamela B.

description:
We had come to Park Tavern after our group's holiday party. I had found this deliciously fruity drink named Washington Square Park. I probably had 3 of those that night and had a great time with my coworkers. 


I ended up coming back with a friend when we were looking for restaurants between Pier 39 and Union Square. After all we needed to grab food between the end of her class and before our play

I ended up ordering the same drink as I had loved it the last time and we also got some food. The brussel sprouts with some parmesan cheese was delicious! Also (on the list) the deviled eggs were not truly traditional devlied eggs with just some paprika on top, but there was some awesome toppings (bacon, jalapenos, and chives). Delicious! We also ordered the demons on horseback, which made our dinner very hell-ish (with the devils and demons). Anyways, the demons on horseback was lardo wrapped smoked prawns with this amazing sauce. Definitely recommend. 

These dishes were enough for the 2 of us for a light dinner before the play. Honestly, I would definitely go back and try some of the other things. 

Protip: call and see if they have any reservations. I probably made the reservations for 2 a few hours ahead of time and we were seated at the bar on the side - it was so cool to watch the chefs plate and it was a lot of fun. Food is amazing!
author: Nina Y.

description: Visited Park Tavern with a friend and his mother on a weekend for brunch. We had planned to go to Mama's but the line was out the door and PT could get us in much quicker. Upscale place, younger crowd. Kind of awkward seating for older folks, but I liked the atmosphere and decor a lot. Food was great for me, just good/ okay for my fellow diners. I went with breakfast, they both ordered burgers I believe. They were very busy but we never felt ignored; bit of a wait for things though.
author: Julia R.

description:
How do I love Park Tavern? I would say let me count the ways, but it would be impossible as there are way too many; not only that, but the list grows every time I go back.

The look, the ambiance, the staff, the cocktails, and my God, the FOOD! Every aspect of this place is impeccable. Upscale without being stuffy, elegant without being pretentious, immaculate service without being boring - they really do nail everything.

In a city where it would be next to impossible to pick an all-out favorite, I can confidently say that this place is on the shortest of lists.
author: Matt V.

description:
We started with the brussel chips and deviled eggs.  The fish was very good, the chicken was good and huge.  It was a whole chicken.  The twice baked potatoes were yummy and the eaters of the steak and other dishes were all happy with their selections.  It was very crowded and very busy.  They put a lot of people in a small space and you end up sitting very close to your neighbors.  We were fortunate that the folks at the tables next to us were all friendly and enjoyable.  

I have to say one of the most impressive parts of this meal was that when our drinks were delivered by a different person than the one that took the order, they delivered the correct drinks to the correct people and they did that twice.  This seems to be something that most other restaurants don't really care about and it is something we noticed right away.  

I can see how this restaurant is good for a lot of different situations, dates, business meals, friends, celebrations.  Pretty much a good all around restaurant and dinner.
author: Sheryl C.

description: My girlfriend and i came here for the first time this past weekend and we enjoyed it very much. Situated on Stockton street right across the street from Washington Square Park, its a nice calm area. We walked in around 1030 and was told that most of the dining room had already been  reserved but there was some opening seating still available in the bar area. Which was just fine. My girlfriend ordered a mimosa and i stole a sip. Tasted great. She also ordered a grapefruit mimosa which i actually liked even more. We both ordered The Buttermilk Pancakes and they were delicious! Nice and fluffy the way pancakes should be. They were big too so two of them was plenty of food. Im glad we found this place. We will definitely be back! :)
author: Joshua H.

description:
Read about this place on 7x7 and decided to come try for dinner.  Had an early 5:30 reservation for dinner, but there was a party going on at the bar so we didn't feel too lonely being early birds.

Loved the ambiance and atmosphere.  Friendly attentive staff.  They had a great selection of cocktails so I started the evening with Mary Etta's Bubbles which had framboise and lemon twist in it.  Very flavorful....my kind of drink!  

For starters, we had their famous Smoked Deviled Eggs which came with bacon, chives, and pickled jalapeños.  You can order as many as you want as they sell them by the piece.  I loved the smoky taste of the bacon with the egg.  I could have probably eaten another.  Went well with the Acme bread that you get.

We also tried their famous Demons on Horseback which are lardo-wrapped smoked prawns with some remoulade and cucumbers.  It had a nice kick to it and the prawns were cooked perfectly that it was fresh and juicy.  YUM!  

After the cocktail, I wanted a glass of wine with my dinner.  I was happy to see they had grenache so I ordered that.  It's not very often that the wine glass list consists of various regional wines.  

For dinner, I had the Roasted Sea Bass which came with fennel and baby artichokes.  My husband had the C.A.B. NY Steak which came with braised Kobe beef and marrow-stuffed bone with potatoes and broccolini.  We both enjoyed our dishes that we left nothing behind.  After all the great food we had, we decided to try their dessert as well.  The only thing the stood out for me was the Tcho Chocolate Creme Brûlée.   All I have to say is, what a great ending to a lovely meal!
author: Erica S.

description:
We were really excited to try this place but left very disappointed.  The positives: nice décor, drinks were good and our appetizers.  We had the deviled eggs and beef jerky.

Our entrees were split.  The veggie pot pie was good.  My steak was TERRIBLE!  Absolute worst steak I have ever had.  No taste, burnt on the outside cold in the middle.  All I could taste was the burnt char and zero flavor.

For what we paid this was not worth it.  Won't be back
author: Karin And Nick S.

description: Fantastic food!!!! Saturday brunch was not too busy even though we made a reservation for 1:30pm just in case. The deviled eggs, avocado toast and the fritters were phenomenal. We also had the egg dish with kale (very rich, I would order this to share with others). The polenta with poached eggs were outstanding, loved the flavors. Will definitely come back next time!
author: Molly F.

description:
Atmosphere - 4, with no AC, patio doors open, I thought the restaurant was uncomfortably warm.  However, decor, lighting, and music were spot on for a nice dinner in North Beach.

Service - 4, excellent service, we had a very attentive, and accommodating server.  More personable would have been better.

Entree - 4, all the food was on the salty side, which took a little away from the food. However, high quality ingredients, decent menu selection.  Unfortunately, they were out of duck.  Mussels were cooked perfectly and large portion, but the tomato broth was disappointingly bland.  Pork chops and salmon looked good.

Dessert - 4, apple crisp was delicious and generous portion with Fuji apples and ice cream.  Tcho chocolate Creme brûlée was bad.  Creme brûlée was never meant to have chocolate.  It was more like a mousse.  Don't call it something it's not.

Appetizers - 2, burnt Brussels sprout leaves as an appetizer, interesting concept.  Sliced lemon chips, interesting.  They get too fancy for their own good.  However, I will give them a 2 because the venison carpaccio was excellent.  Smooth, fresh, and tasty.

Location - 4, nice location at Washington Park in North Beach.

Price - 3, entrees were fair priced.  Appetizers were either overpriced or overrated.  Desserts were fair priced.

Overall, I would give it a 3.5.  Would I go again?  Only for the location since it is a block away from a relative.  Otherwise there are plenty of better restaurants in the area.
author: Ryan Y.

description:
My most loyal readers may remember a review that I once wrote of a mullet-infested, divey place in NJ where we went to a birthday party called The New Park Tavern.  Imagine the exact opposite and you will have San Fran's Park Tavern. 

Our lovely friend Meredith M. took us around town while we were visiting plus made reservations for Mike and I to have a special, romantic dinner. The room was dimly lit and our table was conducive to quiet conversation and sitting closely. The food was as delightful as the ambience and creative too. Brussels sprout chips are a stroke of genius.  

Many thanks to Meredith for being such a good friend and for introducing us to a terrific establishment.
author: Caroline B.

description:
Really enjoyed having brunch here. Had the smoked salmon Benedict which was excellent (they smoked the salmon in house!). My girlfriend had the French toast that they generously swapped out the cherry compote for fresh strawberries, which was awesome as well. 

Drinks were great and service was warm and attentive. Slight tad pricey but the best thing is they take reservations on OpenTable so you don't have to wait in line forever like the other brunch places in town. 

Will be back!
author: Raymond S.

description:
Had dinner here last night and I would say overall it was a pretty good experience. The atmosphere is great, packed and lively. Keep in mind it is loud and dark! The waiter was nice and personable, but would disappear for long periods of time and I constantly had to wait a very long time just for my water to be refilled. 

We tried a good sampling of the menu:

Salmon was good, park tavern salad was very good, shrimp appetizer was excellent, pork chop was exceptional, corn soup was superb, & the Marlowe hamburger was great. Unfortunately, the bar steak was very disappointing- very small portion and overcooked. Chocolate cheesecake was bad-not like a cheesecake at all. Very dry and flavorless. Birthday cake this month is carrot cake and it was delicious! 

Corkage is only $15 so you may be better off bringing your own wine. Their glasses are small so you end up 3 just to equal a normal two. This drives up the meal price.

Overall, really fun place, good service and uneven food.
author: Alyssa C.

description:
Brunch at Park Tavern was one of the best stops on our San Francisco trip, and definitely the best meal we had in the city! I came in with a small bachelorette party of about 6 ladies (we weren't a rowdy bunch, just out to get breakfast!) and the Maid of Honor had called ahead to make a reservation. We waited about 20 minutes past our reservation time while they seated walk-in groups (not awesome), and with some prodding, they finally seated us.

They, thankfully, realized that they had kept us waiting and MORE than made it up to us with some amazing deviled eggs and delicious pastries, brought to us as soon as we sat down. I don't even like deviled eggs... but these looked so good, I had to try one and OMG what have I been missing all of my life?! They were AMAZING! We ordered several appetizers and some fantastic bloody marys, and none of it disappointed. The horseradish in the bloody was new for me, but gave it a great spicy kick! The avocado toast was to -die- for, and the cinnamon challah literally melts in your mouth. (So. So. Good!!!!) 

I had the chorizo and egg scramble, and it was unbelievable! (Then again, there was nothing on our table that didn't look like it rolled out of a gourmet kitchen - which apparently, it did!) The atmosphere was so open and charming... we all agreed that the place was absolutely worth the wait and the value! Next time I find myself in the San Francisco area, this will be a must-do again! LOVED it!!!
author: Heather H.

description:
It has taken me awhile to write this. I had two good experiences at this establishment within a week. 

First was breakfast. The line at Mama's was ridiculous and we had walked from PH and did not want to wait. We did eventually eat there, as well, check out the review if you want (not good).

Our breakfast was excellent. We shared the Pomelo & Avocado w/cottage cheese & cracked black pepper. After a couple of mimosa's, I ordered the Crispy Polenta Cakes (wild mushrooms, poached eggs, arugula, truffle salsa verde & shaved parmesan) and J ordered the Pan-Fried Corned Beef Hash (crispy potato, poached egg, arugula & red wine jus). Excellent brunch.

A few days later, J and I returned with N for dinner. We intended to go to Tony's , but forgot they he's closed on Tuesday. Since we had such a nice brunch at Park Tavern, and it was just a block away, we stepped into the bar. There were not any seats available at the communal bar table so we waited. It was a great opportunity to sample a cocktail and peek at the orders as the servers passed by. Wait was about 10 min.

Our order, which the three of us shared:

FRIED SUNCHOKES creamy harissa & lemon zest
BROWN BUTTER BRUSSELS SPROUTS parmesan & chili flakes 
STORYBOOK MOUNTAIN VINEYARDS "Anteaus," Napa Valley, 2009 
"MARLOWE" BURGER caramelized onion, cheddar, bacon, horseradish aïoli & fries 
THE BAR STEAK  12oz c.a.b. hanger french fries & buttered red wine jus

All were tasty, but our favorites were the brussels sprouts and the bar steak. The Storybrook was a good value. Our sunchokes were overcooked and we did not eat them, nor did we complain, but our server noticed, and offered to take them off the bill. 
Much appreciated!

Overall, great service and great food. Wanting to go back now!
author: Kris M.

description:
The Great: Takes reservations for Sunday brunch. Woo!
+Blood mary. Fantastic.

The Good: Avocado toast.

The OK: Oatmeal walnut raisin pancakes. Fine. I especially liked the figs on top, but otherwise nothing to write home about.
-Also the service. On the arrogant and brusque side. 

The ambiance is high-end tavern - ya know, dark woods, low lights, not much natural lighting. Which I like, but not so much for brunch. But I'll take that over waiting in line for 2 hours on a Sunday morning.

Since I am not an egg eater, I was left with not a lot of options, but this is pretty typical for any brunch place. The egg dishes my companions got all looked pretty spectacular, so I fear that my love of the idea of brunch was eclipsed by my food preferences yet again.
author: Nadia H.

description: If you're in North Beach for lunch or dinner and you don't necessarily want Italian food, come here! The food is very fresh and flavorful. Great drinks and ambience. Fun for friends!
author: Tracey K.

description: Tiny portions, and expensive.  Especially irritating to pay $12 for about 1.5-2 oz of the cheapest wine on the menu (Tempranillo).  A bit loud most of the time, and a few frat boy laughs by groups at other times.  Just moved to the area and don't plan on going back.  Too many other restaurants...
author: Mike L.

description:
So I ate here sort of by accident. My friend and I went to brunch on Mother's Day. We were actually trying to go to this place called Mama's down the street but the line was crazy. So we found this place and got there before doors opened. 

The first staff members we encountered were not very friendly but possibly bc they were still setting up and busy. I get it. 

Once they opened we were told it was only prefix that day since it was. Mother's Day at $40ish per person. Whatever - we needed to eat so we paid the price. 

The food turned out to be excellent! Had the shrimp toast w curry aioli and the crispy polenta w mushrooms and poached eggs. Enjoyed both thoroughly. Had a bite of my friend's lamb burger and salmon salad thing. Both were good too!

Cute ambiance. Next time I'm up in SF, I'll go again. And add a Bloody Mary!
author: Juliet K.

description: The location was gorgeous, right by the park and the inside was dark and romantic. It also had beautiful light fixtures and pretty mirrors. It's a great place for a date. Definitely get the cabernet, it was great! Unfortunately my burger was way too raw for me (or anyone) and the soup was just not for me. The ice cream sandwich dessert was the saving grace for me though. Make sure to ask about the desserts and the drink list!
author: Abby S.

description: Had the pork chop is was awesome, large place and also a good spot for grabbing drinks at the bar! This place makes me want to move to North Beach there is so much space in here which is amazing because the majority of restaurants in NB are so cramped.
author: Morgan S.

description: I really can't say enough about our brunch today. The service was Grade A, the mimosas were generous (a rarity for $10 in SF these days), and my trout benedict was essentially perfect. All of that combined with a radiant spring day at Washington Square Park in North Beach made for a truly amazing Sunday morning.
author: Jack K.

description: I was very much looking forward to visiting Park Tavern after reading all the awesome reviews. However unfortunately my experience was not so great! Our food took over an hour to come out! I'm pretty sure, they forgot to put in the order to kitchen. After about 45 minutes of waiting for our main dishes the waiter realized we didn't have our food and come over to let us know the kitchen was "backed up". He offered to bring over pastries or deviled eggs. We declined thinking our food was coming up soon. However it was another 20 minutes before the food arrived. I ordered the smoked trout Benedict. My one and only egg was completely over cooked and the portion was pretty small for an entree. The manger was kind enough to comp our entrees! I wouldn't recommend this place solely on the service! The quality of food was so so however the cocktails were delicious!
author: Kelly L.

description:
The deviled eggs were pretty good.

My girlfriend and I both ordered the hamburger. We both got upset stomaches from it very soon after. 
The hamburger was pretty rich and one-demential. It could have used something to cut the richness/cheese.

Our service was also very bad. Our server was a bit rude and short. We waited for about 25 minutes before our waiter took our order. We waited well over an hour for our food. I also waited about 30 mins for them to bring me an iced tea.

I wont be coming back.
author: Jeremy B.

description:
Service was great. Lots of floor staff. We were greeted warmly and seated before our reservation as we were about 10-15 minutes early. 
James, our waiter,  came to the table quickly to take our drink order and food order a little later. Smoked deviled eggs, Brussels sprout chips and bone marrow to start.
All the apps were well prepared and flavorful. If anything the bone marrow was a little to heavy on the garlicky side but that didn't stop me.
Everything from there was poorly executed. Don't know if the kitchen was understaffed or what but that night their game was way off on the entrees.
Halibut was very fishy, not sure how old it was but this should not have been used. Halibut should not have a heavy fish flavor. The duck breast ordered medium was medium rare to rare. It was very flavorful. The accompanying polenta described on the menu as creamy was luke warm and was most likely the last of the pan as it was a little lumpy. It like the halibut should not have been used. The "signature" Marlowe burger ordered medium was medium rare ar best.  
We finished with a ginger cheesecake. A nice light flavor. Texture was not what I expected from a cheesecake. Heavy, thick, and pastey in the mouth. If that is how it was meant to be then the pastry staff hit the mark, otherwise it needs some correction as I was expecting it to be of a lighter texture.
I hope this was a one off night for them. My wife has been there several times and always had a good meal. I let the manager, CJ, know how our meal was. He was very apologetic, gave me his card and said to let him know the next time I am coming in. At some point down the road I will be back with the anticipation they have been able to correct the kitchen issues.
author: Michael W.

description: The rhubarb dessert here (done three ways) was amazing. One of the best desserts I've had.
author: Thomas C.

description: All in all it was good, was a bit shocking that the trout Benedict that cost $17 came with 1 egg!?!?!?! I've never ever seen that happen. We ended up having to order a third dish because we were hungry! The waiter was a bit impatient, tried to hide it charmingly but ended up being quite snippety to me. I was quite humiliated. The boozie smoothie was 2.5 sips, definitely not worth $11. The polenta with poached eggs was delicious, so were.the Huckleberry fritters. The bloody Mary's were generous and packed a punch. The French toast was so so, quite soggy. We over paid for overhyped but still enjoyed it. Not enough to come back though....
author: Donna G.

description:
Apps and sides were the best part of the meal.

Best deviled eggs! And the Wagyu jerky is delicious.

The brussel sprout chips were OK. They are essentially just the charred outer part of a brussel sprout without the meat (I like the meat!).

The fries with truffled egg and caviar were to die for. So decadent.
author: Laura D.

description: The starters stole the show: deviled eggs, fries served with a soft boiled egg filled with caviar, and crazy-good lemon chips with burrata. The entrees were great, too.
author: Morris R.

description: Ambience was great! Wait staff was very attentive! Food was so-so... The PT Fries were awesome and so were the Brussels sprout chips. I had the duck, and it was difficult to cut & very rare! Polenta that accompanied the meal was cold! My daughter had the steak & it was chewy! The  dessert were ok... I would recommend the ice cream sandwiches.
author: Susan L.

description:
I was hoping for a 5 star and this is 4.5 stars - there we a few glitches so it gets 4.

My sister had given me a gift cert for my birthday a while back - and since I live on a tight budget I save these extraordinary splurges for special occasions. This was my sweet bf's birthday dinner.

I had poured over the menu for days trying to work out the best was to attack the menu.  We decided to go with a bottle of wine (a rare splurge), a few apps, split an entree and split a dessert, we had:
-Brussels sprout chips - FANTASTIC wish I could make these at home - forget Kale chips, these are where it is at.
-Parisenne Gnocchi - this was our least favorite
-Burrata with lemon chips - this was 2nd our favorite
-We spilt the roasted Poulet Noir  - Our waitress recommended the Pork Chop over the chicken and maybe we should have gotten that - it was very good (and a interesting  presentation, but I can make a good roast chicken at home and I rarely make pork, I was hoping for more truffle flavor.
-Carrot cake - delish!

Service/food oddities: 
-We had to ask twice for bread and the butter that came with it was hard and cold (bummer). 
-The water is served without ice - I had to ask 2x for a glass if ice
the chicken is supposed to come with spinach and some small potatoes (it only had one potato - when I flagged our server down and asked if that was normal - she said no and about 8 minutes later brought out about 5 small potatoes as a side
-Great oddity - they comped the dessert, and it had a candle.
- Over at Marlow they serve a cauliflower gratin that is like the best mac and cheese you ever had, I wish they offered it here
author: Amy W.

description:
I've been to Park Tavern several time for brunch, and I'm going to keep going back. First, they take reservations, which means I know I won't be waiting in a two hour line after driving up to the city ... hugely valuable! Second, it's a great location right in front of Washington Square; they have tables out front and a full wall of windowed seating so that you can enjoy a little sunshine while you dine. That's how brunch should be eaten.

The drinks are totally on point. Let's face it, if you're not drinking at brunch, then you're doing it wrong ... that's just having breakfast late. They have a John Daly, which is a boozy iced tea that I can (and do) drink 3-4 of. Guess how good that makes me feel? Totally sets me up for Sunday funday.

Finally, the food is very good. I've had the Smoked Salmon Benedict; perfectly poached eggs (not easy to do and most places leave the white a little runny, which I hate) on top of a thin layer of smoked salmon, red onions, cream cheese, and toast. Damn good. The Crispy Polenta cakes are a close second. If you love umami, this bad boy has mushrooms, truffle oil and arugula! Finally, don't forget to grab an Avocado Toast as a starter. It's simple, but very tasty. My mouth is watering as I write this!

So, Park Tavern ... a total winner for brunch!
author: Akash K.

description:
Gastropub-style cuisine (comfort food with fancy twists) served in a casual brasserie atmosphere while bordering on fine dining prices.  The food is pretty solid overall with a few real standout items.  Love the extensive mixology cocktail list and love that mixology has become the norm so no one actually calls it mixology anymore.  

Smoked Deviled Eggs: Way better than the traditional version your aunt would make at a family picnic.  These had what seemed like a triple dose of creamy yolk filling and were topped with a nice hunk of crispy bacon.  There was also a pickled jalapeño hiding under the bacon for a mild kick.

Smoked Lemon Chips: These sounded more interesting than they actually were.  I was really looking forward to the creamy burrata pile, but the fried lemon chip was so intense that it overpowered the subtlety of the cheese.  Not really my thing.

Brussels Sprout Chips: Individual leaves of Brussels Sprouts that were deep friend.  AMAZING!  Far superior to the slimy boiled Brussels Sprouts that germinate disdain in one's youth.   Of course, serving deep fried vegetables to kids probably wouldn't have been good parenting move either.  As an adult, definitely worth the snacking!

Clam Chowder: Having grown up in New England, I'm a bit finicky.  This was definitely better than chowder from a can or served at chains (e.g. Boudin).  However, the broth focused more on cream than complexity.  Also, the clam chunks were a bit too small for my tastes.  And, hello, where were the crackers... I feel like homemade artisanal crackers would have totally fit the vibe here.

Poulet Noir: Judging by all the Yelp photos, this seems to be the signature dish.  A super tasty lacquered glaze made the chicken burst with umami.  The black truffle au jus helped intensify it even more (just wish there was more of the au jus).  The swiss chard was a bit disappointing though; soggy and tasteless.

Crème Brûlée: Technically it fit the bill with a crispy burnt sugar layer and creamy filling.  The seasonal flavor didn't do much for me though.

Birthday Cake: I love the concept of having birthday cake as a regular dessert!  But actually, this tasted more like wedding cake to me than birthday cake.  Nice layers of citrus and stone fruit jam between fluffy sheets of cake.  The frosting was like a vanilla fondant, hence the reminder of weddings.
author: Adam B.

description:
Birthdays are such momentous occasions, reflections on life automatically come with it. Park Tavern is the perfect place for special events.  

We came here during the holidays so the handsome dining room felt extra festive. With fantastic service from our waiter and good timing of dishes from the kitchen, we were able to relax and savor every moment.

The brussel sprout chips and deviled eggs with bacon & pickled jalapenos are house favorites for a reason: just right blend of texture and seasonings, these will disappear faster than you can say "feed me!" My grass fed ribeye was a generous serving, done medium rare as requested, with tender baby carrots and buttery mashed potatoes. Your dining experience would be remiss if you skipped on the signature PT fries, these potato sticks are so posh, you would need a pedigree in eating them. Truffle, soft boiled egg and caviar as your accompaniments, the best thing to do is to dip the crunchy fries into the soft boiled egg and eat away. Oh. My. GOD. (wait, was that really $14?!?) 

I was at my favorite speakeasy before heading here so I wasn't impressed with the cocktails even though they were 17 cocktails deep on the menu. The Maclaren with Hendrick's gin, cucumber, lemon and ginger beer was refreshing, but also overpriced at $13.

Nevertheless, I left with a the warm and fuzzies here. It's a meal that won't soon be forgotten.
author: Janice C.

description:
My friends and I went here for brunch. The service was incredibly polite, and seated us immediately (they had just opened for lunch). The drinks were delicious, and the food was perfectly portioned! I had the Fried Duck Egg Sandwich with an arugula salad instead of the fries. The fries are delicious though, my friend ordered the Roasted Vegetable Focaccia with fries, and it was amazing!!! I ordered the Mclaren (hendrick's gin, cucumber, lemon, and ginger beer). it was refreshing and went perfectly with my sandwich! 

Definitely will come back if I'm in the area again!
author: Leta K.

description: The chicory salad was delicious and light - I got it with a tasty cab franc. Service, ambiance and staff are all five star quality.
author: maple leaf d.

description: Park tavern came recommended to us be a friend who lives in the city. The food was very good and the drinks were on point. Unfortunately, the night became quite uncomfortable when a party of 4 sat next to us and were very abrupt and strange.   During our meal this stranger approached our table introduced himself and proceeded to tell us a random story that made no sense, and proceeded to put his dirty glasses on our table.  When addressed he said that he thought we were leaving.. once this happened the staff jumped at the opportunity to make our stay as comfortable as possible. They offered to move our table and made sure we remained comfortable and tried to diffuse the situation the best they could.  The staff was wonderful throughout the situation and management and seed the issue as well with us.. i was very uncomfortable and just wanted to leave but they offered us dessert on the house so we had dessert and left promptly after.  Park Tavern was amazing b side the little hiccup
author: stefanie G.

description:
This restaurant was really the highlight of my trip to SF. We were promptly seated right on time for our reservation. Our hostess and server were wonderful (5 out of 5). We had the lemon chips and burrata (3.5 out of 5) the burratta was so creamy and filling I could only have a few bites, but the lemon chips were interesting. Are they baked? Dehydrated? IDK?

We also had the beef tartare. This was delicious, the rice puffs complimented the texture perfectly, small portion however. (4.5 out of 5)

Now for the best part, we shared the whole chicken with veggies and a side of cream kale. OMG. This was seriously the best chicken I have ever had in my life. It was cooked perfectly. Sooo good. It was flavorful, but not over powering. It was tender and the crisp/baked veggies that were in the pan with it were incredible. The cream kale was next level. My boyfriend and I were looking at dupe recipes to make it when we get home (5 out 5)

Do yourself a favor and MAKE YOUR WAY to Park Tavern.
author: Lauren A.

description: Delicious for weekend brunch! I came here for my birthday brunch and was really impressed. We had a reservation and I definitely recommend you make one as well. We had a lovely seat by the window overlooking the park. I got the bloody Mary and mimosa and they were both delicious. I got the salmon benedict and it was outstanding. The service was awesome and the restaurant is beautifully decorated. Definitely took a long time overall so not the best for a quick breakfast but a lovely place to enjoy a lovely weekend brunch.
author: Jessica G.

description: I took a group here for dinner and was pleased for a few reasons.  First, the ambiance/decor feels like San Francisco.  I had a couple people in the group that were visiting for the first time, and they loved the vibe.  Second, our waiter was knowledgeable on the wine list, and offered samples of anything they pour by the glass while I was pursuing the bottle list. Finally, the food.  It was amazing-- everything from the stellar deviled eggs (yeah, $3 for a half egg, but it was worth every penny) to the egg yolk/caviar sidecar for the garlic fries, to the succulent lamb I enjoyed as the main course.  I'll be back for sure.
author: Shane W.

description:
After putting hours of research into brunch restaurants, I decided to try Park Tavern because of its high ranking on both Yelp and Thrillist. I haven't ventured much into North Beach, so that was also a plus. Park Tavern is in a beautiful neighborhood that intersects Chinatown and Little Italy near a park, and the vibe is very family friendly. 

Park Tavern is definitely a reservation must place on weekends as it was packed when we visited. It has a slightly bougie atmosphere with a large space decorated by dark wood furnishings. It reminded me of a high end seafood restaurant that I used to go to in Utah. 

After being seated, the server was friendly and gave us recommendations on brunch cocktails. I ordered a hummingbird, which was amazing, also because I love St. Germaine. My friend and I then shared avocado toast with chile, lemon, and sea salt along with the French toast with cherries and mascarpone and cod cake. After eating the entrees I decided I will come back. The French toast tasted sweet and creamy but not too sugary. It did not have that fake sweetness that always comes with fruit compotes. The avocado toast was perfect; the zesty lemon and little bit of chile made it have a small kick, which made it refreshing. Lastly, the cod cake was unique as I had never had cod cake anywhere. It was soft and the stronger taste balanced the light salad that it came served with. 

I don't have anything negative to say about Park Tavern and recommend it for brunch. I will be taking lots of friends here in the future.
author: Annie C.

description: Came here on a Sunday afternoon and was lucky to get seated right away at the bar. This place can get busy! Great brunch spot. I tried the avocado toast which had a nice tang. I also had the polenta cakes served with mushrooms and salad. It was really filling but soooo yummy!
author: Caryn H.

description:
Beautiful ambience in a great location of San Francisco. Wait staff was on point and  a delight to interact with. Food was full of taste and creative! We really enjoyed the deviled eggs, the PT fries (caviar + Himalayan sea salt in a 5 min egg & a truffle aioli). Hush puppies were a unique twist of an appetizer.

Certainly will be back again when we are in the area!
author: Michael A.

description: This restaurant has a great vibe and nice bar scene. The food, however is a different story. The burgers ($17 each) were terrible (how do you ruin a burger?..) and the short ribs ($40) were small, tough and tasteless. Maybe we hit it on an off night, but... we did not bring this to the owner/manager's attention because my daughters begged me not to.  The service was good, however. We left, having spent $200! on a bad meal. They were embarrassed, having suggested the place. I hope this review will cause Park Tavern to be more attentive and have some quality control. At this point, I would not go back or recommend it.
author: Bee P.

description: avocado toast - need i say more? this place has fabulous brunch and great for post work or evening cocktails w friends or a date
author: Alexandra K.

description:
Came here for Valentine's Day dinner. Well, attempted to at least. 

My boyfriend made reservations a month in advance. We both looked at the menu online and were surprised to find no pre fixe menu, as most restaurants I had been scoping out for other dinners leading up to Valentine's had all posted a pre fixe menu online. It seemed Park Tavern wasn't offering a pre fixe menu, which was great because I was excited to try the regular menu. Someone from the restaurant called the day of our reservation to confirm and again, no mention of a pre fixe menu.

We get to the restaurant and are seated at a table that is technically in the dining area, but is really about a foot away from the bar and in a weird arched corner with strange lighting. I felt like the hunchback of Notre Dame. We'd made these reservations so early there really was no reason for such a terrible table.

Once we're seated on the island of castaways we're handed a menu. A pre fixe menu! More specifically, an $85/per person pre fixe menu. They are not offering their regular menu that night at all. After not posting this online or having their host let us know when confirming over the phone we are now stuck with $85/pp menu. We got up, walked over to Original Joe's and had a great night sitting in their bar area with excellent service. I also wrote the restaurant to let them know before posting this review and never heard anything back. I'll take my business to Original Joe's from now on.
author: Erica G.

description:
My guy friend told me this place was absolutely amazing and the food was the best he ever had, so I had very high expectations when we arrived. The place itself reminded me of a few restaurants I had been in Chicago, very 50s-60s feel, trendy, young ambiance. We were seated right away and I started with a Cruel Summer cocktail, which was tasty. More so a summer drink then anything else, but still good. 

Since I arrived late, as soon as I sat,  smoked deviled eggs were placed on the table. I don't eat them, but as far as deviled eggs go. they did look pretty tasty. We also ordered the PT fries, which were truffle fries and came with 2 dipping sauces, truffle & soft cooked egg with caviar. It was an interesting combination of flavors. The fries were pretty tasty. The demons on horseback app was interesting, the shrimp was good, I just didn't love how they added a ton of meat and fat onto everything we ordered. I honestly felt gross after leaving this place, too many super fatty foods and so much meat! 

Anyway, I ordered the scallops for dinner and was told they ran out. That really annoyed me because they have all of 8 entree items, 4 of them non-meat, and I don't eat meat, so I was left with 3 options. and the other options didn't really excite me. I ended up with the wild atlantic cod, which in my opinion, was lackluster at best. The cod itself was okay, nothing special, and it was paired with a ton of vegetables including mushrooms, onions, fennel, and some other greens. The sauce itself was kinda bland, and overall the dish did nothing for me, I barely ate it. As a side dish I got the brown butter brussel sprouts which were tasty. I also tried a bit of my friend's butternut squash made 'au gratin', like everything else on the menu...super heavy and fattening. Not really my style. 

For dessert, we got the birthday cake, which came with a candle, that was a little little touch. The cake was okay, white cake with white icing. Nothing out of the ordinary there. We also ordered the ice cream sandwiches, which I really liked. The gingersnap cookies gave it a unique touch and the caramel ice cream was delicious.

Maybe since I came in with such high expectations, I left feeling disappointed. I thought the  menu was very limited, the food was okay at best, the service was decent and the ambiance was nice, but I've been to a lot better. The meat dishes looked pretty good. Maybe if you're a huge meat eater, you'll enjoy this place more than I did.
author: Shannon W.

description: The food are amazingly good. We had corn soup, foie gras torchon, and demons on horseback for appetizers. We love all of them and wish we had more. We shared a Poulet Rouge as entree. The chicken skin was so crispy and the meat was really juicy. The only thing disappointed us was the dessert. We had cornmeal financier.  It was plain and not sweet at all. However, overall, it's a must try sf restaurant.
author: Tina L.

description:
Very happy with the whole experience here, food is excellent and so was the service.
Would definitely eat here again even if it is a little expensive.
author: Brian L.

description:
Top notch place for a weekend brunch.  The only challenge is finding parking (especially on the weekends)!!!!  It took me about a good 20 minutes to find parking and it was a few blocks away.

The restaurant is beautifully located in North Beach so if you're seated near the window, it's a beautiful view while in good company.  I ordered the polenta cakes and the very first bite as an OMG melt-in-your-mouth moment.  Not only were they cooked to near perfection, but the mushrooms and arugula were a perfect complement.  Other hits at the table got the smoked salmon benedict, deviled egg sandwich, and the corn beef hash.  You can't go wrong with anything you order!!  Just a great dining experience here, you don't want to miss out!
author: Kevin C.

description: A great spot for brunch. I ordered the polenta with truffled eggs and it was EGGScellent! The only negative I had was that I wanted to sit by a window and they put us near the kitchen and the restaurant wasn't full
author: Analeise T.

description: Came to Park Tavern tonight and as soon as we arrived we noticed they were packed but the host was so great he found us a table in a matter of minutes. Our waiter brought us menus and before you knew it we had food on our table. The manager Jason Mort came to greet us and sent us some of his favorites on the menu. The service was nothing shorter than perfection! All night at least 3 staff members were checking up on us. I gotta say the food so delicious and couldn't be more happier!!! I just want to thank Jason and his crew for really taking great care of us even though they were swamped! I would definitely return and encourage you guys to stop in for great food, drinks and excellent customer service! Thanks Jason~ the duke
author: Duke Of Frisco X.
