description: Food was really solid (not great). Service was really bad. Unfortunate bc it could have been a really good meal. The fried lemons were really good, same with octopus,
author: Lindsay B.

description: Totally love this place!!! Great atmosphere!!! Kid friendly!!! Awesome food!!!! Highly recommend the frittatas and the cast iron with farm eggs!!! Great pancakes as well, but remember to order bacon on the side!!! The bacon makes miracles with the pancakes!!!!
author: Yan C.

description:
I feel like this place deserves A+++++++ for the PT Fries.

I know this is sort of unfair. But OMG. I don't even like fries???

I came here with the bff and she was really enthusiastic about these fries, so I agreed. Frankly most fries are just ok to me. I think I like steak fries or that style ... but I would eat like maybe 2. I like fries that aren't fried to Kingdom come ... so I guess that limits me to a very few places that serve fries I like.

I love that these fries were very, very truffle-y. The sauce / dipping was fantastic even though I normally dislike aioli type sauces and the soft boiled egg was even better!

Did I mention there's caviar? 

Seriously, this place is awesome. They have happy hour during the weekend as well so cheap but quality drinks! Totally recommended for a quick stop or an actual meal.
author: Lorrie M.

description: Sat at the bar, the bartender tossed me a menu, and tossed me the check in the end, without saying thank you. She was rude and obviously not well trained. Probably won't go again
author: Roy O.

description:
Spacious dining area, with a very dapper hipster sophisticated manly feeling to it (edison light bulbs, crown modeling, vintage), if that makes any sense lol. 

Came here for a birthday dinner with about 15 people. Trying a sizable amount of the menu for that evening.

Of the appetizers the winners were:
Truffle (PT) fries
deviled eggs
brussel sprout chips

Of the main courses the winners were:
Poulet
Marlowe Burger

Losers were:
Red Snapper (main)
Braised pork cheeks (app.)

Overall, we enjoyed the space and food.
author: Julie B.

description: Went for brunch here on Saturday made reservations on open table. We ordered the huckleberry fritters, deviled eggs and split the Marlowe burger. Everything was delicious and generous portions. The cocktail list is great. I ordered the "what happened was," watermelon vodka drink and Irish breakfast (coffee) the bloody Mary's looked delicious. Jeff one of the bartenders makes the best drinks and knows what he's doing. I highly recommend coming here for a weekend brunch. Will definitely be coming back.
author: Mal L.

description: I loved it and I'm only 9. The cheese is Devine and my mom loves the chicken. My parents also loved the eggs and lemon chips.
author: Shawn G.

description:
Not sure why this place gets such rave reviews. Other than the beautiful ambiance and eclectic bar scene its not a place I'll be visiting again. My review is based on dinner only so maybe I need to go for brunch instead. I've been there for dinner twice now and both times have been disappointed. The food is average and the service is nothing to write home about. Took my best friend there for her birthday and after telling them 3 different times it was her birthday, they forgot to send out anything for her. How disappointing. Especially when you see cakes with candles coming out left and right. I spoke with the manager at the end if the night and after a fake "I'm sorry" he said "I wish there was something I could do but I just can't". Seriously? How about a free dessert? Or something? Fail. 

The food is average - I had the bar steak which was fatty and not seasoned. We also had the Brussels sprout chips as a courtesy for seating us 30 minutes late. Those were just ok. Saw someone ordering the whole game hen and that is a joke. So much food! The menu is all over the place and not one dish stood out to me as something delicious. 

Will definitely be visiting another spot for dinner next time. And maybe just stop by for a cocktail. 3 stars.
author: Stephanie B.

description: Love this place. Great vibe. Great ambience. It has kind of a New York feel to it - sophisticated but casual. Great menu. The burger is absolutely fantastic. The truffle fries and the crispy brussels sprouts are also highlights.
author: JT B.

description:
This review is a reminder to myself how much I liked this place. I've been here a couple times and every time was a success and loved the food. 

Great place to bring new friends and even a first date. Casual, but still classy and not stuffy at all. Open space and lots of lighting! 
The food, just look at the other people's reviews. ;)
author: Lorraine W.

description: I've been here a couple times now and love that they have both healthy and indulgent dishes to chose from! This time I had the avocado and melon salad and it was the perfect light and fresh brunch, though I am always tempted by their baked goods! I also had a mimosa (because brunch=booze) and like that they give you the option of either grapefruit or orange juice as a base. They also have valet parking, which trust me, you will need, as parking is almost impossible to come by!
author: Hayley H.

description: My friends took me out for an early birthday dinner and while the ambiance was amazing, I would never come back for the food. We started off by sharing the brussels sprouts chips, which were good, but not outstanding. For my entree I had the beef tartare and this was the nightmare. I thought that it tasted quite bland and left much to be desired. The worst part was that I was left with an extremely horrible bout of food poisoning the next day. Suffice to say, I will not be returning to this restaurant to eat. I will say that the slice of rainbow cake they gave me for my birthday was delicious as was the Mclaren cocktail.
author: Robin K.

description: This review is about brunch here. I think their deviled eggs are fairly decent, but the burger wasn't good at all. It's too plain and bland, and caramelized onion was too little. I don't understand the hype at all. Nopa has much better burgers based on my experience.
author: Yuhuan T.

description:
This will probably end up in the not recommended section because I can't actually comment on the food.  But I have a lot to say about the lack of service.   Seems you have to be young and fashionable to get served here.  I am neither, but have been eating solo since the 1970s, when traveling the South Island of New Zealand on my own.  Thanks to my parents, and etiquette class at Marymount Ecole on Fifth Avenue in NYC, I have no problem eating alone in the finest restaurants, Chez Panisse, for example, where the maitre d' gave me a tour of their impressively immaculate kitchen.  But restaurants are not always welcoming to solo diners and this is one of the worst.  

When I visit the city named after my fave saint, and now fave pope, I stay at the inn right next door to this joint.  Once I got in late and just wanted something to eat.  It was past their crush time.  I got seated, but never got a menu or even a greeting from a server.  I eventually left.  The second time I attempted to just have a drink at the bar.  The bartender passed me by many times until I finally left and found a corner liquor store.  I'm not about to wave down a server or bartender like in a Waffle House or something.  The service is probably more attentive there.  

Lastly, once while attempting to load my car with my bags, the restaurant's valet got all bent out of shape because I parked in front of the inn while the restaurant was was using street parking for its valet service.  Tough.  

BTW, I would like to try Mama's but the line is always sooooooooo long and, as a military veteran, I avoid waiting in line like the plague.  Other vets know of what I speak.
author: WonderWoman W.

description:
With tax a $22.00 Sonoma Pinot Noir 
Yes San Francisco 
But that's a ripoff
author: Curtis A.

description:
I made a reservation here on *someone's birthday, but then had a little too much fun that day and we ended up missing the reservation.  So I made another reservation for a Sunday evening to make up for my indiscretions (with an emphasis on the "s" at the end of indiscretions).  And so it goes.  

We arrived right on time for our reservation at 7:15 p.m. and were promptly seated.  My companion didn't like the table, however, and we were promptly re-seated with no questions asked.  In the interest of brevity, I will only note the highlights, as follows.  

We settled in and got down to business.  We started with two cocktails - the McLaren and the Aquatic Park.  We also ordered two appetizers: (1) the deviled eggs; and (2) the Demon on Horseback (shrimp).  Both were scrumptious, but boy, those deviled eggs were something to write home about -- do you hear me?  Those flavors were WORKING: Pickled jalapeno, bacon and chive?  YES, YES and YES.  

I also want to note right out of the gates that the bread and butter were yummy.  I love when all of the small details are attended to.  

For dinner, I ordered the Marlowe Burger, medium.  The burger was served with caramelized onion, cheddar, bacon and horseradish aioli (plus fries).  So, let's discuss the bacon. I don't care how trendy it is or is not, I frakking LOVE bacon.  But this bacon was pretty special because it was cooked so perfectly--crisp, but not crumbly.  When you took a bite of the sandwich, the bacon remained in tact on the rest of the sandwich, which I frequently find to be the hallmark of finely cooked fare (I am insane about this with onion rings as well - if I take a bite out of an onion ring and the onion comes out of the ring on that bite, it was not cooked properly, in my humble opinion).  

For dessert, we had a piece of "September's Birthday Cake," which is champagne chiffon cake, pears and mascarpone cheese.  Oh heavens, I could be very satisfied with a piece of that cake every evening. I didn't get any cake on my birthday - so I feel entitled to go back and have another piece. The whole reason for birthdays is cake, after all.  

Our server was lovely, attentive and pleasant. I think the evening was pretty successful overall.  Now, I'm going to need to come back to PT for brunch, obviously.  And I believe I'm owed a piece of cake.  Loved it.
author: Sunny S.

description:
SF is a city of brunch. Mama's is right nearby and you get to see the hype that envelops SF brunch. In come Park Tavern. Same people behind Cavalier and Marlowe (my favorites) ... and it shows. Again, brunch is ubiquitous in SF so I'm hard pressed to find a favorite amongst it all, but here's my story:

Mama's had nearly a two hour line. Unless I poop golden eggs after eating there I decide to bail and head over to Park Tavern. I get a table for two within five minutes. Finish my meal of a great mimosa and poached eggs (try anything on the menu, it all seems great, even the famed burger for brunch).

I'm very pleased and leave only to see the same people still waiting outside of Mama's and clearly starving, cold, and from out of town with another 15 minute wait. Is the choice hard? Not at all. Check it out here. Make a reservation, it's easy. Done.
author: Joseph L.

description:
I have had dinner here once and brunch twice. I have tried just about everything from the avocado toast to the burger and so far I have yet to be disappointed. The cocktails and desserts are equally as good. 

A couple things you need to know before you go. Parking is nearly impossible but they do have valet. I really recommend just paying the $12 and valeting your car instead of circling for an hour. You also really need a reservation or you will easily be waiting an hour for a table because this place does get packed.
author: Diane M.

description: Crowded Marina like bar with good food and drinks, for the going rate. I wouldn't go out of my way to go here, but it's fine.
author: Tasha D.

description:
Surprised this is not a michelin star restaurant. Fantastic service from start to finish. Attentive service with a lot of food and wine expertise. Service was attentive and prompt, I was sincerely impressed.

Started the evening with the chicory salad, it was well dressed, and the manchego and almonds were a perfect combination.

Brussel sprouts, not mind blowing but great. 

For my main I had the Crispy Panissa, yumm! The wild mushrooms were earthy and rich and the kabocha was devine. Nettles always amaze me, and my dinner guest could not believe that a veggie like patty was made with nettle!
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Absolutely loved Park Tavern.  The vibe is energetic and very unique with a mix of ages throughout the room.  Very cutting edge culinary creations but with tastes that everyone can enjoy.  

We had an amazing waiter that gave us some wonderful recommendations.  We told him we wanted a sampling of the best small plates/appetizers they serve and just said "yes" to whatever he suggested.  

Here is what we ended up getting:

*Smoked Deviled Eggs - best deviled egg I've tried, and I LOVE deviled eggs.  Comes with bacon and a pickled jalapeño slice on top.

*PT Fries covered in garlic and served with two dips - a soft cooked egg topped with caviar and truffle aioli - there also must be crack in this because I could not stop myself.  The flavors are so unique and I recommend dipping the fry in aioli, followed by the soft cooked egg before eating.  Warning - your breath will be offensive for a few days.

*Crispy Lemon Chips with burrata cheese - another unique taste that I could not get enough of.  The lemons are thinly sliced, dipped in rice flower and flash fried.  Then you have the soft and salty burrata cheese to spread on top.... oh my goodness.  Please order this.

*Demons on Horseback - prawns wrapped in lardo and covered with a creamy remoulade sauce.  Another OMG dish.

*Brussels Sprout Chips - these were OK but a little too oily. 

I highly, HIGHLY recommend this restaurant. Everything we tried was delicious and the entire experience was enjoyable.
author: Whit C.

description:
Great place & great service
Highly Reccommended 
My husband & I had a great anniversary celebration
author: Marina S.

description:
I'm already a fan of Marlowe and Stone's Throw, so wasn't too big of a surprise that Park Tavern was also a hit in my book. 

Went for brunch.  Had a grapefruit mimosa, which as advertised on yelp, was champagne with a splash of juice.  The perfect mix.  My friend had the gin and juice, and again, gin with just a splash of juice and it was yummy!  We ordered the french toast and the crispy polenta cakes.  Crispy polenta cakes were so delicious with the truffle and mushrooms.  French toast was nice, thick and fluffy.  

The decor is standard American (New) restaurant.  Trendy wallpaper, slight rustic chairs, subway tiles, and cool light fixtures.  Even though the restaurant was full, it's not nearly as noisy as Marlowe. 

Location is great, right next to Washington Square.  Plenty to walk around to for an after meal stroll.  Street parking wasn't too terrible to find.
author: Janel C.

description: This place caught my heart! Just very easy, friendly, and definitely delish! We wee fortunate to get a seat at the bar practically right away. The drinks were out momentarily, the food was out pretty fast.
author: Vasilisa K.

description: A great brunch option. Good food, pricey. Would recommend to sit outside and call for a reservation to ensure a seat. Fun for a after church type of meal. Pancakes are fantastic as well as the bloody Mary's.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Park Tavern is overhyped! Came here with my family who were visiting from out of town because of all of the great reviews we've heard about this place. The atmosphere was cool (with the exception of a couple on an awkward tinder date who were making out for 45 mins), but the food was pretty bad.
We ordered the deviled eggs ($3/egg), have made better tasting ones at home. The Brussels sprouts were soaked in vinegar and salt, and were pretty bad. 3 people ordered the bar steak and all of them were overcooked flavorless cuts of meat. All 3 people returned the steaks, as our waitress even acknowledged that they looked overlooked! We were not charged for the steaks, however they charged us each for our replacement dishes (the burger is actually pretty good, but the fries taste like they are from mcdonalds). I won't be back, and for the money we spent, we could have had a nice dinner at just about any other restaurant in SF.
author: Andy Y.

description:
Wow, I loved my meal at Park Tavern from the food, to the drinks, to the service. The atmosphere is trendy and spacious, perfect for a date or a small group. Must eats - deviled eggs, marlowe burger, short ribs. Must drink their cocktails, everything is amazing and reminds me of the mixology at Beretta or Locanda. 

* BREAD: Tasted like Acme - always a good thing :)

* DEVILED EGGS ($2 / half egg): Topped with a crispy, thin slice of bacon, and made with pickled jalapeno and chives. Wow, I did not know deviled eggs could be so delicious! 

* TRUFFLED FONDUE with torn bread ($14): This was an interesting dish, with a hint of truffle which you could smell more than taste. $14 for a small-ish bowl of cheese and a side of torn up bread seems steep.

* MARLOWE BURGER ($14): Wow, delicious and juicy I can see why people rave about it! It seems so simple - carmelized onion, cheddar and bacon, but it was so delicious. Comes with fries and horseradish sauce on the side.

* POULET NOIR ($28): This is a whole chicken, incredibly flavorful down to the core. I just wish it was a little more tender and that they used a bigger chicken. Still prefer Zuni, for overall flavor and juiciness, but this was really good.

* BRAISED BEEF SHORT RIBS ($24): Every component of this dish was so perfect, and tasted very soulful. I could eat this every day.

* SIDE BRUSSELS SPROUTS ($8): Too bitter on the inside, yet overcooked with too much butter. Pass.

* HARBISON CHEESE: Soft, white cows milk cheese. I never order the cheese course because it's too extravagant, but this was a winner and I'm glad I got it. The cheese was soft and paired perfectly with cab. Awesome cab.

* PANNA COTTA ($7): I'm picky with my panna cotta and like when it's uber thick and creamy. This was good, but more delicate like the type at Seven Hills, like it's made with more gelatin or low fat milk. Good but would not get again.

* APPLE CRANBERRY CRISP ($7): I was surprised by the large portion size, it was good and tasted exactly like I would have expected but don't plan to get it again.

* BLOOD AND SAND ($12): If you like scotch mixed with something sweet and tart, this is the perfect balance. 

* OLD CUBAN ($12): I preferred the old cuban because it was more refreshing and felt less potent than the blood and sand.

* LADERA ($18): Amaaazing cab, but ouch it was expensive.
author: Jess C.

description: This review is 4 stars for the Food. 3 stars for the service.  We came here for Mother's Day for Brunch with a large party of nine.  We ordered from a Prix Fixe menu which was a pretty good value - 1 appetizer, 1 entree, and 1 dessert for $50.  Kids ordered an entree for $15.    The food was well presented and tasty. The server mixed up 2 courses- probably due to the lousy acoustics of the restaurant.  This would be a good choice for smaller parties and special occasions.
author: John S.

description:
I just hated everything about this place!  We walked in and the rude hostess' first words were "you will need to order quickly, kitchen is closing in 30 minutes ". Why would she say that when we arrived at our reservation time?? Just a definite mood killer right off the bat.  The gentleman with the beard, although very nice, seated us at probably the worst table in the pretty much empty restaurant!(Soon to be closing time!) And by the way , where did you find those uncomfortable and cold metal chairs?!! Froze my bottom on those awful chairs!!  Don't get why every other table was set up with and without a table cloth.  Ours was without table cloth, for a $100 per person dinner?? Should have had table cloth like the tables next to us.  
The waitress was efficient and polite but got my drink wrong and I didn't say anything.  I asked for JWB with a lot of ice plus an extra cup of ice on the side(I just like lots of ice!), she brought me a shot of whiskey straight up, no ice, with a half full cup of ice on the side. My wife's wine glass had a foul odor and she had the swap it out with another 3 times till it got better! 
The food was mediocre at best.  The Halibut was way overcooked, no longer flaky or tender. The steak was a big mahhh.  
After having been to this location dozens of time when it was Moose's and having enjoyed memorable meals and evenings, we were very disappointed!  In a town with so many wonderful culinary choices, I don't see Park Tavern as a place I'll ever go back to.  



The food was just ok.
author: ray t.

description:
Cozy restaurant with great food. This place always seems crowded but you can always hang out by the bar first while you wait for your table. Tables are seated pretty closely together so noise level is pretty high. Booked a 9:45pm reservation and the restaurant was still pretty rowdy when we left after closing time. 

Plenty of options on the cocktail menu to go with your food! Steak tartare appetizer is amazing and served with tiny lettuce cups which was a first for me. Can't go wrong with a marlowe burger and extra side of roasted brussels sprouts either. Everything on the menu sounds delicious so you won't go wrong with whatever you end up picking :)
author: Maryann S.

description:
Leave no trace.

Ideally at this park: www.thebolditalic.com/articles/7137-dolores-park-is-becoming-a-landfill-for-the-privileged

Definitely at this Park: Melt in your mouth Brussels sprout chips, decadent lardo wrapped prawns, brilliant entire roasted chicken served vertical and excellent salt accented sweet corn.

Left just enough room for dessert: Oatmeal cookie and mocha ice cream sandwiches. Served two each which was perfect when you don't want to share such a delicious finale.

There wasn't a trace of anything on our plates by the end. Everything was exceptional. Confident flavors and flawless execution throughout

Staff was just as good, with an impressive eye for the details such as not asking about a dish until a bite was taken. Not a cheap meal but impeccable food and service never is.

Modern and thoughtfully designed space buzzed with energy. Got lucky with a table right next to a support column and it was perfect for our always engaging conversation.

This was the birthday tradition after all: www.yelp.com/list/birthday-tradition-san-francisco

Long may it continue. Park Tavern too.

----------

37th: Park Tavern
36th: Benu | Coi
35th: Bix | Oliveto
34th: Sons & Daughters | Chez Panisse
33rd: Commonwealth | Prospect
32nd: Kappa | La Mar
31st: Chez Spencer | Boulevard
30th: Quince | Gary Danko
29th: Bobo's
author: Jason B.

description:
Park Tavern is what I would call Gastro-Pub chic. The menu boats delectable eats that are equal parts comforting and gourmet. To me the perfect menu can balance a wide array of pallets while still maintaining a universal theme; Park Tavern's menu has mastered this trait. 

On a warm Saturday evening I ventured into Park Tavern with a group of five. Stupidly, I neglected to make a reservation but the host mentioned the bar was open seating. My family and I snagged five seats at the communal bar table and were greeted by a friendly waitress. We started, of course, with the brussels sprout chips (forget what you've heard about brussels sprouts, these are not your momma's brussels sprouts!). They are ever so slightly greasy with a bite of lemon. The taste is salty and citrusy and the perfect start to your meal. 

While the Marlowe burger is incredible and their fries are definitely something to write home about, I believe their true stand out dish is the  poulet noir. The dish is served in an iron skillet with the truffle butter and the fat from the cornish game hen lending a rich melt in your mouth flavor to the swiss chard. It's rare I dream of a vegetable, and maybe it's because it's covered in truffle butter but, the swiss chard in the base of the skillet is heavenly. Truly, this dish is a foodie's dream. Savory and rich without being overwhelmingly heavy and not to mention a beautiful presentation. 

The remodeled and revamped moose's is refined comfort and it's all the better for it. I recommend this restaurant to all out of town guests or anyone I want to impress. Directly across from Washington Square Park, Park Tavern is the perfect place for elevated comfort food and a delicious cocktail.
author: Sarah M.

description:
Had dinner here with work associates after a long day. They had a wait, but easily accomdated us outside. Thanks to stellar California weather, it was perfectly comfortable easting on their patio at 8 pm. The food was exceptional, and I found myself wishing I wasn't watching calories. We shared a variety of appetizers, and I could have eaten an entire plate of any of them.
I had a pork chop, which was enormous, cooked perfectly, and was really tasty. Might be the best pork chop of the year.
I've walked past this place several times over the years, and always wondered what it was like. Now that I know..I'll not walk past it again.
author: Lou P.

description:
Our last stop of bar hopping with appetizers.
This place is very upscale and what you would expect in the city. Fanciness.

The drink menu was interesting in a good way. Not your typical selection of drinks. I ended up with the Mcleran? Gin, cucumer, ginger, mint and soda. This seems to be the popular drink these days. The BF got a bourbon based drink which he enjoyed.

We also go the lardo-wrapped smoked prawns - holy moly those were so tasty! Wow, lots of flavor.

It would be interesting to come here with a small group of friends.
A bit on the pricey side.
I would recommend this place.
author: Sandra R.

description:
Great place. Make a reservation on the weekend. The only complaint I heard was that it took a long time to get seated.

Great food great service and cool light music in the back ground.

Deviled egg, grapefruit, cornbeef and polenta were all home runs
author: John U.

description:
I highly recommend you start with the Demons on Horseback, which are lardo wrapped prawns. Come on, how can you pass up anything with lardo?  Just try it.  It's amazing.  And the remoulade is deliciously creamy.

Mussels were also very good.  Loved the broth!  Soaked up every last drop with bread.  High quality, flavorful, fresh...Superb.

Finally, I'm pretty picky about my cocktails, but this place definitely exceeded my expectations.  Lotta's Fountain was boozy, refreshing, and the right amount of sweet.  My husband, who likes very spirit forward drinks, enjoyed the Country Lawyer.  We both walked away happy!
author: Riz W.

description:
I have passed this restaurant a number of times. And this place seems always packed.  So I decided to give it a try with my friend and husband.   

Great brunch place! We ordered fresh shrimp tapas, smoked salmon, hash beef and other items(don't remember the names, plz see pics).   The quality/ taste is actually not bad, but the portion is like Asian-style(very tiny).  If you are here starving, you prob are gonna order a lot lol Services are good, very professional (given that we made a number of request to alter drinks on the menu). Anyway, a good experience.
author: Alanda B.

description:
I came here for brunch on a Sunday and not only did it take approximately an hour and a half to get our food after being seated (we were a group of 7), but we hardly saw our server throughout the process (for water refills, checking in, etc), and when my food arrived it was cold and not very good, to be completely honest.

I had the fried duck egg sandwich. It didn't have much flavor, and since it was served room temperature, the super runny yolk was all cold and it kind of grossed me out.

I will say that the hostesses were very helpful and friendly, and the manager was attentive and apologetic at the end and tried to fix the situation by offering to take the drinks off of our tab, but they weren't actually taken off by the server when the check came. I'll also note that the cocktails and champagne are really really good (two stars for cocktails and hostesses/manager).

The girls I was with said they had always had good service here, so it might have just been a really off day, but from the bar service when we were waiting for our table to the actual table service, it was almost comically bad.
author: Jessica G.

description:
soo yummm! was just here for brunch at the bar - it was so packed and we didnt have a reservation. the list of brunch cocktails is quite impressive, which makes it hard to decide what i wanted.  we finally ordered - boozy smoothie (espresso, banana, and foamy) and my gf got the bloody mary. both were amazingggg - i ended up getting a second smoothie.  

to eat - we got the chicken sandwich, and the cast iron farm eggs (with spinach and guyere) - delicious! and so filling! hahaha we couldnt finish, and we normally finish everythinggg! will definitely come back to try dinner or something - yums!
author: Christina L.

description: I can always count on Park Tavern to throw down the most amazing, original salad with whatever is in season. This time, my taste buds threw a party when I had the fried squash blossom salad. My husband loves their burger, same burger he always orders at Marlowe, their sister restaurant. Their fries are solid, and the wine selection is pretty sweet. The waitstaff always offers great wine pairing suggestions. The ambiance is on point, classy without being snobby. Valet parking makes for a relaxed arrival/departure.
author: Gabriela W.

description:
We had avocado toast and deviled eggs to start. Both were great.

I had the baked eggs for lunch and my boyfriend had the burger. I thought mine was great but my boyfriend the burger snob said his was "alright" (which is as good as I've ever heard from him so...)
author: Sarah F.

description:
Went here with a large group and rented out the 2nd floor. The meal was served "Family Style" which I thought might be awkward, but it was really fun. 

We started with the Wagyu Beef Jerky - I love Jerky - but this was the I have EVER HAD! And then we had the AMAZING Deviled Eggs - OMG! 

The fried brussels sprouts, the burrata and lemon chips, pea puree crostini. Okay, now we're nearly full - and they bring more. The PT Fries... I believe I saw two people empty the containers into their purses. WOW.. they are GREAT! 

The baby lettuce salad was wonderful. So many fun things added to it, grapes, fennel, radish, avocado and the dressing had just the right touch of tarragon. 

The main dishes were the cod, chicken and ribeye. All were wonderful - but the twice baked potatoes.. creamy, cheesy, comfort in a bowl. 

The service is warm and professional - from the hostess to the bartenders to the wait staff - all at the top of their game. 

Circle this place on the map; bookmark it right now;  come here, eat, drink, enjoy!
author: Marilyn D.

description: Amazing! Honestly, order anything and it'll be great. Even talked to the chef about how he did his eggs and chorizo (ask for cheese on it and you won't regret it). Got the french toast as well and was great to pair with something salty. Pricey, but worth it.
author: Ghena J.

description: Loved the lighting and atmosphere in here.  Food ain't bad either...party of 3 on a weeknight.  We ordered a couple burgers and the cod along with the Brussels sprout chips.  All excellent!  I heard the bar here is a hot spot on a friday night.  American style cuisine that is better than average.  Service was okay...nothing thrilling.  Brussels sprout chips were like air, really good.  When is doubt go for the burger here...it came w aioli and bacon on it....i loved every bite.
author: Keri K.

description:
We walked in and was happily welcomed by the host. Park Tavern has a great ambiance, and what seemed to be a lively bar scene.

The service was a little off. Our waiter acted like he wanted to be anywhere but work. I get it, its work, but is it too hard to do your job with a smile? It took an unreasonable amount of time for him to take our order. And I have to add he spilt (red) wine on my shoulder. As I looked up at him with the reaction of "ohhhhhhhhhhh" he ignored me and walked away from the table. Zero acknowledgement whatsoever. 

The deviled eggs were tasty. The Duck Terrine with foie gras was 90% duck with a very small amount of foie.  We ordered 2 Marlow burgers which were inconsistent. One burger had 2 huge pieces of bacon, the other had one slice that was torn in half. Two of us also ordered the sole. The fish was very bland. Zero hints of garlic, salt or pepper. It was if they relied solely on the sunchoke puree to handle the small punch of flavor. 

We also ordered the birthday cake and milk chocolate cheesecake. The cake was delicious, probably the best thing we had the entire night. Milk chocolate cheesecake was good, but nothing spectacular. 

At the end of the day, this place is not worth the $400.00 plus dollars we spent.  I have been wanting to dine at this establishment for about a year now. PT is "fit for foodies", but there are a dozen plus other restaurants I would rather visit as well as recommend to others.
author: Denniz S.

description:
Obsessed.  This is one of my go to spots in the NB area.  I'm #blessed, because I live approximately 2.5 blocks from this gem of an establishment.

This is a great place for a celebratory dinner, drinks on a date, or any occasion you want to feel like a real adult.

They have quite a few wonderful dishes here, but 4/5 times I'm getting the hamburger.  Washed down with Mamma Etta's bubbles.  

Also, 5 stars for service, with a particular shout out to the sweet waitress from my last dinner there who played along with my dad comically hitting on her throughout the whole meal (harmless-ly, since he was with his 3 daughters).  

One additional note, I've never brought my dog here before, but I can confirm that per their hostess, they do allow dogs on the patio.
author: Lana O.

description:
Wow... (slowly nodding my head sideways).
Expectations can be high after reading the numerous reviews about this rejuvenated North Beach hot spot; especially, when hearing that I no longer needed to trek to Marlowe to try their famed burger or deviled eggs.  I called the restaurant about ten days earlier and scored a 5:30 pm reservation for a Friday night.  The dining room was barely half full, but the bar was already hopping.  We were seated at a window table, which probably sheltered us some from the noise level that progressively rose as diners arrived.  The menu offered a large selection of choices, but I already had some idea of what to order.  Our waiter was helpful in recommending the third appetizer and fulfilling my fruity nonalcoholic drink request.  Here's what we ate:

Appetizers (all shared)
1) Deviled Eggs (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4-pWX0F9mi_VlN1IAxweSQ?select=-BpBA2ePshJbkHA8yrBrVA) - This signature dish lived up to the hype.

2) Lemon Chips (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4-pWX0F9mi_VlN1IAxweSQ?select=UmGs6fQjtjfTFqGloNYFWA) - Paper thin slices with pleasant zest, but, given the price, something we'd probably pass on next time.

3) Demons on  horseback (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4-pWX0F9mi_VlN1IAxweSQ?select=n8iM1d4gf7oEroTz5d6qJg) - Recommended by our waiter, the large spot prawns were clean flavored and the bacon gave a nice fatty, savory contrast.

4) Marlowe Burger (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4-pWX0F9mi_VlN1IAxweSQ?select=nmnx1kjjyvKuIcR_KkRzeQ) - Cut in quarters for sharing, the burger was good, but not quite to die for.

Entree
5) Grilled Pork Chop (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4-pWX0F9mi_VlN1IAxweSQ?select=J30m39thFwXVEfvGh8xrzQ) - Cooked to a perfect medium temperature, the pork had a pleasant combination of tenderness from the center meat and firm bounce from the grilled outer areas.

Dessert (shared) -
6) Creamsicle (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4-pWX0F9mi_VlN1IAxweSQ?select=R-7hWbO79JG8zpexmw5l3w) - Topped with a candle for the birthday guest, the visual surprisingly lived up to the namesake's flavors.  Hope this is on the menu next trip.

As we relaxed while waiting for our food, we couldn't help but notice the variety of vehicles that pulled up to the valet stand; one could liken it to an auto show, testament to their customers' demographics.  Service was efficient and water/drink glasses were filled; empty plates were quickly cleared.  
Overall, this was one of the finer meals I've experienced recently in the City.  Plus it left me wanting to return for MORE!
author: Mike C.

description: This place is pretty awesome. Love the decor. Its clean, modern and open. Jennifer was a stand out server. Loved the michelada & avocado toast!
author: Chammy C.

description:
*****3.5*****

Had a reservation for Sunday lunch, and upon arrival, discovered we would be ordering off the brunch menu.  I was looking forward to trying some of their most talked about dishes on their regular menu, so a bit of a let-down.  Valet parking saved us from a potential parking nightmare.  

Classy atmosphere and ambiance inside.  Got a table by the window.

John Daly cocktail was tasty, but very weak.  Didn't taste like a cocktail!

Here's what we ordered:

DEVILED EGGS - Tasty little appetizers.  You see them on every table. Not off the chart, but good!

AVOCADO TOAST - I make this at home.  Love me some simple, avocado toast, where the avocado is the star.  I would order this again.  So simple and good.

MARLOW BURGER - Overcooked, but a decent burger.  Won't be writing home about it though.  2 others at our table got the burger and liked it, but didn't *love* it.

POLENTA - My wife's order.  She liked it and said she would order again.  Another at our table tasted it and said they regretted ordering the burger and wished they would have ordered the Polenta.

FRENCH FRIES - Read about the TRUFFLE fries in a lot of the Yelp reviews, but when I asked if the fries were Truffle Fries, she said they were just plain. I asked if they could make them "truffled" and she said she could for an extra $5.00.  So I got them, but it wasn't much different from the regular fries that were sitting on our table.  Couldn't really taste or see a difference in the fries except for an ever so slight dust of parmesan cheese.

Had plans for dessert elsewhere, so we skipped dessert, but the fritters looked good.

I would like to come back and try the food off their regular dinner menu. The brunch menu food was definitely a three star experience, but I think the atmosphere and service is a four.
author: Darien R.

description: We came here last year and we loved the peaches glazed French toast and the farm eggs. We are actually on our way right now to get some. Hope the second experience is as good as the last. It is pretty difficult to get a table here but I feel it's worth the wait. There is a place across the street called MAMA's and it took us an 1 1/2 to get in. The food was good but basic, you could have gotten the same thing at IHOP but Park Tavern is definitely a twist on many comfort foods :)
author: Adriana P.

description:
Had a great meal there last night. First, I personally like that they have all these corner tables for 2 people.  I find at many restaurants they line up tables really close to each other where you are sitting across from your dining companion and it's impossible to hear them or ignore the conversation going on next to you.  So all of these nicely arranged corner tables are great since you can have a nice private conversation very easily, even when the restaurant is crowded. 

We had a wonderful server, Larry, who gave us great recommendations, came around the perfect number of times, and was very friendly and good spirited the entire evening. Major plus is that he asked if it was a special occasion, and when I said it was my husband's birthday, he brought out a piece of cake with a candle at the end of our meal to the surprise of both of us! 

We ordered the lemon crips with burrata cheese (on Larry's recommendation) which was excellent.  It was a unique dish and flavors came together really nicely.  We also ordered the harvest salad, which was really underwhelming - just a handful of baby lettuces with some radish and maybe a tiny bit of carrot? The description said market vegetables and the salad was $14 so was just expecting something more. There was 1/4 of a green bean on there so maybe something was left off? The salad was dressed very nicely. 

We got the Poulet Noir which was fantastic. Beautifully cooked chicken and delicious bread stuffing. I would hands down come back here just for this dish. It was very enjoyable and plenty of food for us both to share.  

We also got the brown buttered brussels sprouts which I didn't enjoy as they were too lemony. Maybe we just got a bad batch. Next time, and there will be one to revisit the Poulet Noir, we'll try the brussels sprout chips!
author: Sarah G.

description:
Deviled eggs- Hell yeah!

Brussels sprout chips- YES! YES! YES!

Truffle fries with soft boiled egg and caviar - Omg, yes.

A chicken (an entire chicken) on a plate with chard - How the hell am I supposed to eat a whole chicken?! It was good but maybe I should have read the menu more clearly to see that I was ordering an entire chicken for myself. I didn't eat it all, of course, because I had to leave room for....

Dessert! - Something with strawberry. All I remember was that it was seriously good. But I think by that point I either passed out or gave up due to the straining against my Spanx.

Nice food, nice evening, not enough room in my Spanx.

Don't be like me. Leave the Spanx at home.
author: Loli L.

description:
Probably my favorite brunch place in SF, and it's right across from Washington Square Park so you can lie in the grass and food coma afterwards. Or go to one of the many coffee shops and stores nearby! 

Grapefruit Brûlée ($7): totally unexpected! I thought it would be grapefruit creme brûlée, but they were 4 slices of warm grapefruit with a crispy caramel glaze. Yummy! https://instagram.com/p/00lKLazZqF/

Banana Coconut Fritters ($9): these were good, but really heavy and there were a lot. If you plan on getting a big entree, make sure you have more than just 1 person to share these with!

Oatmeal Walnut Raisin Pancakes ($12): these usually come in a set of 3, but we only wanted one pancake and they let us! Unfortunately we couldn't just order one French toast. This pancake was super soft, moist, and delicious. 

Three Nut Butters ($9): this appetizer is also heavy. It comes with 4 big pieces of thick bread and pecan, walnut, almond butter, and honey. So yeah you can probably imagine how heavy that is. But all the butters were really good!

Crispy Polenta Cakes ($17): these weren't as good as I thought they would be. I am a huge polenta fan and this came with a lot of things I like - poached eggs, arugula, and mushrooms. It was a very light, clean dish, but just not as flavorful as I'd hoped and I was just expecting the savory creaminess of liquid polenta.

Smoked Salmon Benedict ($17): this is my favorite item so far! I am also on this crazy sushi craze phase, but the salmon is really great and the poached eggs, capers, horseradish sauce, etc make it taste fantastic. It's a light dish, and I hate wasabi but I don't taste the horseradish at all. 

Warm Open-Faced Deviled Egg Sandwich ($14): this one is pretty heavy. The portions are big and has bacon, a chicken breast, eggs, cheese melted on top, and fries on the side. A bit much for me for brunch, but it's great if you're starving or are skipping appetizers! The fries are fantastic.

PT Bloody Mary ($11): I am a huge Bloody Mary fan and this one is fantastic! Great peppery kick (I love black pepper), topped with some beef jerky and some other pickled veggie I don't remember.
author: Cynthia W.

description:
Wife and I visited this place instead of Mama's. We were quite happy. The food is super fresh, brought out promptly and absolutely delish. 

We shared deviled eggs. Wife had the smoked salmon Benedict and I had the in house chorizo W eggs. Each of us had a hand crafted beverage recommended by the bartender and neither disappointed. 

Bill ended up being around $70 w 20% tip.
author: Matthew C.

description:
Really great space just off of Washington Square Park. The room has a friendly, no frills appearance and you are hit with the aroma of amazing food from the moment you enter. Service was great and attentive even on a busy weekend night.

Don't miss:
Burrata / lemon chips appetizer
Cocktail menu
author: Tom B.

description: Good food and our waiter was really nice. However the hostess was very unfriendly and there was no changing table in the women's restroom, even though there was plenty of room to hang one. We get it, you want to be a bougee restaurant and not a family joint. But sometimes people with babies are invited to important brunches with their friends that they can't miss. And hipster restaurants like this could be a little more accommodating on the rare occasion that a baby enters through its trendy doors.
author: Michelle S.

description: Best deviled eggs in the city. They have an amazing brunch as well. Dinner consistently good. We prefer to sit in the bar vs the dining room these days. Favorites include- lemon chips, Marley burger, and chicken. At brunch get fritters, polenta cakes, avocado toast. Their avocado toast is the best in the city as well!
author: Taylor P.

description:
Fabulous Sunday brunch! The service was great and the food was delicious! Following the advice of our server and the many positive yelp reviews, we started with the deviled eggs and avocado toast. Both were exceptional
The Marlowe burger and salmon Benedict did not disappoint either. Will definitely return to try some of the other dishes.
author: Phyllis S.

description:
The service here is really considerate. They turned on the heater and brought us thick lap blankets when we wanted to sit outside since it was slightly chilly. What sweethearts :)

For an appetizer I got the venison carpaccio, which I highly recommend. It was zesty, bold, and not gamey at all. Bone marrow is incorporated into the dish as crispy little nuggets, which I think is more approachable to the average diner than its usual presentation. 

As entrees, my friend ordered the duck egg sandwich and I got the fried chicken one. Both were good and I usually don't eat sandwiches since I have a slight aversion to eating bread. I will definitely be back to try their brunch, which has been listed as one of the best the city has to offer. 

Outdoor seating was nice, but the inside is exceptionally beautiful - rustic with a modern twist. The lighting is dimly romantic and the place is classy, but extremely welcoming and comfortable as well.
author: Charlotte Z.

description: Hands down the best meal I had on my whole trip around the states! You have to get the hen!!! Would eat here every night if I could afford to. The squash was to die for. Don't miss this little gem. My friend had the lamb and was as equally impressed.
author: Lucy H.

description: On the corner of Washington park in North Beach, Park Tavern is great for brunch. Please do yourself a favor and get the challah toast and the avocado toast! My wife doesn't really care for bloody Mary's, but after trying mine she had to order her own!
author: Thomas R.

description: Park Tavern now has a policy that they will call to confirm the day of your reservation. In my case they called 2.5 hours before I was to arrive.  If you do not pick up the phone or call back in 20 minutes - they cancel your reservation!  Total amateur hour and a fine way to lose a long standing customer who used to go there once a month.
author: Tom A.

description:
Review for DINNER:

I'm actually glad that the serving sizes here aren't huge (as compared to the price) because everything is so rich and indulgent! The menu here is packed with traditional American dishes, but not your boring mac 'n cheese and marsala chicken dishes. Oh no, get ready for an entire chicken on your table or chunks of bacon and creamy gouda in your pasta dishes. 

I came here for my birthday around 8 PM, and I loved the fun combination of how intimate and lively this place was! It made for the perfect close-friend dinner ambiance. I highly recommend their margaritas, while the champagnes are good but nothing out of the ordinary. Park Tavern's menu #wins in terms of their appetizers and small plates! I had some of the most unique vegetable chips (brussel sprouts and lemon chips). So I've had and loved fried brussel sprouts in the past, but have never had lemon chips before. For a girl who shamelessly eats lemon skin (sorry dentist!), I HAD to try this and was very happy with my selection! These chips have just the perfect amount of flavor and the seasoning gave a great kick to the citrusy taste. We also got a whole hen, which was definitely delicious and well made but became a little too much salty meat after the first few bites. Finally, we finished this meal with oatmeal cookie ice cream sandwiches. I'm not one of those weird people that opt for oatmeal cookies over chocolate chip, but the graininess of the oatmeal perfectly complemented the sweet ice cream. yummm, happy birthday to me :) 

Definitely will be coming back for brunch!
author: Aradhana V.

description:
Review for brunch...

Solid food.  Get the avocado toast.  and the boozy smoothie is amazing.  The polenta and poached egg dish is also very good.  Pretty big portions.  Great service.  I love the communal table.
author: Valentina X.

description:
Pretty decent brunch - but there was a couple of breakdowns in communication with our server. We ordered two types of toasts and only got the avocado toast. 

My friends all ordered the Marlowe burger which was solid. I ordered the cod cake which was okay. I requested a fried egg on top and ended up getting an overdone poached egg. I requested again to have a fried egg and it finally came towards the end of the meal.

Overall the food was good and service friendly. I'd love to come by and try the dinner menu.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Park Tavern has been my favorite SF restaurant since it opened a couple years back.  The food has been consistently good, and of the best quality.

For starters, you have to get the deviled eggs (so good) and the Demons on Horseback.  Not being a big fan of brussels sprouts, but they prepare them in a brown butter and are surprisingly tasty (share with your table).

For entrees, we had the halibut which was served atop a delicious risotto-type dish.  New on the menu are the braised short ribs, which were cooked to perfection.  I'd recommend either entrée.

The bartenders are always fun, warm and accommodating, and we regularly stop by ahead of our dinner reservation - you should too.

Friday & Saturday night reservations book out about three weeks, so plan ahead - and a reservation is mandatory whenever you can get one.  Valet parking is available for $12.  Save yourself some time and grief, and just pull up and let them park for you; it's well worth it.

Enjoy!
author: Ron F.

description:
Can't say I have a full review here yet as I was upstairs at a private event. What I can say is the food was very good. I'm sure they're the same dishes you can order off of the menu. The burger was exceptional.

It does have a nice "tavern" feel to it - the people I encountered were very warm and friendly - something that's got to be tough in a semi-tourist place (with all of the people coming and going). The location is nice and the SF weather in this part of the city is better than most other neighborhoods if you're going to take advantage of sitting out front on the patio. I'll return.
author: Matt T.

description:
upscale tavern with excellent mixed drinks and a solid traditional American dining menu. 

fried brussel sprout chips are an excellent starter. paper-thin, light and airy, but packed with flavor.

they're supposedly well-known for their pork chop, which I tried to finish but just couldn't. it was perfectly tender and massive, and the sides (lentils, carrot puree, and pickled onions) were fresh and tasty.

service was great, and the cardamom ice cream was off the hook.
author: Mike B.

description:
North Beach has plenty of great restaurants, bars and nightlife, but what I like about Park Tavern is that it feels like it is a little separated from all the craziness of the crowds in that area yet still close enough. Now granted, this may have been just the time we were there, so take that into consideration. I'm sure it gets plenty busy BC the smells wafting out of the kitchen were amazing. We already ate just came for a night cap before bed but none the less still and I still had a peak at the menu. The PT fries were calling to me so that will have to be saved for next time. 

I think PT has a comfortable some what old timey feel. It's semi casual to the point where I thought, I'm glad I'm wearing a dress, though I'm sure you would be ok in jeans.  The staff were in more formal serving attire than your average dive bar and the atmosphere has a more upscale feel. 

This is on my list to come back and try again!
author: Audrey L.

description:
I tried the polenta benedict with mushrooms and truffle sauce, the caramelized grapefruit and one deviled egg. I thought that each of these items left something to be desired. The polenta benedict was pretty plain as were the famed deviled eggs. 

I might have been appeased if the service was better. Our waitress couldn't be bothered to give us utensils once our food came out and the customers sitting next to us felt so badly that they gave us their own unused utensils. Also, when my friend asked to substitute cheese for more spinach for her plate, the waitress responded with "I don't think that would taste good". How about letting the customer decide that. Come on now.

I really just don't think this spot is worth the forty five minute wait or the price tag. There's also definitely a "scene" here. Filled with 30-something professionals and the occasional family.
author: Raha G.

description:
I came here quite some time ago with a large dinner party to celebrate a birthday. I had some high hopes because it became apparent that this restaurant was in some way connected to Marlowe - same font usage, they listed a "Marlowe" burger on the menu, etc. The overall decor and ambiance of the restaurant is slightly confusing. There are some random "small piece" decor items along the wall and spread out throughout which I couldn't help but notice the randomness of it all... Like I think I saw a small boat or sled and some miscellaneous vintage looking pots, vases, etc. I understand the whole "park" theme but I found it to be a bit busy. I also thought the wallpaper near the entrance looked a little dated. The lighting, and the general wood/floor choices are lovely though. 

Our server was incredibly helpful and patient with us, considering we were a party of 15+. She made awesome recommendations for drinks and was constantly checking on us throughout the meal. Everything came out in a timely manner. 

My boyfriend and I excitedly decided to share the $40 rib eye steak and the arugula salad. The arugula salad was absolutely delightful. It was incredibly fresh and the pickled strawberries added just the right amount of sweetness and "summer" flavoring to the salad. Then came the rib eye steak... First of all, I've never thought of myself to really consider PLATING to be a major key factor for me. But, like I said this was a $40 steak, and it was Marlowe's affiliate so I didn't think that it would look any different from their plating techniques. The dishes came in a textured large grey speckled shallow bowl. Not only was the actual plating choice awkward for the size of the steak but the presentation of the food itself just seemed incredibly sloppy. It was dark, and we did split our portions so I slyly checked out everyone else's dishes (we ALL ordered the rib eye... 15 orders of ribeye -_-) and everyone's looked pretty much the same. A hunk of meat and a heap of mashed potatoes that were now mixed and muddled in with the veggies. It honestly looked like something that I made at home, and I don't mean that in a good way. It just looked bad! I'll try and find the photo and upload it to this review to try and press my point but anyway.. let's get to the taste of it. 

The taste of the rib eye was BLAND and it was even slightly tough .... the mashed potatoes were overly buttery and tasted like it literally came from the box. I couldn't even hide my emotions, I turned to my boyfriend and asked if he felt the same way and he nodded, wide-eyed and said how it was a disappointing main course. I was not impressed and really wished I would have just ordered the burger. 

Overall, I would not return. The service was great, the location is great, but the food is not anywhere close up to par with the actual Marlowe's. If you're shelling out that much money for dinner you shouldn't walk away feeling disappointed and like your food was just thrown together.
author: Mariko M.

description:
The Bloody Mary was okay (I miss the salt rims in the new drink out of mason jar trend) but the trout pate was quite nice. But bummed they didn't have the crispy polenta. But the salmon Benedict is really good! 

But the devilled egg was DIVINE ...
author: Prerona M.

description:
Pros:
Great food
Tasty cocktails 
Make reservations on Open Table


Cons: 
Slow service 
They don't serve mimosas by the pitcher 
We put in a reservation online and told them it was our friends bday-- nothing :(

Overall, great restaurant and great food... But service can be a little lacking.
author: Alli J.

description:
Wow.

What a surprise this was!  I came here not knowing what to expect - I had never even heard of it.  I reviewed the menu online and thought that it was going to be another typical, boring dinner. I was totally blown away by dishes I had - every single one of them.

I started off with appetizers: (1) soft shell crab with kimchee, (2) melon salad with olives (I know it doesn't sound good, but trust me, it totally works), (3) deviled eggs (I know - why would I try this? But it was the best I ever had...smoky and slightly sweet with a spicy pickled jalapeno.  It was delicious). and (4) another order of the soft shell crab with kimchee (yes it was that good that I ordered another one).

Main course: halibut and salmon.  I'm not even going to describe the dishes.  There's nothing to be said but....these were one of the best fish dishes I've had.  It was the creative way in which the sauces, purees, veggies, and the fish all were layered perfectly in the most creative way.  The depth flavor was amazing - you could taste each layer of the dish and the fish was cooked perfectly.

I was so full that I was hurting, but had to try the dessert and cappuccino. No disappointments here.  Had the rhubarb cherry crumble with pistachio ice cream.  I've never had rhubarb before but it works!

I am so coming back here for brunch and everything in between.

P.S. the service was great, too.
author: Caroline K.

description:
The ambiance and the surrounding area around park tavern is worth going for (washington park). I prefer going there for brunch dinner was very small portions and not enough food. I tried the deviled eggs and the poulet vert. The poulet vert takes a while to come out but it was amazing. 

Parking is impossible to find you have to uber/lyt/taxi to the place. North beach in general is very hard to find parking. Make sure you have reservations before you arrive especially if it's on a friday or saturday or you will be waiting for hours at end.
author: Kunal T.

description: The pork was tender and delicious, and the drinks were delicious. With a romantic and low-key atmosphere, it's a great place to go on a date. The only downside was how expensive it was- expect $60/person for an entree and 1 drink.
author: Leeyen R.

description: Was looking to have brunch across the street at Mama's on washington but the line was way too long. Decided to come to Park Tavern and there was no wait. I had the walnut raisin pancakes and my boyfriend had the regular pancakes. Both were very fluffy and delicious.
author: Christine T.

description:
A yummy brunch place that takes reservations! Hooray!

I've been here twice now (both times for their brunch) and I think this is a great place to grab brunch with a friend or a group of friends, since they take reservations. This place is a little bit nicer than the average brunch place. I think it's decorated in a really clean and cute style.

For brunch, Park Tavern serves an assortment of little bites (toast with various toppings, pastries, fruit, etc.) as well as larger entrees and cocktails. 

We had (see photos!):

POMELO & AVOCADO (8) - cottage cheese & cracked black pepper. This appetizer was very light, refreshing, and healthy. I thought it was a good start to our meal, but something I could definitely prepare at home.

PAN-FRIED CORNED BEEF HASH (16) - crispy potato, poached egg, arugula & red wine jus. This was super delicious. Last time, I had a chicken hash, but I thought the beef hash with the red wine jus made this dish taste even better! I loved how savory and flavorful the sauce was, and I liked the crispy texture of the potato and hash, along with the soft poached egg. It was a tad bit on the salty side, but I would most definitely order this again. Highly recommended!

WARM OPEN-FACED DEVILED EGG SANDWICH (14) - pickled jalapeño, chicken breast, bacon & provolone cheese (served with skinny fries). I wasn't the biggest fan of this dish. I thought it tasted more like a chicken sandwich and couldn't really detect the deviled egg component. The fries were really good though!And just a tip, we got some hot sauce on the side to add some bite. 

Next time, I really want to give their brioche french toast and crispy polenta cakes a try! :]
author: Eileen E.

description:
I strolled in on a Sunday at noon and was told the wait would be more than an hour, so make a reservation if you can! Happily, though, we were able to get a seat at the bar for brunch, and were served promptly. The bloody marys are generous on the vodka, and are spicy and delicious. The pancakes were piping hot and cooked perfectly. The salmon eggs benedict were exquisite. Everything was priced reasonably for the high quality. 

Definitely give Park Tavern a try! I'll be back for sure!
author: Heather S.

description:
A friend who lives in San Francisco planned brunch for us and we were so excited to check out Park Tavern because we had heard great things. Unfortunately, our experience was pretty horrible and I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone. Let's start with our server. He was fine...didn't crack a smile, rushed everyone along, got visibly annoyed when we had questions. I can deal with that. But when my friend, who cannot eat dairy (not by choice), asked what they could do for her, he was so rude about it. I understand that it's 12:15 on a Saturday and the kitchen is busy, but he basically told her she could get 2 poached eggs and charge her the same $17 as the fried polenta meal. When she asked if she could just get a couple eggs scrambled and maybe add some veggies to it, he shut her down without giving a reason and without trying to work with her to figure out what on the menu she could eat, or what they could do for her. As a server, I understand that modifications can sometimes be difficult, especially when pricing them and dealing with the kitchen being mad at you. BUT there is absolutely no reason a place like Park Tavern should not be able to accommodate her diet restrictions. Especially when she was willing to pay extra for it. She ended up getting avocado toast (for $10 for one piece of bread are you kidding me?!?!?!) and 2 eggs scrambled. So thank you sir for sucking it up and being a decent human. 

We were all enjoying our bloodies and each other's company, but the next time I looked at my phone, it was 1:00. Our food took 45-50 minutes to come out. Other tables in his section got their food before us, and we had a chorizo and eggs come out straight up cold. We sent it back and it came back 2 minutes later hot. Did you put it in the microwave and is that why it came back so quickly? It can't heat up in the salamander that quickly...maybe on the flat top. Either way, the food was fine. I got the 2 eggs served on a mixture of Gruyere cheese and spinach mixed with the egg whites. It was decent but for however much money I paid, I expected a lot more in terms of size and quality. Oh well.

Another horrible part about this place was the bathroom. The entire floor was soaking wet, and one toilet was clogged. Get your shit together, Park Tavern. You try to pretend you are a classy high end place, but everything about your staff and bathroom say otherwise. One positive is they kept my water full the whole meal. And I'm a huge fan of open kitchens in restaurants. So I guess that was cool too.
author: Elana M.

description: Absolutely terrible experience.  Went for brunch and was told a half hour wait, 1.5 hours later we sat ourselves at the bar despite tables being obviously open. When finally sat down we were then told the brunch menu ended 5 minutes ago and weren't willing to make exceptions. Spoke with the manager who offered to cover drinks and the very very limited afternoon menu, however had absolutely no service despite the place clearing out. Overall a terrible experience and doubt I'll be returning. Worst part is when nearly done our drink and apps the hostess came over and said our table was ready...meanwhile nearly the entire restaurant was cleared and every table reset. It was embarrassing and insulting.
author: David B.

description:
The Host team was super well dressed. The flower arrangements are fresh and crisp. I ate 13 deviled eggs.  

I'll be back!
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Solid and substantial brunch.  Wouldn't mind returning, but wouldn't be top of my list.

We ordered the avocado toast (more flavorful than you'd expect), marlowe burger, smoked salmon benedict, and deviled eggs open sandwich.  We finished everything (though partially out of hunger?) and thought they were delicious.  Best brunch #EVER? no. but great option in a great neighborhood without lines.
author: Alice Z.

description:
I want to like you more than I do so more visits are in order for your good food, mediocre service and beautiful people watching. 

Fried Sunchokes $9
Venison Carpaccio, fantastic at $15
The Braised Lamb Tongue with cracked egg was good at $14 and surprised my friends with it's delicate taste. Great to try new things.
$9 Brussels Sprout Chips have serious potential but WAY too salty. I'll make these at home and experiment. 
My biggest disappointment, or more pet peeve was the Smoked Deviled Egg for $2 each. What you get is 1/2 an egg for for the price. Good but not after learning the verbiage double charges me. Bummer dude.
The Scallops @ $29 melted in my mouth and were cooked perfectly. Loved the pea tendrils. Great flavor pairing.

Our server was good spirited but busy. At times he popped off without letting us finish our sentence. The food did come out quickly and as ordered but something rubbed me wrong. In the end, I will be back but I'm not rushing to make my OpenTable just yet.
author: Mark F.

description:
Food is amazing and incredible! Avocado and shrimp toast, the Marlowe burger and Fois Gras on toast (which is no longer in the menu ) and the pork belly cheeks are a must! The bartenders make stiff drinks as well. 

This place is pricey but you get what you pay for. In addition to the very good food, the ambiance makes this place a great setting for a date on a weekend at night or brunch!
author: Miguel Y.

description: We had reservations for three during Saturday morning brunch. We arrived 10 minutes early and were seated right away. Unfortunately we were then ignored for the next 30 minutes. No server came to introduce themselves, no one took our drink order. At this point we (more so our 2 year old) couldn't wait any longer. We got our stuff and left. Which is unfortunate because the food at the tables around us looked really good.
author: Haroon R.

description:
We came for brunch and shared the avocado toast, the bay shrimp toast, and the smoked salmon benedict. My favorites were the avocado and smoked salmon. The avocado toast was simple but super tasty (and definitely something I would like to try to recreate at home) and the smoked salmon had a good texture and smoky flavor. i would definitely recommend for brunch in the area, and outside weather-permitting. 

Service was really attentive. We had to move twice (once our mistake, second theirs), and they were so gracious and sent over the avocado toast on the house. It's the little things like that that make people want to return again and again.
author: Allison S.

description:
My friends and I came to Park Tavern to celebrate a couple of birthdays (and yes, one of them was mine).  We had a 5:30 pm reservation on a Saturday night and expected to walk into a half empty restaurant but the place was packed and bustling at that early hour.  I would describe this restaurant as a place that serves comfort food with great service in a brasserie setting.

Seated at a table along the wall, we had a great view of the restaurant, kitchen and bar area.  While waiting for the rest of the party to arrive, three of us started off with some of PT's house cocktails.  I tried the Washington Square and really enjoyed the various flavors of the drink - hints of bitterness with citrus and ginger.  One friend ordered the Country Lawyer and although that drink smells like it could put hair on ones chest, it was actually quite pleasant and went down rather smoothly.  No hairy chests to be found on all those that took a sip!

To whet our appetites we ordered the Demons on Horseback (shrimp wrapped in lardo), burrata with lemon and basil and the charcuterie platter.  Personally the housemade charcuterie platter was my favorite, as the salami and pate were delicious.  The shrimp was okay, but nothing special.  The burrata seemed to be a hit with one friend.  The fried lemon slices are really, really good and I would pop them like chips if I could.

For the entree I ordered the Poulet Rouge with spinach and peewee potatoes (they were really cute).  The chicken is roasted on a vertical rack, with the spinach and potatoes recipients of the juices that drip down from the chicken.  The dish is so simple, yet so good.  The chicken, aside from being a sight to behold, was moist and tender and full of flavor.  The meat was pretty much falling off the bone, and a knife isn't really needed.  Make sure you ask for extra bread to sop up all those chicken juices.

For dessert, we ordered the birthday cake (with two candles), Arnold Palmer boozy float, the cheese plate and the apple crisp.  They ended up delivering two very generous slices of birthday cake (chocolate with chocolate buttercream frosting), each with a candle (trick candles too!) and both were on the house!  That was so incredibly nice of them.  And who doesn't love a well made birthday cake (sorry, but supermarket cake frosting icks me out)!  The person that created the Arnold Palmer float is a genius.  There is no stopping after that first sip.  The apple crisp was good and full of the flavors of the fruit.  I'm not big on eating desserts but in this case that cake was so good I couldn't stop digging my fork into it.   I wish more places offered birthday cake for dessert.  Sometimes a simple dessert is the perfect ending to a meal of comfort food.

Our wait staff was on point and provided great service, answering all of our questions and making sure our needs were met.  Given how busy it was, we were really happy with the attention we received.  PT is a good place for dinner and/or drinks for large and small groups.   Would I come back?  Absolutely.  How does it compare to Marlowe?  PT is more like the big city cousin, a bit more formal than Marlowe, which is more laid back and casual.
author: Melissa L.

description: They don't have a dedicated gluten free menu nor do they indicate on their menu which dishes are gluten free but don't worry.  The staff are very knowledgeable about gluten and can quickly tell you what is safe to eat.  They are aware of cross contamination risks as well.  A manager once asked if I am a Celiac when I said I need to eat gluten free.  He said he always worries about cross contamination and went back to the kitchen to double check what I had was safe.  All of this and delicious food and great ambiance.  Don't hesitate to give this place a try.
author: Michael C.

description:
What a great brunch we just had! I have to come back to try more items on the menu. The deviled eggs were a great starter recommended by the waiter.  The coconut cream of the kiwi stawberries fruit plate was delicious, light and not too sweet. 

The chorizo eggs was perfectly balanced, not greasy at all. The blueberry pancakes were not to disappoint. We felt great after this great meal!
author: Danielle W.

description:
I was thinking that this would be an amazing place, maybe because of all the hype that built up. What I found was that it was just okay - it's not amazing but it's not like horrible either.

I came here with coworkers for an early dinner. They have unique drinks on the drink menu and the bar is packed with yuppies after work.

I will have to say the crispy lemon chips were unique and the seared scallops were good. The twice baked potato was not a baked potato but more of a casserole.

I definitely think this place was hot when it opened but I didn't find it that amazing. Worth a try though.
author: Julia P.

description: Birthday lunch with a friend. We were smart and made reservations at 12. This place filled up quick . Excellent service from Jason with the cool blue glasses. Our drinks were great! The famous Brussels sprout chips to die for , deviled eggs yummy, cheese plate yummy. I got the chicken sandwich yummy, my pal got the chicken very delish. Great service great food and cool space on Washington Square . I loved Moose's previous place but Park Tavern is on point! I'll be back.
author: Cecilia D.

description: This place looks good, however, I've gone 4x different times of year and the same thing. Slow service and ends in montezuma's revenge.
author: Tiff M.

description:
The saying goes that the way to a man's heart is through his stomach. What about the women? Being from a foodie town, not just any food in my stomach will do to reach my heart. The secret is to mention french fries; there's just something about potatoes fried to a golden crisp. 

Park Tavern had me at PT fries, more specifically fries with truffle oil, soft-cooked egg, and caviar. I chose this restaurant for my friend's birthday celebration based solely upon that description for fries. I was pleasantly surprised that everything else we ordered was just as good, albeit nothing can take the place of the french fries. 

(1) Lemon chips: Burrata has never done me wrong and did not this evening.
(2) PT fries: Can you say food-gasm?
(3) Marlowe burger: The burger is melt in your mouth good. The only thing that can make it better is bacon and low and behold, bacon is part of the burger. My tip is that you ask for the sauce that goes with the PT fries for the fries that come with the burger. You can thank me later.
(4) Ribeye: Delicious meaty goodness with some veggies to "balance" out the gluttony thus far.
(5) Chocolate creme brûlée: The only item we ordered that was average. It tasted more like a pot de creme but I can't knock the restaurant for one item.
(6) June "birthday" cake: Sizable portion that we devoured despite being full. This only helps to prove the theory that people have a second stomach for dessert. 

Reservations recommended and try to book earlier rather than later. We were famished as we waited for 9:45 pm to roll around because that was the only time slot I could reserve.

Parking is a pain but I'm willing to sacrifice the money to pay for lot parking in order to get the fries.
author: Gwen L.

description: Best Bone Marrow we've ever had. Truffle fries were to die for! Pork Chop gave Mastro's a run for its money. Great service and beautiful atmosphere.
author: Carolyn W.

description:
Quite a bit bigger than it's sister restaurant Marlowe, Park Tavern is just as good.

Excellent Service.

What we ordered:

Great cocktail menu - I had the Aquatic Park, twice
Smoked Deviled Eggs - 4 stars
Brussel Chips - 5 stars
Clam Strips - 4 stars
Crispy Panissa - 5 stars
Sweet Baby Lettuces - 4 stars

Was an excellent dinner with a close friend. I'm definitely going back. I think my parents would love this place too.

Valet parking!
author: Amy O.

description:
Great service and understanding staff.   The location is very convenient to Beach Blanket Babylon.

Here are some recommendations:

Appetizers - Truffle fries were heavenly.  My husband loved the soft boiled egg and caviar.  The deviled eggs are small but tasty.

Main Course - Chicken with truffle stuffing was absolutely delicious - best roast chicken ever.   My husband described his skate as delightful

Dessert - We were very full by this time but we had to order the coconut bread pudding.  That was sooo good.   It was buttery and not over sweet.   I would have licked the plate if I were out in public as the sauce was yummy.

Drinks -  We liked the McClarin and the PT Old Fashioned best.
author: Myoung K.

description:
A MUCH Anticipated Opening...

As a huge fan of Marlowe, I was excited when I found out Park Tavern would be opening its doors on September 1st. As the sister restaurant to Marlowe, I have to say Park Tavern is definitely the "big" sister with its larger, sophisticated space and what I thought to be a more refined American bistro menu (there are some parallel items) complete with cocktails. 

On Sunday, 10.16.11, my friend and I came for an early dinner at 5:30 pm (with reservations) and were promptly seated. 

F O O D
*BRUSSELS SPROUT CHIPS ($6) - 4.5 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4-pWX0F9mi_VlN1IAxweSQ?select=UC9h6h6p3P53R7cuCYcTxg
Aside from the Marlowe Burger, the Brussels Sprout Chips is what Marlowe is known for. It's crispy, salty and citrusy; simply ADDICTING! Just get it.

*YELLOW DOLL WATERMELON, PROSCUITTO, TRUFFLE & MUSTARD GREENS ($12) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4-pWX0F9mi_VlN1IAxweSQ?select=1A--nFZxr3yI4GLTXa0d-Q
A refreshing start to dinner, the sweet watermelon was a nice contrast to the salty prosciutto with the mustard greens adding a subtle bitterness.

*PETIT "POULET ROUGE" w/ Bloomsdale Spinach & Peewee Potatoes ($23) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/4-pWX0F9mi_VlN1IAxweSQ?select=EAyjMl8SaHq7HxsbVj9BCQ
Flawlessly cooked, the hen's skin was crisp and the meat was succulently moist and tender. Even the breast was moist and could easily be mistaken for the thigh meat. Well-seasoned, the hen was rich in flavor with a light kick. The condensed meaty flavor from the accompanying au jus gave it that extra oomph.
