The bloomsdale spinach was slightly charred which gave a smoky component while the fluffy as clouds peewee potatoes added a subtle sweetness. A perfectly balanced dish!

Though I thoroughly enjoyed this dish, I would not recommend ordering it on a date unless you want to scare your date off with your lack of proper dining etiquette. The poulet rouge arrives whole and you have to carve it yourself, though it's much easier to eat it caveman style. I plead the 5th on what approach I took. So again, don't order this dish unless you're totally comfortable with your date or if your date is Fred Flintstone. 

S E R V I C E
Professional, friendly, and attentive (different from my experiences at Marlowe). The hostesses were welcoming, our waitress always had a smile on her face and the busboys were on their game making sure our water glasses were always filled and plates were promptly taken away.

My biggest gripe is that our entrees took a while to come out and the restaurant wasn't busy at the time.

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
Vintage meets modern chic with grey tile and red brick walls, open kitchen, communal table, wooden drop candle chandelier, black/white photos and large mirrors. 

Park Tavern is a much larger space than Marlowe (~3 times larger) and more sophisticated with an older crowd. The sidewalk seating is perfect for people watching at Washington Square Park.

Overall, it's a great place to bring out-of-towners. 

P A R K I N G
Difficult street parking. Valet parking is $11.

            OOO 
   OOOOOOO
OOOOOYO  
   OYO     I
      I         I
      I              iLove Park Tavern's Logo
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Came here for after work drinks and light bites.

Definitely has the most fancy pants of fries that's a must try -  think truffle fries and replace your ketchup with an egg and caviar 

The service was super nice and it's a bit on the "upscale" but would make for a nice spot for a date. It's right across Washington square park and close enough to other bar.
author: Tiffany N.

description: Best brunch I've had in the city. Make your reservation online. The deviled egg, baguette with house nut butter, and polenta dishes with poached egg and smoky mushrooms are must try. Best polenta I've had. It melts in your mouth. I'll go back each time just for that. The popular avocado toast are great to try just to know how to make it at home (add lemon, peppers and olive oil on avocado). I can do without the bloody moody next time but that's because I prefer mimosas. Otherwise the brunch is superb!
author: A J.

description: Favorite breakfast place in SF. Maybe my favorite breakfast ever!  Great savory choices. I had Polenta cakes with poached eggs, mushrooms, truffle oil, salty parm with spicy arugula. Great flavor combo. Fun location and atmosphere. Reservations would be helpful but not necessary--large share table and bar seats for walk-ins. Service was attentive and unobtrusive. The Bar back was on it with my coffee,  I am properly caffeinated and happy!  Can't wait to go back and try something else.
author: M P.

description:
Just finished a delicious brunch!  Deviled eggs, banana coconut fritters, avocado toast and fromage toast, shared with a friend.  Everything was delicious, and the deviled eggs are the best ice ever had.

I can't wait to come back!
author: Amy F.

description:
Interior is sleek and yet still feels warm. Think Restoration Hardware. Menu was impressive and had multiple items I wanted. Showing self-restraint, I just ordered a few things. Luckily, I also got to try a few of my friend's meals.

Crispy polenta was delightful - crunchy and smooth inside, flavored with parm and truffle. Absolutely mouth watering. My side of bacon was late (and a bit too crispy) but created a nice flavor profile with the polenta dish.

Got to try the challah toast with cinnamon, which was the star of the table. Light, fluffy and not too sweet. Get a glass of milk and split with someone at your table.

Service was subpar but that's forgivable given it was Sat morning brunch. 


Enjoy!
author: Jeff M.

description:
We were in San Francisco for a nice get-away & Park Tavern is right next to the place we stayed AND we had a gift certificate.  
First the good stuff - the food!
I ordered the Brussels sprout chips, I loved them, hubby hated them.
My entree was the pork chop, hubby ordered the halibut...both were excellent, prepared well & nicely complemented w/ the other food on the plates.  No complaints at all.
Now the bad.
Folks should know that even on a Monday night, this place was crazy busy.  Since the place has high ceilings & no carpet, that means very noisy.  My hubby has some trouble hearing which means conversation was tough.  Luckily for me, we were seated near the kitchen so I could watch the food prep going on which was lots of fun. 
It took awhile for our waiter to get back to us as we were ready to go way before most folks dining there would have been.  As we were leaving, I noticed the outside seating, that would have been the way to go for us.
author: Sara K.

description:
Good food, good service & great atmosphere. 

The dishes we ordered wouldn't get me to rant and rave about, but they were all executed perfectly and tasted good.

Standout dishes : 
Poulton Noir -  juicy roasted whole chicken, presented on a cast iron 'spike' pan.
Deviled Egg - It had a good combination tucked in one bite. Pretty pricy for an egg though.

Overall thoughts : While I only gave it 3-stars, I think the overall experience would still get me to come back for more. I am a fan of all three of their restaurants and will probably continue to visit each one. I might not race to be the first one through the Park Tavern door though.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Just went here for Sunday brunch and had a nice time. Between 3 of us, we split 4 dishes so we could try different things:

Avocado Toast: simple and delicious
Crispy Polenta Cakes: MUST HAVE, this has an amazing crispy outside and creamy inside; if I came back, I'd just get this
Open-Faced Deviled Eggs Sandwich: the flavors didn't work all that well together for me, BUT the fries that came with it are delicious
Braised Lamb Tongue: I was hoping for more marinated and broken down tongue; the texture still looked like tongue and didn't taste all that great; plus we hardly touched the potatoes that came with it since they were pretty plain

The atmosphere is nice but would recommend getting there at opening if you don't have a reservation to snag an outside table or sit in the communal area. 

The reason I gave 3 stars instead of 4 is that the service was spotty. Seemed like the waitstaff was spread really thin and we had a hard time flagging down our server since she was all over the restaurant. Plus some of the dishes were great, but not all.
author: Kim-Anh P.

description: I brought a date here for lunch at 1:30pm on Sunday for his birthday thinking that we would be given a lunch menu.  They were still serving brunch at that time. There weren't very many good options on the menu to choose from. My date ordered buttermilk pancakes. What he got were two 11 inch pancakes each half inch thick. That's all that was included.  No bacon, eggs, toast or potatoes. Was kind of disappointed to say the least. I felt bad so I have him half my egg scramble.  Also the waiter apologized for the long wait claiming the there was a rush of people.  Really at 2pm? Don't recommend the brunch at all here.  Can get better food and service elsewhere.
author: Kristin W.

description:
Deviled eggs - yes.  I'm not a fan of deviled eggs, but these .. 1 more please! WOW. Another 7x7 list success (there are many fails, unfortunately).

BRUSSEL SPROUT CHIPS - why is this not on the 7x7 list? Fail, 7x7.

Marlowe burger = good. Deliciously light fries.

The boy loved his pork chop!

Nice space in north beach across from the park.  Parking is a bit of a headache.

A great alternative if you is going to the sister restaurant Marlowe if this location isn't convenient for you.
author: Melody T.

description: This is our favorite neighborhood restaurant. The brunch is amazing. Whenever we have large groups they are always able to accommodate us by the window.
author: Belen C.

description: We had our holiday party in the large room upstairs. I LOVE the vibe here. Menu didn't seem vegan (maybe one option) but the chef made me a special dish, which was amazing. If you need a vegan option here just ask! The wine was great and I think everyone in my group loved their menu as well.
author: Leslie P.

description: Close to two hours for our meal to arrive. And when it did, no apologies. Getting drinks was also a major hassle. Food was decent but far from great. Overall, not a great experience. Won't be going back.
author: K F.

description:
I give 2 stars because it has a great atmosphere and staff is friendly, but it is expensive with no value for the money you're spending.  The food is of high qualify and the wrinkle is that you get unacceptable portions.  The Hamburger looks like a McDonald's patty of size and you get 1 egg with Eggs Benedict.  The wine pours are a joke.  It's shameful and a ripoff.  They also end their brunch at 2:30pm on Sunday.  So stupid!  

3 Deviled Eggs, 1 Burger and a glass of Wine costs $51 with taxes and tip.  

Don't go if you're hungry and on a budget.  You'll be pissed, not pissed drink, but pissed in the sober sense.
author: Michael B.

description:
Solid fun spot for post happy hour. 
Bar scene is fun at the large communal table. Sat there drinking ice tea entertaining our latest startup idea with Mr Fremlin. Come with a group of 12 or so. Good times!!
author: Zak R.

description: We are in the process of planning a wedding reception and visited Park Tavern today. We were really impressed by the restaurant, their menu and staff. Their manager was extremely helpful and we look forward to visiting here again soon. Plus, their deviled eggs are delish
author: Emm Q.

description:
Food was good - some dishes great. While I did enjoy my meal and the space is really nice, this didn't quite live up to all the hype.

Also: the prices were fairly steep. And the restaurant is LOUD. If you go with a group of 8 like I did, you could really only hear the people sitting immediately next to you. Not really an atmosphere for group conversation. 

Not good for vegetarians. My friend couldn't see much on the menu for herself, and had several back & forths with the server about getting something especially made from the kitchen.

MUST-HAVE: oyster caesar.

* Local halibut, avocado, onion, tomato $11: 3 stars
Not bad, but just didn't stand out in any way. The dish is exactly as described, nothing more.

* Brussels Sprout Chips $6: 2 stars
Had this at Marlowe, where I thought the lemon flavor was overpowering. Gave it another shot here, but still felt there could be a greater sea salt to lemon ratio. The chips are just too small and really could use more crisp. I am being picky.. brussels sprouts are my thing.

* Chicken fried green tomato, remoulade $7: 3 stars
Nicely done, thin but crisp breading. Not bad, not fantastic either.

* Pork belly bites, horseradish aioli $6: 2 stars
Pork belly should be much more fatty & tender! I found the meat quite hard.

* Deviled eggs, Nueske's baken & chives $1.5 each: 1 star
I found this to be really plain in flavor. The yolk filling was just too egg-y if that makes any sense - I could barely taste the bacon & chives, which should've balanced out its flavor mroe.

* Fried oysters "Caesar" $12: 5 stars
Amazing! The oysters were absolutely delicious. When you took a bite and the soup-y insides poured into your mouth, it was savory and had an amazing rich flavor. The lettuce leaves with caesar dressing balanced out what would've been an overly intense rich flavor in the fried breading and the oyster. 

* Yellow doll watermelon & Mangalitsa prosciutto, truffle & mustard greens $12: 4.5 stars
Surprisingly wonderful! Loved the interplay of flavors, temperatures, and textures. Who would've thought that juicy/sweet watermelon would go so well with salty/dry prosciutto? Each time I chewed, my taste buds burst with more new flavor combinations.

* Lamb chops & merguez sausage, broccoli rabe with garlic & chili $28: 4 stars
I didn't get to try this but a couple friends got the dish and it looked wonderful. The lamb was cooked rare to medium-rare and looked incredibly rich & tender.

* Herb marinated whole cornish game hen, Bloomsdale spinach, carrots & baby turnips $22: 4 stars
Really delicious, juicy, tender, and well seasoned meat. A nice dish to get for the "ooh's" and "aah's" - the whole hen is served standing up!

* Risotto: 4 stars
My friend got this special ordered as she's vegetarian. I had a bite & it was creamy and had amazing texture. It had a tart sauce on top, which gave it a little too much of a sour flavor. Otherwise really good.

* Apple & fig dessert with ice cream: 4 stars
Loved it. Warm, soft slices of apple & fig under a wonderfully crunchy yet subtle crust. The ice cream was a great contrast - we forgot what the menu said the flavor was, but we all agreed it had hints of lemon. It was light with a very smooth texture.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Came here for Friday Lunch:

Location: Parking is difficult (unless you get lucky) but there is valet or a parking structure down the street. Park Tavern is right by Washington Park.

The space: Decor & ambiance is nice and I loved the classy with a hint of rustic feel. 

The food:
- CRISPY LEMON CHIPS: (4 stars): Thin fried lemon chips... surprisingly, it wasn't sour and you can taste just a hint of lemon. I liked the dip that came with it. For the price ($15) I expected more chips... serving size was way too small. 

- HEIRLOOM TOMATO & BURRATA TART: (3 stars): Tomatoes & cheese cover this crispy thin bread. You must really like caramelized onions to order this because the flavors really overwhelm this dish.
author: Emily C.

description:
This has been my favorite New American restaurant the past couple of years, only perhaps recently surpassed by Wayfare Tavern (like as of yesterday).  As such, I feel compelled to write a long over-due review to sing Park Tavern's virtues, and I know many others will join me in the chorus.

The owners who expanded upon what they started at Marlowe really got everything right, except maybe situating this New American mecca all the way out in North Beach.  The decor here is casual but classically elegant: rustic wood beams, brown leather banquettes, and white tile flooring.

As for the food, never a disappointment.  My favorite appetizers are the demons on horseback (lardo-wrapped smoked prawns, remoulade & cucumber) and the famous smoked deviled eggs (bacon, pickled jalapeño & chive). Standout entrees have been the grilled pork chop (brussels sprouts, new potatoes & morcilla sausage, pickled onions & mustard jus) and NY steak (braised kobe beef & marrow-stuffed bone, crispy potatoes, smoked cipollini onions, broccolini & red wine jus).  

Cocktails here are done very well, with a balance of the classics vs. some creative new inflections on the old styles as well.  

Service is always polished and professional, they run a tight shop.  Highly recommend Park Tavern, it's worth the journey to NB.
author: Saminda W.

description: Great spot for a solid meal before our Beach Blanket Babylon performance on 10/30. We thought service was on point and the open space rustic layout coupled with the warm lighting made for a relaxing meal. We ordered the hush puppies, brussel sprouts side, burger with PT fries and foie gras torchon. The hush puppies were warm, flaky and jam packed of flavor without being too dense. Definitely a must order. The brussel sprouts were sizzling and great with the chili flakes and Parmesan addition but could have benefitted from a lighter hand on the lemon juice. The foie gras was good but a little more petite than expected. The only thing that wasn't a standout dish was the dessert. The chocolate cake was a little dry and light on ganache. We ordered a side of caramel ice cream which made it better! Dessert was on the house though for our special celebration so no complaints there!
author: NJ A.

description:
Deviled Eggs.  Really that's all you need to know.

The fact that everything else about this restaurant is nearly perfect to me can be summed up by other people's reviews.

So class, what is the take home message about Park Tavern?  
"D-E-V-I-L-E-D E-G-G-S, Deviled Eggs."
author: Susan C.

description: Really great food and fun cocktails in the cute north beach area. The boozy smoothie and the huckleberry fritters and to die for!  Parking can be tough but the area is super cute.
author: Joanna P.

description: Very solid brunch food but inordinately long wait without reservations and service can suffer if they're busy.  I also once saw a valet watch a cab side-swipe a patron's car and let the cab go without getting license plate and a photo. So if you're driving go elsewhere.
author: drew n.

description:
Very impressed. I ate the following: 

1. Avocado toast - Its toast , avocado and hot garlic sauce on top. Perfect melody of flavors. 
2. Polenta with poached eggs and wild mushroom and arugula salad. Amazing again. Poached eggs were cooked just perfectly and the polenta was great too. 
3. Tcho chocolate creme brulee. OMG !!! This reminds me of the tcho chocolate ice cream at smitten. 
4. Cappucino - meh wouldn't recommend it. 

Overall great food, great service. And oh they also have valet parking for $12. Make sure you have reservations though. This place gets busy !
author: Priyanka P.

description:
Deviled Eggs- #95 on the 2013 7x7 100 Things to Eat Before You Die list.

Park Tavern is one of the better new restaurants I've tried in a while. I've been procrastinating on this review, and they've already changed a couple of the dishes on the menu since my visit a couple of months ago, so I had to take a guess for some of the descriptions. I made reservations for an early dinner for a party of 5, and it was easy to do a couple weeks in advance for a Saturday night. We arrived and were seated quickly. We ordered:

-Complimentary Bread and Butter (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/park-tavern-san-francisco?select=t5C10RCRWsnMDtypmfjH5g#t5C10RCRWsnMDtypmfjH5g): The bread and butter were really good- it's hard to go wrong with epi bread!
-"Marlowe Burger" (Caramelized Onion, Cheddar, Bacon, Horseradish Aïoli & Fries, $14, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/park-tavern-san-francisco?select=t5C10RCRWsnMDtypmfjH5g#aew2-QxxyeL_NJBnMQ8APA): Just as delicious as I remember it being at Marlowe. Highly recommended.
-Herb-Crusted Halibut (English Peas & Pea Tendrils, Crispy Shallots, Prosciutto, White Wine Velouté, $28, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/park-tavern-san-francisco?select=t5C10RCRWsnMDtypmfjH5g#fICBimLI_n5YnDY9Z8pwsA): My friend actually ordered this dish, and it was amazing! I rarely order fish at restaurants since I've had so many bad experiences with it being overcooked, but this halibut was cooked perfectly. The herb crust also added a nice crunchy texture, and all the components in this dish worked really well together. Highly recommended!
-Heirloom Beet Salad (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/park-tavern-san-francisco?select=t5C10RCRWsnMDtypmfjH5g#GHVYEfh5Xb5GqHLqZOA6Jw): Just ok. I liked the different varieties of beets, but overall the dish wasn't anything special. Skip.
-Crispy Lemon Chips (Burrata, Nigella Seed, $14, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/park-tavern-san-francisco?select=t5C10RCRWsnMDtypmfjH5g#Z5yOUZZaLC-DAsIF-NzA-Q): Very interesting, and something I've never seen before or tried, and probably for good reason. The burrata was creamy and delicious, but I didn't get the lemon chips idea. Skip on the lemon chips but the burrata is recommended.
-PT Fries (Truffle, Soft-Cooked Egg & Caviar, $14, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/park-tavern-san-francisco?select=bc5IsPTz39oVAcr5B5J7Ww#bc5IsPTz39oVAcr5B5J7Ww): Yum! The truffle fries were crispy and super aromatic, which added to the delicious flavor. I loved the soft cooked egg that you dipped the fries in, and the caviar on top of the egg. Highly recommended!
-Smoked Deviled Eggs (Bacon, Pickled Jalapeño, Chive, $2/ea, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/park-tavern-san-francisco?select=t5C10RCRWsnMDtypmfjH5g#yMLlFP470A0NQgFQBYkRkw): A-MAZING! A must order.! I'm not a huge fan of deviled eggs, but this version is the best I've had, ever, and this was an excellent addition to the 2013 Big Eat list. Make sure you order yourself more than one!
-Brown Butter Brussels Sprouts (Parmesan & Chili Flakes, $8, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/park-tavern-san-francisco?select=t5C10RCRWsnMDtypmfjH5g#xpx_LG76RbSKaNj98QH6wg): Disappointing! I love brussels sprouts, and these were just ok. They were a little underseasoned and not quite crispy enough. Skip.
-Strawberry Cake (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/park-tavern-san-francisco?select=t5C10RCRWsnMDtypmfjH5g#9c85ppSiI_OQpBaK3TlGoA): Yum! This cake was delicious, and not too sweet. I loved how fluffy the cake was, and that you could taste the fresh strawberry in the frosting. Recommended.

Overall, I loved my dining experience at Park Tavern although there were some misses. Service was on par, and the kitchen was efficient. I also loved the decor and ambience here, and will definitely be back for another meal (and more deviled eggs) in the future! The biggest negative about dining here is the parking- it can take a while since this area gets so busy!
author: Amy D.

description: This is my first visit to Park Tavern. I've been to Marlowe and food is delicious so I was expecting the same and Park Tavern did not disappoint. Decor is very clean and inviting. Service is good. Food is amazing. I will definitely return soon. Yum
author: Ellen T.

description: We actually had the intentions of eating breakfast at Mama's but once we saw the line we decided to find a plan b... it should have been plan A. We got a table immediately and our server was over to take our order within seconds. He gave us a few recommendations, though we didn't order any, we definitely appreciated the inside scoop! We ordered the French Toast and The Chorizo and Eggs. The chorizo and eggs were delicious. I could live off of the potatoes that came with it. But lemme tell you... The French toast with a cherry compote was, in a word, AMAZING. I was actually really sad when I got too full to enjoy it any more. If I didn't live in SoCal, I would definitely make that a weekly cheat day. Will definitely come back when I'm in SF again.
author: Brooke L.

description:
After checking out the line at Mama's on a Sunday morning around 11AM, we decided to head over to Park Tavern instead. We were able to snag a couple seats at the bar and were helped by the bartender.

My bf ordered an espresso and the pan-fried corn beef hash. I ordered the warm open-faced deviled egg sandwich. After several refills of water (hydration was key), our orders arrived. The corn beef hash was pretty good, but I think I won with my open-faced sandwich. The bread did seemed a little TOO toasted, though and the edges were slightly burnt, making it difficult to cut into.

This place was busy the entire time we were there and a small wait started to form at the entryway. On our way towards the restaurant, I caught a glimpse of the avocado toast -- looked so good, I think I'll try replicating it myself unless I can get myself back here again!

Everything coming out of the kitchen looked delicious and the ambiance was clean and classy. Definitely a solid place to visit when out for brunch!
author: Leana L.

description:
Country lawyer, truffle chicken. This is the best restaurant in SF! 

Pro tip - take your time and make sure you enjoy each moment here. If you want to be classy without breaking the bank, the burger is $13 and is better than any other in the city.
author: Nolan G.

description:
I try not to repeat restaurants in order to try out all the amazing places SF has to offer, but I find myself back at Park Tavern over and over again.

The ambiance, drinks & food makes it a big hit time after time.

Highly recommended: poulet rouge (whole chicken), pork chop, drinks, and deviled eggs

Foolproof catch-up or date spot!
author: Linda X.

description: What a nice place to sit at the bar on a lazy Sunday! My friend and I wandered over here after brunch at Bottle Cap across the way. We couldn't have been treated better! We took two bar stools, ordered drinks, and just relaxed. The bartender was awesome! Really nice guy who was fun to talk to. We had an excellent time. When my friend kept talking me into staying longer, I asked the bartender for some bread and he brought  me a beautiful basket of fresh rolls with butter. I can't wait to have a dinner here. Already made my Open Table reservation!
author: Sandra P.

description:
We came here to celebrate our dear friends' birthdays. We had a reservation and we were seated right away. The service was not bad. However, when it came to the food, I don't think it's worth the price. 

First off, we got this veggie chips (I forgot what it's called) and Hush Puppies for appetizers. The veggies chips was super salty, but it has a good amount of crispiness. The Hush Puppies was okay, but it had a weird taste to me. 

Then on to the entrees, we got mussels, flat iron steak and the braised short ribs. The mussels was super duper tiny, not filling. The flat iron steak was alright with the sauce. The braised short rib was unbelievably dry with no sauce. The carrots taste like butter. 

Overall, I just don't think the food is tasty at all. Well, at least I tried.
author: Elaine C.

description:
Jeff & Jack-Bartenders-adore. thank you for  satisfying our taste bud needs. 

must haves:
+Lemon Chips
+deviled eggs
+scallops

overall vibe: sheek & sexy. I love love the decor. especially the fresh cut flowers in the restroom. such a sweet touch.

Great date place, very intimate & a perfect music selection that sets the vibe. A classic & beautiful spot. 

Thank you, Park Tavern.
author: Priscilla N.

description:
Sometimes the best things aren't always obvious. You have to be patient and open minded to let things reveal themselves. My experience here came in waves of not good, ok, great, and amazing. I just love when that happens! Love it love it love it! 

I pulled up to see the thing I love most - Valet! For $12 you can dress to thrill and wear sky scraper heels to dinner because the door is less than 20 steps away. That always makes me very happy! 

The space is nice. The last time I was here was when it was Moose's. We were upstairs in the tiny private area after my friend was married at the church across the way. 

Our meal consisted of things that were great and things that were not so great: 
Skip the deviled eggs and demon on horseback appetizers. The Halibut entree was really nice. I loved the balance of the rich hearty broth with fresh peas and pea tendrils. The sear on the fish was a wonderful contrast. 

The vertical poultry reminds me of beer can chicken. Any home chef familiar with Williams Sonoma has vertical roaster in their cabinet *wink*. I am not a fan of brining poultry because often times it winds up being too salty so I employ other methods. This baby was was tender and flavorful despite being salty for me. The rustic bread stuffing that served as a catch all for the poultry drippings was delicious. I especially liked how they didn't over use truffles because those can ruin it for me. I can see why people love this entree. I would easily recommend it. 

Dessert. Banana Split. YES!! The house made ice cream was good - not as rich as I like, but perfect after that heavy meal. The carmelized bananas turned what we consider an everyday treat into something special. Just taking the time to blowtorch or flash broil the bananas makes this the kind of dessert I love. I really appreciate attention to detail. Rare to see that in desserts, which made me love it more. 

We enjoyed service that was friendly, professional, unrushed. I was really happy. The seating isn't comfy, but when you are in good company - that matters little. 

After our leisurely dinner we walked to Washington Square across the street. Ok - I held on to Mike for dear life trying not to break my neck navigating the uneven terrain in my heels. 

Hey, if I fell, I would have looked undeniably faabulous. You can bet money on that! 

Go to Park Tavern. Valet Park your car. Enjoy dinner and dessert (skip the over hyped appetizers). Take a short walk across the street, sit on a bench, and chat at Washington Square while your food digests ... because life is meant to be savored.

Park Tavern is a great place for that experience.
author: Jennifer C P.

description: Fun, lively place. Great for a date for 2 or a group of any size. Chicken roast was amazing.
author: Michelle M.

description: The hen was not my taste. The scallops were good, a bit too salty, over peas on mashed peas.  I took a star off bc it was a disappointing 2 piece of scallops. Usually it is 3 jumbo peice at other restaurants. I asked the waitress how many pieces before ordering and she said 3-4, depending on size. It was not!  Usually dessert can save the meal, but the bread pudding didn't do it. The bread itself was dense with a bounce to the texture which I like. However, since the bread was bland and wasn't too sweet, the taste is enhanced from the sauce. The sauce tasted bitter, perhaps they burnt the sugar too long.
author: Gloria T.

description: Have been here a number of times only for brunch. Love the space and decor. Service is excellent. Bloody Mary's and grapefruit mimosa are delicious. Deviled eggs are the best in SF. Shrimp and grits are tasty and hearty (although sometimes a bit salty). The burger is perfection topped with carmelized onions and a side of fries. Poached egg on polenta with truffle mushrooms is OK. Chorizo with egg is scrumptious and the egg skillet is OK. My mission to to eventually try everything on the menu...will be back soon...
author: Maria C.

description: Came here for brunch and really enjoyed it. Great atmosphere and our service was perfect. Started by giving us three options for where we wanted to sit. We chose the chef's table, neat view of the kitchen. We also received complimentary appetizers. The wrong dish was brought to me, which I didn't mind at all, especially since they brought my order out in literally two minutes, but because of the confusion they comped my meal.... we were impressed to say the least.
author: Amanda R.

description:
Park Tavern is definitely at the top or near the top of our favorite restaurants. Everything from the food, service, ambiance, and location are spot on.

Foods:
Brussels Sprout Chips - Love this stuff. Great starter to order and munch on while you wait for the rest of the delicious food to arrive.

Smoked Deviled Eggs - So addicting! You'll definitely want to order more than one!

PT Fries - The perfect crisp-on-the-outside, soft-on-the-inside fries! Nicely seasoned and a hint of truffle oil? The dipping sauce they serve with it is just fine...but the best part is definitely the soft-boiled egg with caviar. Whoever thought of egg and fries...genius!

Poulet Noir - We've gotten the Poulet Rouge here before which was amazing, and this dish was no different. Don't think we've ever had a chicken that's been cooked so perfectly or so tasty before (other than the Poulet Rouge, of course)!

C.A.B NY Steak - The steak was cooked to a perfect medium rare. Incredibly juicy and well seasoned. The pole beans were delicious as well, but what tied everything together was the red wine jus! The only part of the dish that I was hoping more from was the braised Kobe and bone marrow. The braised Kobe was a tad overdone and a little on the dry side. But...what could've saved it was if there was more bone marrow! It was really tough to identify the buttery, fatty, taste of heaven that we crave in bone marrow.

Desserts:
Wood-Fired Roasted Strawberry & Rhubarb Shortcake - Oh my goodness, this was so yummy. The strawberry and rhubarb was cooked down and oh so tasty with the wonderful shortcake and vanilla ice cream!

Afternoon Delight - When a restaurant offers Captain Crunch ice cream, you have to just get it! It was as you would expect, Captain Crunch-y and rich ice cream with a dust of cereal. This was served with a delicious shot of cereal milk crème. (Also eating this with the strawberry and rhubarb shortcake was awesome.)

The service here is always top notch. We love coming here, and we'll definitely be back the next time we're in the city.
author: Vivian L.

description: PT Truffle Fries- a meal of these plus the beet salad would make a complete and delicious meal! These fries are so decadent. They're delicious enough on their own but dipping them into the soft egg yolk, caviar, and aioli makes them just heavenly. The hubby got the pork chop and I had the Marlowe burger, one of the best burgers I've eaten. The pork chop was also very tasty but there were too many competing flavors on the plate. We also had Brussel sprouts which could have used a bit more time in the pan. Get the burger and PT fries, can't go wrong!  (Also good- lemon chips, cod, and octopus which I had at a previous dinner).
author: tina l.

description: Went for brunch. Had the chorizo eggs -- it was pretty tasty, but nothing special. My friend's buttermilk pancakes were kind of plain. The fritters were almost burned -- we sent them back, and they brought a new plate, which was nice, but those were overdone as well. The room was pretty, spacious. I liked that we had a reservation and were seated right on time. Valet parking for $12 was very convenient too. I might return with a large group, or try for dinner.
author: Sheviche R.

description:
Food: 3/5
Service: 3/5
Ambience: 4/5

We live in the neighborhood. Came here for brunch on Sunday with friends from out of town. Had the fried duck egg sandwich, cast iron eggs, polenta, and the burger. Food was just ok but not outstanding. It's simply the nicest place to have brunch in North Beach, but doesn't necessarily have the most delicious food.

Service was also off today. The hostess wasn't particularly friendly, and our waiter seemed like he was having a bad day. Neither one cracked a smile the entire visit.

All in, I really want to like this place but would only come here to entertain out of town guests who are dying to go on account of the reputation. Shame.
author: T. B.

description: Came here without a reservation around 12pm on Sunday.  We were able to sit right away at the communal table behind the bar area, which wasn't overcrowded at the time.  I had their polenta cakes with poached eggs, truffled salsa verde, sauteed mushrooms and parmesan... one word: amazing.  I will be dreaming about this brunch.  This is definitely a must try in SF, and I will be back.  My boyfriend really enjoyed their seasonal french toast dish, although I'm pretty sure my polenta cakes stole the show :)
author: Michelle R.

description:
We had a really good dinner here tonight.  The crusty French bread & soft spreadable butter they start you out with is yummy.  For starters, we shared the famous brussels sprout chips ($9) and the foie gras torchon ($18).  Both w ere very good.  The brussels chips were a little on the salty side and I could have done without the lemony flavor, but otherwise they were excellent.  The foie gras was also excellent and the cripsy brioche, pepitas and sour cherry compote were good accompaniments, but I felt like the portion was very stingy, especially for almost $20.  For our entrees, my husband had the Marlowe burger ($16), which he really enjoyed, and I had the arctic char with fennel risotto ($29).  The fish was cooked perfectly, and I really loved the risotto.  Fennel isn't my favorite flavor, but the risotto was perfect.  I'm a bit of a risotto snob and frequently find restaurant versions too watery or with too much added cream, but this was wonderful.  Overall, the food was all very good but I felt like it is a touch overpriced, even for SF (especially the appetizers).  The atmosphere is a bit scene-y (and loud) for my tastes, but fortunately the staff is very kind and there is none of the stuck-up attitude that tends to go with that scene.  
Parking in the area is terrible so we used their $12 valet.
author: A M.

description:
What to Do When Your Divalicious Friend Swings Back Through Town:

1)  Ask what kind of food she would like to eat.  

She says, "I will let you decide because as I recall you picked some pretty amazing places to eat the last time I was there."  
http://www.yelp.com/biz/salt-house-san-francisco#hrid:AM3NGe9wtZDiwUyB31DZ2g

2)  Make a reservation at PARK TAVERN.

3)  Breeze up to the valet stand ($12).

4)  Be warmly greeted and quickly ushered to your table in the middle of a large, chic, and bustling dining room.

5)  Order up a round of drinks.

The fruity and bubbly Mary Etta's Bubbles with raspberry flavors was right up my alley and a nice homage to Mrs. Moose ($11).  

6)  Order two bowls of the Brussels Sprout Chips.

Because once you've tried these warm, crisp, salty, and lemony "chips," you will immediately want more!  ($7).

7)  Order the infamous Deviled Eggs.  

At first, we didn't receive them for some reason but they were worth the wait.  Topped with bacon and minced jalapenos, these savory bites will convert even the most staunch deviled egg hater ($2 each).  (Plus they were graciously comped due to the mix up.)  

8)  Next time order more appetizers and fewer entrees.

The disappointingly gritty Mussels, Cockles, and Clams came in a too salty for me tomato broth ($21).  However, the Diva loved her Scallops dish with Butter Beans and Sausage ($28) and the Better Half liked his hefty Pork Chop ($27).

9)  Save room for desserts (note the plural).

The May's Birthday Cake was a gorgeous cake layered with raspberry cream cheese and raspberry buttercream and topped with a lighted candle ($9).  Fun!  We were less enamored by the "It's It" as it was a scoop of chocolate covered mint ice cream and salty and sparse oatmeal cookie sprinkles ($8).  The rhubarb addicted Better Half scarfed down his Strawberry and Rhubarb Shortcake in short order ($8).  

10)  When the Diva declares this the best meal of the trip, think "Mission Accomplished!"
author: Amy C.

description: Went here on Valentines Day, so the menu was prefix. Everything was so good and cooked to perfection. They even gave you an Oyster appetizer complimentary. Will need to come back and try the regular menu. Also have heard great things about the brunch. Apparently you can make reservations which is unheard of in SF.
author: Gabrielle C.

description: Probably the best breakfast I have ever had.  We had the deviled eggs, fritters, burger and corned beef hash.  Unbelievably delish!!!
author: Em W.

description: A great place for brunch. I am a huge fan of the Hummingbird cocktail. The iron skillet eggs with spinach was delicious. The pancakes were nice and fluffy. We ordered a side of berries and cream which was a nice addition to the pancakes.
author: Joanna T.

description:
3.5 stars. Jr. Yelpers say, "Not a value meal". 
The place was rocking because of the massive soccer fans who crowded their way into the bar area after the World Cup soccer game.  The noise was deafening and the dining area is right next to all the noise. I witnessed a senior coming in with his group and he showed his buddy how he was handling the noise - he took out his bilateral hearing aids!

We started off with the fried sprout chips, $9.  A small bowl of green and browned sprout leaves. I've made this at home and the frying process is tedious because you have to pull each of the leaves off and quickly fry them or they burn.  It was OK.  The carrot soup was bland, $11. The butter lettuce was not remarkable.  The Marlowe burgers were the stand out and the fries were very good - crispy.  I'm not a big fan of burgers but this burger was moist and had good flavor with onions and lean crunchy bacon, $15.  The bar steak also accompanied by fries was disappointing. Jr.Yelper said the steak was chewy. 
The Tcho chocolate creme brulee' was not what I expected. It had a light caramelized crust but the brulee texture was thicker and had a caramel-like flavor.  

If you like burgers and fries, then come for the Marlowe burger. I didn't like the other items we tried 'tho.  Our waiter, Phil, was very professional.
author: Ry T.

description: Incredible food! Love the ambiance, and the decor. The best part? They take last minute brunch reservations. Yes, please!
author: En C.

description: Great food and service, cool fit out and atmosphere. Only had brunch but would definitely come back.
author: John H.

description: After a slightly shaky start with the service the staff rebounded nicely and we had a great night. All the food was wonderful and the atmosphere was great. We come to town this time every year and we are sure to return.
author: John H.

description:
Yikes! Health code rating 86 out of 100? That's not good. 

Anyhoo, I digress. Park Tavern....food comes in at about a 6 out of 10, service closer to 9...here's my story and I'm sticking to it:

Brussel sprout chips are delicious, but there must be a pound of butter in each bowl...everything's better with butter, sure....

My dining partner and I both had steaks, which were pretty good...she got hers with fries, I had the entree version which came with some other things....fries were way better than those extra bits and bobs, so stick with the fries as a side. Not the most tender steaks in the world but tasty enough.

I had a carafe of rose that was quite nice, the partner had a couple of fancy shmancy cocktails which she seemed to enjoy....

Desserts were a miss, one a very very dry cake, the other a shortbread with strawberry rhubarb, the fruit was tasty, but again the shortbread was super dry...

A note on the private room, where I attended an event not long ago - it has comfortable furnishings and is pleasant enough, but is more of a loft type space so the noise from the very noisy resto below will creep up into your event....the service was great, which seems a constant, but another very annoying thing about this room is that the stairs leading up to it are used by staff coming and going to the next level up....I don't know what they're doing up there, but the seemingly constant foot traffic was very intrusive and noticeable. 

Still, there's a lot to like about Park Tavern - the Washington Square location, complete with outdoor seating, the communal table and bar seating which I assume is for walk ins, the decor (nice and sort of private club-like), the crowd - very San Francisco, as it has become an institution for a certain set in a short time. I'd go back, but not in a hurry.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
I have only been here for brunch twice but both times were great. The Cast Iron egg dish is really tasty; so is the avocado toast and crispy polenta cakes. The drinks are also pretty good...a great bloody mary to go with the delicious food!

I want to try it for dinner soon as well based on all the other high rated dishes.
author: Derek S.

description:
I was really looking forward to trying this place and finally had an excuse and opportunity to.  

The set up is really nice and the large windows in front make it very inviting with an awesome view of Washington Square. 

For appetizers, we got the Deviled Eggs, the Venison Carpaccio, and the PT fries
Of the three I really liked the Deviled Eggs and PT fries.  Can't go wrong with a runny boiled egg you pour into the fries covered in truffle oil.  The Venison was good, but didn't stand out, and the the inclusion of Beef Tartare and Marrow made it confusing.  

For the Entrees we split the Scallops, Duck and CAB  NY Steak.  The Scallops were really flavorful and perfectly cooked, however the entree was light, will leave you hungry. The duck and steak were good portions but both suffered from a lack of distinct duck or steak flavors.  In other words, the meat was a little bland.  The sides prepared with the dishes were good.  The steak came with a bone marrow, that was also confusing.  I'm not sure how they prepared it but it was dry and flaky, like they deep fried the marrow, and the placed it back in the bone. The potatoes on the dish were delicious. 

Dessert also lacked a punch.  Although the Carrot Cake was good it wasn't outstanding.  And the S'mores wasn't too impressive, other than the ice cream portion.  

The drinks were okay, nothing spectacular but good flavors.  

Don't get me wrong Park Tavern is a good restaurant.  It has some very stand out dishes but also some just okay ones.
author: Veasna H.

description:
Park tavern is a great brunch and dinner spot. I've been here multiple times and, for the most part, it is tasty! 

For brunch:
I would definitely try the french toast. It has the perfect level of sweets where it isn't overkill but just the right amount to be so dang good. The polenta cakes are really good as well but rather small in size. I would avoid the marlowe burger - it's good but definitely not the best item that Park Tavern offers. 

For dinner:
The truffle fries are godly. Though, it's hard to go wrong with anything with truffles and caviar. I really liked the half chicken. The presentation is great and the chicken is really tender. For appetizers, I didn't like the waygu beef jerky at all. I do recommend trying the brussel sprout chips. It's just like kale chips but tastier if you like brussel sprouts.

Overall, Park Tavern is a great spot. The decorations are great and it always seems like a popular place to be. I definitely recommend making reservations in advance to avoid waiting for a table. Though, there is a community table that is first come, first serve if you are in a rush!
author: Brandon P.

description:
Food: brussels sprouts chips were delicious and went great with the excellent "Country Lawyer" cocktail. Overhyped "deviled eggs" were just OK for me. The egg is so deconstructed it was not recognizable as an egg and due to the extreme darkness of the lighting (more about this in a bit) I actually at first thought it was a stuffed mushroom! 
My spousal unit ordered the poulet noir which was not chicken, but a Cornish Game Hen, served whole with sauce poured over it. While this presentation is impressive, it was difficult for him to carve and eat from the serving platter (again, the lack of light caused some difficulty here). He asked for a plate at some point which made the task of carving/eating a bit easier. 
I had the clams with chorizo and grilled bread. It is a truly wonderful dish. Perfectly cooked clams and sausage in a delicious broth that is a wonderful dip for the grilled bread. 
Service: a major plus at Park Tavern. Seamless, non-intrusive, and efficient. Perfect. 
Ambiance: had some problems here. The noise level just about prevents conversation. It is very very loud in Park Tavern. We were a party of 3 who hadn't been together for a while and had a lot to catch up on. We couldn't. We were yelling, which is not pleasant or relaxing. As mentioned earlier, the lighting isn't soft and flattering in Park Tavern, it is dark in there. I kept asking myself "why are we eating in the dark?" A woman at an adjoining table took a flashlight from her purse to read the menu. True story.
author: michelle g.

description: Bomb brunch. Be sure to make a reservation ahead of time, this place is pretty popular on the weekends. The ambiance is also very cool, lots of natural light and a very open space. As for food, I had the corned beef hash, pretty delish, though I favored the french toast my sister ordered. It came with a caramel like sauce and blueberry sauce. Besides that I highly recommend the deviled eggs, it had the perfect mix of tang and saltiness with the pesto, bacon and pickled jalapeño. We also ordered the crab toast which was really refreshing as well. I would definitely want to go back, after all, I didn't get to try the dessert!
author: Samantha C.

description:
I have eaten at Park Tavern before and really enjoyed so I thought it would be a fun place to take my mom for Mother's Day. But our Mother;s Day experience was  horrible. First, there was a prix fixe menu and I was not told that when I made the reservation...which is a bit disappointment. Then the meal and service were even more disappointing. The avocado toast had no taste, the egg was watery. Our server was not attentive and forget to bring us water three times!!! I was a bit embarrassed and disappointed. It was not at $160 meal for me. 

Do not go for holidays...the experience is sub-par at best...
author: Katrina W.

description:
From out of nowhere, this was the best brunch I've ever had. In addition to a couple great champagne coctails, we ordered: 

Avocado Toast
Grapefruit Brûlée
Poached Eggs on Polenta Cakes
Buttermilk Pancakes

Perfectly balanced, complex, building flavors. Warm service. Great location. Easy 5 stars.
author: Jonny R.

description: Liked. Classy, downtempo, spacious, good foods, good drinks, and good service. Communal style setting if that's alright with you without a reservation. Good (thats the 4th good) local stop for an intimate evening
author: Juls C.

description:
Brunch here is pricey but very delicious. I would recommend getting stuff family style because there are so many good things to try! 

Two things really stood out to me - the corned beef hash and french toast.

The corned beef hash is great and so addicting. The french toast is perfect for sharing but I can imagine could be too sweet of one person ate only a full serving of this for their full brunch. The blueberry compote that comes on the side is also a delicious touch.
author: Jenny M.

description: One of the best dinners I've ever had. The demon in horseback are to die for. The braised short ribs and wood fire pork chop are absolutely delicious.
author: Jason W.

description:
There's nothing i can really say that hasn't been said already. They have an excellent menu . It's not too big, and what they do, they do well.

The smoked devil eggs is genius - the tartar is every meat lovers dream with crispy bone marrow. The entree's are well thought out. 
My only complaint is that there scallops is a little confused. But everything else was delicious. Interior was warm. Service was exceptional.
author: Imran N.

description:
This review is for the brunch only. 

Park Tavern is such a classy brunch spot tucked right into the quaint North Beach Washington Square park neighborhood (not the strip clubs part of NB). With a direct view of the park from both the ample outdoor and indoor seating options, Park Tavern boasts a creative take on traditional brunch entrees, great service and a somewhat upscale ambiance. 

Here's what I recommend: 
1. Crispy polenta cakes with truffles: It's basically like an eggs benedict but with poached eggs (not as runny as normal benedicts) on top of fried polenta served with a bed of mushrooms. This is seriously a one of a kind dish that you've got to try! 
2. Marlowe Burger: Deliciously juicy - in the same realm as the NOPA and Maverick burgers.
3. Orange mimosas: freshly squeezed and absolutely traditional in concept. It's almost a rarity nowadays to have just a classic quality mimosa. Everyone always tries to make theirs unique with weird funky twists but Park Tavern stays authentic. 

Seriously though, you really can't go wrong with anything on the menu. Go with what your taste buds desire but if you're trying to decide between two entrees, pick one of the above!

Happy Eating, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description: Pretty good but Marlowe's is better.
author: Amy V.

description: Amazing brunch! I travel for work and love to be in different cities. Brunch is one of my favorites. park Tavern brunch was perfect. The smoked deviled eggs were so good we had to order more. Avocado toast and egg skillet were unreal. Highly recommend it!
author: Julie W.

description:
This is the happenin' restaurant in North Beach currently. Been here twice for drinks before booking for dinner. The food was very good. We only had one disappointing dish: the Cabernet Steak. It was dry, not tasty and small---$38.  Also they stuck us in the far corner of the restaurant, when it was quite empty. This was a bummer since I wanted to sit where I could experience more of the restaurant. 

Some highlights:
1. Service - It was like a choreographed dance. Our server was Patrick. He was awesome.
2. Deviled Eggs
3. Poulet Noir - The hen. Get it, it's great.
4. The bar and lounge. There is a loungey area upstairs and a lively bar downstairs. Very cool.

Next time I come here I think I am going to opt out of the entrees and order a bunch of apps and sides since they were so great. Also I hear the cocktails are amazing, I only had beer and wine. Oh yea... I said and.
author: Christy L.

description: We went here for a family brunch. The food is really good and tasty. We enjoyed the food and will come back again.
author: Ricki Y.

description: Probably my favorite restaurant in North beach. Deviled eggs are top 3 favorite foods on the planet. Drinks are great. Service is great. Go here.
author: Zach K.

description:
One of my current favorite restaurants in the City now!  I can't get enough of their "Poulet" mini-bird (Cornish game hen, same difference) that's cooked and served on a cast iron skillet with a stick that goes up the Poulet's behind.  I normally don't order chicken because it can be overcooked and dry, but the Poulet at Park Tavern is a divine exception.  It is consistently tender, juicy, can't get into my mouth and tummy fast enough, delicious!  The bottom of the skillet is filled with some delicious herb stuffing.  The Poulet's flavors vary by season.  In the winter, it's called "Poulet Noir" flavored with truffles.  In the spring/summer, it's called "Poulet Rojo" flavored with chile and other red spices.  

Other outstanding things I've ordered the various times I've dined at Park Tavern are: the deviled eggs, each topped with a decadent, crunch piece of bacon and the pickled jalepeno makes it one of the best deviled eggs, ever; brussel sprout chips (not to be confused with the side order of brown butter brussel sprouts, which aren't as good); and Demons on Horseback (lardo aka Italian bacon fat wrapped shrimp).

Just thinking about all the yummy goodness has got my mouth pooling with drool!
author: Christina L.

description:
Order the avocado toast. ZOMG. 

Docked 1 star cause the bloody mary was terrible. Maybe it's just me but that shiet is too peppery. However, I do suggest you grab a drink and sit at a table outside on a nice day.
author: Brian L.

description:
Wowowwowowow. Get the deviled eggs and demons on horseback. Everything we ordered was top notch. I'm very very impressed. I would list out ratings for each specification, but I'd just give them five stars for each. Service, atmosphere, drinks, food, pastry chef... All 5 stars. And oh, the pasteries. Chocolate silk mousse was like a cupcake mousse from the great beyond.

This will be the place I bring guests to impress them. As a picky foodie, I officially give Park Tavern the highest seal of approval.
author: Sonya I.

description:
My husband and I stopped in here for drinks months ago, and just recently stopped in again to try out brunch.  

We really liked the decor/feel of the place - reminded us of a place we loved in New York City.  The service was very good, and fast - we couldn't believe how fast our food came out.  Even better than fast - the food was delicious :)

My husband ordered the burger, and I wasn't especially hungry, so I opted for the avocado toast.  The burger was very tasty - the smoky/char taste was very much appreciated!  We also loved the avocado toast - the olive oil that was used was very smooth and yummy - and the chili powder added a nice flare.  

We've decided to try it again for brunch - I think next time I'll go for the crispy polenta cakes, which I would have gotten (in addition to the avocado toast :)) had I been more hungy at the time.   We also would like to pop in for dinner sometime.  

Overall, great food, great service - a fun place for a date with your significant other or dinner/brunch with a group of friends/family.
author: Rachael S.

description:
I celebrated my birthday here with friends. We were seated at a round table which was perfect for our table of 5.  A bit noisy, but it was ok.

We shared the deviled eggs, brussel sprout chips, bacon wrapped prawns, and the venison tartare. All were excellent, but the deviled eggs and bacon wrapped prawns stood out.  It was the bacon on both dishes that made it over the top!

My entree was the pork chop while my partners the lamb.  Both were excellent, but the pork chop more so. It was seasoned and cooked perfectly medium. Not dry as I was concerned, as I wanted it med-rare, but my honey advised not to.

For dessert we shared the birthday cake and apple crisp.  The birthday cake was only for my birthday. It was ok.  But the apple crisp cheddar was Devine. So darn delicious. Sweet, salty, and fruity.  This is the dessert for all dessert lovers!

Services was excellent!

Thank you park tavern for making my birthday memorable!
author: Marck N.

description:
I loved this place.

The food here is excellent. Everything that came out was so good. Tried the brussel spout chips which were yummy. My next favorite was the deviled eggs. It's topped with bacon, and who doesn't love bacon? My main course was the lamb, which was very flavorful. Others on the table had the pork, and I actually like that better than the lamb. The pork was so soft and juicy and full of smokey flavor. My favorite dessert for the night was the apple cheddar crumble. It didn't taste cheesy at all. Just buttery, apple goodness.

Service was excellent. Both the hostess and server were very gracious.
author: Kenson K.

description: Came here on Saturday night to celebrate my birthday. My daughter had called ahead and arranged for a glass of champagne for me so we were off to a great start. Overall our experience was really great. Love the decor, service was excellent, and meal scrumptious! We started with the crispy lemon chips (basically lightly fried thin lemon slices that are crispy, salty (not too much) served with greens and burrata) - mouth watering deliciousness!  We then shared the Park Tavern Salad - a salad with green goddess dressing which was a flashback to the 90s (earlier?). Another yummy dish. I had the lamb entree which was cooked perfectly and served with roasted purple broccoli and potatoes. I made the mistake of ordering a side of brussel sprouts - don't get me wrong - they were also delicious but just too much to eat.  My husband enjoyed his pork dish as well. At the end of the meal the waiter brought a slice of birthday cake - coconut - there is always room for dessert! a perfect end to a great meal. Wish there was such a thing as 4 1/2 stars cuz this was definitely one of the better meals I've had recently. Will absolutely be back.
author: Karen O.

description:
Park Tavern really is as good as it gets for this style of food.  Perfect in preparation and the staff if great.

I had the Brussels Sprout Chips and the Smoked Deviled Eggs for starters and they both should be on your must try list.  I also tried the Truffle Fries and they did not disappoint.  Crispy on the outside, tender in and with great flavor.  The scallops were also prepared perfectly.

I can't say much about the liquor as I stuck to wine the times I've been here but friends have said they are solid on their drink preparation as well.

Great food, great service.  All I could ask for!
author: Michael W.

description: What is the point of good food if the service doesn't match it?  I'm sure we got delt a bad hand but this restaurant missed the details for us today.  Food was terrific,  service was below average.  We waited 2 hours when they told us 45 minutes for a table.  We sat outside in the sun and I overheated because they forgot to turn the heaters off so I sat there baking until I realized in 45 minutes I was about to pass out.  They gave us complimentary appetizers for the wait but then both of them showed up on the bill which we had to ask for it to be removed.  We ordered & they didn't enter everything in the computer so food was missing.  Then the kitchen was closed so I ended up with no meal.  I got complimentary pastries instead. Nice gesture. Everything just took an extreme amount of time.  We put in our name at noon and finished lunch at 4pm. What a terrible waist of our day.  4 hours!
author: Jennifer D.

description:
If you want a classy brunch with a menu full of unique yet tasteful meals this is the place. It allows for all ages alike, young and old. With a full service bar and community table, along with both outdoor and indoor table this bar/restaurant is bound to be a top spot for locals and tourists! I will most definitely be returning! 
The avocado toast is to die for!
author: Lani A.

description: The toast was so tough it cut the roof of your mouth. The deviled eggs were tiny. The mocha was so watery it felt neither like coffee or chocolate. The coffee cake was dry but had great lemon flavor. The one best quality of this place was their blueberry and huckleberry compotes. Price seemed more than it should have. Won't be coming back.
author: R P.

description:
----------BRUNCH ONLY-----------
Since Marlowe is my favorite restaurant, it was a no-brainer to try this place out. GREAT setting for brunch, pretty big restaurant, and such a great menu. You know it's a good restaurant when you want to come back just to try the rest of the menu (the rest of the brunch menu, the lunch menu, the dinner menu!)

Avocado Toast with chile, lemon & sea salt - Simple concept executed so well. It's exactly what it says it is but it tastes way better than I imagined it. 
Warm Baguette with 3 nut butters - The baguette is a little bit on the way harder side (but some people might like that) but the nut butters were really great flavors. We even had a bet going on at our table as to what was what. Good for sharing with the group. 
Cast Iron Farm Eggs with spinach and prosciutto - What a solid meal. It's not too much and it's not too little, it's just right. Very savory but doesn't leave you feeling like you want to throw up 
Veal Schnitzel with bacon fat-basted eggs, spinach and anchovies - How can you say no to anything that is "bacon fat-basted"?! It's definitely a heavier dish so it's a good share with the table but the savory dish is definitely worth getting.

Parking is terrible but if you're not driving, then that's irrelevant for you to know! 

Definitely want to come back and try the rest of the menus.
author: Diana Y.

description:
great brunch spot in North Beach. we made a reservation online and were seated exactly on time. staff was great. not just our waiter but everyone who came to the table.

I had a bloody mary to start which was super spicy with horseradish and cracked pepper, served with a pickled green bean and piece of beef jerky. really great. my two guests had the hummingbird cocktail which was a mimosa with elderflower liqueur and was two sweet for them (I liked it) but the waiter whisked them away and substituted regular mimosas (no charge for the first cocktails). which, in a nice restaurant, should be status quo, but it's still nice to see this level of service.

the deviled eggs were delicious. we should have ordered more. and the avocado toast is also highly recommended. for mains we had the corned beef hash with poached egg (I would have preferred two eggs but it came with only one) and crispy polenta. both were excellent. the people next to us had the other two dishes we were considering and they looked fantastic too. next time we'll order those (cast iron eggs with spinach and gruyere cheese and the smoked salmon Benedict, yum)

it's a really nice space inside, not the dark, woody pub feel you might expect with "Tavern" in the name. but lots of natural light, high ceilings and tile floors. there are a few outdoor tables. valet parking is $12. we'll be back!
author: Bob U.

description:
Went for a fantastic late dinner at the Park Tavern - which featured friendly and attentive service; creative and delicious preparations of staples; and a vibrant atmosphere.

The Brussels Sprouts chips live up to the hype, the fried lemons are amazing, and the burger was executed impressively. Also don't visit without trying the deviled eggs.

My only regret is that I didn't save room for dessert.
author: Benny R.

description:
Outstanding location and ambiance.
Simple but complete menu.
Good burger and correctly prepared fish.
Get reservations or drop in and share the community counter which is well done.
author: Del M.

description: As we had a party of 8 was able to try many appetizers.  All were both interesting and delicious. The clam chowder was good but not amazing.   The wood fired pork chop was really satisfying and tasty with many layer of flavors.   I would be very happy to eat again here soon.
author: Jayn J.

description:
VERDICT: Food was not good, Drinks were expensive

QUALIFIER: We came in a group of 10, so we made a reservation, but they could only offer a party size 8+ a fixed menu for $65 each!. There were selections for each of the 3-courses, but they weren't that good.

FOOD: The shared food/chip appetizers were too salty, sour, and bland. The entrees were alright. The deserts weren't good. Lemon chips, Brussels sprout chips, carrot salad, pumpkin soup, roasted chicken, sea bass, birthday cake, and creme brule. 

SERVICES: Waitress forgot to take my drink order.
author: Harry T.

description:
This is a brunch review. 

And I could not be more satisfied with my experience. What a fabulous restaurant and I can't believe it's taken me 2 years since its birth to get here. 

The venue is fantastic - high ceilings, lots of space, outside seating (the sun, when out, always hits north beach nicely), and modern-rustic decor. This would be a good place to take your out-of-town family for brunch rather than a girls mimosa thing. 

The service...wonderful! Given the older, more serious, and well-dressed demographic, I was expecting some attitude when my friends and I rolled in our in Sperry's and t shirts. It wasn't so. Not only that, we had about a 3 hour brunch discussing important things like yoga class logistics, breakups, and pedis (I know, #marinagirlproblems) and not once were we given looks or hints to leave...as a matter of fact, the server who didn't even have our area refilled our water as we gossiped and figured out our early-twenties lives. 


The food - very, very good. I recommend: 

1. Open-faced deviled egg sandwich with chicken and jalapeno. The jalapeno adds a great kick to the entree. 

2. Crispy polenta cakes. Interesting mix of poached eggs on top of lightly fried polenta. I really appreciated the contrast in textures of these two. And mushrooms came with this dish. They were fantastic. 

3. Marlowe burger. I don't eat beef, but my friend was very satisfied. 

This is not one of those absurd wait-time brunch places, but they do take reservations, so call ahead.
author: Meghana D.

description: I came here for a work dinner, and it was absolutely wonderful! We thoroughly enjoyed the private room they gave us, the preselected menu, and the service. They have valet parking which was extremely helpful! I don't go into the city very often, but this was a very enjoyable experience.
author: S T.

description:
I have dined at Park Tavern at least 8 times over the past 3-4 years and have had excellent food, cocktails and service on every visit! 

On my most recent visit, Park Tavern arranged a dinner for my group of friends (10 people) with a pre-fixed menu featuring several favorites (e.g. Deviled Eggs, Marlow Burger, Red Snapper, Maple Crème Brulee). And once again... Park Tavern nailed it!  

Having lived in North Beach for over 15 years, I can happily say Moose's has been supplanted... Park Tavern is as solid as you can get in North Beach.

Cheers!
author: Marc H.

description:
Wonderful food, but you need a reservation. we ate the avocado toasts (delightful), peaches and berries (yum), chicken burger (amazing but bun was dry), hash (lukewarm and not enough beef), and the polenta cakes-- which were the winner! 

I'd come again. Service was a bit slow, but the restaurant was packed.
author: Katie M.

description:
Food- 1/5 Overly salty. Never returning to eat

Value- 1/5

Ambiance- 4/5 Great ambiance with dim lighting and a good busy atmosphere.

Service- 5/5 Excellent service that attempted to help correct the food issues

DISHES TASTED

Smoked Deviled Eggs- 1/5 Overly salty

Pt Fries- 4/5 Edible, the best I could ask for here.

Cacciucco- 1/5 Had to send back twice. Totally inedible due to over salted.

Duo of Colorado Lamb- 1/5 Didn't bother sending back. Ate a few bites before I was overwhelmed with salt.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
We came here on a Sunday evening during the holiday season.  Parking is difficult, but we found one on the street near the Washington park.  This is the old Moose's restaurant location, which was written about so much by columnist Herb Caen.  Sat at the bar at first and had beers and the brussel sprout chips, which were very good and innovative.  Good Ninnkasi IPA on draft.

We had the PT fries and crab salad for starters, which were both very good.  Kudos for creativity on the egg and caviar dipping sauce for the fries.  We went with the seafood for the entrees:  Atlantic cod with fennel and pearled onions was very good and the seared scallops with kale and ham were good.  We skipped dessert, and just had press pot decaf, which was good.

Service was very good, nice interior, and the atmosphere was lively and festive.  The menu had good gluten-free options.  I would consider going back and trying some of the meat entrees next time.
author: Dan L.

description: Excellent service - very efficient, fast, and pleasant.   Excellent food - try the avocado toast and deviled eggs!
author: T L.

description:
Truffle fries... I cannot get you off my mind!!

We came here with a huge party and started off with drinks and apps. The waiter was super friendly giving personal suggestions and letting us take our time to chat, sip our wine, and review the menu.

Some of the dishes were a hit or a miss, but the apps were all very superb. We had the brussel sprout chips, deviled eggs, and cheese fondue. But the star app was definitely the truffle fries. The fries were accompanied by a soft-cooked egg with caviar as well as an aioli. Yummy gooey delish!

For the main courses, we tried almost everything but the star of the table was the "poulet noir" which was a poulet in command on a cast iron pan with onion stuffing below to soak in all the goodness. All that goodness was accompanied by a brown truffle sauce which the waiter poured over the chicken upon service. Yum! If you are a Californian eater, I suggest you split this since it was huge!  The braised beef short ribs came in as the 2nd most favorite on the table. 

For dessert, the buttermilk panna cotta with mandarin wedges, oats, and toasted oats was perfect - not too sweet, deliciously creamy, and very clean and light. 

This would be the perfect place for a date or to grab a glass of wine with snacks (highly recommend the truffle fries!) after a long day at work. The ambiance, service, and food were all excellent!
author: Grace G.

description: Food was very good with some unique items including the Lemon crisps. Lively atmosphere. No refills on soda and slightly overpriced.
author: Mindy S.

description:
Given that this is the 3rd, possibly 4th place I've been to in this location, you might surmise the site is cursed but you'd surmise wrongly.  "Moose's" was special and had a good, long run.  "Frankie & Johnny's" followed with great food but a tired, out of favor concept.  Now we're back in "Moose's" territory with a better menu, better food, stellar service, and that undefinable X-factor that makes all the women look  beautiful and all the men look rich.    

Having done some early reconnaissance, I knew that it'd be no meal at all unless I sprung for the Deviled Eggs ($2 each, topped with bacon and jalapenos) and the "Brussels Sprout Chips" ($7).  Holy crap, those two things plus a couple glasses of that Rose Prosecco ($12 each) and I was sated on the umami flavors:  salty, spicy, fatty, and rich.  

Went on to sample a "Tuna Conserva" ($8) which tasted luscious atop grilled, sliced baguette.  

The way to dine here and still stash away a little dough is to opt for one of the richest, butteriest, best burgers around.  At $14, in this locale, it's a steal.  My dining companions ordered all sorts of other stuff but I was too consumed with the glorious riches before me so who knows what they were eating.  

I walked outside to find a gaggle of tourists still standing there on the northeast side of Washington Square Park, with cameras aimed at Coit Tower, all lit up in Giants Orange.  Park Tavern is a beautiful place from which to begin your evening.
author: Tracey A.

description: My husband and I were given a gift card to this restaurant as a wedding present and were very excited to try it out. We went during dinner and I ordered their steak while my husband went with the pork chop. We each also got cocktails, I got a white wine and my husband got an old fashioned. The food was by far the best dinner we've had in San Francisco. The sides of our entrees had such amazing flavor and the meats were cooked to absolute perfection. Everything is worth the price as your tastebuds are in for the greatest treat in life. Their menu is New American which is a twist on all of our favorite American meals. You will not regret your visit to Park Tavern and strongly recommend making a reservation as it is a very popular spot.
author: Cindy G.

description:
I can't help but feel that Park Tavern is coasting. Kind of getting-away-with-it and laughing all the way to the bank.

Not that it's bad. It's not bad at all.. but it's a premium priced establishment which 'only' offers good food.

PT seems to have reached that critical mass of popularity at that price point of which restauranteurs must dream - it's always packed, and judging by the crowd it's a Destination eatery in the city at the weekend for bridges and tunnels folks.

What you get:

- Location: On Washington Square, so it looks kind of pretty but parking is a disaster unless you valet.
- Great space (think classic NYC brasserie feel)
- Without a reservation, probably 45mins-1 hour wait. Although there is bar seating and a first come, first served communal table which is a nice touch.
- Menu: modern Californian, with a few nice twists. I like the brunch menu the best, and specifically the polenta cakes with mushrooms, avocado toasts and pastries. The famous 'Marlowe Burger' is also well thought of by the burger-eating community. 
- The Bloodies are worth checking out. As a beer person, I'm always disappointed with the draft selection - but then, it's not really their thing. Wine list is fine.

My issue is one of price and consistency. If the service and food was consistently excellent, I would feel like PT was about 15% overpriced but I'd still come back once in a while especially if I lived nearby, or wanted a boozy brunch in a nice space - possibly for a birthday or something. But the fact is they have consistency issues - the service can get surprisingly sloppy when it gets really busy (which it often does), and for a premium price you do expect the food to be on-the-money every time (which it isn't) - soggy burger buns, overcooked eggs have been served up to my party more than once.

Exec Summary: You can do better for the money.
author: Matt G.

description: Excellent food even better service.  Heather was incredibly on it and very concerned that our guest experience was top notch.  We came in for a special occasion and Heather was even concerned with making sure other guests around us respected our space and experience.  And I haven't even said how impressed we were with the food!  We would highly recommend this to anyone for food, service, location, and vibe.  Thank you, Heather, for making our night exceptional.
author: C E.

description: I was in town visiting my sister, who lives in cool SF, and she brought me to Park Tavern for a late brunch on Sunday. We walked over from Nob Hill, chatting and enjoying the SF vibes. She made a reservation for us so when we got there we only waited a few minutes and our table was ready. They sat us, per her request, in the section over by the window. She recommended we start with the cinnamon challah, and woah, that did NOT disappoint. It was DELICIOUS. Soooo buttery and cinnamony, ah, wish I could have had a few more pieces to myself! :D For my entree I got the smoked salmon eggs benedict, which were not your traditional ones, on english muffins, but instead it was on a piece of toast. It was very tasty! After my meal, though, I still wanted a little something more (mostly because all of their starters and sides sounded so good) so I ordered some toast with jams. Those were just ok. The bread was way too tough, kinda painful to eat, too chewey, and the jams were meh. But besides that last part, everything else was great! I'd definitely come back to this spot. Just be aware, it's very loud in there, so make sure you don't bring your mom/dad here!
author: Ally T.

description:
You must get the Venison Carpaccio. I don't even remember how the entrees tasted nor do I care, because they were completely overshadowed by how good the carpaccio was. The beef tartare was prepared really well. It had a very good balance of citrusy acid with the sweetness of the onions and beef. 

All of that doesn't matter once you eat the crispy bone marrow. Each crunchy cube of deep fried bone marrow exploded with rich, savory, beefy goodness. I could keep eating those scrumptious pieces of heaven until they'd have to wheelbarrow me out. Although they're amazing on their own, they also enhanced the rest of the dish. Not only do they provide a crunchy contrast to the soft tartare and tender carpaccio, they also lend a rich fatty undertone to the otherwise raw and fresh nature of the other ingredients. The ingenious use of flavors and textural contrasts combined with the perfect balance of this dish make it a must have appetizer. Actually, forget what I said; skip it. I just want it all for myself!
author: Nei N.

description:
Food is Ok, but not amazing especially given the premium prices -- given the many AMAZING brunch places in SF, I would not put Park Tavern as a top.  I had every intention to show off SF brunch to our visiting family and took them here -- but I think all they will remember were the high prices..

We ordered:
--Banana Coconut Fritters ($8) -- similar to donut holes but fried as fritters.  There are real coconut shreds inside the banana flavored batter.  Comes with a strawberry and chocolate dipping sauce.  A fun and tasty treat
--Smoked Salmon Benedict ($17) -- Single faced benedict.  Lots of smoked salmon, but nothing particularly good about it.  I found the portion to be very small.
