--Cast Iron Farm Eggs ($15) -- really underwhelming.  Cast iron did not do much to the eggs flavor.  Just basically a tiny pan of spinach, cheese, and eggs.  My fiancé was not happy with his order and had to snack again soon after the meal given the tiny portion...
--Chicken Sandwich ($14) -- probably the best thing we ordered.  Pile of fried chicken between a Kaiser roll with apple cider slaw.  Came with a fried pickle too, which was a nice touch :).

Nice to have tried it, but probably won't come back if I'm planning brunch.
author: Kendra W.

description: This is a great place with delicious drinks and food items. The polenta cakes are not to be missed for brunch, with the crispy outside and soft inside, this dish is just fantastic. When they have the lemon birthday cake for dessert, get two pieces of it because you've never had cake this moist and soft. I'm not a fan of the burger though, the meat tastes too smoky like it's absorbed smoke from the grill. The hosting team is super nice and they take the time to get to know you by name of you come regularly.  Beautifully situated by Washington Square Park,  it's a great spot to enjoy the North Beach neighborhood or the park if you go during brunch.
author: Daniel S.

description:
Food: 4
Decor: 4
Service: 3

Came here for a work brunch on a Saturday around 12:30pm.

1. Oregon Bay Shrimp, 12
Creamy harissa, chives & lemon
~Pretty good. Tasty shrimp on toasted bread.

2. Jam, Jelly & Marmalade
Made in house with beurremont 83% butter
~Pretty good. 

3. Three Nut Butters
Made in house with chestnut honey
~Pretty good.

4. Smoked Deviled Egg
Bacon, pickled jalapeño & chive
~Really good, and I'm usually not a fan of deviled eggs.

5. Pan-Fried Corned Beef Hash*
Crispy potato, poached egg, arugula & red wine jus
~Okay. A bit heavy, but still decent.

6. Carrot cake
~Pretty good, and I'm not a fan of carrot cakes.

Service was pretty good. Overall, a great brunch place (although we ended up spending over $50 per person).
author: David L.

description:
The atmosphere is great, the servers are very friendly and very helpful without being too overbearing, and the several cocktails I've had so far have all been excellent. 

Their food is good, and seasoned well, but almost TOO well....although I think the flavours of their food is great,I find most of the dishes there a bit too salty. I've tried a salad, the brussel sprout chips, the parmesan truffle fries, and their burger so far, but all seemed to be a bit heavy handed on the salt - but not too much so that I would send it back. My fiance loves salt, so he thought everything tasted great, so I think it may be a matter of preference. 

Also, there was one time where we ordered two of their devilled eggs, one regular and one without bacon since my fiancé does't eat pork. They brought it out but both had bacon on it, so we politely informed our waiter that we had ordered one without pork and if we could get another made fresh without the bacon. He smiled, took the dish back to the kitchen, and the seemingly same plate came out less than a minute later...it seemed like they just took out the bacon one of the eggs and sent the same plate back out. We didn't want to ask for it again, so my fiancé ended up not eating his egg and I ate both. 

Realistically, since it's a casual place very close to my house and with good ambience I'll probably go back again, particularly for their drinks. But if I lived further out, I probably wouldn't bother to go back.
author: Anna H.

description:
I came here with a friend from out of town. I didn't want to deal with waiting 1.5 - 2 hours to eat brunch, so I decided to come here on a recommendation of a friend. Plus for having lots of open reservations on OpenTable, beautiful ambiance and decor. The food was solid, a bit on the pricier side, and didn't exactly knock my socks off.

Whole wheat toast with avocado, lemon, chili, and salt ($7) - We ordered this to share. It was good, but tastes like what you'd imagine it would taste like. Toast with avocado and a hint of lemon and spice. You can make this at home. I'd save your $7.

Confit chicken & potato hash, wild arugula & poached egg ($16) - The waitress said this was the best thing on the menu, so I had to try it (my friend and I split this and the polenta cakes). I didn't think it was the best thing on the menu. It's basically rotisserie chicken with potatoes, very little arugula and egg. It was not bad, but I was underwhelmed.

Crispy polenta cakes, wild mushrooms, poached eggs, wild arugula, truffle salsa verde & shaved parmesan ($15) - I thought this was the best - the polenta cakes were delicious, the truffle oil was abundant and all the flavors meshed together well. The yolk from the poached egg was delicious when mixed with the polenta cake.

All in all, it was a nice brunch with a great decor, and I was happy I didn't have to wait for an absurd time in line. It isn't the best brunch in the city, but the food is still great and a nice place to take guests. I was laughing at the people (or rather, tourists) waiting in line at Mama's - I was in and out of this place in one hour.
author: Christina L.

description:
We had a clam chowder soup that was ok. My husband  said he had better ones before. 
We had crispy lemon chips, wich I liked and we had also a PT fries. The fries were delicious and came with a pretty good sauce and an egg with caviar on top. You can't taste the caviar, actually, because the strong taste of the soft egg. 
Our waiter was a little rude. 3 stars are fair enough!
author: Valéria M.

description: Love this place - beautiful decor, amazing service, and the food is exquisite! Love the deviled eggs! Open Friday daytime for "3 martini lunch" The staff is also amazing!
author: Tamas G.

description: One of the best in SF! Always a go-to and must-try if you haven't! Park tavern will quickly become your favorite spot for great drinks and even better food.
author: Katie H.

description:
One tasty brunch joint (and good for dinner as well, but this review is just for brunch).

Came here on a Sunday morning about 30 minutes before our reservation time and grabbed a few seats at the bar to start off on some libations (orange juice mimosas, grapefruit juice mimosas, and a bloody mary made with beef stock.. super hearty) and avocado toasts while we waited. The toast was delicious, don't get me wrong, but not worth the $10 in my opinion. We also nibbled on some banana coconut fritters before our meals, but they were a little too fried-tasting for me and not really a light bite before the main event.

The brunch entrees, however, were divine. I ordered the cast-iron baked eggs (without the ham), two of us ordered the smoked salmon benedict, and another went for the Marlowe Burger. My eggs were cooked to perfection and were topped with just the right amount of gruyère to give them a nice bite without being over-indulgent. My fellow brunchers all gobbled up their dishes with high praises, though I didn't happen to try any of them (other than a couple of those golden, crispy, delicious fries).

On top of good food, the service was really impressive. Our waiter and his shadower were charming, friendly, attentive, and perfect on their timing and offerings.

I'd come back here for brunch again in a heartbeat.
author: Amy S.

description:
I have dined here twice and both visits have been stellar experiences.

My recent visit was for our six year anniversary.

For starters we had the deviled eggs and the lemon chips with burrata. 

The deviled eggs are by far the best I have ever had. We ordered two and immediately ordered two more before we were finished swallowing the first two.

The lemon chips were on point. I was worried they might be slightly bitter, but the were bright crispy bites that paired well with the burrata. They are also served with some fresh fine herbs that take it to the next level.

Our second course was the Panissa with fresh peas/snap peas and mint. This was one of the best dishes I have ever had. It was bright fresh and cooked perfectly! I could have ordered several of these for dinner and been completely satiated.

For third course we had the Ribeye and the Wild Ling Cod. The Cod was out of this world. It was served with roasted sunchokes, sunchoke purée, & baby fennel. The fish was executed perfectly and the set was as well.

The ribeye was cooked to perfect medium, and was seasoned well. The set was pretty standard fair for a steak dish (i.e. blue lake beans & potato purée)

For dessert we had the strawberry shortcake on a biscuit. It was a pleasantly light finish to a large and indulgent meal.

To really take it to the top the service was completely seamless/flawless!

This is without a doubt my new favorite establishment.
author: Soulfire L.

description:
I was here last night for a party of 9 for a friend's birthday.

The 5 stars are only for the PT (Park Tavern) fries with truffle, soft-cooked egg and caviar. While the fries a little on the saltier side, but it works and is balanced with the egg and caviar dipping sauce.

The 5 stars are also for the Blood Orange Creamsicle. It is vanilla panna cotta, blood orange sorbet (ask for an extra scoop for $3), and rum caramel blood orange. This is by far the best panna cotta I have had. A great taste, panna cotta consistency and density, and the sorbet and rum oranges go delicately with this dessert.

It turns out the pastry chef is James Beard winner, Emily Luchetti, who joined within the last 3 months at Park Tavern. I have always been a fan of the molten cake at Waterbar and she helped launch Waterbar's dessert program.

http://insidescoopsf.sfgate.com/emily-luchetti-bio/

I am going to be picking up some of her cookbooks too. :-) She is fast becoming one of my favorite executive pastry chefs.

I also had a grilled pork chop with a brown butter apple puree. I like it a medium temperature, so it came out great and yet the meat was still juicy.

The table nibbles worth mentioning are the deviled eggs and brussels sprout chips.

The food tended to be on the heavier side in terms of taste and salt, so just be aware.

Our table reservation took a little bit longer for us to get seated, but appreciate the complimentary champagne to keep us company.
author: Joseph Y.

description:
Reservations is a must. Don't walk in here like I did and learn the hard way. We ended up standing around waiting for a space to open up at the bar for 45 mins. It wasn't fun. The place was packed and you really have to snatch any seat that opens up.

Anyway, thankfully the food was worth the wait. Marlowe burger ($14), you really can't beat that burger. It was simple but it's simply the best. We also had the brussels sprout chips ($7) and the deviled eggs ($2 ea). The brussels sprout chips were ok. The first few bites were great but then it got really salty. I would not order that again. The eggs however were really good. We also had the poulet rouge ($26), presentation was awesome. The meat was tender and juicy, however, it was kind of bland. The veggies at the bottom of the plate was flavorful but the chicken was not. For dessert, we had the panna cotta ($7). It was good but not spectacular. 

Street parking sucks in that area. Luckily they have valet.
author: Andy W.

description:
Meh is right. 
I think the best dish, which isn't even a meal, are the Truffle Fries. Not going to lie they're the bomb.com/10/fierce. 

I ordered take out from them several times and everything was pretty good, esp the truffle fries with the caviar egg.. omg! 

I had friends from out of town visiting and we had dinner reservations.Granted I wasn't very hungry and my friends meal was just "off". The service sucked. It took over 20 min to place our order and then we were asked by the manager to basically hurry and leave (not his words) as they have other reservations.. etc. 

So, if we were popping bottles and ordering tons of food would they have still asked us to "leave"? 

I will not be taking friends there; I'll stick to take out.
author: Nads Y.

description: What the hell did they put in the chicken?! I went here for a private work event and was able to get a boatload of leftovers and have been munching on this chicken for days now. The skin, oh the skin, on this chicken is incredible. My only complaint was it was so good, that I couldn't wait to heat up the leftovers and ate the chicken cold. Still incredible. All the others dishes were  on par for an upscale restaurant in SF and the scene seemed pretty lively on a Friday night. But damn, that chicken though.
author: Louis D.

description: Very very good. I had the hen which is a huge meal but it was worth it in the end. So flavorful. I also recommend the deviled eggs and the Brussels sprout chips for apps. They are outstanding. It's pricey, but the atmosphere and quality of service/food are top quality.
author: Chad W.

description: Incredible dinner at the Park Tavern in North Beach. Brussels sprout chips, pork chops, truffled chicken and Moscow Mules.
author: Greg M.

description: Another must visit brunch spot in San Francisco. The avocado toast is a must for appetizers, you can also order refreshing pitchers of John Daly's! When I ate here there was a group of young women behind me celebrating an engagement, two old women seated to my right catching up, and a group of guys enjoying bloody's and burgers to my left - the ambience and menu is perfect for gatherings of all kind.
author: Rebekah C.

description: Love love! Excellent and attentive service! Appetizer Demons on Horseback (tiger prawns) was magnificent! Roasted cauliflower was very tasty! Carrot salad hubby loved. Then I had the rib eye and hubby had pork chop, equally delicious! French fries is such a simple dish yet so perfectly done! It was my birthday celebration, got a slice of December Birthday cake on the house, perfect way to end an evening!!!!!! Will definitely go back
author: Wendy L.

description: I had the pleasure to eat a Sunday brunch here. Delicious food, stylish interior, homey service - just what you need when travelling alone for business.
author: Arttu N.

description:
Quaintly appropriate for a couple of successful, career oriented, single SF girls to catch up over a perfect carafe of Syrah, some burgers and deviled eggs.  Our bartender, a shame we did not catch his name, made our experience delightful.

I waited a year to come here and it definitely did not disappoint.  Definitely in my top 3 of favorites in SF.
author: Noey A.

description:
We had an excellent meal here last night.  The brussel sprout chips are amazing.  So was the chocolate mouse and the sarsaparilla sazrac.  

We sat at the communal seating, so are service wasn't spectacular.  A few of the drinks were misses (the negroni was nearly undrinkable).  But otherwise it was a good meal.
author: Jessica A.

description:
A very poor value for the money. While the food was tasty and well prepared, the portions were meager and not particularly inspired (steak with chips, not exactly groundbreaking).

For the price, this place should do a lot more to impress, and currently it's just another overpriced tourist trap in North Beach.
author: Luca C.

description: Awesome experience, great customer service, excellent food - there's a reason it's hard to get a reservation here. The staff went above and beyond to help celebrate a special anniversary for my wife and me. One of our favorite places in San Francisco.
author: Griffin G.

description:
Two words: TRUFFLE. FRIES.

Because I ate this as an appetizer, this set the pallet for the rest of the night. Unfortunately, I was a little disappointed with my meal because it wasn't as great as the fries. I mean, I get it... Anything with truffle is amazing, I just thought the food would be just as good.

Service was good, but not the greatest.

Four stars are dedicated to the ambiance and truffle fries. I'll be back for those.
author: Sammie T.

description:
A somewhat fancy place for brunch or dinner. We were able to get a reservation through Yelp the day before, which was important, because most other popular brunch places have long weekend waits.

Deviled eggs = great
Salmon benedict = just alright, would try something else next time

There's not a wide selection of savory brunch items. Didn't particularly stand out, but would come back to check out their dinner menu.

Very spacious. Not very loud, good for conversations. No pressure to leave right after eating.
author: An Y.

description:
Came to celebrate two of my girlfriends getting married with a group of 7, had a variety of dishes and all were nicely executed and delicious. The waitress was nice, water refilled promptly,  and two desserts on the house as a congrats! 

Apps: deviled eggs, demons on horseback, PT fries, tomato tarts, crispy panissa. Great starters, my favorites being the deviled eggs and the tomato tart. 
Sides: twice baked potatoes, roasted corn, pickled fried green tomatoes, and roasted brussel sprouts. I loved the brussel spouts, soft with a hint of brown sugar, they were delicious. 
Entrees: poulet noir, grassfed ribeye, and pork chop. All the meats were juicy, tender and paired perfectly with their sides. 
Dessert: cherry rhubarb crumble and chocolate silk: the warm cherry and rhubarb crumble had just enough tart and just enough sweetness, the perfect combo to end a meal with. The chocolate silk was a little rich, one bite was enough for me. 

Thanks for a great meal and a start to a great celebration.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Park Tavern was the highlight of an already stellar outing on a school night.  Coming from Biergarten and Tonga Room, it'd be hard to impress me and 2 guests from NYC.  But Park Tavern is just as good if not better than I remembered.  
I came back for the sprout chips but was wowed by everything else.  We GORGED ourselves like gluttons.  We ordered the burger, the demons on horseback, the brussel sprouts and deviled eggs, and that was JUST the appetizers for 3 people!!!
All were excellent and sinful.  
Main courses were the juiciest pork chop I've ever had (take that NoPa!), a delicate steelhead trout which was almost upstaged by the risotto and wood ear mushrooms on the side, and the red snapper with butter beans (the snapper was the weakest item but it was pretty good).  If that wasn't enough, we threw in the cheese drenched twice baked potato.

And you can't skip a Jennifer Puccio dessert, so we went for the lightest thing we could find, the panna cotta which was a refreshing finish to send us on our way to the new bar Benjamin Cooper from the guys behind BIG.  
All in all, a success of excess.  
Now for some salad.
author: Christian W.

description:
Have been looking forward to trying out this neighborhood restaurant for a while. Finally had the opportunity to check it out for Sunday brunch with a group of friends. One great plus is that they do accept reservations and you can find them on OpenTable.

The restaurant itself is beautifully done, classic and modern which matches the food being served. They have a great selection of dishes for brunch that covers everything from vegetarian options to great American breakfasts. The wife had the Crispy Polenta Cakes that she describes as "delish." I had the Cast-Iron Baked Farm Eggs which was also an awesome dish. The food is heavy, but the portion is reasonable. The quality is very high which allows them to charge the premium prices that they do.

So why only 3 stars, you're asking yourself. Well, when we were first sat and our waiter came to take our drink order, he was obviously disappointed that we were not ordering alcoholic drinks. The whole backside of the menu is dedicated to cocktails, beer, wine, etc. But, you know, not everyone is looking to get shwasty pants in the middle of the day on a Sunday. That should not change the way that the waiter treats you. Plus, technically and for etiquette you're not required to tip on alcohol anyways, so y'know. 

Anyways, we enjoyed our time and one of the other members of our party had her diet coke refilled a few times throughout the meal. When we received our bill at the end she was charged full price (somewhere around $3) each time they refilled her drink. What place does that? I understand if they're coming out with a small bottle/can each time that they would charge you. But when they're filling it at the fountain? You definitely do not expect it to be charged. If you are going to charge, at least say that when you're offering a refill and not make it seem like it's a complimentary service.

Regardless, we brought this to our waiter's attention and he did take the additional charges off of the bill. Again acting slightly disappointed with us. I will definitely be back to give them another chance, perhaps at dinner when I will be ordering a cocktail, but when you're already paying a premium price it's annoying to leave feeling like they were trying to nickel and dime you.
author: Ben B.

description:
What an awesome place to hang out, drink, eat and have a good time!

My 2 girlfriends and I went there on a Friday night. 
We left our cars with the valet which is $12 flat, cash only, great option! Way better than tired yourself trying to find parking! 
It was packed but we found places to seat by the bar and we were so amazed by how great the service and food is! 
JACK the Bartender is really the best and all the other bartenders are so nice and friendly too, they are there to make sure you have a good time! 
I had the Maryettas Bubbles to start and it was good, not too sweet! We also had a bootle of a house champagne which was so good, can't go wrong with bubbles right?!
To eat we just had appetizers that were to die for!!!! We shared: 
- PT Fries - I had no idea how wonderful french fries dipped in a soft boiled egg with caviar could taste - You must trie this dish!
- Brussels sprouts Chips - how can they make it taste so delicious and crispy?! Even who don't like brussels sprout would eat this!
- Smoked deviled eggs - really yummy and the pepper inside the egg gives it the perfect kick! I didn't eat the bacon that comes on top of the egg but my friends said that it was so good! 
And after those 3 dishes we got kind full so we jumped straight to desert, we tried the October's Birthday Cake, it was good but the appetizers wowed me more!!!
Overall was such an awesome experience! I can't wait to go back there and have the Pt Fries again and try some more of their food!!!
author: Iza K.

description:
Park Tavern is delicious! Don't hesitate to make a reservation (FYI - they have a lot more availability than OpenTable would lead on - so call them up, because you definitely don't want to get stuck there at 5:30pm when it's kids' hour).

5 Stars (must try):
- Truffle Fries - seriously - order them! You will not regret it! In fact you'll decide right then and there upon tasting truffle fries dipped in egg that this is reason enough to make a recurring reservation at Park Tavern!
- Brussels Sprout Chips - light / flavorful / healthy

4 Stars (would definitely order again):
- Demons on Horseback: lardo-wrapped shrimp! need I say more?
- Lemon chips with burrata: unusual, but flavorful and very refreshing / enjoyable

3 Stars (meh):
- Deviled eggs- didn't live up to the hype, but pretty good
- Crab / radish / watermelon salad - likely wouldn't order again - too much radish, not nearly enough anything else (esp crab)

Very noisy restaurant - but worth every decibel for the truffle fries! Can't wait to return!
author: Helen D.

description:
Great meal.  

The lemon chips and burrata are great.  I'm sure you look at them on the menu and think "what's a lemon chip?"  Don't worry about that and just order it.   The deviled eggs are also good, but the lemon chips are where it's at.

My GF had the scallops and I had the Poulet Vert.  She said the scallops were great and the woman at the table next to us was coveting her scallops.  At one point, after hearing the woman continue to talk about the scallops said "why don't you pick up your fork and ask her for some..."  So, if a scallop dish can make your neighbor drool and continue to talk about them, it's probably worth a try.

The poulet vert is good too.  It's a little awkward to eat since it's impaled on the pan (roasted vertically as if it is was on a beer can) but it's really good.  At first, I was like "baked chicken (cornish hen)" that's not really exciting.  But I figured I'd give it try.  (I asked the server what she thought about it, and she said it was as good as Zuni's which I was unimpressed by).  But, I'm glad I tried it.  It was juicy, and definitely a generous serving (I only ate half of it).  

Do yourself a favor, make a reservation and go all out.  I don't think you'll regret it
author: Larry L.

description:
It's too loud. Too loud. Too loud. My ears were buzzing the rest of the night and the next morning, my throat was raspy from yelling in conversation. 

Five of us out to celebrate a friend's birthday. We had a lot of "what?" "Say that again?" to the servers. When the busser asked about clearing my plate, I said, yes, please I'd like this boxed. He didn't hear me, the food was thrown out. 

Excellent service (if you can hear them) and very good food. All lost on me because of how unpleasant the dining experience is.
author: Mama G.

description:
Came here for dinner (not brunch, like 50+% of the reviews seem to be).

The appetizers were great.  I'm usually pretty conservative with my ratings, so that's really saying something.  Brussel sprout chips had some lemon zest that really brightened up the normally greasy (in a good way) dish.  Well seasoned, tasty, and I could easily eat more of it than I should.  Smoked Deviled Eggs, I initially thought they were a tad pricey, but upon consuming, they were really really good.  I'm not a fan of jalapeno, but it worked well here.  The flavors were very well balanced, with the smokey salty crispy bacon, the creamy seasoned egg yolk, a tiny kick/bite from the thin slice of jalapeno, and tiny bit of chives to lighten it up, all coming together magnificently.  PT Fries were fried nice and crispy (but not burnt), and while dipped in the egg with caviar were good, I will never ever say no to truffle aioli.

Mains:  The burger is really good, and stands up to its well deserved reputation in local food blogs/rankings.  Again, it was very well balanced with discreet complementing flavors and textures.  A nicely toasted bun that held up well and didn't get soggy; crisp, with a fair bit of melted butter.  The right amount of cheese and grilled onions, so they don't all fall out on your first bite.  The actual patty, wasn't super awesome on it's own, but combined with everything else, worked really well together.     The chicken was really succulent and tender.  The seasoning isn't too heavy, allowing you to really taste the chicken.  

Decor:  Upscale modern casual, but not overly so.  It wouldn't feel overly out of place taking your parents/family here.  Some tourists, but that's expected for the area.  Acoustics get a bit loud when it fills up.

Waitstaff were great.  Attentive, but not annoyingly so.  Water/drinks attended to swiftly.
author: T C.

description:
Very underwhelmed.

A lot of these dishes were safe and solid.  Really didn't see any innovation in the food but I feel that there's unfortunate expectation that comes with hype.  Decor was fantastic.  Upon asking the waitress/host what she would categorize the atmosphere she responded, "Urban."  I think she saw my disgusted face because Urban Decor is more City-like loft space with grit.  This place has exposed wooden beams, kitchen tiles, arches.  My pretentious response, "this is not Urban.." she responded, "well, call it what you wish, but it's a Tavern so I suppose a Tavern."  She hated me.  Honey - it's Rustic Vintage.

Enough of that and on to the food:
- Deviled Eggs - Great!  But one was enough
- Crispy Lemon Chips - With burata on top!  Was good, but burata is always good.
- Fried Sunchokes - Too close to the sun, because they tasted BURNT and chard 
- Framage Blanc Constini - Like an hor dourves from a wedding... or company party
- Brussels Sprouts Chips - Not that great.. too much chip, not enough Brussels

-Salad - This came with fried chicken skin which didn't work.  Salad with the blue cheese was great, but the innovative part fell through with how unavoidably salty the skin was

-Halibut - This was amazing and really brought up the stars.  Fish was cooked perfectly, the sauce was yummy, I loved it.

--Birthday Cake - Dare I say it?  boxed cake?  No... but I didn't think it was special at all. None of the desserts were exciting and I felt like you could find them at a friend's picnic.

My Level 5 Vegan friend had them create a special menu for her.  To my delight her dishes were off the menu and off the hook. 

I ordered the Twin Peaks drink which tasted similar.. almost... to an Old Fashioned drink with bourbon, but it came out in a strange color and in an awkward martini glass.  We asked for a second round and asked the bartender to put the drink in an Old Fashioned glass.. it just felt better. I'm sure you would agree.  You don't drink bourbon out of a martini glass.

This review is pretentious, but so was the venue so I thought it was appropriate.
author: Chris L.

description:
My friend took us here when we were visiting San Francisco this weekend.  The food was phenomenal.  Get their brussel sprout chips, if they are available.  They were out of them the night we went, but I had them at their sister restaurant once.  This time we ordered the Gnocchi to share.  The gnocchi was crispy on the outside and soft in the middle...perfect!  The gnocchi was surrounded by by a truffled cream sauce and porcini mushrooms.  Not too over whelming at all.

For main dishes we got the Marlowe burger, the wood-fired sole, and the hen.  The hen takes some time to cook so put your order in if you know you want it.  It looks overwhelming when it first comes out, but it is delicious and moist.  The meat is so tender so it's very easy to cut the meat off the bone.  The staff pours au jus over the hen, which helps keep the hen warm and moist.  The stuffing is like the gnocchi, crispy on the outside and yummy goodness on the inside.  My dining patrons loved their dishes as well.

The staff was very friendly and the restaurant atmosphere was really fun.  The bar looked very happening and you can choose to have dinner there too.
author: Payal V.

description:
Absolutely delicious brunch. I tried:

Crispy polenta cakes (mushrooms, arugula, poached eggs, truffle salsa verde, parmesan)
Grapefruit brulee
Huckleberry fritters

All were amazing, and now I need to come back for dinner!
author: K. D.

description: My friend and I were seated at the long bar table for a late night cocktail and dessert last Friday night..  A group of young adults came in and asked us to move down to make room for their large party.  Their crowd got bigger and louder and occupied the vacant seats on our opposite side.  Adrian, the Manager, was very observant and customer satisfaction conscious.  She comped our dessert and cocktail!  What great customer service!  Thank you Adrian!
author: Ed R.

description:
Wanted to go some place special for my boo's birthday and we decided on Park Tavern. 
Although the attire said "casual", one should've taken the restaurants location into consideration. To me, casual means jeans and a t-shirt. Casual for the edge of North Beach/Marina though, means all clothes should be bought at Ambience or similar and to wear 4in stiletto heels. So mind that, cover up your tattoos and you might save yourself some looks from snooty rich kids spending daddy's money.

Now, once you've gotten past the clientele, literally everything is amazing though. 

Food;
We started with the lemon crisps, served with burrata - it was so delicious. Never encountered deep fried, super thin slices of lemon, but it was delightfully tangy, well completed by the sweet and creamy cheese. 
My fiancé had the bar steak for his entrée - it was cooked perfectly and the red wine buttered sauce--to die for. (It's wine and butter. Of course it's good.) 

I had the roasted red snapper, and it was DIVINE. Served with creamy beans and the most flavourful bacon bits I've ever had. The nest of yam on top of the fish provided a nice texture. 
Opted for the gingersnap ice cream sandwich for dessert and again - very good. Not overly spiced, and the ice cream super rich. Comes with chocolate ganache that's extremely decadent. 

Service: 
Immaculate. Nice, friendly and accommodating staff. Water-level consistently full.

Overall, highly recommend Park Tavern. It might not be your go-to-every-evening-place (as it's around $80-100/person) but it's definitely worth several visits. 

PS. Once you're done with dinner, get away from this area asap. Like mentioned, money is all around and money loves to drink. A lot. Like, a looot. (I.e. I saw a man with his pants down, peeing on a car.) Seriously, get out of there.
author: L Stephanie L.

description:
service : AMAZING
food: AMAZING
ambiance: AMAZING
drinks: AMAZING

I love this place. Totally worth your money, great for date night or a nicer dinner. SOLID.
author: Tessa S.

description:
I Liked it a lot first time I was here, and I always love the Brussels sprouts chips, PT fries, and the Marlowe burger, but service was way off the night we went.  Our server was totally disengaged, and it was completely different from all my prior visits.  

the food is always awesome, but the service just really turned everyone off that night. 

Fortunately, the manager, Adrianne, graciously reached out and offered to make up for it.
author: Marilyn H.

description: I took my bf there for his Bday and it was very great place and luvly food,we were so happy with food and restaurant especially with that tasty chicken cake ;-)
author: Nastaran G.

description:
Absolutely delicious brunch. I had the crispy polenta and poached egg, although I have to say the banana fritters the table ordered were the standout. WHAT is in that chocolate/coffee/amazingness sauce? Bloody Mary as good but Very smoky in flavor. The only reason the review is not 5 stars is that the burger my bestie ordered, while highly praised, was maybe too much so? Didn't find it to be one of the best burgers I've tried. 
Great service, we lingered over our food and drinks for quite a while!
author: Magdalena D.

description:
Booked a reservation at Park Tavern a few months ago. Planned a weekend in the city and needed a a great spot to cure the hangover. 

Arguably the best Bloody Mary in the area. The bartenders are witty and sassy- not pretentious-Food was solid. It didn't stand out as spectacular brunch but it did the job. We enjoyed the crab toast, breakfast burger, benedict, and scramble. 

Service was decent and our reserved table was available about 10 minutes after arrival. Recommend the community table or bar for a last minute decision to dine here.
author: Britt D.

description:
We had a ver good time here for dinner.
Started with deviled eggs, carpaccio, asparagus. 
Then we had the crab salad and the salmon.
Everything was very good, but we are not meat-craving people, so I think we didn't enjoy it as much as other people would.
Also, it ended up costing 70+ dollars each, which is expensive for what we had.
Having said that, the staff was very nice, the service fast and everything we had was fresh!
author: Amira T.

description:
Overall: 4.5 Stars.  In this case, I'll give 'em the round up.  

Ambiance: Neat. Relaxed, but still really nice.  

Service: Delightful.  Our server was prompt and attentive (and not too attentive).  Busboys were exceptional and were very pleasant.  Drinks took a little while to get to us, but that's kind of par for the course when you have two or three bartenders handling the bar and the whole restaurant. 

Food: Exceptional.  

Small plates: beef tartar and deviled eggs.  Deviled eggs were AWESOME.  They have some sort of drizzle (which may just be a chive oil) and the jalapenos were a delightful touch.  Liiiiiittle pricey at 2.50 an "egg" (meaning a half egg filled with deliciousness).  Beef tartar was also pretty great, but I'm a beef tartar snob and I have had better.  However, this beef tartar came with mofo bone marrow.  So...yayyyyyyy.

Entrees:  BF had their signature chicken dish after looking it up online and seeing a photo.  It tasted even better than it looked.  Order it--you won't be disappointed.  I saw a four top where literally every single person ordered the dish.  I had the clams, which I never usually order, but am oh so glad I did.  They were really really delicious.  

Dessert: Coffee ice cream sandwiches.  Yes. 

Will I go back? Certainly hope so.
author: Shannon B.

description: My home away from home. It is hard to pinpoint why i visit this restaurant more than most in all of San Francisco. The food is solid, the bar staff is fantastic and always accommodating. everyone is warm and professional. The whole Space is comfortable, the lighting lovely and the Neighborhood charming. No better place for brunch and sunshine and champagne and the Sunday newspaper. Grab a seat at the bar and stay awhile if you haven't tried it out yet.
author: Mollie C.

description: A delicious brunch menu! Came here with some friends from out of town. Great ambiance! Definitely higher end spot for brunch. Between all of us, we tried the polenta cakes, farm egg, short ribs and the deviled eggs. Everything was  plated beautifully and tasted amazing! Can't wait to come back and try it for dinner!
author: Angela E.

description: Had breakfast here because Mama's line was too long...thank goodness!  Service was good and the food was awesome!  If you like deviled eggs...best ever!  Had the smoked salmon benedict  and it was DELISH!  Highly recommended. The place has cool vibe to boot!
author: Bill H.

description:
Came here for brunch on a sat. after waiting to get in to Mama's for 40 minutes.  Glad we did too.  Great food and service with very little wait. Thomas our waiter was fantastic.  Gave us a great recommendation and was super knowledgeable of the menu.

My friend and I had the salmon benedict,oatmeal walnut pancakes and the crispy polenta cakes (all spectacular).  Also Thomas allowed us to modify our pancake order because it was going to be too much food.  So we got one pancake instead of the three that come with the dish. Love restaurants that give you some flexibility.

They also have a great craft beer menu.  If you like IPAs, get the Ninkasi from OR.

In closing, great friendly staff and a fabulous vibe and atmosphere.  Been here twice now and had a fantastic experience both times.
author: Ali M.

description:
Walked in sat at the counter, and started with the venison carpaccio and pickled sardine toast.  Both, good size portions and very tasty.

Next were the truffle, caviar PT fries (i'm not a fry man, but daaamn these are sooo gooood!), and braised lamb tongue (best tongue i've tasted :-)

Finally, wood-oven roasted beets, amazing burst of flavor!

Can't wait to come for brunch, lunch, and another xxx times for dinner!
author: Carlos S.

description:
Do you want your life changed? Get the PT FRIES! They are the best fries I have ever had. In my life. Wonderfully crispy with truffle, a soft boiled egg, and caviar. I never knew such flavors could exist together in complete perfection.

We found PT Tavern by referring to the Top 100 SF Bay Area restaurants list. We have been to several others on that list, but this was by far the most delicious.

The crispy bone marrow on the venison carpaccio melted in my mouth. The red snapper was cooked flawlessly with delicious Italian butter beans with bacon. 

I wish my stomach was double in size.
author: Rach M.

description:
Meh. Way too loud for anything other than a party. The food was ok but not memorable at all. 

Marlowe has better atmosphere and food.
author: laura g.

description: Reservations for dinner is a must. Located in front of a park, the atmosphere and food was great! We ordered poulet (chicken), pork chop (medium) and lamp (medium-rare); all of which were tender and perfectly done. Just a heads up, the place gets a little noisy.
author: Lee-Hong L.

description:
I've been going to Park Tavern since they opened 3-4 years ago. I thought the food was good then but have been very surprised to see that the menu hasn't changed a bit in 4 years. 
It's shocking that the management & chef haven't introduced new menu items, maybe the chef is banned from making changes there. The menu is so boring, same old deviled eggs, brussel sprout chips, dry pork chop, shaved carrot salad. It's very boring american fare. 
For this reason, I'll only go there for a drink and then head to dinner elsewhere in North Beach. The restaurant is beautiful, bar area is cool if you can get a seat. Bartenders are nice as well. But the food is lame.
author: Giselle B.

description:
Great brunch spot. Great ambience (we sat at the bar) and decor inside.  Friendly and courteous staff. Food was great along with drink options. The avocado toast is really tasty as an app. The brioche French toast was awesome. Good brunch options wish there was one or two more vegetarian ones but fellow vegetarians can get along just fine going here. 
For drinks the unique cocktails are definitely great to have. 
It's a little more of an expensive place but I'd say worth it for out of towers or once in awhile (unless you're rolling on $$)
author: Avi S.

description: Relatively new addition to the neighborhood by the same owner of Marlowe I believe. Compared to Marlowe, I preferred this location more as it was more central to other activities (rather than next to some highway in SOMA). The place was also way more spacious, and well-suited for group dining. The atmosphere is a little bit more fancy than Marlowe, you can still go casual but can also dress nicely if you want. In terms of food, it is pretty solid if not the best of its type that I've had. We tried the pancakes, the smoked salmon with egg benedict, and avocado toast. I feel the food could be better though - or example the smoked salmon with egg benedict lacked a bit of a kick/change in texture and toward the end it tasted too dull. It's somewhere I would bring guests to as the ambience is nice and the food is pretty good, but I prob won't come back again myself out of the way.
author: Sam C.

description:
I love Park Tavern - I've been here for brunch and dinner and feel like the dinner menu is better since brunch in SF is really competitive. I've been seated both outside (cold but they offer military blankets) and inside.

Let's talk about dinner: 
-Brussel Sprout Chips: YYYAAASSSSS
-Crispy Soft Shell Crab Appetizer: YYAASS
-Marlowe Burger: YYYAAASSS
-PT Fries (truffle fries): YYYAASSSSS
-Seared Scallops: YAS

Ok I promise not to review anything else in YASSSS, but that's how I feel about it.

Drinks - loved all the ones I tried because it didn't taste like alcohol, but just a really greatly flavored drink! I've tried the:

-Washington Square
-Mclaren
+ 2 other drinks I can't remember the names of :)
author: Sandy T.

description: Went for dinner- it was alright but nothing special. I wouldn't feel the urge to go back.
author: Rachel S.

description:
We have always walked pass Park Tavern many times since my boyfriend use to live in the neighborhood. Finally, we decided to stop by since it has always been on our to-try list.   

The crowd ranges from mainly 30's to 50's. 
 
Generally, the establishment is modern and chic. After getting seated, we knew immediately that we wanted to try the brussel sprout chips, the pork chop, and the Poulet Rouge which is a whole chicken. Be warned that the Poulet Rouge may take awhile to cook.  
 
The brussel sprout chips were delicious. Perfectly salted and crispy. They were fun to eat! 
 
The pork chop was moist, I thoroughly enjoyed the taste with the sweet apple pairing with polenta. Halfway through my meal, it started to feel a bit heavy. 
  
The Poulet Rouge looked intense as it is served on a platter sitting upwards. Overall, my boyfriend thought it was okay as it started to taste heavy as he ate further into the dish. 
  
Our waitress was splendid. She constantly came back to check on us to make sure everything was tasting okay and that our water was filled.  

3.5 stars. Park Tavern. Check.
author: Becky Q.

description:
Hands down one of the best brunch menus in sf. They finally added the smoked deviled eggs to the brunch menu! Yippee! If you haven't blessed yourself with these guys yet, hurry up! I don't even like deviled eggs, and am all about these bad boys! Bacon, pickled jalapeño and chives makes these stand out.  Now they just need to add the Brussels sprout chips to the brunch menu.

My boyfriend and I then shared an order of the avocado toast and an order of the Oregon bay shrimp toast. Both were delicious and absolutely perfect. I highly recommend the toasts!

We then got the crispy polenta cakes with mushrooms, poached eggs, arugula, truffle salsa verde and Parmesan. Great vegetarian dish!

We then finished with the banana coconut fritters with a vanilla strawberry discs and a chocolate coffee rum sauce. 

Make sure you sample their coffees. We got the stumptown French press and the hair bender espresso latte. Both were a great caffeine fix.

As always the staff was on point. Friendly and efficient. Just make sure you make a reservation because they are understandably packed for brunch!
author: Victoria O.

description:
food: 2/5 
service: 5/5
atmosphere/decor: 2/5 (they currently have a really bad fly problem in parts of the restaurant)

Park Tavern is definitely your typical expensive brunch place in San Francisco. There is no wait before 12pm on any day, so don't need to make a reservation. This was my first time here and I will not be going back. The food is mediocre and the place is not clean. The large area near the windows has a really noticeable fly and gnat problem inside the restaurant. I was really put off by them not keeping the place clean. When I walked in, there were very few people in the restaurant and they put my party in a really bad location; right next to the dishware storage and water/drinks refill area. I thought it was a little rude to do that when the place was empty. We asked to change tables and it too 10 minutes for us to get a different table. Not that the other area was any better because of all the flies nearby. 
 
Aside from the initial bad seating, the service was speedy and great. My water was always filled and the waitress always checked on us. The food prices range from $15-20 for entrees and $7-10 for appetizers/small plates. Drink are around $10. The portions were small and the quality of food did not make up for high prices. I found egg shells in my eggs benedict, but didn't to complain because my meal was almost finished. I didn't want them to just throw away the food on my plate and waste it. Honestly, I did not want to sit there any longer because of the flies even if they offered me new eggs. 

Over all, I did not have a good experience and food was average.
author: Cecile S.

description:
Being a fan of Marlowe,  I couldn't wait to try Park Tavern with the besties and we thoroughly enjoyed our dinner!

We started with the deviled eggs which were delicious, but preferred Marlowe's version by a hair. The burrata served with lemon chips was another excellent starter, and I loved the pairing of the two. As for entrees, the braised short ribs were incredibly tender and seasoned just right, and the pork chop was surprisingly impressive! Perfectly cooked and juicy without being oversalted, what more could one ask for? I loved the upscale tavern ambiance, and the service was amazing to boot. Will definitely be back for a repeat visit.
author: Irene B.

description:
Somewhere between 3 and 4 to be precise... The service is great and the vibe is fun and a bit old school NY. The food is tasty but has a tendency to be hard hitting heavy food start to finish. And pricey. $17 truffle fries anyone? Out of morbid curiosity we tried them but the heaviness of the fries, the buttery black cod, the swimming pool of lobster bisque, even the kanpachi sashimi with shiso and garlic (how do you make sashimi heavy?!) put us all in a bit of a cholesterol funk.

The biggest downer? Not the resident, late night mouse - it's kinda cute - it was the chocolate creme brûlée. I swear they microwaved it. The brûlée top was super chewy. Pass.
author: Priscilla T.

description:
Contrary to most of the reviews here, the service here was impeccable.  Everyone from the maitre'd to the waiter to the busboy to the water guy were 100% awesome.  They made me and my pregnant wife feel welcome and happy.  I honestly could not have asked for a more pleasant service experience at a restaurant.  The waiter even knew what my wife could and could not eat being pregnant.  Wow!  Also the ambiance is beautiful with big wood beams stretching across the main dining area, and big windows overlooking Washington Square Park.  Admittedly it doesn't get much better than that.

The food, on the other hand, was fair..about the same as sister restaurant Marlowe..overrated, and just on the border of being reasonably priced for the neighborhood... but at least the menu was more diverse.  I would say maybe we ordered the wrong things, but given that one of us at the table was pregnant, we basically ordered everything.  

The brussel sprout chips a la Marlowe are the same, crispy at the top, oily on the bottom.  The clam fritters were more fritter than clam, though the corn salad, fresh corn hushpuppies and grilled avocados that came with the clams were AWESOME.  The sardine toast was ok...good portion and a good balance of salty, sweet, and umami flavors.  A little sweet for my taste, but my wife thought they were the bee's knees! The squash blossom salad was ok, though the ricotta stuffed squash blossoms were fried to the point that i didn't actually recognize or taste the squash.  

As for the main course, I had the seafood soup which was really disappointing.  All the seafood in it (literally everything) was overdone and a bit rubbery.  The soup itself was overly vinegary.  My wife loved the corn soup.  

As for dessert, we got the coconut birthday cake and the almond pear crumble with cinnamon ice cream.  Nothing worth noting aside from the cinnamon ice cream being so cinnamon-y it blew out my taste buds for everything else.  

I would try it again, if only for the great service...and hope that maybe it was an off night....
author: Adam E.

description:
This happening restaurant will make any long time San Franciscan forget Moose's even existed. The patrons are a diverse mix of young & old that have a passion for wining and dining in the big city. It's cozy with a hip & trendy vibe. Definitely a "see-and-be-seen" crowd on the weekends, but not pretentious. The restaurant has an NYC restaurant vibe. Most importantly, the food is the center of attraction and will have me returning more than once. 

A must is the smoked deviled eggs and the brussel sprout chips to start of your meal on the right track. The highlight, of course, was the rotisserie chicken from their wood oven. My first bite was an instantaneous food orgasm in my mouth. SMH, chicken is usually the most boring item to order in most restaurants unless you're getting it from Costco of course (Joke).

Park Tavern had me at first bite.
author: Glenn G.

description:
Took my wife for her birthday dinner. It was our first time there and it was outstanding in every sense.
The service was personable and attentive without being overbearing.
The atmosphere was great. It actually feels like a tavern.
We had the Roasted Marrow and the Demons on Horseback (Shrimp) for starters.
Both were perfect in their simplicity.The shrimp is so good ,it was tempting to just order 7 of them and let that be the meal.
The park tavern sweet gem lettuce salad with the green goddess dressing  is the perfect respite between appetizers and entrees.
For entrees I had the Pork Chops w/ a Panzanella that had fruit in it.
Normally I avoid grilled fruit because so many places over cook it but not this time.
The persimmons and pomegranate complemented the delicious chop.
My wife had the signature dish,the Poulet Rouge.
She rarely,if eve, orders chicken when we go out but this was easily the best chicken I have ever had in a restaurant.The fact that it was served impaled on an iron spike attached to the middle of a cast iron pan only added to the experience.There is an option for the cooks to serve it sliced up but a whole bird on the spike is what eating in a tavern is all about.
For desserts she had the coffee creme brulee and I had the chocolate cake w/peanut butter frosting.  Decadent without being heavy which is how desserts should be.
The cocktails were amazing.
Specifically the Ed's Negroni (Gin) and the Twin Peaks (Tequila) were both a synchronous balance of the booze and the flavors. The way cocktails should be.
They also had my wife's favorite wine the Gruner Veltliner.
So all in all it was a great night out to celebrate her birthday.
We were there for almost 3 hours taking our time between courses and enjoying each other's company. At no time did either of us feel like we were pressured to vacate.
The park tavern provided a consummate dining experience.
I can't wait to try out the sister restaurants listed on their website.
Highly Recommended and will return again.
author: Auggie B.

description: I had a couple of George Dickle sours. They came in a, small for today's standards glass. Looked like they were going for the Mad Men vibe. Outstanding craft cocktail with a warm and friendly staff. Would definitely recommend this fine drinking establishment. I was fortunate enough to be taken here by a local. I probably wouldn't have found this gem on my own.
author: Steven M.

description:
This place serves one HELL of a burger!

So good that we endured a chilly evening and sat outside just to sink our teeth into a juicy, mouthwatering, medium rare, delicious, heavenly work of art.

Eric B, you missed out!

Me, my wife and several friends walked in sans reservation hoping to snag a table inside. The dining room (as expected) was completely full, but they did have one small table free outside. The only thing is that this particular table was not under one of the heat lamps. We were hungry and our options were limited. Plus the fact that two of our friends had been to Park Tavern before and were raving about the burger.

Must try the frickin' burger!

The minute we sat down, the service was exceptional. Our server always made it a point to checkin on us and made sure we our water glasses were filled and was quick to the draw on our cocktail and wine orders. 

Try the brussels chips!
author: Rene C.

description: Must order - the poulet noir.  A small hen.  The hen is perched upright and served whole.  Comes on a cast iron plate.  It was the highlight of our dinner for five.  We ordered our own entrees and had the poulet family style.
author: Shirley N.

description:
(See pics) Review #1220. Maybe it's a people watching place, but it's not a food place for brunch.

The feta flat bread was mediocre. Veal schnitzel and cast iron baked eggs were just so so and were on the greasy side.

The space was classic and tables were quite packed together. Surprisingly the place did get busy as we were finishing up the lunch.

Definitely people were more dressed up even on a weekend here but I can't be sure if it earns a return visit.
author: T L.

description: I got the crispy polenta cakes. They were very good. A little on the buttery side, but alas the poached egg, spinach, and polenta (crispy) worked out well. The other people at the table got the fried chicken sandwich. The service is ok, they are always busy so I think it's hard to run a really tight shift (one person at the table got served after we finished eating but I believe they comped his meal). This place gets really really loud. It's hard to hear what is going on at the other end of the table.
author: Jessica S.

description: The fruit salad was very good as were the French fries. Next time I go I am going to just order a bunch of small plates rather than a few plus an entree
author: Kiyo O.

description:
From start to finish this place is tops in my book!

I made a reservation to celebrate my sister in law's 30th birthday and the entire process was seamless.  We were greeted at the host stand and my SIL was wished a happy birthday right away.  That's a nice touch!

We grabbed some drinks at the bar and waited for our table and got to visually explore the mix of modern and classic style of the restaurant.  Upon being seated my SIL was again wished a happy birthday by the server!

We started off with the smoked deviled eggs, waygu beef jerky and PT fries.  Now I really need to make a strong recommendation before I continue....ORDER THE PT FRIES!!!
They were amazing, I couldn't get enough!  The fries were seasoned and hot and accompanied by a soft cooked egg to one side and the egg was topped with caviar, it was the perfect dipper!  ON the other side was a truffle aioli.  We ate every single fry.  The waygu jerky was exactly as described, beef jerky....kind of an interesting app.  The deviled eggs were fine, but not something I"d explore again unless I had a craving although the jalapeno being pickled did add an interesting flavor that I was not expecting.

I ordered the scallops as did the other gentleman at our table and he loved them.  I found them salty and didn't care at all for the way the mushrooms were prepared.  I talked to the server and told him honestly, this dish was not for me.  It may just be my personal taste, but I'd prefer to have pretty much anything on the menu.  He was completely understanding and offered the pork chop.  What at great suggestion, this was one of the juiciest pork chops I have ever tried.  I almost cleaned my plate.

My sister in law got a steak that was perfectly cooked and the twice baked potato, she was really pleased.

Between the drinks, apps and entrees we were pretty stuffed, but I always look at the desert menu.  They surprised us again with a slice of their coconut birthday cake that my sister in law really loved!

I don't leave many 5 star reviews, but I'd come back in a heartbeat and recommend it to friends and anyone that asked me for a recommendation in San Francisco.
author: Nick L.

description: Steak tartare!!!! That itself is a reason to come back over and over again. Oh sooo good! A perfect blend of heat and spice, the good quality meat..it's enough to turn a nonmeat eater around.
author: Jango L.

description:
This place is like a new favorite now!
I had such a nice meal with good company and great service!.
The chicken (poulet noir) was really special.
The deviled eggs were great, tasty little appetizers
The Brussels sprout chips were crispy and nice but maybe a nit too salty.
The apple Cheddar crisp was a good ending to it all.

I think the service here is what really impressed me, everything just came and went at the perfect time and friendliness was as good as the professionalism!
author: Lizzy M.

description:
Really three-and-a-half stars.

The best thing about this place were the appetizers. We had the truffle fries, gnocchi (a favorite), brussels sprout chips, and deviled eggs. All were phenomenal.

But I only have one word to describe the entrees: SALTY. I had the scallops, which were served with cooked vegetables and  some other meat pieces that tasted like bacon. It was good, but too salty. I had to ask for bread mid-way to make more headway with my dish.

One of my friends had the Poulet Noir (a whole cornish hen, I think). Huge and good, but too salty. Another friend had the clams and mussels. Too salty.

In sum, our Park Tavern culinary experience began spectacularly, but failed to deliver at the end.
author: Grace S.

description: Great service and amazing brunch. We had the French toast, fruit plate, and hash. Everything was perfect!
author: Em F.

description:
Park Tavern's usual suspects:
* Housewives of San Francisco: Botox Edition
* group of used-to-be sorority girls...one so drunk, she fell off her chair with a *thud* while waiters scramble to pick her up & her frenemies die of embarrassment
* dressed-up couples (how cute!)
* then there's underdressed me who didn't do her research & had no idea how fancypants this place is. Oopps, to the diners sitting in my vicinity, please excuse the messy ponytail & jeans (pricey, yes, but jeans nonetheless *wink*)

My lemon-themed appetizer (fried lemon chips w/ burrata & some kind of herb) & dessert (an airy lemon cheesecake topped with huckleberries & smoked salt) were phenomenal. 

$20 PT fries include a side of egg yolk & caviar. So frou frou it hurts. At least it was dee-lish. 

Demons on horseback was shocking as my surf tasted more like turf; shrimp isn't supposed to taste purely of lard(on.)

Deviled eggs were not the absolute best I've ever had but the jalepeno & generous crisp bacon gave it a smokey, spicy kick. 

And finally, my salad (an appetizer I chose to have as an entree as the above mentioned grub was filling enough) was unexpectedly divine. I didn't think I'd be okay with chicories but when it's warm & wilted like that, I'd gladly eat that bitter mess forever. And the poached egg mixed with bread & bagna cauda(anchovies, garlic & olive oil)... Let's just say the chef knows what he's doing. 

Attention to decorating details (rivets in the leather, a tree at the entrance, the rustic wheel as a lighting apparatus), an enthusiastic waiter, food that makes me feel the $85 per person bill was worth every penny...five fancypants stars.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Besides the amazing food, the service was out of this world. Eric was such a wonderful waiter... the hostess came over and explained why she had to reserve a corner table for a special couple, and they were on top of all the drinks, water pourings, and orders. 10/10!!

Food: Excellent. Had the trout (YUM!!!) and the burger (I didn't really feel like a burger and I normally go medium or medium rare but had ordered it well bc I was splitting with a friend. So I wasn't in love with the burger... ) The Cauliflower appetizer was delicious too.

Drinks: Negroni (mwah!), Pisco Sour (yum!) and ya.. great bar!
author: Maryam M.

description:
On our way to Mama's one morning we walked right by Park Tavern. And even as we were standing in line for breakfast we received our reservation confirmation call. This place looks super cool, so I was excited. 

The staff here was great. Everyone was super friendly and smiley. The hostess and I shared a laugh while I bounced around in my seat. CP had a glass of wine. The people watching here is great. We were seated adjacent to the bar area and there was some interesting happenings.

We had to, without a doubt, start with the deviled eggs. CP thought we should also give the fried mushrooms with french onion dip a go. The special for the evening was a sol fish with little potatoes and egg and veggies. 

Even with the jalapeno, the deviled eggs weren't overwhelmingly hot. They had great flavor. I loved the touch of bacon. These are definitely a winner. Deviled eggs at restaurants can be a real joke but these lived up to the challenge and the fame. I almost bought more! Definitely delicious. As good as the eggs were, the mushrooms were very average. They were fried and they tasted fine but it was a very monotonous appetizer. Not much punch. Could have used a kick in their shroomy bottoms. Maybe some paprika? I was bored after a few bites.

Special sol was interesting. It probably wouldn't have been my go to for the meal but CP enjoyed it a lot. It was good and had many dynamic flavors, many of which I couldn't pinpoint. The egg was a brilliant touch. 

Though the appetizers were both hit and miss and the entree was probably not my first choice I still enjoyed my time here. I loved the energy and the vibe, plus, there are many more exciting things I can try on the menu. SF dining success!
author: Tai F.

description:
Talk about a 180 degree turn around..!

  Yep, the girl who wrote a scathing review is eating her words.  : /
  
  Why you might ask? 

  Because after giving Park Tavern a third chance, I was actually blown away by the experience.  I'm not too proud to admit it.

  This time, everything was spot on!!! Woo hoo!!!

  I walked in a bit on the defense. I was certain I would be let down again but course by course, interaction after interaction I found myself thinking, "wow, maybe I got it wrong last time..."

The martini...? Perfection. And the bartender who served it was pretty darn nice, genuine even.
--[In my head (Fine we're off to a good start.)]

Appetizers, including the deviled eggs and the charcuterie plate were delicious.
-- (Ok, Ok, so far 2 for 2.)

Our server; friendly and attentive without being over the top.  He was there when we needed him but wasn't obtrusive when we didn't.
-- (Wow, he is so much better than the last guy.)

The wine.  Really REALLY good and,,, wait... Didn't cost a fortune?
-- (Was that priced incorrectly on the menu? Humph. No, it wasn't!)

I got the lamb this time, my husband got the chicken.  Both were FANTASTIC. 
-- (Is this happening!?!? Everything has been amazing tonight..!)

Apple Crisp and coffee?  Just what I needed to seal the deal. 
-- (Holy cow, it happened, they changed my mind!)

 Only one last thing to ask....

When are we going back and who wants to go back with me?
author: Krissy P.

description:
Good Times and Brussels Chips!

And so it was as Rene C., his wife Erica, Joanna M. and her friend MM gathered at Park Tavern after a Gogobot Party at Rosewood. It was a fine second choice as Tony's Pizza had a long wait on this Wednesday evening. 

When we first walked in, the place was full and bustling with "beautiful people", including maybe even Mr. Joesten the 3rd. :)  Sometimes this much "buzz" means that both the clientele and restaurant are full of themselves, but in this case the Maitre D' was super accommodating in finding us an outside table. That sort of attentive and friendly service continued on with our waitress, the wine steward, and other support staff. We felt well taken care of during the entire evening, even though our total bill probably didn't come close to a few bar tabs still running inside. 

Sitting outside also makes for better conversation and we had some good ones. The center of the conversation was MM's fascinating explanation of his new Marker App and tales of travel that have both experienced and wished that I could. The Yelp and Gogobot comparisons came up, as did OCD-fueled writing, and what how virtual social interaction is evolving. And all this engaging interaction timelessly continued while life on this side of Washington Square went walking or whizzing by on this comfortable evening. I knew I eventually had to get in the car and drive back to Pleasant Hill, but I was in no hurry for the evening to end.

But that did mean that I limited my alcohol intake to a glass of wine. That delicious red came from a shared and well priced bottle of Cabernet Franc. I passed on the great looking Templeton Rye (from Iowa!) Side Cars and was intrigued as talk then centered around similar specialty whiskeys such as Whistlepig.

The food was great too. Everyone else at the Table went for the Burger, which unfortunately I passed on as I had already filled up before and during the party. My Bad. However, I was just fine as I happily munched on the Brussels Sprout Chips and Brussels Sprout Hearts (sauteed with lemon and cheese). 

So there you go. When you put together a nice venue, great conversation, and good food, it's an experience that bears repeating.
author: Eric B.

description:
Everything we had was good - deviled eggs, lobster bisque, and Marlowe burger. It's good enough to be the go-to spot for those items. 

Eggs were smokey and the pickled jalapeno gave it the bit of acidity it needed to cut into the bacon on top. The bottom of the egg has been shaped flat and sits on the plate like a bateau of smokey yolky bacon cargo. 

I was actually taken aback by the punch of flavor from the bisque. The cognac (or dry sherry?) was dominant but in a good way. I couldn't quite taste crab as much as lobster but it added another layer of flavor. 

The Marlowe burger tasted even better than I remembered from Marlowe. And it's worth mentioning that another amazing burger is just around the corner at Don Pisto's!

This place was poppin' at 10 pm on a Thursday night. If you make good food, people will come. When was the last new place you tried where everything was surprisingly good, when you already had expectations? If it has been too long, come to Park Tavern. 

Definitely going back.
author: Erika C.

description:
I came here for brunch with the boyfriend, he ordered the avocado toast, grapefruit brulee, and I got the crispy polenta cakes. All of them were unique and tasty - if I had a second stomach or had classy sweatpants on I would've tried the Marlowe burger and the fried duck egg sandwich because those just sound amazeballs! 

The avocado toast is a simple concept but it was executed well, the grapefruit brulee was a light addition to what would typically be a heavy brunch meal ,ad the crispy polenta cakes were filling enough to make my belly happy. 

Parking was rather difficult, we ended up parking in a garage because we didn't want to stalk nice people in hopes of taking their parking space. It is also a more classy venue that is beautifully decorated inside.
author: Tina F.

description: The food here is pretty great, especially their lemon chips. It's a nice, casual atmosphere inside and I had a great time. However, I do have two complaints about my experience, although they didn't really alter the enjoyability of my experience. First off, I have to recommend that the staff take down their "foodie" knowledge. I enjoy a waiter who knows what he's talking about, but ours came off as a bit snobby. Also, the 'birthday cake' dessert I ordered was very, very dry. It almost tasted as if it had been left out overnight. Other than those two blemishes, I enjoyed my dinner there.
author: Steve T.

description: Don't get the French Toast. The Grapefruit Brûlée was good. Charging 8 bucks for the "two brunch coffees" -- that's pretty lame.
author: Tom B.

description:
Sometimes I feel like I just can't go wrong in North Beach :) Another win for Washington Square! I was surprised to secure a same day Saturday night prime-time reservation.  We arrived a bit early and worked our way to the busy(!) bar for some pre-dinner libations. Although it was packed, the bartenders were attentive and quick to take our order. I particularly love that attention to detail.  We were seated on time a few minutes later. 

We weren't starving, so opted for the lemon chip/burrata dish, deviled eggs appetizers, and split the burger. The lemon chips were interesting, just as you would expect them to taste, but didn't find that they went particularly well with the burrata.  The eggs on the other hand were excellent - can't go wrong with a crisp bacon lardon sitting on top!  The burger was just as good. Loved that they went ahead and pre-split it along with the fries.

Overall, Park Tavern showcased amazing attention to detail.  The meal and vibe were just what we were in the mood for. Would happily return!
author: Brianna M.

description:
Did you know Brussels Sprouts is the new black? Which can only mean Brussels Sprouts Chips are the new pink or new Zima or whatever, right? 
Did you also know that surprising your SO with dinner reservations here, will get you... : )

During a really crappy day at work on a random Tuesday, I get a text asking me if I can get off work early and take off to SF (from Sac) for dinner.
Didn't have to ask me twice! Suddenly the clouds parted. I figured the Oldman wanted to stalk Tyler Florence again but, I hadn't heard of any new TF spots opening recently. So, I bit my tongue and held my breath while my inner child voice kept yelling at me to ask where we were going. As we walked into this restaurant, my first thought was "Oldman IS stalking Tyler". Park Tavern reminds me a lot of TF's Wayfare Tavern - it's rustic hunting lodge (complete with animal head wall mounted trophies) meets Posh Spice's dining room. Okay, I say that because we were dressed really casually and eventually seated next to the Real Housewives of sur-reality TV.

Oldman made a reservation (the only time he was able to get was for 9pm), but we had to wait a little bit for our table. So, we waited at the bar which was packed with most patrons choosing to enjoy their meal at the bar... a good option for those ill-prepared. And, a nice opportunity to strike up random conversations with strangers toting expensive goods  - got a great tip on a very nice looking iPad case (Mulholland Brothers... there, now I won't forget).

We were very pleased with the booth Oldman requested; it was in perfect view of the kitchen action. I LOVE watching beautiful food being prepared. Between the kitchen action, the wonderful menu, and the bright shiny objects adorning the Real Housewives, I had a hard time deciding what I wanted to order.

Oldman was set on the burger, after a friend's high recommendation. I wanted to try a little of everything! 

Our wonderful meal that night:

Deviled egg with bacon, jalapeno, and chives - excellent (I sopped up whatever lovely sauce was sitting under the egg with their warm delicious bread).
Brussels sprout chips - Oh my! Absolutely amazing (the housewives and I ended up discussing how we could possibly re-create that dish at home... we were thinking the chips had to have been flashed fried).
Pork Chop served with baby turnips, carmelized apple, AND even more pork... pork belly. Who does that!? I think every restaurant should!
"Marlowe" burger, sans the caramelized onions, with bacon, cheddar, and really nice horseradish aioli and fries.
 
Standout of the meal had to be the Brussels sprout chips and pork chop. Unfortunately, the friend that recommended this place was a little too slow to text me back with another rec to order their homemade beef jerky! We'll just have to make another visit to try more of their menu.

After we finished our meal we were stuffed and in a hurry to get back on the road but, we struck up a convo with the housewives - Oldman just had to know whose birthday they were celebrating, and I just had to know what dessert they were sharing... and, actually ended up fighting over. Turns out it was a "Boozy Arnold Palmer Float" (Black tea ice cream, whole lemon gelato, and St.Germain)... are you kidding me! Arnold Palmer is my absolute favorite beverage, and they have made a dessert out of it!?  If it weren't for the booziness factor, I would have knocked one of them over and ran off with it!

Two thumbs up for PT, and Oldman!
author: Kara B.

description: One of the best brunch spots in North Beach, but good for dinner as well. Lovely atmosphere and fantastic service. The smoked salmon benedict and Marlowe burger are some of my favorites. Bloody Mary's are good too, and served with jerky on the side. As for dinner, I've only been here once but the grilled asparagus salad and crispy lemon chips were amazingly refreshing. My only complaint would be my order of a Marlowe burger at dinner was somewhat overcooked (I ordered it Medium), but great restaurant and one of the neighborhood's gems.
author: Caroline W.

description: Loved this place for brunch! My friend and I misunderstood each other about who was making the reservation and walked in at 10:30am on a Sunday without one. The hostess was so nice and even though they were fully booked, managed to find us a lovely table for 4. For brunch I had the corn beef hash which came with a soft poached egg and crispy potatoes. The service was fantastic. The bloody Mary's are spicy and delicious. Can't wait to come back here to try to polenta cakes as they looked amazing!
author: Nicole W.

description:
Met up with some friends here for a weekend brunch. Scoffed at the line at Mama's and were immediately seated in Park Tavern (we had made reservations). We all ordered rounds of coffee (which was tasty) then ordered entrees.

The vibe is contemporary and comfortable with tiled floors and rustic textures. It felt refined, welcoming and relaxing. Prime people-watching with Washington Square across the street.

I got the polenta with eggs asparagus and an arugula salad. The polenta was incredibly light and crispy. The egg on top was perfectly poached. I thoroughly enjoyed the salad. All in all, I very tasty and satisfying dish.

My dining companions ordered the Corned Beef Hash, Duck Egg sandwich and  Cast-iron Farm egg. Lots of enthusiasm for the food around the table. It might not be the best deal in town but a meal here is certainly worth its asking price. I'll be back!
author: Kevan M.

description: I've tried this place for both brunch and dinner and have always been satisfied with the service, food, ambiance, and cleanliness.  Had brunch yesterday, and the highlight of the brunch was the blueberry fritters. AMAZING!!! Also had the polenta with poached eggs, and hubby had the corned beef hash. My brunch was absolutely delightful! Since this place is so great, it typically has a long wait, so prepare to wait for an hour if you go during peak hours.  The cool thing is that you can leave your cell phone number with the hostess and go down the street for a cocktail while you wait for your table, and they'll call you when it's ready. If you're lucky enough to get an outside table, you'll have a great view of Washington Square and the hills of SF. Highly recommend!
author: Meredith A.

description:
-Let me start by saying that this was not our first time at the restaurant, and we were considering another spot, but decided to go here because our 14 year old son (who has a better palate than 95% of adults we dine with) was with us for the first time and we thought he would enjoy the ambience.  My husband is a general manager of a popular fine dining restaurant, we are foodies, and we basically came to San Fran to dine and enjoy a different urban scene (we live in Denver). 

-The night started out by waiting until 9:20 for our 8:45 reservation - we were offered a drink for apology, but had a reserve bottle of wine from a Napa winery and didn't want to overdo it, so we decided to hold off...and wait...there was another party of 3 that was there before us (we were there on time) - and they had a 9:00 reservation, but were sat a good 15 minutes before us, which we already found odd... the host was apologetic and was trying to take care of us, but we already had too much time to scrutinize the situation, and were feeling a bit unimportant.

-We finally get to our table, and laid our bottle of unopened wine on top of it - our waiter, who seemed super busy and uninterested in us, managed to get our water order, but we didn't see him again until it was time to order the main course.  Another busy waiter came by with our water, we asked him to open our wine as nobody else that passed by saw that we were still waiting, but he had to go check on his own tables first...so we waited again...he was nice enough to get our appetizer order.
