-as an apology, brussel sprout chips (seems to be a theme) and deviled eggs - both of which are not things we typically eat for multiple reasons and ended up barely trying - were brought to us, but nobody asked what we might like to have in the situation... a nice try, but poor execution -  later our waiter said he waved the corkage fee, which we laughed about because we could have opened it ourselves and nobody would have noticed, the waiter didn't open it, and the only glass poured for us was by the other waiter that gave us more service with one stop than our waiter the entire night.  

-To shorten this poor experience, I will sum it up to say that the food was bland, apps were weirdly prepared, salad was drenched in salty salad dressing... the steak, which our waiter could not describe for us, was tough, the side of marrow didn't make sense and wasn't executed well, and my son's steak (who always orders medium rare) was tough and undercooked (have you ever seen a 14 year old growing boy eat part of a steak?) - he actually sent it back because he couldn't chew it, and it came back medium well...but of course that was on the bill... I ordered the chicken, which was good, but it came with a huge amount of heavy stuffing instead of the greens it had last time.

-We saw our waiter maybe 2-3 times, always briefly and rushed, and a little fake - my son was laughing because he felt like he talked to him like he was 5 years old.  We skipped dessert, and my husband (who has NEVER done this) didn't tip - he felt cheated the whole night, and still payed 160$ for food that was just not good.  The hype is there, but they've lost their touch, don't care about anybody that's not VIP, and maybe they should look into their reservation technique, because it didn't work for us more than once, and I've seen several other reviewers say the same.  

WE'VE HAD SO MUCH BETTER IN SAN FRAN, LESS EXPENSIVE, BETTER SERVICE, BETTER AMBIANCE, AND RESPECT...oh, and did I mention that this is fine dining and they can't even manage a bottle of wine?  Not one manager ever came by, if he did, he sure wasn't being a manager....  needless to say, we won't be back, and I would recommend 20 other places before even considering Park Tavern.  Ingredients were probably above average, but execution failed.  The host tried to help us out, he was more of a manager than anything else we encountered all evening.  Denver as a city may be behind in dining, but I can tell you, we are quickly catching up and our hotel rooms are affordable too.  

I've never before left a review, but this one was deserved.

-
author: Brooke B.

description:
We must came at a off-night, but then again I think the issues I had probably are pretty prevalent. 

First drinks, nothing to rave about, and in fact my cocktail and the old fashion someone else ordered were just too sweet. It was borderline gross.

Second food. The brussel chips were good, but I am not a fan of brussel sprouts, so no much can be say about that. The devil eggs had too much onions in it, Wayfare makes a much better one. The lemon chip with burrata was just also okay, the burrata had something mixed into it, so it is not like its normal fresh creamy self. Tomato tart, well, it was more tart, and squash than tomato! I ordered the pork chop, which was done perfectly, but the turnip that came with it was so salty that it was not edible. My friend who was a vegetarian who got a veggie plate that also came with the turnip had the same issues. He ate everything else, and left out the turnip. The steak and fries, seriously for $33, you get less than 4oz of steak? Plus it was overcooked, and it was served in a bowl that it was hard to cut the steak, all and all, an insult to the steak knife we got. Dessert was nothing to ride home about, the cream burlee had too much sugar crust. Seriously I wasn't trying to picky, but pretty much everything missed the mark by a lot. 

Third service. It was not bad, but our waiter must be a robot, because he did came and check in with us, and said everything that he needed to say, but he only gave us about half second to responds, and if we missed that, he promptly walked away. It happened a few times, that we thought he was totally strange and just laughed it off. Literally when he came by and ask how our entree was, before I can tell him the turnip is too salty, he said:" great, thanks" and walked way. Face palm!

Decor, really great atmosphere. I do like the classic tavern decor. 

The dinning experience was rather disappointing to me.
author: Alice C.

description: Love this place I eat out a lot in SF, Seattle and Portland. The staff here are awesome!!!
author: Sarah G.

description: One of my favorite brunches in the city. The polenta and poached eggs are to die for. And the deviled eggs are a must.
author: Madeline H.

description:
How can you not give this place a 5 star. Amazing food, service and ambiance. 

Bar Steak and Rib Eye are my favorite choices for Dinner. And don' forget the brussels sprouts!
author: Antonio I.

description: Amazing neighborhood spot.  The brunch is top notch.  The cocktails are unique and exceptionally well crafted.  The food is delicious, they have a diverse brunch menu, and the bartenders embody the concept of hospitality.  Can't say enough about this place except it makes you want to be a regular.
author: Justina L.

description:
I adore this plAce!! 

Super cool vibe inside - nice ambiance and great service

The menu is unique and delicious. Makes it hard to choose but I don't think you can go wrong with anything here. 

Loved grabbing drinks and some bites to eat at the bar. It was comfortable, fast and delicious. Great cocktail menu too! The Kentucky mule was my favorite. 

Brussels sprout chips - lemony & crispy 
PT fries - oeuf a la coque topped w caviar... Paired with truffle sauce. Ya must order. 
Prawns - smokey jumbo deliciousness

Yum. 

So many more dishes to try! The burgers from the couple next to us looked awesome. 

Gets pretty busy but were able to grab a couple seats at the bar with out any problem Wednesday around 7p.
author: Shanna N.

description:
This place is good for any meal:  brunch, lunch, or dinner.  Even Kanye has been here.  

There is nothing else to say, except awesome.
author: F K.

description:
Great atmosphere for date night. Place is upscale with old school charm. I would recommend this place to anyone looking for a fun place to take out a date 

Another little gem, go to Beach Blanket Babylon before you go to the restaurant. Great first or send date type of thing to do.

Order the steak, always order their steak and DEVILED EGGS. MUST ORDER.
author: Waseem A.

description: I prefer Park Tavern for brunch. I live in the neighborhood and it is one of my favorites. My brunch go-tos are the corned beef hash (yummmm), the avocado toast to share, deviled eggs (the best) if you don't feel like a full on egg dish, and if you want dessert and have a friend willing to share with you, get the French toast!!!!
author: sarah m.

description: Our dinner last night was disappointing. I've always liked the vibe of Park Tavern's dining room but for some reason last night they had the lights so low it was practically dark inside. We had to use our cell phone flashlights to read the menu and noticed others doing the same. The signature Park Tavern cocktail was excellent. However when our entrées arrived the dark room prevented us from immediately seeing how poorly presented the food was.  My partner had the lamb chops one of which had a bite of edible meat about the size of a silver dollar and the other which was nothing but an inedible slab of fat. I had the bar steak which dry and over salted. The accompanying truffle fries were reminiscent of greasy garlic fries at the ballpark. When we pointed out the inedible lamb chop entrée to the waiter he shrugged and said sometimes lamb chops come out fatty but no problem he would take it off our bill. There was no indication of regret for having served us an inedible meal to begin with or for my partner still being hungry. I have enjoyed dinner here a few times in the past but unfortunately it seems to have gone seriously downhill both in terms of the food and the service. I can't recommend it.
author: Steven Z.

description: I have earn at this restaurant at least 20 times by now and every time I leave very satisfied. The service is always great, food is amazing and they have a very fun and upbeat atmosphere. Marlowe burger is great. Chicken is great. I have tried numerous desserts and have loved every one of them. After all the times I have been here I have never had a complaint.
author: Eddie E.

description:
Everyone seems to rave about the food here and I am STILL not convinced...three visits in.  I am applying the three strikes rule and, Park Tavern, yer out!

There are a few things that are definitely tasty although a bit greasy - the Brussel Sprout chips, for one, are good but very oily at the bottom, the Sommelier (really knows his stuff but most of the bottles are waaaay marked up), and the desserts are good.  

So, water and Creme Brulee for one, please.

I digress.  In all honesty, when you pay $29 for a "Bar Steak", you expect more than 4 chipped off ends of an overcooked steak at one end of the plate with a scattering of french fries to cover the remaining 83% of the plate...oh ok, 84%.  It looked as though my dish had been viciously intercepted by someone hungry on the way to our table and they left me the bits they didn't want.

It was so off putting - grisly, meager, overcooked chips of meat.  I even took it home in case it was dark at PT, I didn't really see what was on my plate and I could give the meal a second chance.  No WAY!  It looked way worse the next day.  That meal was given a proper burial down the trash (it would have broken the disposal).

The wine list is very good but the prices are beyond jacked up.  I get there is always a mark up on wine - no problem, but this was kinda silly.  Thankfully, the bottles our table ordered were delicious and numbed the shock of the bill at the end of the unsatisfactory night.  $100 / head....and I had to stop for a burger on the way home...and I don't recall the last time I did that.

Come on, Park Tavern, you can do better than this in SF town.
author: Kristina A.

description:
I came for brunch with a few friends last weekend. Reservations are a must. It looked like they had a bar area for walk-ins, but it was completely full. We were all very hungry, but luckily our table was ready when we arrived. 

Atmosphere: classy, trendy, modern. Perfect for impressing a hot date. Not especially intimate and can get somewhat noisy when crowded.

We ordered a few starters to share:
Toast with avocado - eh, I could have made this at home
Almond croissant - yum!
Ginger scone - good

Service was a little lacking, but we didn't need much and our waitress looked frantic trying to deal with all of her tables, so I'll let that slide. 

For my brunch meal I ordered the butter lettuce and lobster salad. It was...small. In fact, all of the dishes at our table were small. The french toast came with 3 measly little pieces. The baked farm eggs seemed to imply that there would be multiple eggs, but it looked like just one. 

On the plus side, plating was beautiful and the food was tasty. The salad was fresh and had a nice citrus/dill dressing that was not too overwhelming. 

As a brunch restaurant, I thought it was pretty pricey for the quantity/quality. But it's a beautiful restaurant and their dinner menu looks amazing so I will give them another try at a different meal time.
author: Rachel E.

description:
Brunch was excellent. Oatmeal, walnut pancakes were excellent! Still craving those pancakes. :)

Open face, egg salad sandwich was okay. Would not order that again. Also tried the root beer float on the brunch libation menu and that was excellent. Very good brunch spot in North Beach.
author: Nick K.

description: I come here often for brunch. The corned beef hash is light, but very flavorful. It's one of my favorite dishes on the brunch menu. The drinks are pretty good too! The service is top notch. All around a great dining experience.
author: Hassaun V.

description:
Love coming here. The staff is amazing, the food is delicious especially if you love European-style food  (with an ever changing menu), and the setting is perfect next to Washington square park. Park Tavern has added so much to North Beach. 

I've been here so many times and my favorite dishes are the meaty ones - especially the beef tartare.
author: Cynthia M.

description:
I was taken here one night for a work meeting. Usually the places these people select are dull, expensive, and predictable. Think upscale chain restaurants. So when this place was suggested, and knowing nothing about it, I wasn't expecting much. 

We get there, and the place looks great. Very cool vibe. Order a cocktail (I wish I could remember which one), had one sip and knew this place was going to be good. 

When we got our table, we just told the waiter to start bringing out food... whatever he suggests. I will NEVER forget the first dish that came out. Fries with a runny egg and caviar as a dipping sauce. Holy cow. That dish set the tone for the rest of the night. We also had the ribeye (wow) and the pork chop. Other than the fries, the pork chop was my favorite, and that's impressive because I usually would never order a pork chop. I've never been a fan, until that night.

Desert was this chocolate dish. It was possibly the most decadent chocolate I've tasted. Two bites and I was done. It was so good, I tried to get my friends to go the next night (I was only in SF for 3 days). 

I haven't been back to SF since, but I will for sure be coming back next time I am in the area.
author: Greg P.

description:
It was an annual holiday dinner with two of my great girlfriends and this year chose Park Tavern to be part of our holiday experience. Dinner was at 6 and though we arrived to an empty place, by the time our waitress came to take our order the floor was filled with diners. 

After many recommendations from our waiter, we decided to share a few starters, a side and to each get a different entree so that we made get a taste of everything.

Starters:
-Demons on horseback
-Deviled eggs, bacon, pickled jalepeño & chives 
-Brussels sprout chips

Our favorite starters for the night was the Demons on horseback- the melted bacon fat gave the prawns a pop of flavor. My second favorite was the famous brussels sprouts, and I don't usually eat brussels sprout. There is a rave about their deviled eggs but to us it was just mediocre. 

Sides:
-Anson Mills polenta

Finished before I had a chance to dig into my Petit "Poulet Rouge". Yup, it was that good!

Entrees:
-Grilled pork chop
-Seared local albacore
-Petit "Poulet Rouge"

Out of the entrees, I would have to say that my favorite was the petite poulet rouge. First the dish came out cold, when we notified our waiter he quickly took it back to the kitchen and the manager later came out with a new and hot dish. It was wonderful! Moist, juicy and full of flavor of spices.  The seared albacore and the pork chop was good too but nothing compared to the hen. 

Desserts:
-Lemon cheesecake parfait 
-Apple & red wine-caramel crisp 

Lemon cheesecake parfait was creamy and rich. Can't really taste the "cheesecake" in this dessert but it was still good. The apple & red wine caramel crisp was a tad bitter, and it is probably because of the red wine. However, the bitterness balanced perfectly with the sweet and tart lemon ice cream that it was served with. 

Overall, the dining experience was really delightful. I admire and respect restaurants who will own up to their mistakes and are willing to take that extra step to make their service more than exceptional. Their generosity in making up for their errors made my dining experience with them much memorable.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Came here with my girlfriends for a Sunday Brunch. This place is solid. I am celiac and the waiter was very knowledgeable about what i could or could not eat off the menu. What i got tasted great and was beautifully presented. The service was very good.
Bonus is that you can make reservations at this place which is not very common for San Fran brunch places.
author: Nataliya C.

description:
We arrived at Park Tavern at 10:15 on a Saturday night.  It was packed but we had reservations:-)   I am not a vegetarian but was eating vegetarian and not drinking for a week when we went to this restaurant.

Deviled eggs - excellent!  4 stars
Compressed watermelon - just ok.  3 stars
Fries - very good.  4 stars
Brussels sprout chips - very buttery.. too buttery. 2-3 stars. 
Twice baked potato - this was super good.  Very cheesy so beware if you don't like a lot of cheese. 4 stars
Ahi entree - my husband said this was excellent. 4 stars
Chocolate cream brûlée - this was a cup of chocolate goodness!  4 stars

I would like to check this place out again when I can eat more than just veggies!
author: Jennifer L.

description: We went here for brunch on December 24th. Usually we love Park Tavern but this was a awkward experience that makes me not coming back. Too many other good choices in the city with better customer service. It was fairly empty but the waitress was totally stressed. She was pretty rude and pushy. We waited for the food forever, water glasses were never filled and no one came by to take our drink order. Something was totally off this day.
author: Diana B.

description: Incredibly tasty burgers with horseradish sauce . Its amazing !!!! Service , atmosphere , everything is beautiful ! Would recommend . Especially for dates !
author: Jay M.

description: Food here is awesome it was my third time back!! previous times were all amazing ! This time we came in on a Monday and we  sat at the bar! I should of sat at a table because the bartender splashed me so many times it was as if i was on an amusement park ride.. "caution if u sit in the front row u may get wet !!" still love this place. next time ill bring my rain coat !!
author: David L.

description:
Came here for a work dinner and was given a prix fix menu (with customized menus).
The first course included brussel sprouts (YUM!) and deviled eggs (equally YUMMY! I think this place began my kick for deviled eggs and egg sandwiches haha!) Had seared scallops as an entrée, which was melt in my mouth happy. Dessert though was a bit meh, they had a "birthday" cake and it tasted a bit frozen. They also had a chocolate creme brulee-esque dish, and it was good, but very, very indulgent.

Service was impeccable and they have an extensive drinks list (cocktails and wine). Make a reservation if you want to come and eat here!
author: Christina C.

description:
Food: amazing! The chicken is a lot of food so consider sharing. Wonderful presentation. The truffle fries and the steak were great. 
Service: great. Attentive and nice. 
Atmosphere: very cute.
author: Lena R.

description:
Only came here because it was related to Marlowe.  I arrived about 15 minutes before the friend I was meeting and decided to wait at the bar.  Bar service = fabulous.  A woman seated beside me ordered a drink that the bartender *thought* he knew how to make, once served - he stood and waited for her review... she stated that it was 'alright' but that she was used to a couple other particulars, he took the drink and re-made it to her specifications (even crushing the ice to match her description) and handed it back to her.  Having been a bartender previously - I felt this was pretty impressive, considering that the bar was full.

The drink selection alone was impressive - and wines were also varied.

The food was simply excellent.  I tend to shy away from the new age 'deviled egg' that has less egg and more deviled - but the waitress convinced me to give them a try - and I am ultra happy that she did.  They were delectable.

We shared the scallops (entree) as an appetizer, which they properly split for us - I had the twice baked potato and a salad for dinner, my friend had the marlowe burger - sub truffle fries.

With regard to price, I'm not sure what some people expect - it's SF and you're either a foodie or not.  If you want $5 toast don't come to a restaurant of this stature.  The end.

Everything was simply awesome.  I will be going back many times to come.  Happy to have a version of Marlowe even closer to my apartment, and a larger more upscale rendition of one of my favorite restaurants to boot.
author: Candace M.

description:
I just like this place...just like I like Marlowe. It can get a bit pricey, but service has always been good, food is consistent and drinks are strong. Can't ask for much else.

I am still craving the deviled eggs and Marlowe burger. Scallops are also really good.
author: Karen S.

description:
A fantastic selection of meat and seafood... and if you fancy, just share a bunch of appetizers and eat tapas style.

I especially loved the Devil on Horseback (prawns with lardo), lemon chips (fried lemon slices! Strangely delicious) and two applications of brussel sprouts.

Their wine selection kicks ass and we progressed from light (Pinot) to bold (Zins) reds. The cocktail selection was pretty sensational also.

Come eat outside on a sunny afternoon/ early evening... it is well worth it.
author: Joyce L.

description:
I really liked Park Tavern for brunch. We showed up early and were seated promptly. When our order was put into the system incorrectly, our waitress apologized and brought over some delicious pastries for us to eat in the meantime.

My husband had the duck egg sandwich, which was fantastic. I had the cast-iron baked eggs which were just okay. The avocado toast was really, really delicious though and the Bloody Mary was on point. I would definitely come here again!
author: Meghan S.

description:
Food was okay but do not come here if you have any kids. They will make you feel like second class citizens. We came on a Sunday for breakfast. After waiting twenty minutes to be seated they put us at a table by the bar away from the main restaurant seating. 

The table they gave us was so high up from the high chair they provided us. Which, made it really impossible for us to feed our son. Since he couldn't reach the table we asked to be moved to one of the many empty seats in the dining room. Upon asking the hostess looked around for a second and came back and said sorry we can't move you.

In addition they gave us a really dirty look when they saw our stroller as we walked in.

We were so hungry or we would have walked out.
Talk about a bad experience 

In the end of the day we are all paying customers and deserve to be treated fairly
author: Carl L.

description: My hubby took me here for a mother's day surprise (thanks hun!) However, he didn't account for what a pain in the arse finding parking would be and by the time we arrived, we were in a rush to catch a show. The staff was more than accommodating to our situation which deserves 5 stars on it's own. The food itself was delish. The arugula salad with strawberries was fresh and reminded me of a happy summer day. The polenta was flavorful with a perfect poached egg.  I loved the ambience and decor.  I would definitely come again.
author: Grace H.

description: Came here around noon after a wedding at St. Peter and Paul's on a Saturday.We were seated at a booth right away. Hubby and I got the cast iron skillet eggs and the crispy polenta cakes with poached eggs and mushrooms topped with Parmesan. Mushrooms smelled strongly of truffle oil but the taste wasn't overpowering. Went perfectly as a bite altogether especially with the yolk from the perfectly poached eggs. I wish they had a side menu to add extra protein as hubby only had a slim slice of ham on top. Hubby's plate looked pretty but the flavors weren't strong enough for me. Kind of pricey for the size of the dishes at $12-$18/plate but it was tasty and the service was excellent. I recommend but don't come starving. Or go get some gelato around the corner.
author: Erin T.

description:
I came here with some people from my firm as a work dinner and I am so happy that my firm partner chose this restaurant.  Our 4+ hours there were so amazing and I cannot wait til I can come here again with the bf.

As soon as I sat down, I ordered the Moscow Mule.  It's a bit stronger here than I'm used to but still good.  Their drink menu looks very extensive though so I'll be sure to order something else next time.

We had the much raved-about Deviled Eggs, half with bacon and half without for the vegetarians on our table.  I don't know if it was the bacon but these were so damn delicious.  I loved that it had a little kick from the smoked jalapenos.

The Brussels Sprout Chips surprised the entire table - who knew that baked vegetables can be so darn good?  It has inspired me to turn every vegetable in my fridge into a chip with the use of olive oil, salt, pepper, and an oven.

The Lemon Chips with Burrata were okay.  They fried the lemon peel with it so you get a slight bitter taste but it was a refreshing dish.  I'd rather pick the sprout chips.

The table forced me to pick another appetizer so I asked our waiter what he recommended.  He responded PT Fries and he promised it would be amazing.  I have to say, I was very hesitant because how amazing can fries be?  Yeah well, they can be pretty amazing if you fry them in flavorful truffle oil.  I'm talking about truffle that you can taste, not like other restaurants that call their regular french fries "truffle fries."  On the side was a cracked soft boiled egg with caviar inside, which not only made the dish visually appealing but enhanced the flavor of the truffle oil.  There's also sauce on the side, which I think was some kind of aioli, most likely garlic.  In any event, you don't need it - the fries are perfect as they are.

The boss wanted the Butter Lettuce Wedge to take a break from all the fried and heavy foods.  The fennel vingaigrette made it a great refresher.

Some people at our table really liked the Cool Roasted Cauliflower but I did not, mainly because of the bellpepper sauce (romesco) the cauliflower laid on.  I'm not a fan of bellpepper so that's that for this dish.

The boss ordered the Scallops and she was very satisfied with it.  I had a taste and it was just okay for me. Someone else ordered the Sea Bass, which was really good.  The fish was so soft and juicy it melted in our mouths.

I, being a red meat fan, ordered the CAB NY Steak.  For all of you who are immediately captured by the words "bone marrow," just be aware that it's fried kobe beef stuffed back in the bone.  In other words, you're not going to get the creamy, full-flavored deliciousness that is bone marrow.  Trust me, I found out the hard way.  But that is not to say that it wasn't delicious.  It's creative and it was flavorful (though the flavor and texture reminded me a bit of corned beef) but it's kind of a waste to fry perfectly good bone marrow.  The NY steak was done perfectly to my liking - medium rare.  You get two pieces, though I did not need that much since I was popping out of my buttons by this point.  The broccolini and crispy potatoes were also done well.

Though dessert seemed ill-advised and impossible, we still manned up and ordered an Apple Cheddar Crisp and the Chocolate Creme Brulee.  The apple cheddar crisp is really the way to go.  You get ice cream on top of a warm apples with a hint, but not too noticeable, of cheddar.  The creme brulee was a little burnt on the top so we tasted some bitterness but even if it wasn't, I don't think it would've been anything amazing.

All in all, we had a great time.  We enjoyed our servers a lot (they were all very accommodating and didn't mind when we sat at the bar longer than we needed to) and the food was terrific.
author: Linh V.

description:
Greg and I had been wanting to try out Park Tavern for awhile, especially since the American restaurants have been a huge success in San Francisco (namely Wayfare Tavern, Bix, and Baker & Banker) in our opinions.  I took Greg here for an early birthday celebration last Friday night, and I was surprised with how amazing and vibrant the crowd was there.  Usually when I think of North Beach, I think of late night pizza, King of Thai, and cheesy Italian restaurants.  Park Tavern, however, is a total gem right by Washington Square Park.  We showed up to our reservation just about 20 minutes early, so we were prepared to sit until our 9:15pm reservation was ready.  Just as we were getting comfortable at the bar, we got seated!  The whole restaurant is a little on the noisy side, and while normally sitting in the back corner is a bad thing, I actually think that this made the whole experience that much better.  We were shielded away from the noise, and got our own private nook right by the kitchen.  I had done some research on the place (thanks Yelpers!) leading up to this, so once we sat down, I knew almost exactly what I was ordering.  And the decision went as follows:
-Twin Peaks and Panhandle cocktails.  Personally, I thought my drink (the Twin Peaks) was better than the Panhandle.  But the bourbon and lavender combination in the cocktail was unique and definitely tasty.  
-One deviled egg. Yes. Just one.  Isn't it awesome that you can order things that way?  Now, Prospect has exactly the same style of deviled egg, and while this one tiny appetizer was amazing, I have to say that the deviled egg battle goes to Prospect.  Still, it was an impressive take on something that is usually meant for Super Bowl finger food.
-Brussel sprout chips.  It's true Yelpers, this is exactly as awesome as everyone proclaims them to be.  Greg typically doesn't like brussel sprouts (I'm just coming around to them), but the one word we both used to describe these are "addicting".  You couldn't just have one without wanting to dig back in and have more.  I would definitely say that this is one of those things where I attempted to clean the bowl without licking it.
-Classic Angus steak tartare, quail egg, wild arugula & grilled baguette.  In comparing to our previous experiences with steak tartare, this was definitely good appetizer, and I would definitely encourage people to get this, but this comes in second in comparison to Bix's version.  Like I said, the arugula and baguette that comes with the dish is a nice pairing together.
-Both of us ordered the Marlowe burger and enjoyed every bite of it.  I was tempted to order the Poulet Rouge, except cutting through a chicken that size seemed a little intimidating.  We ate everything on our plate.  And I mean, everything.  For something under $20, I thought this was a complete steal.
-Earlier on we had ordered the artisanal cheese sampler and asked for it to come out after our dinner.  By that point, I was reaching maximum capacity in terms of stomach space, so I only got to sample a small tasting of each one.  The soft cheese, which was probably goat cheese was my favorite.
-Normally I stop here and discuss how great of a meal it was, but being that it was Greg's birthday, we couldn't have dinner without a small slice of this month's Birthday Cake.  Yep, they change the birthday cake each month!  This month's sampling was of Doolin's Gingerbread Cake with quince compote & cream cheese frosting.  And really, when you see cream cheese frosting, all of a sudden your stomach has just created a little bit more space for you to try it.  

Our waitress was great, and always made sure we had our glasses full.  I really enjoyed our whole experience there, and thought that it was a great place to take someone for their birthday.  Overall, it doesn't quite overtake Bix or Wayfare Tavern, but this is definitely a solid four star meal.  A big restaurant, a great crowd, delicious food, a wonderful date, and good service.  You really can't ask for more than that on a Friday night!
author: Lisa I.

description: insanely amazing brunch.  i just wrote a resounding review for Chapeau another non-affiliated restaurant we had dinner at the night before so my apologies if this review is brief.  but sometimes brevity can go a long way especially when it potentially paints images of incredibly prepared corned beef hash and the most amazing oatmeal walnut pancakes you dan dream of.  again, only went for brunch, but would go back 52 weeks a year if I didn't live in LA.  that being said, please open up a location in Los Angeles, i will be your ambassador.  for now, i'm gonna stick to being such on Yelp
author: Ashley S.

description:
I normally don't brunch in North Beach but on Saturday my friends and I checked out this place before trying wedding dresses near by. Amaze me the number of great reviews this restaurant has, I would have to come again and see if it amaze me as well, it definitely didn't this time around.

Things you need to know, for brunch this restaurant is in the pricey side and portions are not too big. I loved my dish and everything else looked delicious, but was a bit meh that some of us left hungry after eating here. Figured we should have ordered more than one dish. I ordered the beef hash and was very delicious, a bit salty for me but I enjoyed it very much. We also had a pitcher of a vodka lemon drink, was just ok.

I was not a fan of the service, super slow! It took a long time to get our food, to get the check, to get receipts back. Lots of smiles but there's opportunity for improvement on the service part. Service is a big part of a good restaurant, I was upset the Whole time because was too slow for me.

I would love to check it for dinner. The presentation of dishes was great, but again for brunch I personally would like bigger portions.
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
It's always in the girls' bathroom where you get good intel on a place.

I was supposed to come here with my brother and some guy pitching to sell something.  The guy pitching bailed (hey, he's selling) and my bro and I went on to have dinner here anyway, then drinks.

The place is cavernous.  It's not an intimate sotto voce place either for dinner or drinks.  The seating is neither family style or intimate. Even in the bar area.  There's diners and drinkers but no one feels cared for.   Essentially, you feel uncomfortable in either space.  

It could be the seating, it could be the service or even the meh food.

Like the other Yelpers, and the lady in the loo, she said service is uneven, food is ok, head to cocktails.  haha she's pretty on.

What's cool about this place?  It's really big, there's an outdoor part so if the weather's nice can do a sidewalk al fresco.  

Would I come back, sure, but it's not a place I would say hey babe rock my boat bring me to Park Tavern.
author: S P.

description: Omfg what a complete waste of money and effort. This is our 5th time here and last, all other times have been for brunch. The staff is useless and obnoxious. For such an expensive place with a great location...it has become a tourist trap. The servers were just extremely rude and tried to pretend that the restaurant is upscale....yes it's an upscale IHOP.
author: Christian R.

description: We got the foie gras, lamb, pork chops, and maple crime brûlée for dessert. The foie gras melted in my mouth and was absolutely fantastic - must try if you're here. Lamb cooked to medium rare was a great choice, and comes with a spicy sausage as well. Everything was absolutely fantastic, but make sure to get reservations in advance unless you want to sit in the German beer-hall style table.
author: Or R.

description:
One of my absolute favorite places not only in North Beach but in San Francisco!

The restaurant itself is a simple and rustic style of decor that draws me in and never gets old. I love the vibe of it. The staff is excellent. They're true professionals and there has never been a time that I've been in there that even one of them has disappointed. They great me with a warm welcome every time I go there.

The food has always been consistent and delicious. I'm a huge fan of their deviled eggs; simply a must-have virtually every time I go. The pork chop is one my favorite entrees for flavor and portion size. This thing could easily feed two people! Don't forget the classics that they've brought from their first restaurant, Marlowe, like the brussel sprout chips, the Marlowe burger, and the truffle fries.

If you're there for drinks only then sit at the bar or the community table which serves as an extension to the bar and allows visitors to eat too. You can eat at the bar too but the table allows you to sit face-to-face with your friends, etc.

This is and will always be one of my favorite go-to spots in town!
author: Gabriel R.

description:
I will probably receive some backlash for this one, but I digress...  I am currently attempting to go to a new restaurant every week during the calendar year of 2012.  Park Tavern is restaurant number 3 for me.

Ambiance:  This place is sleek.  Like really sleek.  It has a very sophisticated, 1920s decor.  I was personally absorbed with the vantage point from the front door; to the right you see a very classic bar that has both standing and tall tables, while to the left you have the main dining area.  You may catch yourself being absorbed with the modernly metallic, yet classically appealing lighting, same as you may come to appreciate the intricacies of the tiled floor.  The bathroom is also quite impressive.

Service:  Ack, the sticking point.  We ordered about 5 things - two entrees plus three items from the small plates/appetizer menu.  The food came out in a disjointed series of some together, some later on, and some being forgotten.  We sat for a good 15 minutes before our order was taken, and we spent another 10 minutes before our drinks arrived.  Mind you, this was on a Sunday night, but it was the Sunday before MLK Jr. Day, so it was unusually busy.  The bright spot is that when we asked for our Deviled Eggs (the item that never came and had been forgotten), the waiter was kind enough to comp us for it on our bill.

Food:  We came here specifically because of a review that I saw in the San Francisco Chronicle.  We were prepared to be wow-ed if not amazed.  In the end, it was good, but nothing was amazing great.  One item in particular that we REALLY wanted was the Brussel Sprout chips.  They were out (grin).  So we got the Deep Fried Oysters...  They were okay.  We also got the deviled eggs... which were tasty.  We split a burger, and they were kind enough to double up on the fries that came with it, but... nothing about this burger was remarkable.

Maybe next time we'll try different items.  I give this place a 3.5 - 3.75.  I'll try it again someday, but hopefully I'll have a better time.
author: Bryan H.

description:
Went here on a recommendations from a friend we were meeting. This place is very high class spot in North Beach area. The customer base is of those who probably have a company expense card. 

We order the Sea Bass dish with mash potatoes and veggies. When it arrived at the table our eyes were larger than the cube of fish on our plates! The mash potatoes were literally a little squeeze from a pastry bag and spread out in a tear drop on the plate to hold the veggies which consisted of celery and a few chopped olives on top. 

Food quality, flavor, presentation and service was the reason for the 3 stars. I might have given them 4, but when I walk out of a place after spending over $60.00 for one person to dine with a glass of wine and tip and I'm still hungry, there is no reason to ever return. 

It had all the qualities I look for in dining out but I didn't order a sampler plate for that price.  There are BY FAR way to many other fabulous choices in the North Beach area to spend that kind of money and walk away feeling satisfied you got your $$$ worth.
author: Jennifer D.

description: This place was unbelievably good, and the service was outstanding!
author: Galina H.

description:
The service was very good and the food was tasty. The portions on the short rib and the mussels were what I expected, hardy, however, the bar steak with fries was enough to feed a petite woman, but not a hungry man. The noise level as most others have posted was very vibrant.
I enjoyed the desserts of mousse and Creme brûlée.
author: Kris G.

description:
I lived in North Beach for 5 years and the space was always occupied by terrible restaurants until Park Tavern came along. Thank goodess! The location and space is amazing and shouldn't be occupied by lame-ass reataurants, esp in North Beach

I really enjoyed my dinner here. 

Highlights:
- Lemon Chips with Burrata: Heaven. Truly. Light, slightly tart, and amazing with the creamy burrata
- Deviled Eggs: i'm not a fan of deviled eggs but these were SO delicious! I wanted 5 more...!
- Shirmp wrapped in bacon: i had this and the soup for dinner instead of an entree. It was yummy
 Lobster Crab Bisque: tasty but really really salty. They should really take down the salt a few levels. Otherwise, a tasty dish
- Dessert: Honestly, i don't remember what i had for dessert but it was good...just not very memorable

The restaurant was quite a scene. Be sure to dress for a night out!
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Really great. On the pricey side but worth it if ther for a nice dinner. My favorites are the appetizers - deviled eggs, kale salad and Brussels sprouts all delicious. Healthier are the Brussels sprout sides. The fish and meat are great, and wine selection delicious
author: Allie M.

description:
I think that rating on the star spectrum has lost its luster for me because it doesn't fully encapsulate an experience. Thanks be to yelp for allowing me to pen a discursive narrative that subverts the stars.

MM and I ventured here this week after realizing that we'd both placemarked it. Made a quick reservation for 8:30pm but arrived an hour earlier hoping to sit at the bar or snag a table. Were the stars aligned for these aspirations? Yes and no.

We were seated at the communal table and told that we could either dine there or wait, but that we probably couldn't get an earlier seating. Hakuna matata. The place was packed and  it was a vibrant and kinetic scene. Laughter, cocktails en route, discourse, and all that makes a place worthy of your presence. Just after ordering we were told that we could be seated, as there was a last minute cancellation. Wunderbar. We had already ordered drinks but were told that they'd be able to catch our connecting flight to a real table. They failed to be rerouted, but we ordered them again with our waitress, and were soon delivered a gorgeous bourbon sidecar and a negroni for my classy companion that were perfect representations of the ideal.

MM wanted the Mendocino uni with chili served on butter lettuce because I'm from Mendo County. Actually because we both love uni, but the former reason sounds cooler. We soon ordered entrees, mimicking each other and choosing medium-rare Marlowe burgers. The uni came quickly, and was delicious, though didn't need to be served on lettuce as it detracted from the uni. The burgers took over an hour to arrive, because the order was misplaced! It was nice to have time to catch up, but wow, that was a long time. Once the misdeed was realized, several beautiful people dropped by to express their apologies, and the drinks and entrees were graciously compensated. The burgers were perfect as perfect. They've got this TCHO chocolate creme brulee with chili that purged any misgivings I might have been having about this restaurant, and when paired with a glass of Mary Etta's bubbles, I was a forgiving bubbles.

I might have been initially bruised by the frenzied service and misplaced orders, but the gallant gesture to waive most of the bill, and the bill of fare itself turned my scars to stars.
author: Joanna M.

description: I was a little disappointed, ordered the ribeye and it had great flavor, however I didn't like that they cut into chunks and it was tuff. The chairs are very uncomfortable and the tables are barely wide enough for two plates. I won't recommend this place. Two stars for the great flavor of the steak.
author: Tom L.

description:
Been a fan of The Cavalier and Marlowe so Park Tavern had been on my list of a next great meal.  Went there for my BDay dinner.  Everything was amazing -  food, decor, ambiance & service.  The place was hopping on a Mon nite, pretty incredible in the restaurant biz.

We had lemon chips w burrata and PT fries w truffle, soft-cooked eggs and caviar to start. Somehow I'm still missing Cavalier's chicken fat fries.  Duck was slightly over cooked and on the chewy side but still decent.  Petrale sole was perfectly cooked.  Gnocchi w wild mushrooms & thyme was lightly browned on the outside and delivers plenty of flavor.  Side dishes: butter-braised spinach and broccolini were over cooked, but brown butter brussel sprouts were great.

Had Dave's classic carrot BDay cake w cream cheese frosting which could go down as the best carrot cake in history!  Both the olive oil polenta cake w almond ice cream and the carrot cake were incredibly light yet delicious which are hard to do.  

Will go back to explore the rest of the menus for sure!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Wow, their brunch pallet is the best around.
Five stars for about their whole brunch menu. 
Tried dinner twice. I'm not sure how it's  possible, but it's like a polar opposite experience. The hen's awesome though. We'll stick to coming here for brunch.
author: Christopher R.

description:
We were two couples who had dinner here on Jan 2.   We expected the place be a little down after the big holiday rush.  We were not disappointed.   The location is great.  The interior is very well done.   All four of us marveled at the the place.   We started with cocktails.  They were well crafted and served right away.   Lots of bar space.   We were promptly seated for dinner.  The waiter made great suggestions.  I hate it when the wait staff says that everything is  great.  He answered all our questions.   We tried three appetizers and four entrees.   The deviled eggs are THE best I ever had.   They are currently pretty common on alot of menus and so I didn't expect much.   We ordered a second batch because everyone in our group wanted another one.   We also had the brussel sprouts and creamed kale (i think.)   Entrees were the burger (Fantastic,) the tuna ( no one cared much for it,) the Poulet Rouge (very very good,) and black cod miso  (everyone's favorite.)

Wine selection was good.  Had a tempranillo (same bottle three times, about 18.00)
author: Mando G.

description:
Update- two words for your mouth: CAULIFLOWER SALAD. I. cant.get.enough.

Oh, but I saw stars during the consumption of their brussels sprout chips.
author: Angela B.

description:
Nothing brings a smile to my face more than good food, fabulous cocktails and friendly bartenders.

Walking home the other day from work on a bright and sunny day I realized as I passed Park Tavern I had yet to be in to the highly acclaimed "new" spot in the hood. I felt like a disgraced North Beacher thinking that I hadn't made my rounds to one of the newest editions in the hood. So I stopped, turned around and walked inside. 

The bar is well lit but not overly bright, with just enough mood lighting to make any drink look sexy. Though small in size, I was able to navigate the area and find a stool right up front in the heat of the action (just the way I like it) and upon touchdown met two of the nicest bartenders I've ever encountered. Upon their recommendations I started with the Brussel Sprout Chips (to die for!), the deviled eggs (even better!) and ended with the beef tartar (holy cow, blew my mind away fantastic). Washed all down with the Country Lawyer and I do believe you've made me a loyal fan.

Thanks gentlemen for the lovely evening...
author: Stephanie J.

description:
Excellent service, excellent food, excellent drinks.

I especially would recommend the deviled eggs, brussels sprouts, and the poulet. I've dined here three times in the last 6 months and it is now firmly one of my favorite SF restaurants.
author: Jeff S.

description:
Park Tavern is a breath of elegant air in the heart of Washington Square.

Yes, it's a masculine tavern-esque space.  Yes, it draws a more upscale crowd than it's sister restaurant., Marlowe.  Yes, it's a change-up from the typical North Beach beat.  But rest assured (exhale), Park Tavern emits warm vibes from the moment you walk inside.  Anna Weinberg and her team have successfully executed a space not lacking any personal attention.  Anna glides through every corner of the restaurant greeting her guests, consulting her staff, and ensuring that everything runs smoothly.  

Now let's get to the food....I had the pleasure of trying some small dishes and a dessert :)  Flavors are reminiscent of Marlowe--simple, a hint of bold, a lot delish!  Did you expect anything different?  Stars on the menu:
**Fried Green Tomatoes
* Buratta with fried lemon and basil (LOVED this dish)
**Deviled eggs
***Just a note, they do have Brussel Sprout Chips a la Marlowe :)

The dessert menu is short and sweet.  The lemon cake cake sings :)  It's a birthday dessert that rotates each month, so get in and try it before it changes next month!

Park Tavern, thank you for bringing some well-needed style to the North Beach :)
author: Angella S.

description:
Having been a fan  of Anna Weinberg's South and its transition to Marlowe, I couldn't pass up the opening of Park Tavern. I enjoyed Moose's back in the day, that gave way to Joey and Eddie's and has since shuttered. Now the Marlowe team with Dave Stanton of Tres Agaves has taken the Marlowe concept and multiplied it in a singularly large space. They've darkened the interior and given it a nice brasserie classic look. After having a business meeting across the square, we made our way over for dinner.

Some Marlowe classics and some new ones to be sure read across the menu, all sounding very good. With four people you can do a lot of damage so our order storm looked like:

-NY Steak crudo, horseradish, arugula & parmesan
-Brussels sprout chips
-Sea salt & vinegar pork rinds
-Pork belly bites, horseradish aioli
-House made beef jerky
-Fried oysters "Caesar" salad
-Yellow Doll watermelon & Mangalitsa prosciutto, truffle & mustard greens
-Creamed seasonal greens
-Roasted farmers market peppers
-Twice baked potato, crème fraiche, cheddar & scallions
-Anson Mills polenta, roasted nectarines & balsamic glaze
-Park Tavern "Poulet Rouge", Bloomsdale spinach & Peewee potatoes
-Lamb chops, Merguez sausage, greens
-Fernet milkshake
-Seasonal Fruit crumble

Did I say we were having a feast? As to Marlowe's excellence everything was delicious. We finished just about everything. A fantastic meal. Even their cocktail program is excellent. I had a drink I'd never seen before, the County Lawyer,which is a classic throwback to the days of yore. Our server took great care of us and made quite a few great recommendations. I think one of the highest praises you can give a restaurant is that if you can't tell that they just opened, they're doing something right. It flowed like they'd been open for a while. Definitely worth a trip back if you're on this side of town and not already at Marlowe.
author: Kim N.

description: A really fun place - love the decor (cozy, dark, rustic, modern at once) - hip young crowd - amazing deviled eggs. We sat at the common table and our waiter was lame. Took us asking three times and 30 minutes to get my stepdad a glass of chard, and the others of us all had our wine. Other than the waiter, this was a winner.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I was lucky enough to be invited to the Zagat Survey's Launch Party here.  I remembered the space as Frankie and Johnny's (yes, I stand corrected, at least I got the "two male names" concept right) recently and as Moose's when I was a kid.    

The surroundings are beautiful - dark, masculine, sexy - MR. Park Tavern.  The bathroom was pretty and I love the mosaic design on the walls.  The heavy use of wood evoked warmth and the lighting added to the overall impact of the place. 

Some specialty cocktails were available for the event and I had one in particular that was lovely and packed a punch - the Washington Square, which was anything but!  The bartenders were friendly and watching their mixology was like watching mad scientists in a lab. 

They had bar bites which included smoked almonds, house made jerky, and brussels sprout chips (divine).  We also had pork rinds (4505 still wins, but these were pretty darn good) and deviled eggs that may give another "Tavern" a run for its money.  Burrata served on lemon "chips" with basil was refreshing and yummy.  Fried oysters served atop a lettuce leaf were also good.  The winner...pork belly bites!  Little bites of heaven and triple bypass rolled into one.

I'd like to come back and have a proper meal.  I admit that the food may have played second fiddle that evening -- being part of the intimate affair with some of the industry's bigwigs had me kind of awestruck.  Next time, I'll pay more attention to the food, the service (which was friendly enough as dishes were passed by servers), and the people making the food-magic happen (they have an open kitchen).

Till we meet again, Mr. Tavern...
author: Moo C.

description: Simply delicious! The place has great ambiance and the food was outstanding! The brussel sprout chips are a must !!!!
author: Micole A.

description: Comfortable restaurant with tasty food and drink. Enjoyed the Brussels sprouts chips and deviled eggs for appetizers. Short rib was tasty and tender, as were the greens and beans. For dessert chocolate mousse was rich and flavorful. Good craft beer, cocktails and wine. Nice atmosphere for conversation.
author: Larry P.

description:
We went here for weekend brunch.

Decor is very attractive.

Service was good, everyones food was good, nice tasting creative plates.

They serve mixed brunch type drinks by the pitcher, the iced tea vodka one tasted like a bad Snapple drink :(

Prices were average for the city.
author: J. G.

description: Our service was 5 stars! Armando and Jason were amazing and catered to our every need. The food was wonderful as well. Can't ever go wrong with the burger. The deviled eggs and French toast were great too. One star off for not having PT fries till 5. We need those fries for breakfast please. Jennifer Puccio please bring the fries to the day menu!!
author: Mary s.

description:
The food is pretty good, and service is ok, maybe a bit on the slow side. A couple of outside tables have a view of Washington Square, but you are right on the sidewalk.

I had Brussels sprouts chips, PT fries, and scallops - everything was tasty, but their portions are quite small, so the price doesn't seem right.

I recommend to visit this place at least once, but I wasn't impressed enough to go there again.
author: Stacy A.

description:
The last time I was at this location was when the place was called Moose, I think that was the name. So basically, years ago. North Beach is a funny one for me because I love the neighborhood and have never had a bad meal there. But the parking is horrendous.

Park Tavern solved that, valet! Love it because I think valet helps raise the expectation a bit and lets you really make your dining choice feel like an occasion. 

The decor was lovely but I'm wondering if just a few more noise canceling pieces might help. However, that's really nit-picking because the food was pretty notable that I honestly did not care if the conversation was interesting or not, I just wanted 'one-more-bite'. 

Favorite bites were:
The Polenta. Hot diggity was it good. Small portion but a good bite doesn't have to be a trough of food. Perfectly crispy on the outside, delicious soft center with very clear flavors. 
The Hash. Wow, this is not your average interpretation of hash and 100% better for it. My poached egg was lovely and the corned beef devine. It was a little salty but nothing the acidic greens didn't correct if combined in the bite. 

Yum yum yum guys. Yum!
author: Kerensa H.

description:
Pros:
-Upscale, modern decor. Think black-and-white color spectrum, moose antlers, wooden frames, and succulents. 
-Excellent customer service. Waiter was extremely attentive and accommodating. Busboys ensured that water was never less than hall empty. Hostesses were polite and waitresses cleared our plates immediately. 
-Clientele was mostly upper middle class to upper class yuppies. Well dressed, and I presume well educated. An interestingly far cry from the usually SF restaurant. 
-Food was spot on. Waiter's suggestion of the deviled egg single toast with pickled jalapeños, cheese, chicken, and bacon did not disappoint. Not gonna lie either, the fries on the side kind of made my day. I was less impressed with the Brussels sprouts chips, perhaps because it was overhyped on Yelp. In reality, $6 for a bowl of mini Brussels leaves seemed anticlimactic. 

Cons:
-Only major major major disappointment was the price to portion ratio. My friend and I were not ravenous or anything. In fact, we were mildly, or normally hungry. However, we were still noticeably hungry after $15 individual brunch plates and a shared side of Brussels chips. A tall and husky guy seated next to us ordered drinks, appetizers, two brunch entrées, and ate part of someone's burger! Definitely not enough for a normal appetite; you will either over order at Park Tavern, or continue eating your way through the city. Personally, I suggest the later potentially cheaper option!
author: Phoebe C.

description:
I'm a fan of any place that plays John Legend, and especially if they play P.D.A!

I came here for my birthday, and it was a really great experience.  We were seated promptly, and we had a nice table right next to the window.  I think this place is filled with a lot of work dinners on weekdays, work dinners more than dates.  

We ordered two carafes on wine, red and white.  Our server was very attentive, offered a lot of suggestions.  We started with the deviled eggs, a must have!  

And then I had the Wild California halibut for dinner.  It comes with smoked sweet corn & potato "risotto," snap peas, pea tendrils & toybox tomatoes.  It was delicious.

I definitely will be coming back.
author: Anoo L.

description: Ate brunch here on xmas eve, the food was delicious and the ingredients were very fresh. Only complaint was that all of their brunch dishes are $20 and only come with one egg? I asked for an additional egg on my egg(s) Benedict and they did so for an extra $2. No adult breakfast entree should come with only one egg.... Overall food is delicious and staff was very nice.
author: Alyssa W.

description:
I've been wanting to try to place for awhile since I'm a fan of Marlowe and have only heard good things about Park Tavern.

The grilled pork chops were heavenly, as were the little pieces of bacon that it came with!   I would say these chops were comparable to Mustards in Napa and that says a lot.  I've driven to the wine country just to go to Mustards.

I'm a sucker for burrata, so we had to start with the lemon chips, mint, burrata, & Shelley's pea tendrils, which did not disappoint.  I was a little hesitant about the lemon chips but they weren't overwhelming and balanced well with the cheese.

Good pre-dinner cocktails and great atmosphere.  Despite the crowd, it was easy to converse with my guest.  

It was definitely worth the wait and I plan to return.
author: Marleen C.

description:
Park Tavern is excellent. Bravo!

Definitely a gem in North Beach.

Excellent space, great bar and cocktails.
 
How do you make ordinary fries extraordinary?  You add a soft boiled egg with caviar as a dip. Duh !

Gnocchi was different than any gnocchi I've had.  Great

Deviled eggs. Yum

Steak.  Cooked perfectly and leaves a nice char taste in your mouth.

I shall be back here.
author: S G.

description:
Love love ............loved it here!! 
Started with the brussel sprout chips, deviled eggs, and the burger to share. YUM! The brussel sprout chips were so light, airy, and addicting! The deviled eggs were impeccable. Bacon and jalapeno complimented it very well! The burger did not disappoint and I can definitely see why Marlowe is so successful!

For entrees we got the mussels, chicken, pork chop, and scallops. Mussels were delish, the fennel sausage cream sauce on the bottom was even better!! My dad sopped up all the goodness from my plate. Haha. The pork chop was hefty, juicy, and delish. The star of the show though was the chicken. SO GOOD! Moist and juicy and oh so flavorful. Such a neat take on beer can chicken. This is a mustttttttttttt try if you are here.

For dessert we shared the cheesecake parfait with smoked salt. Wow- it was a crowd pleaser!! The smoked salt atop was a great compliment to the creamy parfait. 

Overall, a wonderful experience. Service was excellent and they even comped my mom's soup because it didn't come out at the same time as the rest of our dishes. Talk about customer service!!!! :)
author: Angela D.

description: Brussel sprout chips are SOOOOO good! Had my doubts about them until I tried them. And the deviled eggs were seriously amazing...mind blowing! Lamb tongue was delicious and tender, and the crab was good with a crisp taste of apple slivers to refresh the pallet :) loved this place and would absolutely come again!!!!!
author: Amanda T.

description:
Absolutely love this place. If I lived in the Bay, I would definitely frequent it. 

Unfortunately my friends and I were only here for brunch, which of course, did not disappoint. Embracing my new obsession with polenta, I had to get the Crispy Polenta Cakes which was elegant and delicious. The eggs were poached perfectly and the wild mushrooms complimented the cakes very nicely. My friend ordered the Open-Faced Deviled Eggs Sandwich, which was definitely the most hearty of dishes but she enjoyed it.

Our waiter was extremely helpful and warm and provided excellent service. Love the open kitchen as well! Definitely a must try if you're in the area!
author: Jaimie L.

description:
Well what can I say about Park Tavern? We really wanted to love this place...and we did like it but definitely did not love it. We had been sitting on a gift card for dinner there for sometime and we finally decided to head over on a Wednesday, figured middle of the week shouldn't be too busy right? WRONG! Earliest reservation 9pm! Oh well we took it. 

When we got there I was a little surprised how very busy and loud it was! Why the 4 stars? Because the food was very good, the famous brussels sprout chips were a unique experience, braised short ribs were cooked perfectly, and my wife said her pork chops was a win too! However I really can't get over how loud the restaurant was ...maybe just an extra busy night? Wednesday?  

If we came back it would probably be more for a cocktail or brunch, yeah the food was good but wouldn't be our first choice for a romantic dinner.
author: Jay L V.

description:
Two must have items for me here:

Deviled eggs, bacon, pickled jalepeño & chives - $2 ea

NY Steak crudo, horseradish, arugula & parmesan - $11

It's that good and I am happy to sit at the bar just to have these two apps with a glass of wine.

We have also tried on another visit:

Kampachi, kaffir, grapefruit & finger lime - $13 - if you like sashimi, you'll like this

Hawaiian tombo tuna, crispy sunchokes, white anchovies, baby artichokes & salsa rustica - $26 - this is SO GOOD.  Enjoy it while they have on the menu - it's such a perfect combo of everything.

LEMON CHEESECAKE PARFAIT - $8 - Huckleberries & smoked salt - not bad.

One extra app we tried last time: 

Demons on horseback - $13 - large shrimp wrapped in lardo, lightly pan seared - YUM!

The Cabinet Franc under Rose - $12 - is quite good.
author: Gloria H.

description:
To be fair...it seemed like a very off day today when we attended brunch, but $60/pp later no excuse!

Waited an hour before our food arrived, they brought us one of their featured toast's as an apology (could have given us free drinks rather than pushing more product), but unfortunately when the food finally arrived it was less than average. Not sure what happened in the kitchen today but I could have made myself a better meal and it wouldn't have cost $60. 

I will say they were apologetic, but I honestly do NOT get the hype of this place! 

Next Sunday Brunch at my house! I guarantee it will be better, and I won't charge my guests $60 a piece!

so disappointed!
author: Wendy W.

description: It´s good but not in a way where the food itself would make me return. More the ambience and that it´s quite inside. The service is good, not impeccable. I would go here again but I do understand why place does not have 5 starts.
author: Hanna A.

description:
I really can't say enough about this place. Some of the highlights:

1. The bar: I love the bar. Forget the great people watching and beautiful people; Jack the bartender rocks. 

2. The burger: Try it. The burger here is top-5 in SF.
author: Yum N.

description: Deviled eggs, Brussel Sprout chips and the best martini I've had in San Francisco. They book easily, so plan ahead of you want a table. Otherwise, there is seating in the bar. I love the dim lit atmosphere.
author: Blythe B.

description: Do you like Micheladas?  This review is for the brunch. Everything we got was horrible. How do you mess up a Michelada? By making it so spicy that you can't drink it. Be prepared to pay way too much for not great food. Everything we got was mehh. The food for dinner though is really good. So 3 stars for that.
author: Michelle B.

description: Excellent breakfast place and you don't have to wait hours to get a table. Bloody Marry with Devil's eggs and beef hash was very delicious!
author: Aleks D.

description:
Brunch here was horrible.  We ordered Michilada's and it was so spicy that not one of us could drink it.  When asking for tomato juice to calm our drinks down we were charged extra! The food was watery and overlooked and each dish was so salty.  

I do not recommend coming here for brunch.. Although I have heard dinner is amazing!
author: Stephanie B.

description: Just before closing the tables in the dining area start to clear out, but who moves in? The mice!!! I saw more than one mouse rumbling around the tables. The only reason I did not make a scene about it was because I was too embarrassed to have suggested this place as an option to bring our customers for dinner. They did not need to know that the mediocre black cod they just ate might have been walked on by some small creature.
author: Karla B.

description: One of my SF mainstays. Food is always delicious, cocktails are inventive and fun (try the "Saturday Morning Cartoon" for brunch),  view is beautiful, and service is consistently great. I can always count on Park Tavern to be a good time all around!
author: Rebecca g.

description:
The place is very pretty.
The service is professional.
The food is just ok.

We came on a Sunday night for dinner to meet out of town guests.  It has a large dining room area and an open kitchen so it was a good place for a group, albeit somewhat loud.

Entrees are priced between $20-35.  I had scallops, which were cooked really nicely, but sloppily thrown on a plate with prosciutto and spinach.  Also ordered at the table were the burger, red snapper, and the restaurant's version of cioppinno (can't recall what they call it).  No one was over-impressed with what they had, especially at that price-point.

Probably won't return- plenty of other great restaurants to try in this city.
author: John B.

description: Nice place. Good service and good food. The Brussels sprout chips were great!  The ribeye and hangar steaks were well prepared and delicious.
author: Phil M.

description: First of all, the restaurant neglected to tell us it was a set 3-course menu @ $85pp for Valentine's Day (and that's not including drinks), so when we sat down, we were surprised with that.  Once we sat down, the service was just OK.  They forgot a couple things here and there.  Lastly, the food was seriously mediocre.  I've been to my fair share of restaurants in SF and I've had a much better/flavorful meal for a third of what this place ended up costing.  My girlfriend ordered her steak Medium and it was rare.  I really expected more for the price, a lot more actually.  The ambiance, however, was nice, so I'll give it that.
author: Jason P.

description:
Sound level - 2 stars - Wow, what is it about these folks from down under?  All three of their places (The Cavalier, Marlow AND Park Tavern) in SF are way loud!  Could hardly have a conversation with the person standing right next to me.

Wine selection - 3 stars.  Good variety but they need to provide richer flavor whites.

Deviled Eggs - 4 stars - delicious and not greasy.  Love it

Lamb Tongue - 4 stars - yummm! Loved the balance between the acid and richness of the tongue

Bass Main course - 2 stars - over cooked and dry.  ARGH! can't stand it when restaurants overcookd their fish so it's dry and flavorless

Pork Chop - 3 stars - very flavorful but again a bit overcooked.  Tone it down boys - the meat should be flavorful in itself.  No need to go crazy

Orange Birthday cake - 3 stars - descent - cake part was airy and flavorful but it would have been more interesting if they could have balanced out the sweet with some bitter flavors.

All in all, a decent place.
author: Lev E.

description:
Worst brunch place ever. The food was good. I had the burger and it was okay (not like nopa or anything) and the rack of bacon which was amazing. But it was after that made me dislike this place.

I woke up with a massive headache and felt awfully sick. Park Tavern was the only thing I ate that day and i felt like i was hit with a massive dose of MSG. I doubt that Park Tavern uses such a thing but there was definitely something that was wrong with my food that made me feel so awful.
author: Grace C.

description: My sister who lived in SF for more than 5 years wanted to share one of her favorite restaurants with us, Park Tavern, and I happy she insisted until we decide to accept giving it a try. We were happy to experience some of the most original flavors we've tasted in American style food. I had the Spaghetti squash carbonara, it was incredibly decadent with lots of cream, butter, bacon and some squash thrown in! My sis had the Demons on Horseback: bacon wrapped prawns with Lemon chips? Yes! A great idea: lemon slices topped with a light burrata cheese, then decorated with sorrel. Everything we ordered was a feast for the senses. Desserts are
author: Alicia R.

description:
A group of us had brunch at Park Tavern recently to check out the brunch menu that was unveiled in March. A fairly new restaurant in the North Beach neighborhood, Park Tavern is spacious and modern, while maintaining a rustic appeal seen in distressed wood ceiling columns. It is restaurant decor that I could easily see Bobby Flay or Tyler Florence embracing.

While having a beautiful interior, I have slightly mixed emotions about the food. I sampled a decent selection...some was good and some was easily skippable:

- banana and coconut fritters with raspberry compote: A huge fan of banana served in sweetened preparations, and of coconut in general, I had high hopes for this starter we ordered to share. However, apart from the banana flavor, I tasted nothing but oil from the deep frying process. Coconut was unfortunately absent. Yea it was cool that it was served on a piece of black slate. But for $9? Don't bother with this dish.

- brioche french toast with blackberries and vanilla-maple syrup: I'm not sure why this dsh doesn't have better reviews on Yelp, but it was actually decent french toast (yes, I've had much better, but I could've easily been pleased with this dish). The portion size was ridiculous with two monstruous pieces of brioche. Consider sharing with a friend, else this dish can, and will, overwhelm you with its sweetness.

- cast iron baked farm eggs with baby spinach, gruyere, and prosciutto: Nice menu description, but unless you're Popeye or an extreme spinach-lover, skip it. The spinach is lightly sauteed and very much in its raw form, so its flavor overwhelms the other components of the dish. While an egg dish to begin with, you forget egg is even involved.

- crispy polenta cake with wild mushrooms, poached egg, arugula, truffle salsa verde, and shaved parmesan: Hands down the best dish on the table. Also a large portion size with two large squares of polenta each topped with a poached egg, I actually could've eaten the entire dish had I not been sharing. The tuffle flavor complemented the egg, polenta, arugula, and mushrooms perfectly! I really enjoyed the various components of this dish.
author: Mansi A.

description:
The good: The food was amazing. Well executed with some not so me-too twists on familiar dishes (Yellow Doll Watermelon & prosciutto).

The bad: The restaurant could use to feel more quaint and intimate, maybe, um, like Marlowe.

The final thought: Compared to it's food/price/type contemporaries, would I return? Yes. Soon? Depends.

The P.S.: Shannon, our server, was knowledgeable, personable, and comfortably attentive.

---

Mclaren Cocktail
Pork Belly Bites
Fish Dip
Yellow Doll Watermelo & Prosciutto
Seared Scallops
author: James G.

description:
Brunch review.  

This place is delicious for brunch.  Came here last Saturday morning and sat outside.  Great view of Washington Square.

Drinks - the bloody marys are perfect - very spicy.  The espresso drink with fernet is pretty good as well, but I barely caught a buzz from two of them...maybe the pancakes soaked it all up...

Pancakes - I love good pancakes and these hit the spot.  Fluffy and the perfect size.  The butter and syrup are already on the 'cakes when they come out FYI.  

Cast-Iron Baked Farm Eggs - amazing.  The cooked spinach and eggs are great together.  Comes in a small cast-iron skillet.

Crispy Polenta Cakes - girlfriend got these.  Had a bite and they were amazing.  

Toast - order one of the sides of toast!  Had the Avocado toast - I'd never had avocado on toast before, but it was perfect.

I'll be back.
author: Dane P.

description:
From the team behind Marlowe, proprietress Anna Weinberg and chef Jennifer Puccio, Park Tavern is a great addition to the restaurant scene around Washington Square Park.

Located in the space the formerly housed Moose's and Joey & Eddie's, Park Tavern is the perfect antidote for these uncertain economic times.  Rather than frou-frou, Park Tavern is solid and simple; it is American food:  reasonably priced meat and potatoes, not tarted up frisée salad with poached organic, free range quail eggs sprinkled with some esoteric salt harvested by blind one-armed nuns on a remote island in Java.

With white tiled floors, dark wood paneling, and nicely dim lighting, the frill-free, the dining room is cozy without detracting from the main event:  the food.  Park Tavern is not a place for vegetarians.  It is a meat-eater's restaurant--the kind of place that makes you want to order steak medium-rare.

The Brussels sprout chips ($6) are so good they will make you forget you are eating a vegetable.  The "Marlowe" burger ($13) served with caramelized onions, cheddar, bacon, horseradish aioli, and fries was tender, juicy, and delicious.  Moist and tender, the Park Tavern "poulet rouge", (AKA Cornish game hen, $22) was served on a upright spit with spinach & Peewee potatoes on the side. 

While the food is good, the bar is not far behind.  High-end, "mixologist" cocktails are available, at least six craft brews are on tap, and at least 25 well priced wine selections can be had by the glass or carafe.  

Service was spot-on.  Water glasses never went unfilled, dishes arrive with good pacing, and used plates and utensils were quickly removed.  Servers were knowledgeable about the menu, easily answering questions about ingredients and how dishes were prepared.

With Park Tavern, Weinberg and Puccio have a hit on their hands.  Grab your reservations before everyone else finds out and you cannot get in.
author: CJ G.

description:
The smoke flavor on everything including on their salad and devil eggs was overwhelming!!!
I usually have a great experience here but last night it was just awful......even their scallop dish was poorly prepared. I mean what happened to the simplicity they used to offer! Maybe it's just their new chef.

I'm glad Marlowe keeps it original!
author: Maz G.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  It's a very classy and fresh restaurant.  Great for cocktails and dinner.  Or you can just stop in for drinks.
They have a great appetizer menu.  There is a range of menu prices which makes it great for a casual burger dinner or a fancy steak night.
The Burger is excellent by the way.
author: Rob S.

description: There was a two hour wait at Mama's across the street, and I was on a time crunch, so I went across the street at the advice of another Yelp user who did the same thing instead of waiting at Mama's. I got sat immediately, and a delicious meal of French toast with blueberry compote, and a Shirley Temple. The bartender was friendly, and I was in and out of there as quickly as I needed so I could explore the rest of the city for the first time. A great price as well!
author: Melvin D.

description: Perfect brunch spot don't forget to order the avocado chili toast
author: Mel S.

description:
There's good food everywhere in the city, so comparatively speaking, I would give Park Tavern 3 stars. It's located right by Washington Square Park in North Beach, so it's super convenient and popular. 

I will say that the service here is great. Our party had a reservation, but we had to wait an additional 10 minutes for the waiters to clean the table. In return, we got free brussels sprout chips. Our waiter was also super effusive and happy to explain everything on the menu and make recommendations. He actually recommended one dessert we didn't end up liking, so he comp-ed that. Um, amazing. 

As for the food, I really liked the pork chop. However, the poulet noir was a little underwhelming. The chicken was dry, and for $28, I'd expect something a little bit more special. They also have an amazing dessert menu, so definitely check that out.
author: Alice W.

description:
Park Tavern is a rare balance of sophistication, liveliness, and tastiness. The place is well designed and feels welcoming.

The bar is well staffed and a great place to get a meal if you don't want to wait for a table. The drink menu is quite extensive and they can make great cocktails.

In terms of small bites, I'd recommend the brussel sprout chips. They are basically leaves of brussel sprouts roasted with some salt and maybe oil. Very tasty.

The mushroom/khale soup with poached egg has a complex flavor that is quite good.

The kampachi dish is well presented (on a stone slate) but is otherwise unremarkable.

Service is attentive and stellar.
author: Victor W.

description: Delicious deviled eggs and a damn good old fashioned.
author: Caitlin C.

description:
I have now eaten at Park Tavern twice, and both times it was equally as impressive. 

Both visits I ordered the Brussels sprouts as an appetizer, great crispy and lemon taste! Plus, you get a fair amount!
