I've had the pork and the burger, and I loved both! Beer and wine selection was awesome. Service was great. If you make a reservation, it seems that you get seated pretty much on time.
author: Rebecca M.

description:
I am so happy that we got a recommendation to come to Park Tavern for our first night in San Francisco! From the service, to the awesome cocktails, to the to die for food...this place was perfection to me.

We came on a Friday night around 8pm and they told us it would be about an hour wait for an outside table.  We thought it would be worth it so headed to the crowded but bearable bar.  Even though it was packed the bar tenders were still really attentive.  I only had to glance down at the menu and see a strawberry basil caipirinha to decide on my drink. It was really nice and  refreshing!

Once we sat down we ordered the brussel chips and devilled eggs.  My best friend and I have always said there should be brussel chips! They were awesome with a slight lemon zest taste and the perfect crunch.  My very picky boyfriend even loved them.  The devilled eggs were some of the best I've ever had.  They use almost the whole egg ether than just half and top it with a generous piece of crispy bacon...ah mazing!

Both of our entries were really good as well. We got a steak and the burger.  To top it off every single staff member at this restaurant was super nice and attentive.  I you find yourself in San Francisco make it a point to come here!
author: Kelsey S.

description: I'm a regular customer and usually go for their Marlowe Burger. Park Tavern has become my favorite restaurant/bar for any occasions, bday, date, friends brunch, family dinners, you name it! And their drinks... those guys know their craft!
author: Gabriela M.

description:
Brunch has always been the best, especially the avocado toast! 
Service has been mixed - be sure to make a reservation. Always busy!
author: Jalpa P.

description:
One of my standby restaurants when in San Francisco. I'm not sure I've ever said this about another restaurant, but I think brunch here actually exceeds dinner. 

I guess toasts are already becoming passe, but the toasts here (particularly the one with dungeness crab) are tasty little morsels. Both the sweet and savory brunch options excel: I particularly like the oatmeal-raisin pancakes and the warm, open-faced deviled egg sandwich. 

Dinner options are well-executed and tasty. The NY steak and Colorado lamb are very good. I like the pork chop a ton, but think I prefer the one at Foreign Cinema. All in all, a great and predictable food experience that could use a dash more creativity. 

A couple last notes: I love the space. It somehow manages to feel fashionable and timeless all at once, though the bar area can get loud and crowded. Service is always reliably polite and competent.
author: Andrew D.

description: Saw the piece on Bay Area Check Please and decided to go last Monday. The show featured brunch, we went for dinner -- a $108+tip mistake. I ordered the Bar Steak medium rare and my wife the Pan Seared Halibut. The steak arrived in a bowl with the fries. It was blue/rare. I should have returned it but thinking it was a good cut dug in ... I was wrong. I was barely able to cut it with the steak knife and whoever thought it should be served in a bowl obviously never had it themselves. Not sure why there was nerve running though it, but that stuff is like strapping tape. The fries with the steak were good. My wife's halibut was cut very thin and cooked to a crisp leaving it dry with a crust, not pan seared. The mush of vegetables and rice under it was ok once you figured out what it was. The brown butter Brussels sprouts were greasy with what appeared to be a crust from the pan. The Park Paloma tequila cocktail and deviled eggs were both good and kept the meal from being a total waste of time and money. The service was very good. I guess that on Mondays the owner is absent and no one is watching what comes out of the kitchen ... not what you expect from this kind of restaurant. The other reviews say brunch is good, perhaps. Dinner was disappointing.
author: Jeff M.

description: Over $100 to be ignored by the bar staff and jostled by passing waiters for a "Bar Steak" which was an over-seasoned, sliced, piece of tough beef the size of a packet of matches, a plate full of McDonald's like fries, a bitter salad, and a glasses of terrible house cab sav. Interesting crowd but don't bother with the food and don't expect good service.
author: Aaron C.

description: My son ordered the salmon. It was undercooked. Then when it came back out it was way over cooked. I ordered the ribeye and it was ok but the sides that came with it were not good at all. Ordered a side of their brussel sprouts which were great. No refills on sodas for kids either. Who does that?!?Also had a 9:15 reservation and didn't get seated until 9:50.
author: Jake G.

description: I love this place! Great food and the service is also good too! The Marlowe burger is delicious! I highly recommend it. Also the salmon Benedict is really good too. It's a great place for brunch , lunch or dinner! It isn't so pricey. I highly recommend this place :)
author: Aubreyana P.

description: The lardo wrapped shrimp are a must. Also enjoyed the Gazpacho. Very cute vibe but our waiter was a bit of a dud. We wanted to try a bunch of different things and he seemed irritated we weren't just ordering two entrees.
author: Lacey L.

description:
I've wanted to check out Park Tavern since it opened as everyone I know that has eaten there has had really good things to say.  We didn't get to have dinner here (yet) so we opted for brunch.  We didn't have a reservation but were there when it opened and we got a table no problem.

We listened to our waiter and got most of his recommendations which were great.  I started off with a Bloody Maria which was good but definitely not the best Bloody Mary type drink I've ever had.  The meal was delicious though.  We had the butter cake which was so tasty and the grapefruit to start off.  Our group had the dutch baby, polenta cakes and country ham steak and everything was delicious.

Can't wait to come back for dinner now.
author: Blake B.

description:
Love the location, love the ambiance. Roomy restaurant. Solid in every way.

Deviled Eggs interesting and and worth a try. Everything else very good - professionally presented - yet all for me unspectacular. 

That isn't to say you shouldn't try - it's very good and worth a visit.
author: Jim S.

description:
Not your typical North Beach joint, this is a classy eatery! Really nice bar with hand crafted cocktails, amazing deviled eggs and house made Wagu Beef Jerky.... I ordered two orders to go!
Our dinner was just as expected, great. Very busy, hard to get in without reservations but worth the try!
author: Brook M.

description: Had a dinner party here and really enjoyed it. The deviled eggs were a hit as an appetizer. All of the dishes were delicious and the service, ambiance and location were great.
author: Tina N.

description: Wonderful attention by the receptionist and the wait staff. Great food, friendly vibe, and relaxing ambiance. Great place for business dinner.
author: Evaldo G.

description: I came for brunch and my Grapefruit Shandy was refreshing! I like dark rich coffee, a cup that gives you an orgasm feeling after the first sip, you know. I didn't like theirs, it was too light tasted a bit watered down and almost sour tasting( I even asked the waiter is your coffee sour? He said no). I ordered the polenta cakes with poached eggs and wild mushrooms. OMG so good! The polenta was very light and creamy perfection. I LOVED the mushrooms, they were perfectly cooked delicious. Poached eggs perfect too. I tried my friend's baked eggs, meh. Crab toast to start, not a fan. I would so go back for the polenta cakes.
author: Karen T.

description: One of the best city breakfasts. Enjoying everything from savory polenta to not too sweet pancakes.
author: Becky A.

description:
Fantastic food and drinks.  I've been for brunch and dinner and stopped in for cocktails only.  Each time I have enjoyed myself and so have the people I have been with.  Love the space (thought watch yourself on those slippery floors).  The upstairs bar is really cute too and very laid back.

P.S.  Great brunch cocktails.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
My husband LOVED the burger at Marlowe, so when we heard about this place opening, he made reservations ASAP. 

We were a few minutes early for our reservation, so we ordered drinks at the bar, but were seated by the time we got them. Nice. 

Service wasn't great, but it was only their second day, so it can totally be forgiven. Our server was very pleasant, just not very attentive. 

We each a had a DELICIOUS deviled egg. I was impressed they could get so many textures and flavors in such a small item. 

Neither of us had ever had fried green tomatoes, so we had to try them. They weren't overly greasy, (which is always my fear with fried food.) It was a perfect amount to share, and we both enjoyed them. 

My hubby had the burger and fries, which was just as good as we remembered from Marlowe. 

I had the mussels, which were awesome. The broth had great flavor, and i loved the bits of leek and sausage. 

We shared the "birthday" cake for dessert, (it was even going to be my birthday soon.) It was light and moist, and a perfect finish to a great meal. 

I really liked that many of their dishes are smaller, that way I get to try more items. 

Good drinks, good food, beautiful space, and service that is sure to improve.
author: Amanda G.

description:
I came here when my friend lived on Polk Street and the brunch was fantastic.  I ordered the corned beef hash, which was super unique.  I would definitely recommend this dish!  You could literally see the corned beef hash and potato, whereas other restaurants the corned beef hash normally looks like cat food (which I think still tastes great).

All of my friends ordered a Bloody Mary, which was super strong.  Surprisingly, they didn't have extra stalks of celery or veggies to put in the drinks.  I ordered some citrus whiskey-like drink which was refreshing.

Overall, a great brunch spot in a great location.  I would highly recommend this restaurant for brunch, and still have yet to try it for dinner.
author: Andrew H.

description:
I heard about Park Tavern in an edition of Man's World that I purchased in Paris.  Being from SF, I was surprised that I didn't know about this place, and it was great that I learned and went to it.  

It was a nice change of scenary for me, since its located in the heart of Little Italy.  You'll find locals and tourists.  Locals will be dressed up; tourists...the usual attire for them (very casusal).  The service was excellent, but it was pretty noisey. 

The food was excellent.  If you want steak and pork, this is the place for you.  I had the pork, which was amazing with a great portion.  The starters are a good size too.  

The cocktail list is pretty broad and they have a wide selection of wine.  The desserts were amazing.  We had the cake of the month (celebrating my partner's birthday) and we had a Captain Crunch ice cream sundae.  I'm not a big dessert person, but I'll admit that these were amazing!

We'll definitely go again.
author: Bobby James G.

description:
Our party of three ordered starters and main courses. Everyone agreed the food was very good. The drinks were as well.

That said when auditing my charge account I noticed the waiter gave himself a larger tip than I wrote on the check. Three are many options in San Francisco thus unfortunately I won't be back.
author: R S.

description:
Went for lunch on Friday and it was more then I expected. The open door seating was exceptional, the noise on the inside was the typical lunch rush conversations, moderate noise level. We chose to seat inside facing the street. Nice choice. I had previewed the menu on line and pretty much knew what I wanted when I got there. I had the Marlowe hamburger, Hush puppies and the 24oz beer. Our waitress was the BEST ! Her name was Shayna and she was right there serving us and helping us with the little things that we had requested (I wanted my hamburger cut in half). My friend had the steak, arugula salad and a nice wine. We wanted to have coffee and (oh my God) pumpkin cake on the sidewalk seating. Perfect again ! Shayna found us a table and brought us perfection on a plate. We watched the entertainment pass by and people were shopping and returning to work. 
Here's the bottom line, the valet parking works but is a little pricey ($12.00), the food and service is VERY GOOD and fresh, again a little pricey but worth it. The service is fabulous, thanks Shayna. Open air for desert and coffee (priceless) and you car is delivered to the sidewalk when your finished. But when you read the menu, read the lower right corner, which reads that there will be an 8% extra charge for "City Mandate". So our bill was $100.00 for 2 people and 8% was $108.00 plus tax and tip. But if you pay the price, you will enjoy the food, service and convenience. . . .I'm sure that we'll be back. . .
author: John94521 H.

description: Fantastic food in a nice ambience.  The bar tender was particularly friendly and had great mixology skills, though sadly their scotch collection leaves something to be desired.  Really I want to give it five stars, but it's lacking something to push it to the top 10% for me (that's my bar for 5 stars).
author: Greg B.

description:
Hype.... not worth the trip
Our dinner was free and I can not recommend it !
There  was something amiss with every dish.
They do not care.
author: Roxanne Y.

description:
Ate a casual dinner at the communal table last Friday night.  It was my third time at Park Tavern -- once previously for dinner and another time for brunch.  I've always had good food when I'm there, though it is definitely not a value dining destination.  

We had the PT fries at this most recent visit.  OMG.  Unreal.  I've never dipped a french fry in to an egg before...but I plan to again :)
author: Tami S.

description:
First, let me give a shout out to my homie, Nathan, the host. 

The fireplace was roaring, the booths were intimate (as promised), and everyone except our server was really awesome. Then we saw some guest appearances by some bomb pork chops, good cocktails, and these deviled eggs with bacon and jalapeno. Me and the lady are coming back soon to say hi to our new friend Nathan and get drunk at the bar - and heckle our server.
author: Jordan E.

description:
I wish this place was around when I lived in North Beach.  The food is amazing, all the way from the deviled eggs and demons on horseback (shrimp!) starters through the chicken fried sweetbreads and steamed mussels.  Definitely get the twice baked potato and brussel sproud sides, and follow it up with the chocolate creme brulee.

Everything here is excellent followed by some true moments of brilliance.  If they keep it up they're going to earn their first Michelin Star in a few years.
author: Chad T.

description:
Bottom line at the top: High quality and tastily-prepared food. Great fine-dining atmosphere and can accommodate larger groups. Service is ok ... but should be better given the tier of restaurant. Portions are too small for what you're paying. Would I come back? Yes... if it's on someone rich's dime.

Came here for brunch in a large group. Thoughts about particular items:
Avocado toast - this was incredibly incredibly tasty. But I have to kick myself in the face every time I start to think it was worth the $10 for ONE piece of toast, half an avocado, and seasoning.
Smoked Salmon Benedict. Since when is one and not two poached eggs delivered with your benedict? Never unless you are at Park Tavern. On the plus side, the smoked salmon was plentiful and tasty. No way you'd fill up on this single $17 dish
Marlowe Burger - can't speak for the taste but my friend who ordered it was not too ecstatic that the burger patty did not come close to covering the surface area of the bun.

Service was friendly enough but our coffee cups sat empty for a good 45 minutes until someone finally came by to refill at the very end of our meal. Small detail, but one that shouldn't be overlooked.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
Got lucky and scored a reservation for 7PM last Saturday night, by calling in at 11pm the night before! We drove and used the $11 valet which is super convenient for the heart of North Beach.

We started with the deviled eggs and NY steak crudo. The eggs were just OK, with all the hype I was expecting a bit more...but they were almost too pickled like they had been sitting in juice for a long time. The steak crudo on the otherhand was fabulous. Slices cut about 1/4 inch thick, lightly covered with a lemon sauce, arugula pieces, and breadcrumbs. All the flavors complimented each other perfectly and the only downfall was that is wasn't twice the size to make me twice as happy!

For entrees we ordered the poulet rouge - tender, large, and living up to it's reputation; the pork chop - cooked perfectly, worked with all the sides it came with, yumm; and the tombo tuna - this was our least favorite, not much flavor, small. We also ordered a side of polenta - the richness of the dish contrasted perfectly with the pickled cabbage on top. One of the better polentas I've had!

For drinks I had the Mckinley to start. At $13 I expected more, it was nothing special. The Au Bon Climat Chardonnay was amazingly buttery and delicious, went perfectly with the fabulous meal!

We a port to end the night and were sad they didn't remember to bring out the birthday cake since we had stated with our reservation it was a birthday dinner. Oh well, we were satisfied enough with the overall experience that I will happily go back - as long as someone else is picking up this bill because this place aint cheap!
author: Rachel G.

description:
Michael Mina, Gary Danko been there done that. But Park Tavern, now there's something special!

Saturday morning Brunch was AMAZING!!! Service was top notch. Staff was very attentive and intuitive. I stated in our reservation that we were celebrating our anniversary, when we arrived not only did we get one of the best seats in the house we also received two large glasses of champagne, compliments of the house.

Bravo Park Tavern!!!
author: Luke B.

description:
If I could give a 3.5, I would. And it might be a 4 if it hadn't been so hyped. We had a very nice meal at Park Tavern, in lovely surroundings, with above average service. But it wasn't all that I was hoping for. The brussels sprouts were excellent, but everything else was just fine. Well cooked and presented, but the flavors just weren't that exciting to me, and my dining partner was even less impressed than I was. I would eat here again, but probably won't seek it out, which is unfortunate as it's in my neighborhood.

And on a side note: when dining out, get off your smart phones and live a little! It creates a really different atmosphere to have everyone staring at their phones, the blue from the screens illuminating individual faces, rather than  people chatting with each other in convivial conversation. I love my phone, but sometimes I think they are the scourge of society.
author: Jeneen J.

description:
Some things a Black, Southern woman doesn't do.  One of them is say that anybody cooks something better than her grandmother.  So, you must keep what I'm about to tell you a secret:  Park Tavern makes the best deviled eggs I have ever tasted.--hands down.  Do you understand that Black women across the south are rolling over in their graves right now!! Forgive me! I just can't tell a lie--those eggs are that daggone good!

Everything is good here.  I don't have time to go down the list like I'm a professional reviewer, but everytime I've eaten here, everything has been exceptionally delicious.  It's loud so don't come here looking for a romantic evening for two.  It's trendy and delicious. You want a good time, good service, and exceptional meal--Go.  It's that simple.
author: Randi A.

description: Good space, nice food, and some pretty looking dishes.  Everything was upscale solid, not quite mind-blowing. We didn't get the chicken everyone was getting, so might come back to try that. And they brought out a birthday dessert, which was nice.
author: Jay S.

description: We had the 3-course fixed menu for lunch.  It's $150 of average food. Definitely not worth coming back.
author: Levent K.

description:
The cheese plate was pretty good. The soft Harbison cheese was my favorite. Excellent pork chop: juicy, tender, succulent... I could go on. The deviled egg is necessary. The chocolate creme brulee with chili flakes and sea salt was quite mouth watering. 

Interior design: Nice open layout with various configurations for seating. The bench is  a lot lower than the chair which was a little awkward. Ambiance is great. Our server was very knowledgeable and friendly. Also for the sober people out there they have a great cocktail called the Mclaren that they can make non-alcoholic: cucumber, lemon and ginger beer. 

Highly recommend.
author: Roxanne L.

description: Took my client to this place for dinner it was such a lovely place! We picked the place because we wanted something casual and nice... And turned out it was still pretty upscale casual! The place was beautiful with brick interior and nice decor. Very classic and fresh. Lots wine to choose from. The only down side is the food. It wasn't all that great but I love the feel about this place. The tables are very small and kinda of shaky so ideally not so good for large or small group seating. However we had fun! Spent over $400 on dinner and didn't look at the wine menu but I bet it was expensive cuz the food was only like $150. Over all pretty nice but wish for that kind of money the food would be better. The Brussels sprout chips were completely burned and dry... PT fries was ok too. But if you are looking for a cute place to catch with friends or have happy hours with customer, this is a place! They also have a long bench&chair set up by the bar which looks really cool. Didn't have reservation and got in right away is always a good thing!
author: Mingge L.

description: Came here for dinner with some work peeps. We started with the Brussel sprout ships (excellent) and deviled eggs (looked better than they tasted). The cocktails were excellent and the vibe was lively. I ordered mussels as my entree and they were awesome. This place is known for the burger which many people in our dinner party seemed to enjoy.
author: Meg S.

description: Park Tavern is consistently great when it comes to food, service, and ambiance. It is always the place I can count on to impress my out town guests and its Washington Square Park location adds to the charm. The food is innovative and delicious for brunch and dinner.
author: Sophie J.

description:
More of a cafe than tavern to me. Park tavern is a definite stop on your SF BUCKET LIST. But as a restaurant not a tavern. 

The Marlowe burger with PT FRIES is a must. 

Though I'm not normally a fan of bread pudding I'm looking forward to coming back for seconds sometime.
author: Mike D.

description:
Awesome food!  Parking here is a huge pain but the experience was worth it.  Friendly hostess willing to seat when entire party isn't there yet (cuz of parking nightmare).  Having valet is good.  Fries with soft cooked egg w caviar is great!  Impressed the head chef did quality control on dishes and actually sent some back that didn't meet her quality standards.  Dessert was creative and tasty.  Drinks were good but expensive.  Brussels chips are delicious and just like Marlowes, though I'm a bit turned off by the doubling up on Brussel sprouts where we pay for the chips and again for the sides.. For essentially the same Brussel Sprouts :p.  
Summary:  yummy food with great service and I would return.
author: Win L.

description:
Ok, I'll just jump right in with the 3 reasons this place is 3-stars in my book.

1) I understand that saturday nights are busy but if you can't provide excellent service to each person you seat, I strongly suggest you put a cap of the number of people allowed in the restaurant. The only reason I remember our waiter is because he kind of looked like Mark Zuckerberg, but I don't remember his name because he never introduced himself and only came back to take our order and ask us if we wanted more booze, in passing like he couldn't even make a full stop. For real?

2) Can you say pretentious? I did about 12 times while seated on the patio watching the other patrons arrive in their maserati's wearing micro mini skirts and bandeau tops grasping the shoulders of the people they were meeting and pulling them in for air kisses saying "bisoux bisoux!" I kid you not. This ain't Beverly Hills, lady, take a pill.

3) The food was honestly nothing to write home about. I don't know if it had to do with the rush the kitchen was in, but my pan-seared sole looked great and the fish itself was cooked well, but the flavor was just not hitting the mark for me. The veggies that came on the plate were good, but the sauce tasted like whipped mustardy hollandaise and mayo and I ended up avoiding it a little. The BFs roasted halibut was much better, but made me realize that maybe we're very gifted chefs, as it wasn't in any way better than what we make at home. I think it would have been more enjoyable served on top of a warm salad, and once again, the sauce was a little mustardy or tart, why? The PT fries were very good, the caviar in a soft boiled egg is an idea that we will be using but the horseradish mayo, while cost effective for the kitchen I'm sure, was unoriginal and not particularly enjoyable. My etta's bubbles cocktail was delicious, and paired pretty well with my meal, good job bartender person.

While the flame of my love for this place's brunch menu burns on, I will avoid dinner hour here because it turns into a "see and be seen" reality tv sideshow, instead of the upscale but laid back place to get a good meal and take in little Italy, that I described to the BF to get him to give park tavern a try. Overall I think the service and food suffered from a focus on quantity over quality and crowd was too "chic" to notice, or maybe didn't care. But we found ourselves disillusioned by the experience :/ Oh well...
author: Courtney L.

description:
Lovely place, lovely service, lovely food. It was bustling and warm and welcoming. The food was delicious

 My husband ordered the NY Steak that was served with bone marrow, several types of potatoes, a wine jus, and amazing broccolini, I stole most of it off of his plate.

I ordered the scalloped with tempura forest mushrooms and roasted peppers. It was delicious and cooked to perfection.

We enjoyed the lemon chip appetizer served with burrata and a seared ahi dish. The desserts were great, don't miss the smore that's served with buttered popcorn ice cream topped with caramel corn. Oh-my-God!
author: Cary A.

description: I waited awhile for my friends to show up at the restaurant. By the time they showed up I had been there awhile and the restaurant had gotten pretty busy. When we reminded the waiter  he forgot about us he took care of our dinner for us.  Very classy restaurant. The food was great and I would definitely return. Love park tavern!!
author: Natalie P.

description:
Called in for reservation around 6pm on Sat evening and as expected they didn't have table until 9:30pm. We passed by and gave it another shot. Turned out they can seat us outside and we took it. They have heater of course and blankets but proved to be inadequate later in the evening.

On to the food.. 
Brussel sprouts chips: good flavor and crisps but too salty.
Lemon chips and burrata: zesty chips but nothing special otherwise. Burrata, as expected, is creamy.. We slather it on the bread as well.
Cold roasted cauliflower: interesting take, good flavor but I'd rather have them warm..

Bar Steak : cooked right, amazing french fries but the butter wine sauce didn't go that well with the steak
NY Steak: I finished everything on the place, except the bone. Each was tasty on its own but better eaten together.. yumm..

Roasted sea bass: my party really like the fish but not the sides, too salty.

Unfortunately, the heater was too far up and it got really chilly later so we decided to get desserts elsewhere indoor. Just a warning if you decide to sit outside on a chilly evening.
author: Agustinus T.

description:
Usually great place for lunch and brunch however last experience was not that good.  Poor service (lazy waiter) and ok fish dish.  Sat at table for extended period of time and had to ask for server.  When server appeared treated us as if he did not care to take our order. 

Regarding the food (fish) server did not describe dish and if he had it may have changed my choice to something else on the menu.  

Generally a good restaurant option in North Beach but management needs to  work with wait staff on customer service.
author: Steve F.

description:
My parents are a huge fan of this place. I finally went to dinner with them here after maybe a year of their nagging. Overall, some dishes were very good, some were less impressive. 

In particular, the roast chicken is good, but not unique or interesting in terms of flavor. I was more interested in buying a Staub pan ($160 at William-Sonoma) afterward than coming back to eat that particular roast chicken again. 

Everyone (including my parents) seem to rave about the deviled eggs -- I was disappointed. Maybe I prefer different things in my deviled eggs, but while the toppings were unique and flavorful, I found the egg yolk too yolk-y and not creamy enough.

All complaints aside, nothing was BAD. And the PT Fries were amazing (but it's hard to go wrong with fries and egg yolks...) as was the braised lamb tongue. Would come back, but will skip the deviled eggs and the chicken.
author: Katherine L.

description: Ah' finally a place that offers delicious food with excellent service and valet parking is cheap. Love that. I think the name is a bit misleading the word Tavern generally doesn't appeal to me. We went here with a larger group about 10 of us for my sister in laws graduation. I had brought her a huge boutique of tropical flowers and they were even sweet enough to store them in their refrigerator for us while we ate. I was surprised how much I loved everything on the menu there isn't anything that isn't done really nicely with a lot of care to detail. We'll be back!
author: AMBER W.

description:
Never had anything but amazing food here. Some favorites:
-Any of the toasts at brunch
-The deviled eggs, obvs.
-The lemon chips with burrata
-Brussels sprouts chips
-And THE BEST are the fries with truffle, soft boiled egg and caviar

Always a great go-to spot
author: D S.

description: So disappointing. Food was good--but tried to be too creative. Shouldn't be called a Nicoise salad with no lettuce, all beans, and only tiny scraps of tuna. We had a party of 4, but our waitress fawned over the table next to us, practically ignoring us. Overpriced for the experience.
author: Cindy K.

description: LOVE Park Tavern. Love it even more when someone else is paying because it gets a bit pricey ;) I pretty much recommend anything and everything. We went for a work outing once and between our team, we got most of the menu. I have also returned for brunch a couple of times. Food and service is always extremely high quality, this is a restaurant I would put on my list as a reliable standby for whenever needed (parents in town, friend wants to grab dinner, etc). My only mild complaint is that brunch is very very expensive for ... brunch. It's almost dinner prices.
author: Anna J.

description: Wow! What a great dinner! Delicious bourbon cocktail whose name i can't remember and then we had the lemon chips with burrata and the deviled eggs. They were both amazing, we could have eaten several more orders of both. Lemon chips were seriously crazy good, excellent flavors and loved the generous serving and the DIY bunch of herbs it came with. Shared the pork chop and the tomato tart, both were great. Tomato tart was fresh and well seasoned an the pork chop was tender and had crispy sides that were bacon perfection! Our server was great and very helpful with choosing items and he was spot on with his descriptions and recommendations. July's Birthday Cake was good but didn't hold a candle to the rest of dinner. Will certainly be back and having tried Marlowe we will now try Cavalier.
author: Kelly C.

description:
The atmosphere is so warm, cozy & comfortable here. 

For brunch: Love the avocado on wheat toast. It sounds so plain but it packs so much flavor. Spicy, tangy & salty all in one. We tried ordering it during dinner too but it's only served during brunch.

Brussels sprouts chips are a must here. Wherever I go & order brussels sprouts I always compare them to Park Tavern. None have ever compared to these. 

I always tend to get the negroni here. Strong, bold & delicious. 

Overall everything is consistently excellent here.
author: Val L.

description:
If you are in the area you HAVE to check this place out! for brunch!
Service 5 stars
Food 5 stars
Drinks 6 stars

Try the boozy smoothie!!!! Don't get too excited as it comes in a small glass but holy mother of earth it was amazing!!!  You just might have to order 2!

I had the pan fried corned beef and hash and I can't stop dreaming about it, (hope that doesn't come across creepy) it was just that good!!

Might be one of the best places I have been for breakfast/brunch in a long time!

Price is a lot but worth every penny!!  I am excited to be in town again and try their dinner and see if it stands up!

Either way, check this place out as I think you will for sure like it!!!
author: Mike H.

description:
Good spot. 

I had brunch, which was pretty good. They have a seasonal menu, and I got CAST IRON-BAKED FARM EGGS* | sautéed baby spinach, jamón serrano & Gruyère cheese. It was pretty good, but I was pretty surprise how little ham there was, given it was $15.  

I like the atmosphere - very new york. The service was good.
author: Stephanie M.

description: Eh. Not very friendly. We had a reservation and they had three tables outside. When we asked they said it was reserved. Well, what about the other two tables. I guess our money will be appreciated elsewhere.
author: Kevin M.

description: Amazing! Amazing! Amazing! My first time to san francisco visiting a friend, and she had heard about this place so we made it my last meal of the trip, and i am SO happy we did. Every single thing we ate was delicious. I ordered one of the deviled eggs, and i could of eaten an entire plate of them. The brussels sprout chips were being fought over amongst the table, so good. And last but certainly not least, the chicken. Where do i even begin with the amazingness of this chicken. My friend and i ordered the chicken to share, only in the end were we fighting over the leftover carcass of the chicken trying to eat every last bit of meat. IT IS THAT GOOD. We also ordered the twice baked potatoes to share, which there was not a single bite left of that. SO, all in all, this place is so so good and i would buy a flight right now just to eat that chicken again. PLEASE OPEN A RESTAURANT IN OC!
author: Shea H.

description:
This place is upscale but casual, with a really warm vibe. The staff here is great; our waiter was incredibly friendly and knowledgeable about the menu. 

The food was good but not anything I'd get super excited about. The pork chop dish was good; honestly, the best part of that dish was what came with the pork chop. I had the salmon, which was good but a little salty for my tastes. My brother had the burger and said it was quite tasty.

The July's birthday cake was a really interesting dessert, but it wasn't as good as I'd wanted it to be. Oh, and skip the banana split; there's really nothing good about except the chocolate mousse/ice cream at the bottom.
author: Rachael H.

description:
The food was not impressive.

We tried Park Tavern based on a recommendation from friends (dinner, walk-in, no wait). The service was good, the ambiance was good, but the food was disappointing. We had appetizers, entrees, desserts and drinks and not one thing we tried was great or even very good. The best thing we had were the drinks and they were pretty standard. Personally I would avoid the lobster bisque, it was extremely salty and not at all what you would expect.

No real complaints but I would expect much better food from a high end SF restaurant with a good reputation.
author: Maya M.

description:
Great restaurant! It's consistently good and I always leave happy. I've had brunch and dinner here and love both. 

The brunch polenta cakes are divine. Talk a out yum. For dinner, I've tried a bit of almost everything at this point and really enjoy it all. Even the burger is awesome. One thing I really love are the mussels! It comes with garlicky bread to sop up the glorious broth. I'm getting hungry just writing this...
author: Annie C.

description: loved this restaurant! Nice interior and ambiance, similar to a New York style upmarket restaurant. I came on a date and had the foie gra, carpaccio and brusselspouts, all delicious!
author: Marina D.

description:
Sticking out like a sore, very pink thumb, we coulda been kicked out.  Everyone else was classy, urban, and clean - just like the decor.  And in we burst, a bachelorette party with feather boas, tiaras, and discerning albeit high-pitched palettes.  But the only hard time they gave us was when they warned that only 6 could fit around their round tables.  Really, even with the angel wings, 7 of us fit just fine.

The food was compelling enough to distract us from bachelorette mayhem.  My faves: 
- Crispy lemon chips with burrata: Just genius.  I thought a slice of lemon, dredged in rice flour, and fried in rice oil would still be bitter (given the pith) but it was uh-maaaaazing!  Someone get me a bag of those chips now!
- Poulet noir: Others were not so impressed, but this was a creeper dish for me.  The more I ate, the more I realized how excellent it was.  The skin's truffle perfume matched divinely with the moist, tender meat.
- Parisienne gnocchi: This dish made me swear and shake my fist.  Even after numerous attempts, my gnocchi cannot compare to those light, silky pillows.  Fucking bastards.  Cotogna's gnocchi has now been shoved into second place.
- And while not as mind-blowing as the above, the brussel sprout chips, roasted chioggia beets, lamb croquettes, and variations of duck were solid and drool-worthy in their own right.  The beets were plated like a gorgeous, smattering of jewels.
- Mary Etta's Bubbles and Washington Square were very refreshing. 
- Finally, deviled eggs: everyone else's eyes rolled back in their heads.  But as an oenophobe, I can't comment.

I wasn't as impressed with the leafy salads, halibut, jerky (I don't think this is a worthy expression of Wagyu), the squash soup du jour, strawberry-rhubarb shortcake, nor banana split.

Service was impeccable (aside from the initial resistance to seating 7 people).  Valet at $12 was totally worth it.  And our waiter was terrific.   He comped us a scoop of chocolate ice cream with cocoa nibs.   And he was such a good sport with our bachelorette game of dares...poor guy is probably still trying to remove all the pink feathers.
author: Sandy C.

description:
We had a nice dinner at Park Tavern a few weeks ago.  Nothing spectacular, simply good food and attentive service.  We had a visitor in town,   so I wanted to show her a good time, and figured I'd use my gift card on a splurgy dinner.  

Things started off awkwardly when we arrived and the hostess ushured us through the nearly empty restaurant to a table right next to the bussing station.  Uh-uh, homie don't play that, so we moved to a different location.  Our waitress was really friendly, but a little bit pushy.  Stop coming over every few minutes to see if we are ready to order - we're not!

Once the food started coming out things got much better.  Between the three of us, we sampled the deviled eggs, the lemon chips with burrata and the beef jerky.  After overdosing on the burrata, we decided to simply take the jerky with us when we left.  

I had the halibut, which was amazing, but as reviewer Gwynnie P mentions, everything is drenched in butter, including my piece of fish.  Not that I mind butter, but wow.  My hons of husband had the duck four ways,which was killer.  Duck confit, slices of breast, pate and crispy skin.  Sister ended up with the salmon, which was another fantastic piece of fish.

Again, a pleasant time, but I don't think I'll be back for a while, especially if I'm paying!
author: .Hon H.

description:
Deviled eggs were delish, the burger was very nice too (both of these left me with bacon overload!).

What stood out most was their excellent service. Our server was amazing and replaced my wife's order twice (kinda their fault) and didn't even charge us for it.

The corkage is reasonable ($20) and they decanted our wine (what turned out to be a great barbaresco).

Overall great value and a nice dinner spot.
author: Sumit C.

description:
The brussels sprouts chips are a must try, if you can get into this busy, popular spot. It was hard to get seated even with a reservation on a weekday night.

Good food, but really loud. Not a good place to go unless you know sign language to carry on a dinner conversation.
author: Lee H.

description:
Park Tavern - fucking delicious 

I've been here now for both brunch and dinner.  It initially caught my eye because the decor is modern with lots of wood and really nice flower arrangements, plus it's right on the park. 

Brunch: 
Delicious and got to sit outside with a view of Washington square park.  Had some Stumptown coffee, really interesting 'toast' with sliced avocado on top with sea salt and olive oil (so good!) and some perfectly done poached eggs on some (baked?) polenta.  Honestly, I was pretty tired, so don't remember too many details besides how yummy it was.  Also, the dudes next to us ordered lots of cocktails that looked pretty good. 

Dinner: 
Went with my family for this one, started with a couple of salads (good - not too memorable), but my God was my steak frites (Bar steak?) amazing! Sometimes you just want a good cut of meat and this is the place my friend - steak and fries, no frills, just delicious.  Be warned though, medium is not that pink. Definitely glad I ordered mine medium rare.  

We ordered the brussel sprouts on the side for veggies, and these were really good and complemented our steaks perfectly! And for dessert, we were totally caught off guard by how amazing the 'strawberry rhubarb shortcake' was.  It came in a cast iron pan (small), and was basically strawberry rhubarb pie filling (yum!) with short cake and cream in the corner, and strawberry icecream on the side.  2 weeks later I still dream of this dessert! 

Scene: 
Valet parking! woot
Also - the Bar at night was POPPIN OFF, had to yell across the dinner table to keep the convo going! I also saw these long tables which have full food service (I think) so you can just come by if you're in the area. Definitely will have to come back for an evening out on the town.

Highly recommend this spot, and if you don't find a rez on open table, just try calling!
author: Claire A.

description:
This place has delicious food, but more importantly, great service. Such amazing service, in fact, I decided to right my first Yelp view to recommend them. 

I had made a reservation for 4 but 3 of us arrived originally. We were seated at a table, given menus, and ordered drinks. My friend asked out server's opinion of one of the wines, and rather than speak about a wine he hadn't tried, he brought her out a sample of the wine she requested, plus one the bartender said she might prefer. She loved both and ended up opting for the bartenders recommendation. 

Our 4th arrived with an unexpected 5th in tow. Park tavern was able to move us to a new table, and even brought our drinks to follow us. Basically, we felt incredibly cared for, despite realizing the in convince we posed. 

In summary of the food:  the Brussels sprout chips were delicious, simple, and tasted like lemon. The demons on horseback was the least kosher thing one could imagine, but savory and delicious. I had the salmon which was surprisingly filling, given how fresh it was. I would recommend everything I ate.
author: Alexandra S.

description:
wow this place is overrated.

+ nice, attentive service
+ mussels - good, but not special

- waited a 20min despite having a reservation
- HALF a deviled egg for $2...ummm overpriced. tasted like a hard boiled egg with bacon flavoring
- lemon chips - too salty

this place would be a 3, but the food doesn't justify the price.
author: Margaret R.

description:
Bad food: Our chicken wasn't seasoned, yuck! The dessert was one peeled mandarin with "chantilly cream," aka whip cream for $11...ridiculous! I even had better tasting mandarin oranges at home. And everything else was just average. Not worth going. SKIP. 

I live in North Beach, so I like to check out the new restaurants. The people who dine here are those who are snooty and pretentious.
author: Jenny K.

description: I really liked the lamb, the roast chicken and the deviled eggs. There is a very expansive wine list. It's definitely a $$$ venue and feels just a shade over priced for what it is. Service was good. It's a little dark so bear that it mind if you like to see your food clearly.
author: Barry O.

description: Food was great! Reservations are recommended we sat at the communal table since we did not have a reservation. Started with a deviled egg (very tasty) had the cod cake which was also very good, they had a lot of potatoes which I wasn't expecting with a cod cake. Make sure you give yourself enough time because the food can take a while. The bottomless coffee comes in a huge mug, and if you like michelada the one here is extra spicy and refreshing! The waiter had no problem splitting up the bill for us which was a huge help! Overall great experience.
author: Emilia W.

description: Amazing food and considering it's on the fancy side.. The servers were all very sweet and accommodating when it came to my daughter. Will definitely be back again!
author: Jackie B.

description: Brunch is awesome; make sure to start with the deviled eggs! Valet parking makes this an easy stop in San Francisco, and the food, drink and service makes it a must. The iced coffee is perfect. The most challenging part of the day was deciding what to order. Cast iron skillet was yummy. Next time I think I will try the French toast.
author: c z.

description: Very good food a little pricey though. On the weekends they have pancakes and OH MY they were AMAZING! I normally dislike pancakes but these were out of this world. We ordered 2 more orders to go they were that good! The deviled egg was good, I wouldn't call it amazing, but it was good. The crab toast was pretty good too but it's not enough to fill one person. The burgers were pretty great but honestly if you want a burger go to in-n-out. The pickled chicken sandwich was OK too but if your not used to dark chicken that's a little pink inside then this isn't the sandwich for you. Overall good place, definitely recommended going on the weekends and getting the pancakes. This is definitely the place for people who don't mind spending a good amount of money on breakfast. It was around $145 for 5 people.
author: Patrick P.

description:
Went in for brunch, had the michelada (great spicy and saltiness for a drink) and the oatmeal pancakes. Had to ask for extra syrup, other then that it was spot on (three huge pancakes!).

My partner had the polenta which also was great. 

Service was awesome.
author: Mario P.

description:
We went here for brunch on my wife's birthday and I have to say that other than the unfavorable food portion-to-price ratio, we were definitely pleased with the quality of the food and even more so the service.

We set reservations for 10am when the restaurant opened and when we got there, we were seated outside in front as it was a bright sunny day. We sat there fore a while without anyone coming to take our order. Right when I was about to speak up, the owner came out and explained that the main waiter was running late. So the owner who was extremely nice sparked up a conversation with us and apologized for making us wait. He ended up taking our order which was fine. 

So we ordered the pan-fried corn beef hash, cast iron-baked farm eggs, and an order of 
buttermilk pancakes. To top it off, I ordered the boozy smoothie cocktail. We thought the food was delicious. My only complaint is that the boozy smoothie, while really good, was definitely smaller than I expected for the price. 

We didn't really experienced the ambience inside (since we sat in front) but the outside tables had comfortable chairs and the tables were nicely decorated with white flowers (my wife's favorite). 

Overall, we enjoyed the experience and the food. We would definitely recommend that our friends check this place out at least for brunch. We hope to make it back sometime to check out their lunch and dinner menus.
author: Jeremy B.

description:
It's been a couple years since I been to Park Tavern and this time we decided to take our mom here for her birthday.  Atmosphere was excellent especially on the night we came which was a warm, bright summer night where Washington Square was bustling.

We ordered a variety of appetizers ranging from gnocchi, carrot salad, corn soup, PT fries, fruit de mers, and demons on horseback.  Overall the appetizers were good and probably worthy of coming back for.  For entree, fish, poulet noir, pork chop, burger and duck.  The portion on the duck was small and my brother said it was on the salty side.  My dad's pork chop wasn't good, he left half of it on the plate.  The fish, I forgot what kind of fish, was decent but on the salty side.  The burger which is supposedly the best burger in town is not the best burger in town.  What was most disappointing were the fries that came on the side.  There were probably twelve pieces of fries, as if half the order was missing.  The poulet noir, had a good truffle aroma but that's about it.  It's a small piece of chicken, the greens on the bottom were swimming in oil which isn't exactly enticing.

We ordered the birthday cake since it was my mom's birthday and let's just say we were glad that wasn't our actual birthday cake.

When the bill came, we noticed a bottle of wine for $42 which we didn't order.  The waiter apologized and said he gave us the wrong bill but you know what, everything that was on bill was ours except for the bottle of wine.  I don't know if he was trying to pull a fast one or made a mistake but that was definitely our bill unless another table had exactly the same things we had which seems unlikely.  

I would say it was somewhat of an average experience.  I want our mom's birthday dinner to be great but it was well short of that.  We asked for more bread plates since they took ours away and they never came back with it.  It seemed the dishes came out quickly, maybe a bit too quickly.  I may come back for the PT fries but that's about it.
author: Pierre L.

description:
Two words: deviled eggs.

Just go. Its so worth it. Most nights, with a party less than 4, you don't need a reservation... but its always good to plan ahead. Drinks and wine selection are great too. Fun place.
author: Natalie R.

description:
Four enthusiastic stars for a very good meal last night. We arrived at 8:15 for our reservation and were told they were running behind. We went to the bar to grab a cocktail, and were seated 20 minutes later. It was the perfect opportunity to try one of the many specialty cocktails they make. 

I went with the Twin Peaks drink which was a Four Roses drink and I actually didn't like it at all. It was way too sweet for my taste. I asked the bartender to add something to take some of the sweetness away, and he graciously made me a totally new drink that had more lemon and I really enjoyed. My husband got the classic manhattan, it was made very well. 

Once we were seated we ordered the scallop, shrimp and crab salad since we knew we were going to both get beef for our entrees. I really enjoyed it.  Very light way to start the meal. I then got the Bar Steak, which was served with french fries. It was cooked perfectly rare, just the way I ordered it. The steak was seasoned perfectly. Overall it was very good, I was just wishing the juices form the steak didn't get all over my delicious fries. Maybe the fries in a dish would prevent this. 

The It's It dessert was the best. Mint ice cream with crunchy cookie crumbles and a hard shell on top. I highly recommend it! The service was also attentive, friendly and help with suggestions.
author: Natalie N.

description:
Brunch is great! I love the location and interior.
The boozy smoothie is dangerously tasty.
author: Mimi S.

description:
Sometimes the kids table is the most fun place to be at a gathering.

We were a last-minute party of six and ended up at the "short table" in the bar. When you go, you'll know the one we were at. It turned out to be a great spot for people watching, drinking and dining. I would not have changed a thing.

Upon arriving, we were greeted with champagne and the restaurant's signature deviled eggs. These are not your Aunt Myrtle's deviled eggs. These flavorful deviled eggs benefit from the picked jalapeno and piece of thick smoky bacon on top. They were terrific and I could easily see us going back just to have a pint of Anchor Steam and those eggs. But, last night we forged on.

The next course was porcini mushroom soup. As you know, mushroom soups are usually cream flavored with mushroom. Not at Park Tavern, this was a dense, flavorful, all mushroom cup of soup served with a garlicky piece of sourdough with parmesan on top. Very earthy and perfect for a chilly evening.

Then came prawns wrapped in lardo, which is of course thin petals of fat. The fat actually cooks off so all you are left with is the smoky essence of the lardo on the very fresh, perfectly cooked prawns. This was a winner. The lemon chips with burrata were good, though not earth shattering. The signature brussel sprout chips were not available, because it's not like you can just go down the street and buy brussel sprouts at any market at this time of year. Oh, wait, you can.

For our entrees, we tried a little of everything. The steak is actually a New York served with braised Kobe beef on the side. I was wondering why a chef would braise Kobe and drain all the fat out of it since Kobe beef is all about the fat, but the plate was one of the first to be cleaned completely. The first member of the clean plate club was the pork chop, which is served on ribs that must be picked up to be fully appreciated. 

Two of us had the seared scallops served on greens with these amazing beans served pieces of pork belly. I loved mine while the other diner found her's to be too salty. If you like salty pork belly, then this is probably a great dish for you. If you are looking for a light seafood dish, then this may be too hearty and salty for you.

For sides, we had twice baked potatoes, which are not for people shy about flavor and fat, and wild mushrooms. I personally thought the wild mushrooms were the winner. They were oven roasted with thyme and rosemary and had a simple, earthy flavor I really enjoyed. They went great with the beans and pork belly that came with the scallops. 

For drinks, a couple of us enjoyed the Southern Lawyer, which is little more serious Knobb Creek take on sweet vermouth and bitters than your standard Manhattan. The fresh orange peel in the drink just makes it. You need two of these.

The service was professional, responsive, always there when you wanted them to be, yet laid back and unpretentious. We never felt rushed and our server was happy to guide us to his favorites without sounding condescending. 

The atmosphere, as advertised on Yelp, is indeed trendy and casual at the same time. 

The wine list is not for bargain hunters. Plan on spending $70+ for a mid-range bottle of wine. 

So, if you are one of the cool ones, or, like myself, aspire to be surrounded by people cooler than yourself, I'd recommend Park Tavern for a romantic evening or a fun place to bring your group of friends.
author: Eric W.

description:
If you can deal with crowds on a Sunday night (or every night) and parking issues, the place is fine.  

If you can write off business, doing the valet thing is worth it. 

The deviled eggs and bacon are sublime.  Worth eating with a shot of tequila.

Any of the meats work, including the steak all the way down to the burger.

Overall the appetizers are worth sharing; I'd do 7-8 sharing plate among a few people.  Because the freakin' everything is awesome: Brussels sprouts chips, fries, shrimp/prawn (whatever, they're good), tartare, foie gras.  By the time my steak arrived it was anti-climatic.  And it wasn't because I was full; I still had dessert.  Just...appetizers.
author: Dina F.

description:
I had the most delicious meal at Park Tavern last night. Great ambiance, great food, and great service. Since our meal was last minute, we weren't able to get a reservation and ate at the communal table. This was a perfect solution and was great. 

Favorite food item: For sure, for me it was the venison carpaccio. Slices venison, small bite size deep friend bone marrow, and a nice portion of steak tartare made this wonderful. Lots of hidden little flavors that popped out along the way. 

Gnocchi was another win. Delicious and light. 

We also had the scallops and the sole. I am not sure in the future I would have ordered both of them. The sole was a little heavy and I was hoping for something lighter. By the end of that meal, I was a bit over salted, and I love salt. I think I would have ordered one or two more appetizers. 

The waiter picked our dessert. (We like surprises!) When it came and I had a bite, I immediately was transported to my Bay Area childhood days- a restaurant version of an Its It. Combined with a pot of french pressed coffee and some good conversation, it was a really good night and very delicious. 

I can't wait to go back.
author: Danielle V.

description:
Park tavern is such a great place in the neighborhood to get a fancy meal and treat yourself. It's basically impossible to get a reservation, but we decided to go and eat at the bar, which turned out to be a lot of fun. The bartenders are so friendly and helpful, and they sat us almost immediately. I ordered the Mclaren (Hendrick's Gin, cucumber, lemon & ginger beer) which was delish. We decided to try a bunch of things on the menu, which ended up being a great idea. For starters, we ordered the venison carpaccio, the deviled eggs, and the brussels sprout chips. The carpaccio wasn't that great, and there was too much onion on it. The deviled eggs were fantastic though, and the chips were also very good. 

For the entree, I ordered the poulet noir and my date ordered the mussels, cockles and clams. The chicken was AMAZING (caps are necessary here). I actually finished the entire chicken, and wow, the truffle flavor! And that stuffing! And that juiciness! Almost too much to handle. Seriously though, if you don't like food really salty, or think that truffles can be overpowering, I would not suggest this dish. It was verrrry flavorful. Thankfully I can't get enough of salt, so it worked out in my favor. The mussel dish was also delicious, especially the broth! And the bread, which is soo good, is the perfect way to sop it all up. When the dish first arrived we noticed that a good number of clams/mussels were still closed, and when we brought it to the bartender's attention, he immediately brought them back to the kitchen and we were given a new bowl. We also ordered a bottle of white wine which was reasonably priced and perfectly complimentary to the meal.

I really appreciated how attentive the servers were. They knew when to step in, and when to give us time. They also knew the menu inside and out. While the meal as a whole might be worth 4 stars, the service and overall ambiance makes it a 5. Will definitely be going back!
author: Regina L.

description: I had the crispy polenta cakes that came with poached eggs, arugula and mushrooms with a salsa verde and it was bomb! Our table also shared the avocado toast which was very fresh avocado nicely sliced covering two pieces of wheat toast with some form of chili powder sprinkled on top. We also had great service in a good atmosphere.
author: Paula F.

description:
We went here for our anniversary dinner last night and really had a lovely time. Everything was top notch, the service, the food, the atmosphere. I was quite impressed.

French fries were perfectly cooked with black truffle aioli and a soft boiled egg with a little bit of caviar in it. Decadent and really nice. The venison carpaccio was lovely. Very light and flavorful without being gamey or too much.

Hubby had a nice roast duck ("mine is better though," he said, which isn't far off) and my NY strip steak was perfect. The accompanying super cripsy smashed potato was interesting and really flavorful.

It's not inexpensive (entrees are $25-30) but the entire meal including a small carafe of good wine was around $200. Not bad for an excellent special occasion meal.
author: Mike F.

description: Without a doubt this is my favorite brunch in SF! Park Tavern has great ambience and is always bustling with people. I recommend booking a reservation on Open Table to secure a spot and avoid a wait at the door. I usually order the Chorizo & Eggs, but the hamburger is fantastic too if you're more in the mood for a lunch meal at brunch.
author: Katie E.

description: Our waitstaff was amazing, but the most amazing thing was definitely the Demons On Horseback- the bacon-wrapped shrimp we ordered with our drinks. Everything was perfectly cooked. Definitely check it out!
author: Meghan K.

description: Been here twice now; for brunch and dinner. Always delicious and well plated food. Service is great. Bartender was a little heavy handed on my cocktail but if you like a good stiff drink then you should be fine.
author: Rachel H.

description: Fun spot, good food, great service, nice looking local crowd.  Burger was delicious, clams were too salty--I didn't complain because I wasn't all that hungry (plus I was eating them anyway) but the waitress noticed and insisted on taking them off the tab despite our protests!  Fun sitting at the communal bar table--will definitely return when in the City.
author: Molly W.

description: I randomly came across the reviews for Park Tavern. It was date night so I decided to book a reservation. When we arrived we were seated immediately. The décor is beautiful and the lay out really made the place upscale. We were seated a corner booth near the kitchen. We were ordered the Yellow Doll watermelon & Mangalitsa prosciutto, truffle & mustard greens, the Pork belly bites and horseradish aioli, the house made beef jerky, the pork and the burger. I rarely ever say this, but everything is amazing. However, the dessert lacked. There were only 2 choices and they were both slices of cake. We chose the Yellow Birthday Cake and it was decent. I could have made a better cake myself. I suspect they do not have a pastry chef yet but the food made up for that. Highly recommend.
author: Katie Anne N.

description: Park Tavern is my go-to in SF!  Great food, staff, atmosphere.
author: Scott B.

description:
Finally I'm reviewing Park Tavern. I felt like ordering half of the new season's menu. My friend had just worked out and couldn't help me indulge my wandering food eye.

While the burger, my main motivator, wasn't the best in the city as friends had told me, it certainly was very good. Candidly, ordering it in such a nice setting concerned me by perhaps passing up on more adventurous items.

Pro move: Consider limiting your prior meals to build the hunger. You'll enjoy the additional time, and of course the food and drink, at Park Tavern.

Demons on Horseback? Yes, of course. Fried sunchokes? Most definitely. Smoked deviled eggs? No, but only because I've eaten them so often at Marlowe. Seared scallops? Oh, they were excellent. Grilled pork chop. Nom nom. 

Yes, the burger was not my only entree. Sigh.
author: Mike H.

description:
*3.5 stars*

Park Tavern is designed to be perfect for any occasion -- birthdays, business meetings, catchups with friends, anything. It has a great atmosphere, thanks to the excellent design of the place. 

The service was absolutely incredible. From the hostess to the bar server to our wonderful dining server, Emily, everything was on-point. We had to add 2 people last-minute to our table, and Emily graciously and happily helped us move to another table halfway through our meal. It really made our experience that much more enjoyable.

The food was a hit or miss for us. I'm a fan of Marlowe, so I was expecting the same level of excellence here, but it was just lacking a bit when compared to Marlowe.

----------------------------
FOOD:

Deviled Eggs = Delicious. Everything goes together perfectly.

Brussels Sprouts Chips = Addictive as always. Can't go wrong here.

PT Fries = Good, but nothing spectacular. The caviar wasn't salty enough to bring the flavors together between the egg yolk and the aioli. Half of the fries were overfried.

Grilled Pork Chop = Tender for the most part and had a pure flavor to it. It wasn't exciting, but it was definitely a well-cooked pork chop.

Mussels and Clams = This was good, but again, nothing exciting.

3 Variations of Duck = I had high hopes for this one, but again, it fell short. The duck breast was a bit dry, the duck confit was a bit overcooked, the duck skin wasn't crispy enough, and the duck liver mousse was too watery. The flavors were all there, it just could've been so much better. Plus, the beans didn't really add anything beneficial to the dish.

Venison Tartare = This dish was a great attempt, but was definitely lacking in execution. The beef tartare was good, but it was missing something with a bit more umami (for instance, it could've used some sesame oil or quail egg). The deep-fried bone marrow is an interesting idea, but was completely lackluster in execution. The bits of bone marrow was easily overpowered by the breading and it just tasted like fried oil.

Hamachi Crudo w/ Gin & Tonic = This dish wasn't good at all. There was no depth or excitement whatsoever -- it needed a couple of extra layers of flavor (something salty, something tangy) to really make the hamachi pop. Unfortunately, it ended up being just a bland, strange mixture of flavors between the overpowering cucumber, the bland gin & tonic ice, and the nonexistent flavor of the hamachi.

----------------------------

All in all, Park Tavern is a good space with a great bar and phenomenal service. I'd definitely come back for some drinks and small bites. The food, however, just doesn't match up to everything else.
author: Roy C.

description:
The service here was fantastic. I made a reservation for my boyfriend and I for his birthday and they made it really special. The staff was very attentive and they organized a special birthday cocktail and dessert. 
The brussel sprout fries are pretty tasty as well!
author: Bree D.

description: Thank you very much for the wonderful food and the best service grazie Gianni!!!! Wonderful night .... Love the foie gras the figs the egg with fries the beef tartar.... Every thing was amazing!!!
author: Miriam B.

description:
Tasty food and good service!

After putting my name down at a pizzeria for a 1.5 hours wait (with the car at a 2-hour parking) a woman standing by with her kids suggested we go to Park Tavern, which has more seating, so we took her advice!

Service was good. We sat down at the bar area, and someone cleaned the table right away, someone else got us our menu and water. The waitress, Aura, and all the other people were friendly, helpful, attentive, and fast. We had our waitress but I there were about 5 people filling the water, serving food, getting drinks, taking plates, etc.

Even though service was fast, we weren't rushed at all, and I like how they took care of us.

I ordered the Poulet Rouge, which is game hen standing on top of spinach and peewee potatoes. Sauce was good, meat was juicy, but the spinach was salty. If you eat the chicken with the spinach I guess the salt is balanced out. I was happy with my dish! $28

Dad ordered the scallop. We laughed at his plate, because he had 3 little scallops with some veggies decorating the plate. Fancy-Schmancy! My dad likes a hearty meal and more bang for your buck, but he defended his dish. The scallop did taste very good, and the salt was more balanced than mine. Dad approves. $29

Mum ordered the bar steak, which came with fries. Steak was good, but she did not like the red wine sauce. Too bitter for her taste. The fries were good, but she was upset the sauce was soaked into the fries. Might have been better for her if the sauce was on the side, or the fries on a different plate. $27

The coffee was good. Did not need sugar or cream. It went well with the July Birthday Cake, and it was fun blowing out the candle, even though none of our birthdays is in July. The lemon poppy cake wasn't really standout, but the apricot on top made it a treat! $8 and $9

Afterwards, it was funny to think how we got to Park Tavern. We originally came to Little Italy, to eat at Original Joe's, but we passed on it, because we thought it was too expensive and 20 minutes too long a wait, not knowing all the pizza places had even longer waits and all the other restaurants were just as expensive. So we ended at Park Tavern, which is more pricier than Original Joe's. The food and service though was worth it. And it's nice to treat your family to good food once in a while. Especially if Dad is picking up the tab!

Overall, Park Tavern was a good place to eat, and I would definitely suggest it as a place to take visiting family and friends.
author: Poiuytrewq A.

description: Sadly, I'm quite disappointed with Park Tavern.  I had really high hopes with it being on Michael Bauer's Top Restaurants list.  But the food was completely mediocre.  That said, the deviled eggs are still on my mind a week later.  Wish the rest of it was.
author: James S.

description:
After the super disappointing food at Radius, I had to make my tummy happy again. 

Everything I had was so yummy!!! The quality is fresh and good portions.

Fried artichokes w/ lemon aioli and fried garlic-perfectly crispy and the fried garlic is what made the dish.

Brussel Sprout Chips-Super addicting. 

$2 each for Deviled eggs-Now that is pricey, but so worth it. Very good and it comes with bacon and pickled jalapeno.

Venison Carpaccio with angus beef tartar and crispy bone marrow-I wasn't sure about eating raw venison, but it was very fresh and good flavors. The beef tartar was excellent. Very well seasoned. They give you little bite size fried bone marrow. That just hit the spot!

Scallops w/ tempura mushrooms-delish. They give you about 6 to 8 pieces. Perfectly cooked and seasoned.

Steak-now this is what a steak is suppose to look like. Not no cold chewy messed up meat (See Radius review). N.Y steak that was prefectly cooked. 2 square pieces that had so much flavor and it melts in your mouth. Came with kobe beef stuffed bone marrow. That was amazing. It was like beef jerky! There was a big crispy potato and even mash potatos. The broccolini was a good touch to all that meat. DROOL!!!
author: Karen H.

description:
Ok we went for Sunday dinner, took our 7 and 9 year old (they eat at places like this a lot-but would not necessarily say kid friendly). Usually the only problem with taking our kids is not the kids but the restaurants assumption about kids- some places stick us at cruddy tables, ignore us (assuming low check) that kind if thing!
Park Tavern was absolutely 1st class from the minute we walked in!
The hosts were kind and accommodating  from the get-go. Out waiter Hudson was awesome, friendly-attentive and patient with the kids (we like them to ask questions and order for themselves).
The manager, Steven...checked on us throughout the night...and was also very friendly, accommodating and seemed pleased we were there!  We will be back many many times-oh and the food!!! OMG OMG! Brussel sprout chips, mussels, burger, pork chop, deviled eggs, wagu jerky, And prawns....everything was better than GOOD, and the wine was superb!
Can't thank Hudson, Steven and all of the staff for making ALL if us feel welcome, comfortable and appreciated!
author: Jen S.

description: In all honestly for this place to be the restaurant that once was Moose's it has not comparison in my eyes.  It also no place for a vegetarian.  Our server recommended I order the gnocchi which was an appetizer dish but he told me I could have it as an entree.  So I ordered the gnocchi and I was not all that impress.  The gnocchi tasted like greasy potatoes.  Our party also had desert, three different ones for all of us to share.  I wasn't impressed.  I love my sweets but the desert here was no comparison to my dad's homemade cobblers, pies and cakes.  It is also very expensive here.  I'm grateful that our dinner was a paid for by a very well known local Franciscan but if I knew that the food was just eh, then I would not have dined here.  I will not be back again.  Sorry but we're all entitled to our opinions and I enjoy a great dinner, where the food is delicious and the service is super duper awesome.
author: Liz D.

description:
Dinner review is 3.5 stars so I'm being generous and rounding to 4. We came here for dinner on a Tuesday night (made the reservation about an hour before so they were really good about getting us in). We got there and were seated at a small 2-person table extremely close to the surrounding tables on either side of us; however, it wasn't awkward or too close for comfort. I don't know how they manage to pull that off, but they did. Props, Park Tavern.

We ordered:
1. Brussels sprout chips - 3 stars. They were good but extremely salty.
2. Devolved egg - 5 stars. BOMB! The pickled jalapeño made it.
3. Salad - 4 stars. I can't remember the exact name of it but it was a simple salad with avocado and a nice vinaigrette.
4. Burger - 3 stars. The meat was cooked well (we ordered medium rare) but there was way too much sauce/aioli on the burger. I like my meat plain and it sort of overpowered the burger. Ask for it on the side next time. 
5. Porkchop - 5 stars. Dank. Rivals the pork chop from The House. This one is more traditional and served with Parmesan risotto and root vegetables.

No dessert so can't vouch for that but the ones that the table to the left of us ordered (approximately 5 inches away) looked great.

I'll be back but not for the infamous burger. It's better at Marlowe and I think there are much better burger options around the city.
author: Nicole W.

description: We loved aura! Not only was she exceptional with her service, she was on top with all of what we wanted to order. We wanted to come here for a while, but we were very skeptical because we never went here before. Thanks to Aura, we had EXCEPTIONAL service! We had an amazing diner which we loved! We wish to come back here every time we come to the Bay Area which is very frequent for us. Thank you aura! We appreciated your business!
author: Dreher L.

description: The food was delicious. My favourite was the buttermilk pancakes. They were so light and fluffy and not overly drenched in maple syrup. The service was decent but could have been letter. I felt that the waiter did not come as often as j would have liked. The setting and decor was nice and wait time was not unnecessarily long.
author: Sally D.

description:
This is as good as it gets in North Beach.  The PT fries, in house beef jerky, and other snack work perfect at the bar.  The crowds can get out of control, but the beauty of the restaurant, location, stellar food, and the drinks are amazing.  

Jack and Brian are an insanely good team.  Order off menu and let them work their magic if you catch them at a slow late hour.
author: Zack M.

description: Was here for my birthday dinner on Friday night and enjoyed it very much.  Loved their cocktails and all the appetizers were phenomal.  I tried the deviled eggs (excellent) and truffled fried, and veal carpaccio.  There's a nice twist to all their dishes which makes it different and unique and very tasty.  Definitely will be coming back the next time I'm in town.
author: Eve O.

description: Perfectly uppity for my taste, food was good, but the portions left me hangry.
author: Annie F.

description: Brian is the Boss behind the Bar!! Juicy and Generous is the pork chop! I never knew I could eat carrots cooked in so many different ways~yum!! Very lively inside of the spacious modern hip NB eatery! Bravo!!
author: yvette c.

description:
I like coming here a little before the crowd and hanging by the bar-Order a Washington Square while you wait for your bites.... Obviously try the deviled eggs and brussel sprouts. 

Or-if you're a bruncher like myself-stop by early to get a table outside and overlook the beautiful park. The Crispy Polenta Cakes were great with a side of fruit and a mimosa with grapefruit juice. 

Of all-the service, ambiance, food, drinks, nose level and overall feel-Park Tavern is by far one of my favorite restaurants in the city.
author: Stephanie G.

description: Delicious!!! Veggie friendly aspect- not a huge choice, but the pastries and the polenta were delicious - plenty of mushrooms and a hint of truffle which was a delicious combination, the egg was perfectly poaeched. Coffee: maybe I miscommunicated with the waitress regarding my cappuccino, and had to send it back (in general, American prices of making cappuccino confuses me, so it's hard to explain how I like it made). The mimosa was perfect and have me a great luck. My husband had the burger, which he loved, and the fries were perfect. Got some pastries which were also great. Yum yum yum#
author: Rachel W.

description: Great place for both brunch and dinner.  Great service and the bartenders are really service and quality oriented.  Make reservations and go.
author: Michael S.

description: Park Tavern has the BEST french fries. I think they might be my favorite fries in all of SF. The Crispy Lemon Chips are great too. They throw a little black sea salt on the burrata cheese so each bite has good flavor and just a slight tang. With all this heavy savory appetizers, it's nice to have a little green on the table. I love the snap peas in the Sweet Baby Lettuces salad. You can taste the dijon in the vinaigrette and it's refreshing - especially if you're planning on having the steak! Unfortunately, the steak wasn't as exciting as the rest of the meal. Far too smoky for my taste. Not sure if there was some extra worcestershire sauce in the meat or au jus but i preferred the Red Snapper. Healthier, yet still outdone by the classics AND sides.
