I often roast brussel sprouts at home and still wanted to eat the entire dish at the restaurant. The twice baked potato surprised me in that it came in a scalloped potato plating. It was great, probably due to all the room that created for creme fraiche, butter and cheddar cheese. For dessert, i enjoyed the August Birthday Cake which could have been made for me! It was the lightest coconut flavored cake with lemon curd and plenty of whipped cream. I only stopped at 1.5 slices because we ran out of dessert at the table.. I'll absolutely be back for brunch.
author: Samantha L.

description: Update for the bar area:  came in with three visiting girlfriends to sit at the bar and hang out.  The bartenders are friendly & had great recommendations on drinks/wine when asked for them.  They noticed when glasses were getting low and made sure that we were taken care of!  I also noticed that they had a good number of regular customers that came in and joined into conversions/created a really great "classier" bar vibe that I loved!  Definitely will be back to hang out for drinks before dinner/after work.
author: Raina D.

description:
This review is for going to Eden Lounge, the pop-up bar upstairs, for cocktails. Turns out the website calendar is not accurate, leaving one sad birthday girl. Don't plan to have a birthday or other gathering there on a date based on the website schedule: http://www.parktavernsf.com/eden-lounge/

I chose a night where it was unreserved (the website indicated being open to the public at 7:00, i.e. no private events scheduled) for my upcoming birthday celebration, sent out invites, got an estimated headcount (about 15), then called today just in case it was possible to make a table reservation. I was told the lounge was reserved for a rehearsal dinner, and I told them they should update their calendar. I'm guessing they will have some disappointed people showing up on Saturday.

I need to go re-plan my birthday and notify all of my guests now. Let's see if the Hancock Room is free...
author: Rachel H.

description: Foods are really bad :/ i ordered fruit and omelette they get me something completely looks different
author: Selçuk M.

description: Outstanding!  My first visit was a big disappointed, but the second time around, everything was great.  In fact, we went back because the management responded so positively after reading my review of the first time.  This time couldn't have been more different.  The corn soup was really special, the scallops were excellent and the July birthday cake was delicious.  Having said that, the real difference was the service, Andrew was an outstanding server, really knows his stuff.  We'll definitely go back time-and-time again.
author: David J.

description: This place is a total ripoff. The food came cold. The portions are small. The taste is so so. My salmon Benedict is so salty that I couldn't finish it.
author: S L.

description: The fries, cocktails, and service were excellent, but everything else was unfortunately incredibly oversalted, from the deviled eggs to the seafood stew to the lamb. This place had so much potential, if only they had gone easier on the salt.
author: Jia H.

description:
I've been wanting to go to Marlowe, but haven't been able to make a reservation at a good time, so we finally decided to try Park Tavern.  The location is great and the decor inside is nice.  We started with cocktails and some really good appetizers: my wife had a side of the braised mushrooms and I had the onion and mushroom soup.  The soup was awesome - different than a traditional onion soup (more savory, I think) and something I would definitely order again.  The mushrooms were also good, although a bit salty.

Our entrees were fine, but didn't live up to the soup.  My wife had the scallops, which came with beans, kale and pork belly.  Too much salt on the pork belly she said, and a bit too much kale.  I had the NY steak, which came with brussels sprouts, onions, carrots and a nice sauce.  I really liked the veggies, but the meat was only OK.

Overall, a very nice meal and I'm sure we'll come back if we are in the area.
author: Richard M.

description:
I was able to get a reservation for brunch very easily. Dinner reservations are a bit harder to get. 
The hummingbird cocktail is delicious. I love sweet fruity champagne cocktails.
The food was pretty good. The smoked salmon on toast was excellent. The crab crostinis were good too. 
Hard to find parking in the area. Took the 30 bus and just crossed the park to the restaurant.
Our server was a bit standoffish. Forgot to get her name. 
But overall a good brunch place.
author: Wanlan X.

description:
Came here last night with a few friends and we couldn't have had a better experience. We ordered as follows:

- VENISON CARPACCIO
- SMOKED PUMPKIN SOUP
- BRUSSELS SPROUT CHIPS
- SEARED SEA SCALLOPS
- GRILLED NY STEAK
- MARLOWE BURGER 

Everything was absolutely excellent and I give each dish 5 stars. With our dessert we each ordered a port wine and our waiter brought over an expert to help us decide which. He was very knowledgable and explained each in detail. I was more than happy with what he recommended. 

WIll definitely be back again!
author: Carlynn A.

description:
One sunny afternoon (a couple weeks ago), my friend and I were walking through North Beach trying to decide on a place to have lunch. It was between Tony's and Park Tavern. I am so glad we went to Park Tavern - I have had Tony's many times (no bad reviews).

We decided to sit outside, which was great! The sun shines right on the outside tables. 

I had the Marlowe Burger which was awesome. The sauce that comes with the burger is (in my opinion) the best part (I am big fan of house-made sauces). I also had the grapefruit brulee. Im not a big fan of sweets but this is a must try...

AND how could I forget the Michelada! VERY different! The pickled jalapeno definitely gives it a kick!
author: Tania D.

description: Everything on the brunch menu is dope. Definitely recommend the avocado toast - just get it, you'll understand why once you taste it. And then you'll crave it often. The hash is another dish that sounds fair but is actually unbelievable. The hummingbird is my fave drink - a light and refreshing sparkling raspberry vodka cocktail, but the bloody Mary's are good too - spicy, filling, and garnished with beef jerky!
author: Becca S.

description:
Ate at the communal table, sat on stools and the table was too low.

Food was divine. I ate the fried polenta, which was perfectly crispy and buttery. Recommend!
author: Tiff C.

description:
food: tasty, but costly. i like their brunch. the bread with butter and jam... yum!!!

Atmosphere: hip, but loud. Nice space.
author: P L.

description: I went here with family to celebrate my grandma's birthday and my experience was not how I would have wanted it to be. We went in and It was boiling hot inside . Some of the decorations were cool though like they had a giant moosehead on the wall. The place has really kind of dark lighting. we started off with the deviled egg which were amazing. Then I got my burger which was not good. The burger tasted like very salty blood. Whenever I squeezed the burger blackish blood would come out.on the other hand the French fries were to die for. Or wait or was nice which I like so at least I got good service. I got to say that the bar was really cool and they have a huge television so you can catch the game. I think the cooks are really pressured because the kitchen is open and if you have a tBle overlooking the kitchen you can watch their every move but on the other hand I guess that is a good thing because if they do some thing you can call the out on it (that is of course if you Are a little crazy ;-) My desert was really good. I orderd the ice cream sandwich and it was excellent.
author: Ford W.

description: The deviled egg was delicious but so tiny!! Loved the challah toast as well but a bit pricey for 2 pieces of toast. The chorizo and eggs were ok.
author: Irene L.

description:
Love the contrasting decor of dark wood and white subway tiles.  Staff was nice although our server had an odd way of describing the food.  She used words like, "fun and interesting" which made me worry about how that translated over to food.  

We shared the
Tomato tart:  I really enjoyed this and it was easy to share among the 4 of us.
French fries:  the fries themselves were good.  I didn't see the point of dipping it into the egg yoke though.  We bypassed this step and went straight into the aioli.    
Demons on Horseback:  5 prawns wrapped in lardon.  You can't really say anything negative about that.
Brussels sprouts chips:  yummy!

for entrees
Bar Steak:  Fiance enjoyed this.  Simple go to item for him at most restaurants
Scallops:  I had been craving scallops for a while now.  These were rather small but they gave me enough to fill me up.  There was also something unrecognizable and deep fried.  I ate it anyways but will probably check the menu later to figure out what it was.  Might have been a mushroom.
Herb crusted sole:  both my friend and her boyfriend tried this dish and both did not like it.  They thought the crust was odd and thought the description  misrepresented it.
CAB NY steak:  friend loves marrow and didn't like this dish.  She thought it tasted strange but it was the largest of all portions.

We also had two glasses of champagne and a red and a white.  No dessert since we were stuffed.
author: Rosalind S.

description: Extremely happy with the vegan vegetable plate (not on the menu, but waitress said it was pretty common to do) - every piece was well seasoned, cooked really well and came to the table HOT- not always the case and luke warm veggies are blah. It had a little bit of carrot purée on the sides which dressed up the plate, but didn't add much taste. The corn soup was really unique in a good way- sweet but balanced well with the chiles and seasonings on top. The atmosphere is cool- cozy because of the dark wood but still lively. We sat next to the windows in front and they added just enough light and let us people watch! All in all, really happy to have dined here. Even the woman who spoke with me on the phone was cheery and accommodating. Things may seem expensive, but even as a diner with high-standards, I think it was worth it for the food and the service/experience. Not somewhere I would go every week however, but I think most people go into it knowing that!
author: Maureen H.

description:
Perfect Sunday scenario: Outdoor seating overlooking Washington Square, sipping on delicious cocktails and to-die-for deviled eggs while people watching. I could die a happy girl.

Solid restaurant with a solid menu and even better cocktail menu.

Maybe it was the company I was with, but I've genuinely enjoyed every visit I've had at PT. It's super packed here, but kick back, grab a few cocktails, share some laughs with friends, and before you know it, seating will magically open up for you. Service is always friendly, which is definitely a plus.
author: Helen Z.

description:
Many, many delicious things here!  The PT fries with the soft-boiled egg dipping sauce, the upright poulet rouge, the addictive brussel sprout chips, the birthday cake (we had gingerbread with cream cheese frosting!  Who doesn't like high-quality cream cheese frosting??), the chocolate creme brulee, the beautiful figs with burrata, and of course, the stellar drinks. The paloma and twin peaks were both quite unique and delicious.

Servers were friendly, relaxed (considering how much was going on around me, my head would be spinning if I were them!), and informative.

Why not 5 stars?  It was just a bit expensive for me.  Each drink, glass of wine, main course/appetizer, was, like a dollar to 3 dollars too expensive (except for the poulet rouge - that was a good price).  And that really all adds up.  I mean, 8 dollars for a french press of coffee that puts out one large mug of coffee?  Hmm.  6 bucks for a tiny plate of olives?  Hmm again. The bill for the 3 of us came out to $300 with tip. 

So, I'd say this is a great place for a special occasion, because the food is delicious but the prices "know" the food is delicious.  Or, I'd go for the drinks and just have a few snacks like the brussel sprout chips on the side!
author: Annie F.

description:
Park Tavern is my favorite restaurant in the city. 

From the owners to the janitors, this place is world-class. It was built right, it is staffed right, and the food is f--king phenomenal. I eat there maybe once a month and they treat me like I'm family. My friends ask me why I'm so obsessed; "There are way nicer restaurants than Park" is often what I hear- that's not what I care about. Quality and class have nothing to do with price or exclusivity.

The host/ess is always in full control of the restaurant; they take a drink order if we arrive early. The bartenders are professionals. The servers are informed and discreet about any special requests, and not once in the many times I've eaten there have they made a mistake.

The food- I show up, order two deviled eggs, a McClaren, a glass of water, and the pork, and I'm good. It's priced right and the reviews here speak for it. 

Anna Weinberg is doing things right, customer for life right here. I have plenty of places I love in the city but there is nowhere that makes more of an understated, flawless effort to simply get ev-er-y-thing right from the reservation to helping you into your jacket on the way out the door.
author: Andrew G.

description:
Park Tavern has a fantastic location of overlooking Washington Square and a large and spacious interior. I have a feeling that chances of it being fully booked is a little slimmer than some of the other trendy but smaller venues with like 10 tables. 

The menu has an array of interesting looking dishes. Although most tables around us were munching on squash blossoms, we opted in for the lemon chips with hummus dip.  So glad we went for that! The thinly sliced chips combined the crispiness of a potato chip with the lovely fragrance of a lemon. Refreshing and tasty!

The famous deviled eggs did not disappoint. Nice kick from the jalapeno bits inside and the bacon on top gave it a nice texture and additional flavor.

My entree, the red snapper, itself was okay.  I really was hoping black cod would still be on the menu, but it wasn't.  The bed of cabbage and leeks the fish sat on was incredibly flavorful.  That alone I can eat again and again. 

One of us had the halibut which came on a nice bed of corn risotto.  The corn risotto was so smokey and sweet, again, made the fish itself pale by comparison.

Another friend got the Marlowe burger. I am not a burger eater so I didn't try but she said it was worth the hype as well, being very moist. 

Some unknown birdie must have informed the restaurant that it's one of our birthdays.  Wasn't the intention of our dinner get-together, but one of us does have a birthday coming up next week.  The restaurant generously sent us a slice of chocolate cake for dessert. And when I say generously, I mean, the cake was large! It was delicious, but the four of us didn't finish it!

I would absolutely come back again. It seems to be the type of restaurant that has something for everyone, but still serves food innovative and tasty enough for the easily-bored, hard-to-please foodies.
author: Candice B.

description:
I really enjoyed my dinner at Park Tavern.  They serve one of the best pork chops I've had, and delicious deviled eggs.  The wine list is ample (but not cumbersome) and reasonably priced, and the service was solid.

My only complaint is the noise level.  I really had to struggle to have a conversation.
author: jeremy d.

description:
Came here for brunch on a Sunday. Here is a short list of why I'm coming here again for brunch.

-Boozy smoothie (banana, espresso, bourbon holy f*ck so good. I would order an entire pitcher of this if they had it). 
-Baguettes with goats milk butter and the most delicious jams ever.
-The egg & savories dishes were all great. Perfectly poached eggs.
-Stellar service. 
-Did I say Boozy smoothie?
author: Michelle K.

description:
How did they not get rated 5 stars?! As a local who lives 2.5 blocks away, I go here all the time- it's PHENOMENAL! We love great food, and this one is on my top 5 I go to of all restaurants- the best for its price range IMO.

Whenever we have friends/fm family in town we bring them to Park Tavern for an amazing meal. 

Service is always attentive and informative- no matter who may serve us! I can't help but resist the creme brûlée- the salted TCHO is my favorite. Sophisticated flavors, and always leave satiated and happy. 

If you haven't tried yet, GO! Delicious every time.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Good, modern food and excellent, accommodating service in a spacious and (relatedly) uncrowded dining room.
author: Jon F.

description:
3.5 stars....this review is for the brunch only.

We popped in on a Saturday around 11:30 with no reservation.  We were easily able to get a table for two, the restaurant was quite busy but there were open tables scattered here and there.  

We really enjoyed the food, I tried a dish with spinach, cream, gruyere and farm eggs and it was quite ice.  We also tried the poached eggs with polenta cakes.  Both dishes could have used a little salt and pepper as they were a touch on the bland side (the tables do not have salt and pepper shakers).  Though we did enjoy the food, the service was very much on the slow, yet very polite side.  We will try Park Tavern again, the atmosphere is fun, the clientele as well.  This is a cool spot, hoping the service is a little more attentive when we return and I can bump up the review to 4 stars.
author: Janelle C.

description: Our waiter was pretty rude / clearly didn't want to be there. But the food was good. Would recommend ordering the burger and berry parfait
author: Lauren G.

description:
I went to Park Tavern for dinner - the place was hopping for a Sunday night.  The crowd was generally dressy and a mix of young and old.  The decor and space are very nicely done - they are definitely going after the "upscale" atmosphere.

Unfortunately, I found the food very average and very overpriced.   (I had the salmon as my entree.  The brussel sprout chips weren't bad... how can anything deep-fried not be amazing?!)   

Service was okay - not terrible, but not impressive.  Our waiter was spotty in checking in on our table.

Overall, an average (3-star) experience, but relative to price, I would rate Park Tavern a 2-star.
author: Princey W.

description: This is literally as good as it gets! I came here with 10 people for a brunch on Mother's Day and I've literally never had better service nor food nor drinks (well maybe this helped me think positively about the first two). Drinks are delicious and they have an amazing mix from healthy feeling to downright glutinous. The service is impeccable - I never had to wait for a refill or to order a new drink or side, the food was presented at a perfect pace to allow us to relax and enjoy but not get impatient, and THE FOOD! I'll definitely be coming back.
author: Elena F.

description:
I live in the area so Park Tavern is unavoidable since it's one of the few Non-italian restaurants in North Beach. There are certain aspects I love and some that I am not a fan of:

Like:
The brussel sprout chips, smoked burrata (new on the menu and to die for!), deviled egg, the Marlowe burger is a must try! Probably one of the best restaurant burgers in the city. The decor is gorgeous and detail oriented. There is not one part of the restaurant that hasn't been perfected by the owners even the restroom decor is gorgeous. The service has also always been consistently great!

Dislike: 
The pricing is a little on the steeper side and I do not believe it is in line with the quality of the food. I would avoid the brunch menu as many of the dishes I had were on the greasy side. And their wines by the glass could have a better selection.
author: Ajna V.

description:
Absolutely superb dining experience.  The ambiance here is glorious - beautiful tiling on the floors, tall ceilings, dark wood tables, and the front "atrium" dining space is perfect for Sunday brunch. 

I've been here for brunch and dinner, and both are delicious.  Why do I keep going back?  Because of the *feel* of the place, and because of the BURGER.  I am a bit of a burger afficionado, and PT's tops my charts.  Seriously, it's my #1.  The deviled eggs are amazing as well - incredible combination of textures.

Get some wine, make friends with your service, and settle in for a great dining experience.  I love love love this place!
author: Kate O.

description: Beautiful place with great service and carefully prepared season food. The restrained playful bent makes it perfect for delighting parents and elders more than ruckus reunion with foodie friends.  Great brunch menu means it will be packed on Mother's Days, Father's Days, Graduation weekend, et al.
author: Barndi K.

description:
Ever had a lemon chip? At Park Tavern, you really must. 

While this place looks like the kind of dimly-lit bar your pa or grandpa might frequent (complete with soft-rock soundtrack, at least on the night we visited), the menu's all inventive and modern. Crispy, salty lemon chips pair up with fava been puree for an appetizer that's cooly creative. A seasonal seafood plate aims to boot charcuterie off your plate and and back to 2009. The corn soup is surprisingly creamy and flavorful, and perfect to go alongside something fresh and fishy. And the only thing stopping me from calling the deviled eggs "divine" at this point is my desire to avoid too much cloying alliteration in this paragraph. 

It's the kind of place that makes you feel guilty for ordering a burger, but since I come from an amoral, bohemian-type background, I was able to move past these feelings and do it anyway. And it was good. So good that my dining partners found themselves straying from their fascinating entrees and stealing my fries. 

The only thing I wouldn't order again was the squash blossoms (which may be off the menu now anyhow). Skimpy portions, not ideal for sharing, which you definitely want to do when the food's this tasty. I'd rather have like, 5 more bacon-topped deviled eggs. So good!
author: Ryan W.

description:
This is a "sister" location to Marlowe's in South Mission. 

Similar lay out and food menu and just as good. 

Prices are reasonable for nice clean food. Strong drink menu and service does it justice as well. 

I had the Marlowe's burger with carmalized onions. Absolutely amazing, juicy and not heavy. 

Highly recommend this place for lunch.
author: O M.

description: Amazing brunch!!!!! Smoked Salmon Benedict is out of this world!!! We also had an avocado toast and coconut fritters with orange and chocolate sauce as starters. The place has nice decor and excellent service. Yummy cocktails and selection of wines too!
author: Elena S.

description:
My friend Rupert paid his quarterly visit to San Francisco and it seemed totally fitting to dine alongside Washington Square Park on an almost balmy Spring evening.

Order the deviled eggs as soon as you're seated as they are delicious. I loved the very smoky bacon on top and believe the cayenne pepper and wafer-thin sliver of jalapeño takes this egg dish to another planet.

The Brussel sprout chips were very tasty as were the deep fried artichoke hearts served with garlic aioli. 

I really savored the hamburger with that amazing horseradish aioli on the side. Wow. And the French fries were done to crispy perfection.

I especially enjoyed the peanut butter ice cream that was part of the foundation to our shared banana split. That was scrumptious!

My next guest shall be my lovely wife.
author: Jay D.

description:
If you look for high-quality and delish food served in a chic & trendy restaurant  in North Beach (unlike many cheesy so-called italian! restaurants around! ) then Park Tavern is your thing. So many good things to say about the dinner: burger, steak, fish and brussel sprout chips are the most noteworthy ones and i stick to every time i visit Park Tavern. Also communal table and the bar is another great alternative if you're just in the mood for a drink and light bite.
Brunch is excellent not only because of the food but also the convenient of being able to make reservations (take a look at the next corner: Mama's and sigh inside for those poor waiting in line for hourS just to eat a waffle!).
author: Beril Y.

description: The first time I went here I was amazed by the food so I took my sister and boyfriend here for brunch. The deviled eggs were still awesome but I had the corned beef hash and my sister had the cod cake. Both sounded so good on paper but way too salty. The pancake was nice and fluffy but still sad about my savory dish.
author: Elizabeth N.

description:
I can't BELIEVE the dinner I had here at Park Tavern last month. When my boyfriend and I spotted $20 fries on the menu we wanted to scoff and then as if we could read each other's mind we both said out loud, "If they charge this much, maybe they're just THAT good." And trust me. THEY WERE.

But that's not all. We had cocktails and variety of other appetizers and small plates. Everything was more than good, it was phenomenal. Definitely a place you have to visit if you're coming to San Francisco and want to leave knowing just how great the food is in this city. In fact, I noticed my mother (who lives in SF) wrote Park Tavern a 5 star Yelp review last year. Great minds must eat alike!
author: Katy H.

description: Delicious brunch, the eggs with polenta and the cod cakes are solid. The challah bread is a must order. The ambiance is cool and rustic, especially for brunch.
author: Sheila E.

description:
WOW! I went here recently for the first time for dinner and was blown away. The decor is pretty upscale but the atmosphere is friendly and casual. I shared some plates with a friend and was completely happy with out entire order. We had a BLT-with a twist- which included a piece of raw tuna on butter lettuce... yum! We also had the crab dip with chips. 

I visited this place on vacation and loved this place so much that I tell people who are visiting SF to make sure to go!
author: Nicky L.

description:
I'm gonna go with 4 stars because overall, our meal and experience were positive and I think its a solid restaurant.  But I'm going to spend the rest of my review with nit-picky criticisms because I thought this place could be a 5 star.

Overall, my husband and I left saying that we would have rather eaten at Absinthe.  I think the comparison came from the fact that they're both "California-French bistros" in both look and menu.  But PT, because of its size (not terribly cozy) and a couple of flaws, came in second place for us.

Let's eat, shall we?

Deviled eggs:  Yep, these are pretty f*cking delicious.  Zero complaints here except that our dinner kind of peaked too early.

Lemon chips with burrata:  I defended this dish not because it blew my socks off flavorwise but because I've never had anything like it.  Its very light and perhaps not the best pairing with the deviled egg-flavor bombs.

Brussel sprout chips:  Solid.  

Crab and lobster bisque:  The first 3 bites of this soup were orgasmic.  The remainder was more of a struggle-- its a VERY rich, flavorful soup.  I literally don't think I could finish this bowl on my own.  

Rabbit and lardo terrine:  At first too simple, but actually when you mix all the components on the dish (er, slab of slate)-- mustard and spicy arugula-- it elevated it.  I could have used some kind of a cracker type thing to go with.

"Marlowe" burger:  This is where you really lost us, PT.  THE BUN WAS NOT GOOD.  Like, really, I'm not even being picky.  Its just a bad bun.  Crumbly and dry with no give, it really ruined the burger.  My husband has had the Marlowe at Marlowe and he says their bun was 100x better.  The burger was good but I couldn't tell because I was so angered by the bun.  The fries on the other hand, made me very happy.

May birthday cake (cappuccino): Tasted like refrigerator.  Kind of like, supermarket cake with half the sugar and better frosting.  Love the idea though!

Next time, if there is one, I want to eat 4 deviled eggs and those $20 french fries.
author: Kristin P.

description: Had brunch here with some friends and while all the food I had was good, I'm not sure I would go back on my own suggestion. There are plenty of amazing brunch places and I'm not certain the food with that price tag brings it to a higher tier for me. The service we had wasn't the best - she looked pretty annoyed the entire time and for me, a smile goes a long way.
author: Sarah G.

description:
I was taken here for my bday, and let me first just say that this isn't a place I'd normally walk into. Let's just say the crowd lacks diversity.

With that said, just about everything we ordered was tasty. The starters were great. In fact, we were considering ordering nothing but starters, since their menu descriptions were quite appetizing.

My entree was the pork chop. A thick, double cut, pork chop. Let me tell you... I was reluctant to order it, not because I dislike pork (quite the contrary, as pork is my favorite protein when done right), but because pork is all too often done poorly at nouveau American joints. I'm not sure what prompted me to actually order it this time, but I'm sooooo glad I did. This was one of the best pork chops I ever had. It was cooked perfectly medium rare, the flavor was full and smokey, it was fatty but not excessively so, and it was quite juicy.

I will end it right there before I drool on my keyboard.
author: J K.

description:
Technically, the food was three stars, but the value (quality/quantity/taste of food to money spent) makes me bring it down to two.  We had the deviled eggs.  Maybe we expected too much after all the rave reviews, but our table found them overly salty.  The egg flavor got lost among the bells and whistles of jalapeno, bacon, and chives.  Good, as any deviled egg will be, but not amazing.  We also shared the smoked burrata and heirloom tomato appetizer.  It was delicious, but the portion was tiny!  Our table of four had to share three tiny tomato slices, draped with prosciutto and burrata, and two pieces of dry toast.  I'm no glutton, but three tiny tomato slices seemed a bit meager.

For entrees, the seafood special was good - scallops, bay scallops w/ crumb top, calamari, and octopus.  Again, not better than anywhere else, but good.  The whole roasted chicken was good, but pretty much equivalent to any other roasted chicken.  The spinach at the base was disgustingly greasy, just swimming in chicken grease which really is not as good as you'd think.  The halibut was a little sad.  A diminutive portion of fish arrived on a big, long white plate with some legumes scattered about.  It did not inspire excitement and tasted just okay.  The pork chop, on the other hand, was thick, juicy and tender.  The only dish, I felt, that lived up to what we expected of the restaurant.

We departed not hungry, but a little disappointed in the food.  Also, be warned - this place is a definite scene.  Not everyone is going to enjoy and/or feel comfortable in this type of scene.  Most people will figure out whether they want to stay or go as soon as they get there.  On the plus side, the servers are very attentive and warm.
author: Pearl L.

description:
There's a lot to like about Park Tavern, which is the kind of place that feels like it's been there forever, even though it hasn't.

First of all, it's HUGE, with a scrubbed tile floor and open kitchen, reminiscent of Old New York (at least in my memory of Old New York).  It has a lively, bustling atmosphere, with a noise level that might be too much for some, but I found energizing.  The crowd also feels very "established", as in moneyed, but in that casual San Francisco way. 

Cocktails are delicious and range from the classic to the inventive.  I enjoyed the Country Lawyer, a bourbon cocktail with a dash of chocolate bitters as a subtle surprise.

We shared numerous appetizers, with my favorite being the Deviled Eggs, the Lemon Chips with Burrata, and the Uni.  I was disappointed with the Brussels Sprouts Chips, which were not as crisp as I would have liked.  Without even knowing that it's the same restaurant team behind Marlowe, I said "They have these at Marlowe and they are much better".

My dinner was good - seared black cod. Next time I would get the Poulet Rouge, which comes standing upright (like beer can chicken).  Unfortunately, my friend's halibut was not good and we sent it back, but luckily there was plenty for her to eat from our dishes.  They were very professional about it and offered another dish, and didn't charge us for it.

The desserts were just ok - we had the Chcolate Creme Brulee and another one I can't quite remember.   Next time I am getting the Fernet with a Ginger Back! 

The service was very polished and friendly, so I would feel comfortable taking anyone there, from a rowdy group of guys to my in-laws.   

All in all, a solid experience, and a place where everyone all around us seemed to be having a good time.
author: Liz S.

description: What a nice restaurant! Visiting from out of town we probably wouldn't have chosen to go to this restaurant based in its menu. But our son lives here in SF and he made reservations for all of us. Normally I do not like what I call "fancy" food, and this menu left me thinking there was nothing on the menu that sounded good to me. But when the waiter announced the special was salmon I decided to try it. I was not disappointed. In fact  it might be the best salmon I have ever had. It was served with some kind of creamed corn and mushrooms which were delicious. Atmosphere was very nice and upscale. The prawns appetizer was to die for and I could easily have had that for my entree. Dessert of ice cream sandwich was plenty big for 3 people to split and delicious. I highly recommend this restaurant.
author: T.M. K.

description: Fantastic brunch!  The deviled eggs, avocado toast and bloody mary are not to be missed!
author: Patty T.

description:
Stopped in on a whim without reservations and snagged 2 seats at the bar. Decor was amazing - rustic but contemporary. Having been to and loved Marlowe, we ordered the burger for comparison. Starters we had the much raved about deviled eggs and brussel sprout chips along with some cocktails.

Hands down best deviled eggs of my life!!! However, the price prevented me from ordering half a dozen for myself. Cocktails and the rest of our food were delicious as well, but seemed pricier than Marlowe. Parking is a pain in the you know what, but luckily they valet here.
author: Vivian D.

description: Maybe it's just me, but Park was ehh. Came here on a Friday for lunch. I decided I was going to get the ahi tuna with veggies. And I ordered a glass of wine with my lunch. The waitress was very helpful in choosing a wine that would complement my ahi tuna. I love that. If you are a waitress or waiter in the city, you need to know this. It's the basics. When I received the ahi tuna, I could immediately see that it had been overcooked. Usually ahi is this nice pink and this was almost pink-brown. Not a good look for ahi tuna. Also, whatever they had grilled the veggies with tasted like burned rubber. It was just not good. I ate it solely because I was starved. I was disappointed to say the very least. Other than the atmosphere and the location of the place, I would pass on this place. I am inclined to try it again, just not the ahi.
author: Carina R.

description: The food is fine, but my group felt that none of us had ever been to a LOUDER restaurant.  We were a table of six barely able to have a word of conversation the entire dinner.
author: J.j. A.

description:
Good gourmet food. Docked one point for a small menu. I'm all for picking a few dishes and perfecting them, but it was a really restrictive menu and some of the items are fairly similar.

But it has a good environment, the staff was nice, the food was excellent.

Try the fries with the egg dip and the steak is excellent.
author: Chris I.

description: We visited this place for brunch last Sunday and it was amazing! The drinks were delicious we ordered a carafe of the hummingbird cocktail so yummy with the st. Germaine. Then I ordered the polenta cakes with poached eggs and mushroom arugula salad my husband ordered the corn beef hash with red wine sauce. So divine but I will say the best part is the coconut chocolate banana fritters:) the table next to us had them and we decided the looked too good to pass up they were delicious! You must go here you won't be disappointed!
author: Gabby G.

description:
I don't think they do analogies on the SATs anymore but.....

Cafe Lulu: Web 1.0 
as 
Park Tavern: Web 2.0 

perhaps Park Tavern will survive when Web 2.0 crashes..... 


Ditto Chris L. 

Underwhelmed. 
I had been there a few times when it was Moose's, and hadn't been back in the neighborhood since... that's what a toddler will do to your social life.... in any case, we ended up in bar seating, which was fine by me, but wtf is up with people who continue to elbow you once, not twice, but multiple times during your meal? seriously dude in plaid shirt who probably works in some douchebaggy industry... NOT cool. 

Anyhoo. Service was brisk and friendly, but I guess the idea of a bowl of Brussels Sprouts 'chips' is not that amazing to someone who makes kale chips on a regular basis.... 

scallops were decent, dessert (i think it was a creme brulee?) was decent but not amazing.
author: Sf Momm Y.

description: Very good but avoid the brussel sprouts. They always seem to be too oily
author: H. T.

description:
I may have had the best meal I've eaten in a long time last night at Park Tavern. The food and drinks were outstanding but what really put it over the top was the opportunity to sit in the best seats of the house- the chef's table. 

Coming in on a Saturday night without reservations can be risky, but luck was on our side! We could have sat at the communal table at the bar, or at the chef's table- which is on the side toward the restrooms...but you get to see all the chefs working their magic and creating magnificent looking dishes. They work very efficiently and the plates they're carefully assembling look mouthwatering and absolutely beautiful. It made dining at Park Tavern dinner and a show. When I come back I only want to sit here! 

The food didn't disappoint either. Some of the chefs were laughing at us because we were outright enjoying our food so much! We started with the brussel sprout chips which were AMAZING! I could seriously eat these all day, everyday. They were nicely seasoned and fried for just the right amount of time. Next, we got the duck liver mousse which was smooth and flavorful. (Note: different from foie gras, but a perfect alternative now after the state ban). The plate comes with two generous spoonfuls of the mousse, cherries, pistachios and grilled bread. Finally, we got the burger. Mmmm...from the first bite you can immediately tell all the ingredients are high quality and it just melts in your mouth! There are fries with a horseradish dip that accompany the burger which also were perfection.

 From there, there wasn't much more room for dessert and we really wanted to try the Birthday Cake- so I'll be back soon for the brussel sprout chips and a slice of cake!
author: Christine A.

description:
I came here on a Thursday at 8:00 with reservations and got seated probably 10 minutes later, they were pretty packed as it was a nice day.

i ordered 4 shots of tequila it did the job and made my meal more enjoyable
I ordered the hen which was tasty
my friend ordered the burger with aioli on the side but when we got it there was some white sauce on top of the burger so i passed it off to my friend.
he also got the deviled egg which he liked.
our waiter was decent, the guys that provide the water and bread were on top of their game :)

i came here when it was mooses , and then joey and eddies. this place looks extremely nice inside. I would come here again to check out the bar:)
author: DOM d.

description:
Order the black chicken, it's great if not consistent. I've had it served too dry before or without potatoes, but it's generally the best thing on the menu.

Biggest gripe: The. servers. do. not. get. off. your. nuts. Every 30 seconds they're filling your water, wiping your table, replacing your silverware, checking in on you, etc. It's hard to maintain a conversation when all of a sudden there's an arm jutting in your face trying to pour water into a cup that's still 3/4s full. It wasn't "good service", they were just trying to rush us. 

Probably be a while before we go there again.
author: Jesse G.

description: Hmm, maybe I didn't order the right thing. I went with two deviled eggs and the shrimp toast. The shrimp toast had way too much mayonnaise in it, basically masking the taste of the shrimp. The deviled eggs were good but over-hyped on Yelp. The service was great and it's certainly a cool ambiance but I'm not sure this worth the high prices.
author: Madeline S.

description:
Very cool ambiance and a young professional crowd.  The food was very good but overall, didn't blow me away. 

+ Brussels sprout chips - Delicious but a little too oily.
+ Compressed watermelon salad with feta, olives, and mint - Wonderful, light and refreshing. 
+ Wild arugula, mushroom conserva, porcini & charred onion vinaigrette - Super simple but fantastic flavors
+ Seared Morro Bay black cod, sugar snap peas, baby leaks, red radish & Calabrian chile butter - Good flavors but could have been more tender.
author: Natasha P.

description:
Came here for brunch with friends on a packed Sunday, but thank goodness I had a reservation. We were seated promptly at our designated time. 

Ambience: hip, lively crowd on a sunny Sunday afternoon.

Service: Attentive in spite of the packed restaurant; wait service saw that we were chatting away and pretty much left us alone after food arrived, but did refill water, take away dirty dishes, etc., just didn't bug us with the bill.

Food:
First came the banana coconut fritters. Had really high hopes for this one but was too doughy inside and not much banana flavor. The accompanying raspberry sauce was delicious, though. The chocolate sauce was just OK, but combined with the raspberry sauce made the fritters a little more palatable.

The much raved deviled egg was a yummy combo of deviled egg topped with pickled jalapeño and bacon, if you're into that kind of flavors. But at $2.50 a pop, which is essentially 1/2 an egg, maybe good to try once unless you have deep pockets.

The dungeness crab toast points (three per order) was a disappointment. Too much lemon juice or something rendered it very tart. I thought I was eating sour toasts. Geez, leave the dungeness crab alone...it tastes good without working too much into it, just mayo salt & pepper is all it takes, really. 

The brioche french toast was excellent. Served with a blueberry compote/syrup, it was nice and crispy around the edges with a custardy center...yum!

The chorizo scrambled eggs was also very nice, with just a small kick. Scrambled eggs cooked the French way, which was creamy and perfect to my taste.

Didn't try the duck egg sandwich part, but I did steal a few french fries from my friend's plate and they were yummy...so good that I had to polish off what was left on her plate.

A great place to hang out with friends.

Parking is hard to find. It's North Beach after all. But there's valet parking available.

Tip: make reservations.
author: Lil D.

description:
Came here Sunday around 1pm and ordered from their brunch menu. 

Smoked trout on toast - 4/5. Was very pleasantly surprised with the smoked trout. Will definitely order this again.

Warm baguette with nut butter - 2/5. Basically just filler food. This is pretty identical to getting bread at a restaurant.

Crispy polenta cakes - 4/5. It was good, but portion was small. May consider ordering this again if I wanted something light.

Overall, I would come here again for brunch with friends. Food I tried wasn't particularly spectacular.
author: Andrey L.

description: My husband and I had brunch at the Park Tavern today and it was pretty close to perfect. We had the avocado toast, which was good but just a little too much lemon. I had the cast iron baked eggs and they were amazing. My husband loved his corn beef hash. The bloody Mary's were also yummy... spicy, just the way we like them. Our waiter was also awesome.
author: Aman S.

description:
Had a spontaneous dinner here on a Thurs night and was pleased with the pick.  We actually didnt have reservations but got seated outside (per request since my friend had her pup with her) within 45 minutes.  
Service: Friendly and on point.
Apps: Deviled eggs and brussell sprout chips were perfectly prepared.
Entree: Marlowe burger and fries were AMAZING
Crowd: On the hoity-toity side, but interesting none-the-less

I'll def be back soon, and want to check out the brunch on my next visit.
author: Gohar J.

description:
I'm so happy my friend moved into the neighborhood and introduced us to this place. They couldn't fit us in for an earlier dinner, but we did get seats at the common table. We first started with the devil eggs and the reviews are right. They're just so simple, but so delicious and fluffy! Oh, did I tell you there is a little present on top.. a crispy bacon. Yea, now you want to run there and grab some too right?!?!

My seared black cod was super delicious, cooked just right where the meat stayed together but was fork tender. It was pretty funny how the restaurant had 2 sets of customers. The older crowd seated in the dining area and the younger crowd hanging around the common table and bar. This place is enjoyed by all ages.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Possibly my new favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  Great location near pre-dinner cocktail spots...or just drink at the bar inside.  Menu items to order:

Cocktail:  Country Lawyer
Appetizers:  Deviled Eggs, Brussels Sprouts Chips, Demons on Horseback
Entree:  Pork Chop
Dessert:  Creme Brulee

Bo was our waiter and he recommended our entire dinner.  Looking forward to going back ASAP!
author: Ryan M.

description:
So loud. I felt like I was being punished with noise. At a Wednesday dinner, not some rowdy weekend party night. My throat is still sore from shouting to trying to make myself heard and this morning I owe apologies to my friends for only hearing half of what they were saying. A restaurant with tile floors and tile walls is inhumane.

Very good food and personal, well trained service. But I won't be going back, at least not if the place is full.
author: Nelson M.

description:
We ate lunch here a few weeks back sitting outside in the sunshine, it was very pleasant. The food was quite good, I had the burger which was cooked nicely. 

The service was kind of slow but I suppose that is the downside of sitting outside. 

The only nasty bit about this meal was the surprise I got a week or so later when I checked by amex and saw a charge a lot higher than what it should have been. The charge should have been for $35 dollars plus tip. I tipped an appropriate amount but they added a much larger tip, $19. I called to let them know, they took my details and were pleasant but never got back to me. After 3/4 days I decided I would just dispute the charge with Amex. Amex was quick to respond and refunded the money. I have still not heard back from the restaurant. 

Overall it is a pity as it was quite nice but I would be apprehensive about going back or I would only pay in cash.
author: Neil A.

description: Very unfriendly service between 230 and 530. If you don't want people to dine during that time, just close. The Marlow burger is of course great - - but not being able to sit at one of the 30 empty tables seemed unfriendly.
author: Janet R.

description:
You probably can't go wrong with anything that you order at this place. Everything on their brunch menu is delicious, but I particularly recommend their avocado toast and buttermilk pancakes. Good food, good ambience, good service, what more is there to ask for? 

However, one thing that I would recommend is to not get their drip coffee, which is mediocre compared to the rest of their food. Other than that, best brunch in the SF Bay Area, for sure.
author: Tara P.

description:
Great food, atmosphere, and location. 

This is an ideal brunch spot. I had the crispy polenta cakes with sautéed wild mushrooms, poached eggs, wild arugula, truffle salsa verde & shaved parmesan with a Mexican Mule (Reposado tequila, lime and ginger beer) and highly recommend it all. There were six in our party and all the plates were thoroughly enjoyed. I'm not sure this place knows how to make a bad dish!
author: Jen N.

description:
Came Saturday night with the boy and we got seated by the window near the front which was nice. It seemed much more nosier everywhere else. 

We started with the truffle fries with an egg yolk and caviar. Omg this was Delicious. The soft egg with caviar was nice added touch that I've never seen. Now next I come I want to try the lemon with burrata and the deviled eggs.

Entrees we both got the pork chop. It was nice an tender and cooked perfectly. They give you a big sized chunk of meat too!

For dessert we got the banana spilt. It was a fun dessert to each together. It comes with peanut butter ice cream, raspberry and chocolet. OH SO GOOD!
author: Jess O.

description: My friend and I had a very lackluster dining experience here.  I got the feeling this was 'the' place at one time, but it wasn't when we were here.  My $29 fish entree just wasn't good ~ fish was nothing special, greens were super bitter (and I love greens), it was oily, and the dish my friend had was super heavy and cheesy.  Execution just didn't work.
author: D B.

description:
Food:  5 stars
Value:  4 stars
Service:  4 stars
Ambiance/Decor:  5 Stars

An all-around great restaurant experience for a night out.  The experience begins with a beautiful, hip, upscale decor within a restaurant situated in one of the marquis spots in SF (adjacent Washington Sq Park).

Fantastic food.  Creative- brussel sprout chips.  Decadent- Crispy lamb croquettes with sauteed sweet breads (holy crap these were good).  Hearty- braised short rib over smoked potato puree.  All EXCELLENT.

A new local favorite.
author: Duke K.

description:
Ridiculous how good Park Tavern is. First time? You must try the pork chop, burger and deviled eggs. Tasty cocktails. Gorgeous space. There's a full bar and they offer communal tables if you dig that style.

Make a reservation or come as soon as they open. This place is H-O-T.
author: Yee-Shing W.

description: Excellent brunch food. They have some very simple dishes. Good drink selection. Make a reservation for brunch or dinner, otherwise you will be sitting at the bar.
author: Cara C.

description:
Food: High quality, unique combinations, and overall very delicious! I highly recommend trying the deviled eggs, they come with crispy bacon on top! Also ordered the carrot pesto salad, pork chop, and scallops.

Drinks: Sophisticated cocktail menu, I tried the Oaxacan Flower which  was very smokey. The coffee was really good as well and perfect close to a relaxing evening. 

Service: Attentive, food and drink came out quickly!

Ambiance: It honestly feels like a large, modern and fancy tavern. It has a great bar when you walk in. The entire place is dimly lit. There were mostly couples and small groups dining. 

I recommend this place for a special occasion, we came here for our anniversary! For a complete dining expereince you will sepnd well over $100, but totally worht it!
author: Julie J.

description:
I've been here twice in the last couple months and I can confidently say that this place is going to be a top recommendation for me.  The design of the dining room is inviting, comfortable, and not too loud...big for me as I approach middle age.   Anyway, I'm not sure the owners want this effect but it's the kind of place you just want to take your time eating and enjoy the food, the company, and the surroundings.  The restaurant is right on Washington Square so really there isn't a bad table in the house.  A window seat gives you a great view of the park.  Further back into the dining room, it is comfortable and cozy.  

The service has been excellent both times I've been there.  The servers know the menu well and are happy to help you make your selection.  I haven't had to flag them down for more water, or more coffee, or delays between courses.  Just the right amount of attention, and excellent follow up.  

The food is just friggin' delicious.  I've had the pancakes with bacon, and the hamburger.  All the details are done per your request, and the quality of the food is among the best I've had in San Francisco.  But try it yourself.  I'd be very surprised if you came away disappointed.
author: Kurt L.

description:
Got chummy with the bar-back and bartender right off the bat.... which led to some heavily poured Jameson drinks and great conversation. Thanks, Park Tavern! I'm now a fan!

Really mixed crowd once the dining area closes and primetime nightlife kicks in.

VERY hard to find parking for all those rare drivers that decide not to cab (very close to Coit Tower).

Definitely worth checking out if you want something a little more up-scale.
author: Drea B.

description: Why would I ever leave my neighborhood, and only to be disappointed, ahem the Marina.  Thank you Jake for your graciousness and making this an awesome neighborhood gem icon, with great cocktails, superb food, and excellent service.
author: K G.

description:
I think those stinky trust fund kids who continue to occupy the world are talking about places like Park Tavern and the folks that inhibit their four walls when crying foul about the 1%. I don't think I've ever found myself situated around so many well-to-do older men and their diamond-studded escorts in my 29 years on this planet before a recent stop into PT. Sitting at the bar alone (it's how I roll at times) and overhearing some of the conversations that only wealthy people could ever relate to made me feel so bad for less-fortunate members of our society, I actually seeked out the nearest panhandler and gave him a $5 bill upon exit. It made me feel roughly 99% better than I did before I left the bustling traditional American juggernaut across the street from Washington Square Park.

Aside from a pretty stuffy hang and an hour-long wait just for a single seat at the bar (it's not their fault they make delicious food that many, many people want to eat), Park Tavern is worth its weight in gold. Being a fan of Marlowe since they opened in SOMA, I knew right off the bat I'd be a fan of their latest project taking over the old Moose's space in North Beach. 

If I were on a deserted island and you were to ask what five foods I'd want around me at all times, you'd find deviled eggs somewhere towards the very top of that list. And when I heard rave reviews from friends and colleagues alike about their version of the classic comfort food item, I just had to get in there and try them at any cost. Sure enough, while not as good as the deviled eggs at Wayfare Tavern in my opinion, they didn't disappoint. They were spiced up with jalapeño and bacon, and a sweet element that I couldn't quite put my finger on (but added a nice, unexpected twist). Upon future visits, I'd order these every single time.

In addition to the deviled eggs, I had to tackle a couple of their other standout bar bites: the brussels chips, and the demons on horseback. The latter features grilled shrimp wrapped in lardo and grilled in olive oil until the fat melts into the outer layer of the crustacean. It comes accompanied with slices of cucumber dotted with a black pepper buttermilk cream sauce that adds a nice visual touch to the smokey snack. It was fantastic (as I'd hope at a price point of $13 for four of them total). Regarding the brussels chips, there's not much I can say except you'd be a lunatic not to order these if you find yourself splurging on Stockton. The delicate leaves of the brussels sprouts are separated from the hearts, grilled, and doused in olive oil. For such a heavily-oiled appetizer, it's a light snack that packs an intensely flavorful punch. Perfect for sharing, or in my case, devouring every last piece until you're left with nothing but glistening fingertips, an empty wooden bowl, and a defeated soul. 

It's worth mentioning that the cocktail program is as good as any in the city as well. They have a scaled down list of craft cocktails that concentrates on the classics, and they have a few Park Tavern originals as well. They also boast a nice-sized wine and beer list for folks looking to avoid the hard stuff.

It's about as far from my comfort zone as it gets, but Park Tavern rewards with a truly memorable epicurean experience. I've been an Anna Weinberg fan ever since I shared a symposium panel with her before SF Chefs in 2010, and while I'm not even close to the bullseye of their core demographic, Park Tavern will be on a short list of special occasion hangs for ol' Ruggeford H. Joesten III.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
It has always been, and will always be, what's inside that counts.

While the space remains relatively the same, the heart and soul of this Washington Square location has been masterfully rewritten by Jennifer Puccio and the leadership of one of SF's best, Anna Weinberg.

Park Tavern is a sweeping space, with a penchant for details hidden under the history of a storied block. 

There is a caffeine like energy which adds springs to conversations, and a charming glow that sets the very diners visiting at the core of it's design. Genuine, heart felt and hungry. 

Our group began with a special unlike anything I've ever experienced. While fries may not seem extraordinary, the imagination of Puccio delivered. 

Truffle fries nested on a plate, accompanied by a 3/4 eggshell which contained a creamy yolk crème topped off with caviar. The rich gravy coated each fry with a decadent cloak, which was only elevated by the delicate black ornaments of caviar.

Ketchup just lost the rose ceremony...

The house made charcurterie plate was a brilliant display of craft, and the duck liver crostini was a marvel. If you didn't feel guilty, you weren't enjoying it.

The grilled pork chop with dinosaur kale and toasted garlic served as the entree.

Fork to protein brittle, and matched with timed seasoning, the pork is a hit. Every note was selected with purpose, and the dish proved itself a phenomenal keeper.

Park Tavern is a mature adoption of another of my Weinberg favorites, Marlowe, and if this type of re-imagining continues, Anna might just have to run for Mayor.

Bravo.
author: Mike K.

description: Had an amazing Fathers Day brunch here. Brioche cinnamon toast for the kiddo, smoked cod cake, peach and avocado with cottage cheese, and avocado toast for the adults. Refreshing, creative and delicious!
author: Urban C.

description:
I am giving this place 3 stars based on service and entrees. I have been here twice and each time, i had wished that I just ordered an assortment of appetizers instead of my $30 entree that I didn't love. This past visit I ordered the halibut(one of the two pescatarian items on the menu. No vegetarian item entrees and the other fish entree had bacon in it) the portion was extremely small and my favorite part ended up being the corn that sat underneath the fish. It just didn't have much seasoning or any sauce.(on a side note, my friend ordered the pork and he loved it. and the portion was HUGE). I know their menu is seasonal so i may have better luck next time.

The hostess staff is excellent. I know they are always busy and you always need to have a reservation but when the 4 of us walked in, they were able to seat us immediately outside under a few heat-lamps and provided blankets. wonderful. :)

I was disappointed in our server. He seemed a little out of it. We ordered drinks and they took close to 20-25 minutes to get them. When we ordered our second round of drinks, again it took close to 20 minutes. Our bill was almost $300 and we couldn't get our drinks. IT was just weird. The whole meal process was very long....

On the upside, i love the appetizers. The brussel sprout chips, marinated olives and devilied eggs are yummy. I can't wait to try the crab dip and the cornmeal crusted oysters :)
author: Whitney S.

description:
Park Tavern is a perfect place for a date where you can sit outside during nice weather. Or just a perfect place for reunion or sex-and-the-city kind of brunch.

Service was good and not overwhelming; parking was tough but there's $10 brunch valet. 

Unfortunately it was hard to love the food here. Our crab toast was delicious but there was't sufficient crab. Veal Schnitzel sounded much nicer than how it really tasted. Surely bacon fat eggs that accompanied the veal sounded delicious but there was nothing special with the taste. Perhaps the concept was similar to duck fat french fries but was not good once implemented. Even worse, the schnitzel seemed like something you can fry it yourself at home. 

The dessert on the other hand was quite good. 
TCHO chocolate creme brulee was not your regular brulee because there wasn't hard sugar to coat the creme. The taste was decent and the salt was a good touch. Panna Cotta with orange was good but also not great - you could possibly find the same dessert at other joint. 

All and all, Park Tavern has a warm ambience for intimate dinner. You won't be disappointed if you lower your expectation or if you are here when you are hungry from the mad Mama's line.
author: Fred F.

description:
I was so surprised to find such a upscale, trendy and cool place like this in my hood. Great crowd, great food, great ambiance, and you're still in North Beach.
I would totally recommend it both for a dinner with friends, and for a date.
author: Steve E.

description: I may just come here every time I come to SF. Best food, best atmosphere. We had reservations, our table was a little late, to make up for it they gave us 2 appetizers and 2 drinks: classy!!! The brussel sprout appetizer was sooooo good. Dinner was excellent. As was dessert. Our server Heather was great, honest and gave us honest input about the food. 5 stars my friend.
author: A J.

description: Really enjoyed the Park Tavern.  Service very professional but friendly and the food was above average.  All the recommended dishes in the other reviews were spot on but agree the brussel sprouts chips were just okay. Worth a visit
author: Graeme U.

description:
Fantastic place for brunch.  A bit heavy for me but they do so many things well here.

I had some fantastic poached eggs on toast, lux with a bearnaise sauce, and some terrific no frills toast.  All of the little details were tended to, including the complexity of flavors, variety of textures, and the warm with the cold.  

Really quite terrific - as was the service.  My only "greivance" was that things were a bit on the heavy side, but that is a matter of personal preference I think.

Best of all, go take a stroll in the park across the street afterwards.
author: Mark M.

description:
I ate and drank at Park Tavern, and I'm seeing stars. Lots of 'em. The service gets stars, the cocktails get stars, the not-overwhelming, cherry-picked best-of wine list gets stars and- most importantly- the food: stars. The fried pork-belly bites with horseradish aioli are not to be missed. The whole chicken with greens was stellar (albeit a scooch salty for my taste). The yummy, cheesy twice-baked potato topped off our American Heart Association recommended meal. 

I also give extra star power to the lively, lovely space the new proprietors have created. Also of particular note: these folks seem to be making a point to pay attention to the neighborhood, it's long-standing businesses, those who live here. They "bring it", but do so with a complete lack of hubris and they seem very sweetly inclined to honor North Beach's true character and long history.

Go here. You won't be disappointed.
author: Suzanne K.

description: Great food, great service, and of course great cocktails! A great experience, their Devilled Eggs are a must!
author: A M.

description: Nice ambiance, but the service leaves something to be desired. We miss the corn bread stuffing with the cornish game hen dish, not as good with just the chard.
author: Derwood A.

description: The appetizers and dessert were better than the entrees. We loved the PT Fries and Braised Lamb Tongue.  We also ordered the Colorado lamb and bar steak which were ok. The strawberry shortcake was absolutely delicious!  Drinks took a while to show up but the bar was pretty busy.  Atmosphere was pretty cool but noises (if you were expecting an intimate dinner).
author: Lanae S.

description:
Came for a friends birthday party with about 8 people. I always expect slow service with a larger group, but this restaurant actually was very quick with taking orders, making the food, fillings waters, etc. 

The food was good; I recommend the PT fries - truffle fries with boiled egg (yolk is still runny, great to dip fries in) and the "poulet noir" which is a hen cooked and served on a skillet (very juicy, very generous portion)!

Valet parking is convenient since parking around Washington square park is close to impossible.
author: Daniel K.

description:
I've been hearing a lot about this place from friends, so decided to go there for dinner on a Sat night.  Overall, I give it a 4/5.  Great food and lively atmosphere (if you're looking for that).  Service so-so.

Made reservations a month in advance, as it's gotten quite popular of late.  Upon entering, you get this feeling of stepping into a huge space (for SF at least) and very energetic (read loud).  Most of the time I felt like I was yelling to my friends.  There was a lot of "what did you say?".  In any case, we were seated promptly.

Food (apps)
* brussel sprout chips - probably my favorite app there.  I could see myself sitting in front of the tv scarfing these down.  although, after eating a bunch, they def. started to get salty.
* beef jerky - nothing special, other than the fact that you can order beef jerky at a restaurants
* watermelon, feta, olives - this dish was ok, i'd pass next time
* seasonal fig dishes - if you like figs, elegantly put together and very balance in flavor
* demons on horseback - very well put together bacon wrapped shrimp.  I love bacon and i love shrimp, so how can you go wrong.  

Food (entrees)
* Grilled pork chop - next to the roasted chicken "Poulet rouge", this was a very delicious pork chop.
* Poulet rouge - striking presentation, a small whole chicken served in cast iron, upright.  look for the images  you'll see what i mean.  Very flavorful and moist, rounded out with spinach and mini potatoes.

Service - so so.  Perhaps it was a busier night than normal, perhaps it was a relatively new waitress.  We were left waiting around a lot, for water, for the check.  When I asked our waitress for a wine suggestion, she could not give her answers promptly. Granted there is a huge wine list, so I will not fully fault her.
author: Alvin Y.

description: I don't understand how you could not give this place 5 stars. What exactly could they do better? Their bar is amazing, service is fantastic, and their food is simply perfect. Yes, as you've heard, get the deviled eggs. They will change your life. But every other starter is fantastic as well. Anyone who does not give this 5 stars is simply a snob, plain and simple. Been here over a dozen times and not had close to a bad experience or anything that wasnt delicious.
author: Brandon L.

description: I get what all the fuss is about. Came here with girlfriends mid afternoon on a Sunday. We sat outside, drank wine & creative cocktails and dined on bar bites. The fried brussel sprout leaves were everything I dreamed about...crisp, salty and nice hint of lemon. The girls loved the burger they shared and I thought the fries that accompanied it were solid with a nice horseradish aioli. Also had the delicious deviled eggs, the thinly sliced jalapeño was sweet and spicy & divine. Beautiful interior, welcoming and on point service. Can't wait to go back. Maybe next time it will be with a hot man with a big wallet...a girl can dream.
author: Cec D.

description:
The appetizers were great! The entrees were so-so. We got the crispy brussels sprouts, the demons on horseback, and a deviled egg each. yum. All 3 entrees were just so-so after those amazing appetizers. The dessert was also... eh. We shared a peach cobbler thing. 

I would go back! I have a feeling they're usually better than that! (and I live two blocks away)
author: Claire b.

description:
A lovely Anniversary dinner choice...kudo's to the hubster. My hubby is always scanning the Sunday paper or reading articles online about the newest places to eat local and in NYC (for our treks to the big apple). So this year since we couldn't be in New York for our Anniversary he'd been wanting to go to the Park Tavern. So he surprised me with making the reservations 3 weeks in advance (Go dude!).
It was pouring rain when we arrived for our Friday night 7:30 reservation, but no worries with $11 valet. We were seated in a small corner seat. Our waiter got our drink orders out to us right away, and we ordered some starters while trying to decide what to order. We heard the deep fried bussel sprouts and deviled eggs were really good, the deviled eggs come with a small slab of bacon and a slice of jalapeno. WoW! Spicy, fatty and rich. The  deep fried brussel sprouts were crisp and airy and melted in your mouth (a tad salty) but delicious. 
We decided for an appetizer we'd share the truffle fries with caviar and a soft boiled egg? (I know, talk about cholesterol overkill...hey it was our anniversary).
Never waited more than 10 or 15 minutes between each dish. We both decided to throw caution to the wind after all the other starters and go for the Fillet Mignon with twice baked potato. It came with a wine sauce and it was pretty much "I've died and gone to heaven..." delicious. Whoa.....but alas....silly me ate too many fries, and other things and couldn't finish my dinner. So I took my dinner home in a box. Which I got to enjoy for lunch at work the next day (and was equally as good). That Steak which we both ordered medium rare, was perfect. and the sauce was rich and the crunchy twice baked potato.....oh and they gave us strawberry cake and after dinner drinks for free since it was our anniversary. What a perfect evening!
(one small thing on a rainy day, their tile floor is uber slippery)
I hope we get to go back here sometime soon for dinner, I really enjoyed my evening and food...oh and my fabulous company! Score for the hubster!
author: Susan D.

description: Went here for brunch on a Saturday with my boyfriend.  Nice ambience.  Try to sit outside or near the windows.  The cocktails are delish!  Great service.  Amazing food. All in all, a very nice upscale brunch.
author: Mari R.

description: Was meeting a friend for dinner. I arrived early and they offered to seat me while i waited or I could go to the bar and wait for my friend. Sat me promptly at 7. Waiter was very attentive and patient. Considering we didnt order food for at least an hour after we sat (could make up our minds). Settled on the braised pork cheeks. They were just amazing. Came out about 5 minutes after they were ordered. I ordered the duck and she ordered the steak. Both were perfectly cooked. The chestnuts that came with the duck held a lot of the flavor from the fat of the duck and paired perfectly with the spinach.  We ordered a drinks both grey goose cocktails. Well made . Maybe a little pricey for the pour but they were consistently made and brought to us. I highly recommend this place.
author: Steve S.

description:
Had an awesome brunch here and the star was actually their boozy smoothie....bourbon, bananas.....I only wish it were bigger. 

Check out photos of what we ate at 

http://eatsporkjew.com/restaurants/park-tavern-brunch-in-north-beach-sf/
author: Philip H.

description:
SO good. Yummy food, great atmosphere and excellent service. 

The goods: Brussel sprout chips, summer squashes w/egg and burrata, lobster bisque, black cod. Hubby got the pork chop, which was also quite good. 

Highly reco making a reso - it's so much more comfy to sit in the dining room. Def a must-return spot.
author: Adrienne C.

description: Iron-baked eggs with spinach was amazing. Everything on the menu looked really. Will def come back and be a regular. Liked the atmosphere. The service was a little spotty, which is to be expected on a busy Sunday afternoon - my companion minded, but I didn't, yet he said he was def coming back too. Viola!
author: Pamplemouse L.

description:
I was on a mission for a really good burger and it was suggested that the Park Tavern would meet my needs.  They did not disappoint.  We started with the pork cheeks appetizer, which was excellent.    

The Marlowe burger lived up to expectations.  perfectly cooked, crisp bacon, cheddar on a soft bun.  the fries also lived up to expectations.  

For dessert we got the ice cream sandwiches.  They were good but nothing extraordinary. 

Service was also great.

The whole menu looked good and I'll definitely be back to taste some of the other .  On this night, i was on a mission and Park Tavern did me right.
author: Rahul A.

description: Love this place! I was worried about the long line for brunch, but we sat at the community table and had no wait at all. You can't go wrong here! You must order the avocado toast! The atmosphere is an A+ too! I can't wait to come back and try their lunch and dinner! :)
author: Heather P.

description: I love this spot. Great bar, great brunch, all around favorite.
author: Stacy W.

description:
Went for dinner on Saturday night with a friend - we were 30 minutes late for our reservation but I called ahead to let them know. The hostess was very gracious and said they would seat us when we arrive, chich they did. No waiting and she thanked me for calling. I had the pork chop, my friend had the scallops and I tried a deviled egg - it was really good. The food was delicious and our service was excellent. Our server was great, he was very engaging and attentive. 

The vibe is contemporary and comfortable with tiled floors and rustic textures. It felt refined, welcoming and relaxing. Prime people-watching with Washington Square across the street.
author: An S.

description:
Delicious food in a great atmosphere! This place is busy all the time! Make a reservation if you can - to avoid the wait! We sat at the bar, the last time, and the bartenders are nice/attentive, but not chatty.

Brunch is amazing...great Bloody Mary's!! The deviled eggs are delish!

Dinner is even better! And dessert - yum!! I believe the "birthday" cake changes each month?

This place is here to stay (I hope)!
author: Pam W.

description:
We went here to celebrate a birthday. Let's start with the hostess or the person who takes the reservations. This lady could give a class on customer service in the hospitality industry. We changed the reservation times twice (flight delay) and she didn't bat an eyelid, she was cool about the whole thing.

Secondly, we had people in our party who have major food intolerances, the hostess relayed this information to the kitchen - the waitress had this information on her docket when she brought our menus. This level of caring for one's customers is special. For this reason alone, I'd dine there again.

Overall, the service from the barman, to the waitress to the waterboy was excellent. I like my food on time, my waterglass filled without asking, and unobtrusive service. I don't need to be asked more than once if the food is to my liking. I don't need to know my waitress's name , and I hate fawning. All of my requirements were filled. Service was great!

The food was good too. From the brussels sprout chips, the deviled eggs, the pate, the squash blossom salad.... I'm getting hungry just writing these things again. 

My most favorite thing was the polenta side dish with  orange & red cabbage relish on top. 5 stars right there! Delicious, creamy, smooth not gritty. Yum. Yum. Yum.

My dining companions had mixed seafood, filet mignon, halibut, and the pork chop. They were happy diners. The only disappointment was the burger - the meat patty was tiny and flat, the fries uninteresting.

The restaurant itself is on Washington Square. It has a great buzz to it - it's not fancy, just a nice place to hang out with good people.
author: G M.

description:
My favorite restaurant from my trip to SF this June. We came here for brunch and it was probably better than any brunch I've had in NYC!

We ordered a feast and tried a ton of things. Must haves:

- Avocado toast  (it is THE BOMB)
- Nut butters
- Deviled egg sandwich
- Pancakes (if you want to splurge)

I tried the duck hash and didn't love it, but my friends did.

Service: Very friendly and attentive.
author: Sarah M.

description: Well to be honest this was our plan B for brunch but because the line outside of Mamas was so long.... Let me tell you this will not ever be a plan B again. I have a side of two eggs and the avocado toast... It was the perfect amount of food and cooked to perfection. They have a spice they put on top of the toast that makes it amazing. I will definitely be coming back!!!
author: Cameron M.

description:
Yelpers high-remarks disappoint again.

Great atmosphere BUT
NOT WORTH THE MONTH+ reservation wait
NOT WORTH the tough parking
NOT WORTH emptying my wallet on food that's not impressive

What are you ppl thinking?!!!
author: Keiko C.

description:
I came here with my roommate on the recommendation from a local friend (I'm from NY).  Overall a great meal and certainly was busy on a Tuesday night.  Here's the rundown:

We started off with their Deviled Egg's, Dungeness Crab dip, Wagyu beef jerky, Kampachi, Devils on Horseback and Rabit, Duck & Foie Gras Terrine (yes we eat a lot and exercise to make up for it).  Everything was delicious.  The Terrine was really really rich and for the amount of food we ordered, might have been a little overkill, but it was still delicious.  I was a huge fan of the kampachi and probably my favorite from the app's.

We ended up splitting our entree's.  I got the tuna while he got the pork chops.  The tuna was cooked perfectly and presentation was nice.  The pork chops were good, but a little too salty for my taste.

I also had their Old Fashioned and something similar to the Old Fashion (can't remember the name).  The Old Fashioned was really smooth and probably not for my own good!

Atmosphere is definitely loud and they were playing modern rock (Black Keys, White Stripes, etc).  I would definitely recommend this place!
author: Byron K.

description: The atmosphere of this place is quite cool - steakhouse meets Italian family living room. The entire menu sounded amazing and the food did not disappoint, though I wonder if that's more due to the gratuitous amounts of butter and oil used. Otherwise, great.
author: Eric J.

description:
