Holy crap, I'm so bad w/ names. My friend and I came here after grabbing brunch at Mama's. We wanted a place to relax and have a drink and this was definitely a good choice.

We were immediately seated at the bar. Although I can't tell you the bartender's name or the drink(s) I ordered, I can tell you that he was very nice and the drinks were super good. We told the bartender what kind of drinks we liked and he made us something delicious! He was super nice and friendly.

I saw the food people around me ordered and it all looked so good.

Note: the toilet in the second stall in the women's bathroom is super crooked. I thought I was drunk at first!
author: Justine O.

description:
Oh, Park Tavern.  Now you're courting us with brunch? Time for a little review update, and one helpful hint...

In one word?  Heaven.  Polenta cakes with truffled mushrooms and poached eggs?  Devine.  I don't even like mushrooms, but these were to die for.  My husband had veal schnitzel and fried eggs.  Washed down with a bourbon smoothie (booze, espresso, banana....hello, best milkshake EVER?) Shared the cinnamon sugar challah toast.  And of course the little guy had scrambled eggs and pancakes....which brings me to my only critique of the amazingly ridiculous Park Tavern.

Park Tavern, I know you're sexy.  I get it.  See and be seen, and all.  So evenings at Park Tavern are for lovers, and hot singles looking for other hot singles (with good taste in restaurants), and classy couples trying to keep their cool quotients high.  I get it.

But weekends, circa 11 am?  Weekend brunch is for families.  I was a little embarassed bringing my two year old to a restaurant that has been coined SF's new hot spot, but then I looked around, and the preschool set pretty much ruled the restaurant.  Because brunch is for families.  So Park Tavern, can you do us families a favor?  All we need is a single selection just for kids.  I'm not talking junky paper kid's menus with a cup of crayons.  I get it.  You're sexy and all.  I'm just saying a discreetly placed note on the side of the grown-up menu, maybe a "Little Combo" (one pancake, some scrambled eggs, a piece of cinnamon sugar toast....I mean, since you asked).  Because really, your food is rich and delicious and spectacular, but a little too out of this world for the 5 little girls that came for a "ladies lunch" with their moms one table over.  Brunch is for families.  Just sayin'
author: Kim S.

description:
Their brunch is delicious, especially if you play around and order parts from all over the menu. While the dinner has been terrific two times I went, I can't forget the dry fish I had the first time.

Appetizers are better than the entrees (minus the delicious chicken and burger).
 And don't overthink it - get the truffle fries.
author: Cristina C.

description:
Goodbye 2011.  

After a crappy Friday at work my friend and I decided we needed a treat (and dinner).  Park Tavern has been on the list, so we gave it a go.  

The space is warm and inviting.  I liked the mixture of old and new decor with a grey and white color palate.  The Moose head and antlers on the wall by the bar pay homage to the original tenant, nice touch.  

Our server Aura was great, she brought us a glass of wine in a quick minute to help erase our night at work.  Things were looking good.  

We had deviled eggs, just the right amount of spice, the appetizer winner for us.  The fried Oyster Caesar was a little messy, but the flavors were all there.  For dinner we had the Creekstone NY Steak, red wine jus, Mangalitsa butter & french fries.  Steak cooked a perfect medium rare, tender and juicy, just what my friend was craving.  I had the grilled pork chop , Italian butter bean pistou, dinosaur kale, toasted garlic & chili flakes.  The chop was huge, double cut and cooked perfectly.  The veggies were a little on the salty side for me, but I liked the combination of flavors.  What night would be complete without dessert?  We shared the TCHO chocolate creme brulee with chocolate biscotti.  My friend is a creme brulee junkie, he totally loved this version.  The lemon zest shaved on top was really noticeable on the first bite. 

The perfect end to our 2011 working life.  Cheers!
author: Kim A.

description: The lemon chips and burrata appetizer was quite tasty. The salmon was great, but the quality of meat used for the ribeye steak wasn't quite up to par.
author: Amin S.

description:
Brunch at park tavern was amazing.  Get there pretty early on the weekend or you'll need to wait in line for a bit.  

also a great place for happy hour.  I met a friend right at 5 and there was plenty of seating for us at the bar or at standing tables - it got a bit crowded right around 6:15 but the vibe was still nice.
author: Patrick M.

description:
Try the deviled eggs. You will think "really? deviled eggs at dinner?" - yes, yes to deviled eggs at dinner. They are absolutely the greatest things ever and I don't think that was the wine talking.

Here's the rest of the breakdown:

Food - amazing. just flat out delicious. we had a steak tartare app, the deviled eggs, scallops, brussel sprouts, and the fish of the day, everything was just melt in your mouth good.

Wine - expensive, but well paired.

Service - on point.

Wait - if you don't make reservations well in advance you can still show up and wait for a cancellation. We got lucky doing that but you can't count on it and you have to be with a group (or date) who's good natured enough to be willing to waste an hour or so hanging out in the bar. If you keep good company this shouldn't be a problem.

Price - it's expensive. but it's worth it so just be prepared for it. Decide before hand wether you can afford it so once you get there you can forget about it. This isn't a place to go if you have to worry over every little item. But if you decide you can treat yourself then do it! Enjoy yourself, check the diet and the budget at the door, you can pick them up on your way out.


I would love love love to go to this place again!
author: Katie V.

description:
Came to Park Tavern past Saturday with a group of friends. We arrived and I was immediately impressed with how large the dining area is inside.  Dark colors, white tiled floors, nice touches of greenery (cute topiaries) and just an overall warmth in the  restaurant.  We were seated promptly and served with warm bread and butter. Yum! We decided to try a variety of appetizers - beef jerky, uni, raw salmon, and the deviled eggs.  The clear standout appetizer is the deviled eggs (much better than Wayfare I must say).  For my main I had the filet which was super yummy. How could you go wrong with steak? Our table also shared the $20 fries and those were immediately gone after it hit the table.  Our group also tried the pork chop, poulet, and the fish dish (I think cod).  

Overall the food was okay, no clear standouts then the fries and the eggs. As the night continued on the bar area was getting more and more crowded and it was definitely loud. We were yelling across the table to each other.
author: Julie F.

description: Really, really good breakfast. Great feel, professional staff, ridiculously delicious food. Definitely order the cocktail with espresso, banana, and bourbon (one I'll be making at home).
author: M F.

description:
I went on date last night at Park Tavern - this place is beautiful!  I am a vegan and had to eat a salad, which was just excellent. The service is very knowledgable about drinks and had pretty spot on recommendation for wine. People seem to be local here, not a touristy place at all!

I will definitely be back for a cocktail, their bar scene is vibrant too!
author: Marie A.

description: This restaurant was really great. It has a amazing location and have great food. The only reason that I have to give 4 stars is because of the waiting. While our waitress did not write anything down she forgot about half the order. Although they refunded the chicken it was not worth the time. But this restaurant is really great and has great food
author: Frank S.

description: The deviled eggs are beyond AMAZING! every time my bf and I take a trip to San fransisco we always come here for some good beer and the amazing deviled eggs! The eggs have a slice of pepper topped with bacon, and a little oil. Every needs to try them!!
author: Kat J.

description: Great brunch spot! Loved the detailing in their decor and the overall ambience. The food was excellent - we tried the avocado toast, the chorizo and eggs, the corned hash, and the grapefruit mimosas. Everything was excellent. The chorizo was flavorful but not too spicy. The hash was so tasty and cooked to perfection. The mimosas were unique and very good. The avocado toast was simple and light, absolutely delicious. We would definitely return and recommend to anyone. A little pricey ($150 for 4 people, but this included multiple rounds of drinks).
author: Daniel C.

description:
After the symphony Saturday night, I took my boyfriend for a birthday dinner at Park Tavern. The staff seem intent on making the place feel more casual and friendly than its pricing, location, and clientele -- much appreciated. We were given a cushy corner booth, which was perfect. 

As for the food:
They were out of deviled eggs. (Our reservation was for 10:30p, so running out of something was not unreasonable.) We ended up with this:
homemade jerky (as expected)
brussels sprouts chips (they were simply the fried leaves of sprouts)
warm chicory salad (salty!)
tombo tuna (good! sorta salty)
apple crisp (super salty -- how? why?) with black tea ice cream (superb!)
McKinley cocktails (no. do not order.)
glasses of a malbec and a torrontes (both great)

Overwhelmingly, this meal was salty. The salad was delicious at first, but not finish-able. Indeed, I kept retreating to the jerky as a palate cleanser (jerky is salty, too). The tuna was really nicely prepared and, had the preceding dish not been so salted, I probably would not have found the fish so. It was nicely seared, in good portion, and nicely seasoned (salt notwithstanding). We were both excited for the fruitiness of the crisp when it arrived, but the crumble was incredibly salty as well! (I generally like the trend of salting sweets, but this was excessive.) 

I remarked that the whole meal had the feel of having been over-tasted by the same person during prep. I have made some horrendously salty soups when I've been the only taster, getting more and more used to the salt and feeling as if the dish could stand just a pinch more. (The black tea ice cream was lovely, though.) Yet, I have hope for reform!, since the food is potentially delicious. If they'd remove like half the salt.
 
The cocktail we had, from a "program" much lauded in reviews, was also disappointing in that the McKinleys we both had were veeeeeeeeerrrrrrrrrrry sweet. 

On the upside, our waiter was great. We were the last in his section, but we didn't feel rushed, we never waited for something we wanted, and he was helpful.
author: Aimee F.

description:
Was super busy on a Wednesday around 7:45pm. We talked with the hostess saying that a table would be about 45 minutes, but they gave us the option of dining at the bar or at the communal table. Decided to get a drink and put our name on the bar's dining list. The bartender was really nice and said that there was a party of two before my friend and I, and he got us started on drinks. About 15 minutes later, he came over and said that he had to unseat us because someone had to take the seat I was sitting on to dine. He felt really bad, so he comp'd our drinks (@ $12 each, I didn't mind that one bit). He then sent us back to the hostess and within 10 minutes she got us a seat. Granted, it was at the communal table, but I didn't care at this point. At least they were super nice and accommodating about it. 

Now the review:

Bread: Eh, could have done without it, but I was starving.

Fries: Eh, standard. Not much to say about it. It came with parsley and horseradish aioli which made my face scrunch up. Weird combo, but I guess there's people who like it...

Roasted Halibut: Fish was cooked perfectly, but a little too salty for my taste.

Friend ordered the Pork Chop: Really good from my taste of it.

For drinks we both got the Greenpoint (Bulleit Rye, Yellow Chartreuse, vermouth & bitters). I love this drink; I've been here once before for drinks and I ordered this one then, with dinner this last time, and probably if I ever make it back out here.

Overall, the food was good, but I'm giving 4 stars mainly because of the service.
author: Denise Z.

description: THE BEST. I loved loved loved the tangy beef tartare with salty venison carpaccio and crispy-gooey fried marrow, and the tender lamb tongue with salty whole grain mustard sauce and oozy poached egg, and the addictive truffles caviar fries with a pleasant mix of crispies and soggies... what a f-ing great meal. OH, and they sell carafes of wine. Forever enamored.
author: Kate M.

description:
I had dinner in there a few weeks ago with my family and it was fantastic. I find the food always consistently good here. From appetizers to the entrees. I also find that the staff is very good at suggesting what's good based on your tastes. They also have a great wine list. 

I think it's a neighborhood gem!
author: Tracy P.

description:
This place has slowly deteriorated since it opened.  This place used to have the best lobster bisque.  Sadly disappointed it went from bowl to cup to a crappy shooter using a different recipe.  

Sadly, I don't really have much a desire to return.
author: Jerry W.

description:
Went to Park Tavern last night to celebrate a new job offer for me and a legal name change for my recently wed friend! We arrived early, 5:30, and easily scored a seat at the bar. I've shown up later a few times and have been forced to give up on getting in at all. Reservations are a must if you aren't okay with squeezing in at the bar or communal table. 

We had a bottle of champagne to celebrate, good rec from the bartender on one of the more reasonably priced bottles (Laurent Perrier). We each had one deviled egg, wow. The little crunch of bacon on top was amazing. We then shared the lemon chips with burrata. Flavor. Explosion. The lemon was sliced extremely thin and then fried to a crisp, and served with a very light burrata. It went so well with the champagne, I could have eaten just those all night. 

We then shared the gnocchi, which was loaded with wild mushrooms and just the right amount of truffle. Finally, just to be extra gluttenous, we shared the pork chop. This was so delicious, but after all the other food the meat combined with the parmesan risotto was a bit rich for me. I brought it home to feed my boyfriend and he more than appreciated it. 

This place is a true gem amid the touristy Italian spots that dominate North Beach. I will definitely be back for more indulgence soon. I've got my eye on the cocktail list!
author: Rosie C.

description:
An exceptional addition to the San Francisco dining scene.

Ambiance: lively, classic yet updated look, everyone looked like they were having a great time

Food: every dish succeeded and exceeded expectations, particularly the deviled eggs, burger and steak

Drink: attentive and skilled bartenders - try the 'Washington Square' cocktail. Perfectly sized and well chosen wine list as well.

Service: everyone was very friendly yet extremely professional and knowledgeable. We were in a group of 8 and they handled our large group with exacting skill and perfect pacing.

Bottom Line: An instant classic. Suitable for a date, fun business dinner or a group celebration.

Can't wait for weekend brunch to start!
author: Don D.

description:
Tons of great reviews here already, so I'll just put in my succinct two cents.  
Eating at the bar is a great experience - the bartenders are top notch. 

The food is really, really delicious.  I order the pork chop medium rare, and it's divine.  The 'Demons on horseback' consist of perfectly grilled shrimp wrapped in lardo - fantastic, and amazing flavors in the sauce as well.  The creamed seasonal greens are pure comfort.  [And for those of you who ordered the pork belly bites and complained about the pork fat -- really?!!!!  :P ]

Really, really happy Park Tavern opened, as I am a local and have been missing the yumminess and classiness of Moose's.
author: Kimberly Q.

description:
The food: ordered a variety of items off the menu; all very very tasty. All around a solid meal of "traditional american" items. One of the best pork chops and deviled eggs I've had. Also, really good cocktails. 

The ambiance: awesome location right on the Washington Square. Got lucky with the parking, but could see it being a challenge; however, it is in the heart of North Beach so that is to be accepted. Inside, the restaurant had a modern decor and it is well designed. However, our siting was in the front half and the tables were somewhat small for the plates / appetizers to fit at the same time.

Service: great service, although it got less attentive as the night progressed and the space filled up.
author: Oleg A.

description:
Pretty good apps.  Brussel sprout chips with sea salt and zest were great. Too much truffle on some items.
Pork cheeks were very good.
Scallops cooked perfectly.
author: Tom K.

description: Update: I have been back to Park Tavern multiple times since that first time, and boy do they have all of the kinks worked out. Their brunch is now one of my favorites in the city, and that's really saying something. Dinner is excellent too. I was particularly impressed at one brunch, when there were 10 of us there for my friend's birthday...the restaurant was running late for some reason, and we ended up getting seated about 45 minutes later than our reservation. Not only did they apologize profusely, but sent over 1 of each pastry and 1 of each toast for the table to make up for it!
author: Melissa H.

description:
We chose Park Tavern as a special night out for my sweet baboo's birthday on a Monday evening. And special it was! The service and food were outstanding. We were seated at a sweet little corner booth, near the kitchen. Fun to watch the food coming out of the kitchen. 
We ordered the delicious Butter Lettuce Wedge, tantalizing Brussels Sprouts chips, exquisite Poulet Noir, and drool-inducing Marlowe Burger. 

At the end of the meal, the server brought 2 small scoops of ice cream with a birthday candle. Classy. 

A very special place. 
.
author: Bonnie B.

description: Great ambiance and really well prepared food here. It's a nice and lively which makes it great for brunch either at a table or at the bar. I got the chorizo and eggs and it was fantastic. Love how it was one big scramble with everything mixed in! Eat here and walk it off on Coit Tower.
author: Carl N.

description:
My Review of Park Tavern, in Chat:

Me: I had 2 cocktails, a fernet float and a "Marlowe" burger
Friend: Oh I see
Friend: Marlowe burgers are good doe
Me: it was ok
Me: the meat was really good
Friend: You gotta order it med rare
Me: but i was mad at the meat vs bun ratio
Me: i always do!
Friend: Oh yeah
Friend: good point
Me: you think im a dope!
author: Faffy L.

description:
This place is awesome, the food is amazing as well as the staff & service, it's a must go!!! It is definitely my favorite brunch place in the city.

I highly recommend: Banana coconut fritters, the crispy polenta cakes, dungeness crab (toast) and cast iron baked farm eggs. 

Coffee lovers attention, they serve Blue bottle coffee!
author: Carol S.

description:
Great to meet with a small group of friends for dinner and drinks.  This place gets crowded, but the food and ambience are well worth it.  I definitely recommend the deviled eggs, as other yelp reviews have stated.  Since the menu changes a bit, it's hard to focus on select entrees.  I've had a couple of items and each were great.

Get there early to eat at the bar or communal areas next to it.  Otherwise, make a reservation.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Jeff P.

description:
My first time here was great!

We had reserved a table for two at around 7:30pm on a Wednesday night, however it didn't seem like we needed one because there were a few tables still open.

The restaurant is fairly loud due to the popularity of the bar, and it happened that we caught the tail end of happy hour.

Decor and set up were great!  It has a very rustic feel, and the best seat in the house (in my opinion) is the two counter seats near the open kitchen where you can enjoy the chefs hard at work!

Now onto the food!

Since me and my girlfriend are lightweight foodies, we generally like to sample a variety of things on the menu.

We started off with the deviled eggs.  We ordered one each because we had a lot of food coming, but it was so good we ordered another round!  I could have easily eaten 20 of these.  It is definitely the best I've had in a while.

We also ordered the Uni, brussel sprout chips, demons on horseback, and the lobster bisque.

The uni was very fresh, and up there with some of the best Japanese restaurants.  The bussel sprout chips were alright, and it's something that I'd probably never order again.  However, the demons on horseback was delicious!!!  It's basically 4 huge pieces of prawns wrapped in bacon, and their oh so delicious sauce.  

The lobster bisque was a something we added in the middle of our appetizers because there was a party of 15 people behind us, and they each ordered it.  So we thought why not order one too to share?  And it turns out that party did us justice.  The bisque was savory, sweet, and rich.  A little too rich when you kept eating it.  If you order this, make sure to share because I think it definitely tampered with the rest of my meal.  Although it was delicious, the flavor kinda coated my palette and made everything thereafter too salty.

For our entrees we ordered the Cod, and the grilled pork chop.

The Cod was very average, and it didn't really possess any flavor to me.  Again, this could be due to the bisque.  My grilled pork chop was definitely too damn salty due to the bisque.  I only managed to eat a quarter of it because I started to get full, and the saltiness was a turn off.  However, I did bring it home and ate it the next day, in which it definitely held up very well.  It also tasted much better the next day, but I'm sure it tasted great the first time they made it!


So ultimately, the bisque is really good.  Just don't eat too much of it because it's heavy, or pair it with a burger.  Deviled eggs, and demons on horsebacks are both winners!


Definitely coming back!
author: J V.

description:
A group of friends and I had dinner at Park Tavern this past weekend and I was pleasantly surprised.  If you watched that chick flick with Reese Witherspoon and Mark Ruffalo featured in SF, part of it was filmed here.  I love the open air ambiance outside and tall ceilings and abundant amount of space between tables which made our dining experience even better.

Food:
Pork Belly Bites (delicious!)
Burrata Cheese with lemon and basil (Very innovative and something I never had and would definitely order again)
Uni on butter Lettuce (Interesting combination, I've never had uni on lettuce, but they give you a generous portion of uni)
Fries with Garlic Aioli
Seared Scallops 
Chocolate Creme Brulee (the biscotti was burnt, would probably opt for the Apple/Fig Crisp)

I would definitely come back again to try their other dishes as well.  The service at Park Tavern was stellar and they also had a great cocktail menu that is worth checking out.
author: Carli F.

description:
Yes please. Brussels Sprout Chips? Um, amazing and demolished in a heartbeat. Lemon & basil leaf, burrata also totally amazing. Seared scallops, roasted cauliflower, braised baby fennel & grapefruit, best dish I've had in a long time. 
The atmosphere is also adorable and we loved our little outdoor table on their front patio, which helped me feel like I was dining in Europe again. Their cocktails are delectable and their October Birthday cake was really yummy. We also very much enjoyed people watching, as there were lots of Sugar Daddy's with their super young girlfriends. Haha awesome.
author: Sonya D.

description: I have always had a great time, solid service and tasty food at Park Tavern. I went recently for brunch an really enjoyed our selections and lively vibe. Because it's a bigger spot, it's relatively easy to get a rezo or walk-in, which has made it my go-to spot for entertaining parents and out of town guests.
author: Gretchen S.

description:
Love, love, love!  I have never been so full in my life!  I think we ordered one of everything and I ate it all!  Deviled eggs, beef jerky, brussel sprout chips, steak crudo, Demons on horseback, Chicken entree...a minute on my lips, a lifetime on my hips.  It was worth it!  
Until next time Park Tavern!  Anna Weinberg and her team nailed it!
author: Kattya B.

description: I adore this restaurant and staff! The food is spot on. Lemon chips and burrata was a perfect nosh at the bar while we waited for our table,(we arrived early). Service by Carlos, Armando and the GM Peter was friendly and attentive. I might have to log some extra hours at the gym but totally worth it.
author: Lesli B.

description:
The Setting:  Work dinner with team Wednesday evening, had a reservation for 5, seated after 10 minutes.

First half of meal - 4 stars
Second half of meal - 3 stars

The GOOD:
1.  Brussel Sprout Chips - perfeclty flavored, crispy, melted in my mouth.  A group hit.
2.  Twin Peaks (Cocktail) - loved it, had a second.  Great for Bourbon drinkers.
3.  Lobster Bisque - one person thought it was too rich, two of us loved it!  Huge chunks of lobster meat and great bisque taste.
4.  Twice Baked potato - wow.  Standing "O" from the table, definitely get this if you only get one side dish.

The OK:
1.  Aarowfarms figs - one person loved it, three of us thought it was only ok.  The figs themselves were great, but the burrata and proscuitto were sub-par.
2.  Marlowe Burger - not the best bun, meat was decent.  Try Wayfare Tavern or NOPA for a better burger.
3.  Salmon - This was a safe option, pretty good fish.  Nothing stood out about it.

The BAD:
1.  Golden Gate (cocktail) - too sweet.  3 of us tasted it, none of us liked it, sent back.


The Bottom Line:  A meal that had great atmosphere and started great but had sub-par entrees.  My guess is that, had we stuck to appetizers, sides, and small plates, my rating would be much higher, possibly five stars...
author: Kevin S.

description: This place is not up to the hype at all. The food is a bit heavy for me and pretty average. There are just too many fried items on the menu, and the dishes overall just read very heavy. It's sort of like the place isn't sure if it's a pub or a fine dining establishment.  I had a pork chop that was pretty good, but it was sitting on a very dense pile of sausage hash. I asked to sub that out for something like a vegetable, and they said no. Really? Are you kidding me? I can't trade a side of hash for a different side that is on the menu? Are all the dishes pre-made? That cost them a star. For me, if i want to switch a side out, for that price, you do it.   Also, service was pretty damn slow.
author: Josh B.

description:
Went here for my birthday din this past October.......awwwwwwwwwwesome! Deviled eggs were amazingness, brussel chips were chippy, and my pork chop was huge! I 
had leftovers because the portions are great- go there hungry!

Bar is always packed- so if you are looking for a drink and a seat....better get there early.
author: Ricquel N.

description:
Had a wonderful meal here with friends. Service was first-rate, and the food was mmm mmm tasty. It'd been awhile since I was really faced with too many choices of things I wanted to try at a restaurant. Seems like they have a great balance of classic dishes that stay on the menu awhile, and some great seasonal additions. 

The smoked burrata and steak tartare dishes were nothing short of amazing, although be prepared for some kick-ass zestiness on the tartare (which I loved). The NY Strip (my favorite cut of steak) was also perfectly seasoned and delish. I opted for the twice-baked potatoes over the fries and couldn't get enough of them--carbtastically amazing.

Can't wait to go back!
author: Aaron L.

description: Food was good, a bit overpriced however our waiter was absolutely terrible. Was forced to leave a low tip. Oh!... and i saw a mouse under our table outside. Won't be back.
author: Chapa J.

description:
Thank you Food Overlords for Jennifer Puccini, executive Chef of PT. This place continues to amaze and impress me with their overture of impeccable food and reasonable prices. Big ups for being nominated for a James Beard award for best new joint as well. 

Got here for our 10PM reservations on a saturday night, and let me tell you...it was popping...at 10PM. We are not talking kinda sorta busy, we are talking reservations only busy still at the late hour. 

This place still has all the super whites that I saw last time i was here..in fact, I think some of them haven't even left since last time. So many striped Brooks Bros shirts and slacks and mink coats....where is the goddamn recession? Not here folks. 

Fried Brussell sprout chips were as good as ever, the deviled eggs fantastic, and the pork chop as tender as JLO's ass. Wife had the mussels and whatever they put into that broth at the bottom of the bowl is so addicting, I want to swim in a pool of it. 

I think I saw the owner Anna Weinberg somewhere shaking hands and thanking patrons left and right. Big ups to this place, and hopefully the super whites will let us lowly plebians get a table now and then.
author: Jerry C.

description: Love the atmosphere, the waiters and waitresses are amazing and friendly, lovw how they incorporate what you need. Besides that, I love the lamb tongue especially as brunch, it is so over the top, one thing that I might use less is the mustard seed asides from that, the green and everything is braised wonderfully, the brussel sprout chips is a go, I also love Paloma which is the cocktail.
author: Bryan T.

description: I was skeptical because the menu seemed a bit boring, but Park Tavern wowed me in the execution, taste, and presentation.  We ordered most of the apps (deviled eggs and PT fries are standouts), everyone's entrees were excellent (although my personal fave was the stuffing side), of course we ordered everything on the dessert menu.  Cause that's how we do it.
author: Cin S.

description:
I went there on Sunday and the service was HORRIBLE. It took a while to get our orders in and when they were it took FOREVER.  The couple eating next to our group had a full meal and left.

It took so long that our server came back and asked if we wanted a dessert menu.  We were appalled.  We told her we didn't get our food yet and of course our food was served to us instantly so it was obviously just sitting in the kitchen.  My skillet wasn't hot, the burgers were ok, everything was just horrible. One of our orders were incorrect as well and they cooked up a new burger and it was out in 5 minutes which shows that their cooks don't take THAT long.  The food was ok and nothing spectacular.  If it was then maybe it would've been worth the wait.

We had two servers "help" us and afterward they never came back and I think a supervisor assisted us and she wasn't very apologetic about what happened and she seemed annoyed that each person paid with separate cards/cash even though we asked for separate checks.  

 We had already lost our appetites so I don't even know if the food was good or not but I will not be returning to find out.

PS My friend ordered an Americano which took a bit to be served but it was $6.00! WHAT/

Never again.
author: Melissa F.

description:
My man and I went to Park Tavern to have a special night together. We picked this place (more like I) because it was talked about I think in San Francisco Magazine. The restaurant is REALLY BIG, it looks small from the outside! We made a reservation and were seated right away (it is best to make a reservation for this place!). Our waiter was nice but I think he could have been a little bit more friendly, I had noticed more friendlier staff waiting other tables. 

The food was very good. We ordered the Saikou salmon, baby beets, creme fraiche & dill and the Brussels sprout chips the share, both amazing! Then I had the Grilled pork chop , sauteed baby turnips, carmelized apple, Nueske's bacon & mustard jus and my man had the Hawaiian tombo tuna, crispy sunchokes, white anchovies, baby artichokes & salsa rustica, he liked it, but liked my pork a little bit better ;) For dessert we had the  apple & red wine-caramel crisp, is was SO GOOD!

I don't remember what cocktails we ordered but I do remember what I had was VERY GOOD!

For sure this is a place to bee seen but what I also liked about it there were all walks of life as well, it was not all posh people, their were families and older couples. After your done with dinner I highly suggest you take a walk (thats if your wearing okay walking shoes) to Coit Tower to walk off your dinner, on a clear night the view is so beautiful!
author: T C.

description: I picked this location because it's right across the park with out door seating for my dog. I use to live in north beach and didn't get a chance to try out this restaurant. The location seems great, the food is ok. We got one of the fish dishes and it was super salty that day. I think the portions could be a bit bigger and less saltier. I don't think I would come again.
author: V N.

description: Went to the one in Richmond some time ago, and I loved it. Now in SF, wanted to try the one here. In general, the food is really good (especially the sprout chips), the location, in the center of North Beach, is a big plus. The service is alright, effective but somehow impersonal. The wine list, in my opinion, definitely overpriced, like in too many other restaurants in San Francisco. Not disappointed, though, a good experience.
author: Serge B.

description:
To begin with  food at PT is OK: some dishes can be a total blah, smoked bacon flavor gets boring after a while but overall food is decent. This review, however, is about service, attitude and integrity of those who served us. We intentionally came in about 45 minutes before our reservations and set in the bar area relaxing, waiting for our table, having drinks. We ordered specifically Ketel One Vodka martini. When the martini arrived it was not Kettle One. We did not make a big deal about it but for the next round we insisted on Ketel One. Waitress assured us she will get that drink right and that she placed the order for Kettle One. She went to the bar, talked to the bartender, he took a bottle of Gray Goose made two drinks in a shaker and served us one of the two. WFT? We saw the whole thing and at this point returned the drink back. Did we get a cheerful apology from the bartender? No way! Instead we got a really watered down Ketel One martini with attitude. 
Our table was ready only 30 minutes after the time of reservations. When we got to the table our new waitress told us that to comp for the wait she liked to offer us free Brussels sprouts appetizer ($9). We then went to order two more appetizers and a whole chicken ($15+9+28 + 3 martinis +$20 wine). We never tip less than 20% and you would think we spent enough money so that there would not be a need to scheme us for $9 bucks?  But when the bill arrived the Brussels sprouts app was included. We pointed that out to the waitress and in ONE second she produced a copy of the correct bill. Wow! So this was actually planned? I had many dinners at PT but mainly in the bar area. Never had I experienced this shameless petty scheming and F+++U attitude. Bar scene is fun and sharing a dish in the bar area is OK, but a sit down dinner here again: I'd be worried.
author: K Z.

description: I love park tavern! One of the best in north beach! We love going for brunch and dinner.
author: Kelly D.

description: Pretty tasty food and cool vibe!  Truffle fries are amazing!  Close seconds are brussel sprout chips (who knew?!) and deviled eggs.   Staff is great.   An overall great experience!  We will be back!
author: Kimberley H.

description:
Great atmosphere for a nice weekend brunch! On a sunny day like today, the outdoor seating out front is perfect. 

I had the burger and we ordered pancakes for the table, all was delicious. The cocktails were also great, had the Paloma and the Bloody Mary =)
author: Sareena N.

description:
Delicious!  We really loved the appetizers.  You must try the:

Crab dip
Deviled eggs
Liver mousse
Brussels sprout chips

The Poulet Rouge was moist and delicious-- worth the wait.  The lobster bisque was probably my favorite item on the menu.  It was rich, creamy and you can actually taste the lobster.  And the Washington Square was great with just the right amount of alcohol so it's strong, yet tasty.

We loved the ambiance.  It was dark, but felt lively.  A perfect spot for a date or group dinner as they have a number of larger tables.

I cannot wait to go back!
author: K V.

description:
Sat at the bar for brunch on Saturday afternoon and the food was quite delicious. 

CON:  the bartender rushed us the entire time, must have wanted to end his shift or something. He said that the kicthen only had 5 minutes left for brunch and then stood there tapping his pen while we tried to peruse the menu. Five minutes after we placed our order the bartender came to inform me they had ran out of it so I had to pick something else.  Again, he stood there, breathing down my neck,  rudely impatient while I re-decided what to eat. 

PRO: ambiance and some of the best challah I've ever had
author: Jeannine R.

description: Love this place!  I have been there for a New Year's Pre Fixe dinner as well as dinner on regular nights and all of it is supperb.  Not only is the place nice aestehtically but the staff is top notch.  A must have are the deviled eggs and the bar steak as well as any of the salads they have.  I have also tried a pork chop they had on the menu and it was mouth watering good.  This place is perfect for a date, business dinner, casual dinner or special occassion dinner.  I cannot reommend it enough.
author: Kirsten M.

description: Great casual place. It has valet parking and the service was great! Try the Brussels sprouts.
author: Nan T.

description:
What a great addition to the neighborhood!

I was excited to try this place and was not disappointed.  

We arrived on time for our reservation on Friday night and were seated immediately.  Plus one!  I was starting to think the idea of being seated on time at a popular restaurant was a thing of the past.

The restaurant was nicely decorated for Christmas with white lights and a nice Christmas tree.  We were seated in the window area, a very pleasant section with views both outside to the park and into the restaurant. The tables were a little close together but with enough aisle space that it didn't feel crowded.  With a full house of large and small tables happy pre-holiday diners, the noise level was a bit high at first, but the overall atmosphere was so nice, we wouldn't let this keep us from returning.

Service was warm, efficient and knowledgeable.  The menu is varied and interesting. We enjoyed everything we ordered:

duck liver crostini
arugula salad with mushrooms - unusual and very tasty
pork chop with kale and butter beans
scallops with cauliflower puree and braised fennel
twice-baked potato  - so yummy with a lovely scallion flavor

There's a very nice selection of wines by the glass and the servings are very generous.

As a non-meat eater, I'd like to see a few more seafood and vegetable options on the menu.  Without even a vegetarian dinner option, a vegetarian would have a hard time ordering a meal here.

EDIT: I'm bumping my rating from 4 to 5 stars in response to the restaurant's decision to remove the "healthy SF" surcharge. This bugs me EVERY TIME I see it on a bill. It's as if the owners are saying, "I'll give my employees health care...but I really don't want to."

Owner Anna Weinberg said  "The way I saw it is that it's just become a cost of doing business, so you adjust your prices just like you do if your rent goes up."   EXACTLY.
author: Martha M.

description:
I said the same thing about Wayfare Tavern,

this place is just ok. Man oh man, what can you say about this place?

1.) it's trendy?
2.) the food is whatever (for the main courses, but the brussel sprout chips are to die for.).

Just nothing special about these places anymore, just trendy, i need something that excites me something that wows. This is not one of those places, it's just an ehhh, or wah wah. lol but yeah.

actually i wanted to update this. it's actually two stars, because my food came out cold not once but twice. BOO on that...
author: Benjamin L.

description:
Tossup between four and five stars but they're new and oversalt the crap out of their food so I'll give them four.

Gorgoues location.  Inside is epic and outside is perfect if you have a dog or kid or noisy monster.

It's only been open a few weeks and I've had half the menu.  Let me tell you, it's all delicious.  Perhaps the best so far is the pork chop (sorry, Jewish ancestors).  It's a double thick, moist, smoky tender lump of deliciousness.  Seriously, one of the best pork chops in my life.

Other random stuff is inventive, inspired,and tasty, without breaking the basic idea that it's all comfort food.  The heirloom baby carrot salad, the most giiry thing on the menu, was pickled and salted and delicious.  On the other side of the coin, the caviar style fried oysters were like five po' boys without the roll, days later I'm still fantasizing over that.

The service?  It's what I call "your hand been shook" service.  Back when Bill Clinton was President people met him and they all said, when Bill Clinton shakes your hand, your hand has been shook.  That's what I think about Park Tavern.  When you eat there and you get service, youv'e been served.  These people are professional career waiters, with that perfect combination of skills, weird semi-snarky cockiness and teasing, loving concern over you and your food, and just plain interesting personalities that makes for an experience you come home and to to sleep with.   I can't say enough good things, it's like an hour and a half experience with a personal food guy and you leave smiling all the way home.

The main reason for four stars instead of five is they need a little more work to polish it up, and way too much salt and butter.  Nevertheless this has the potential to join the pantheon of great SF restaurants.  I'll definitely return for the second half of the menu.
author: Gil S.

description:
Large restaurant for SF. The cocktails were okay, the deviled eggs were the best thing we had. Our charcuterie board (our waiter's favorite thing on the menu) was mediocre at best. The bone marrow, which I didn't know could be anything be succulent and delicious food of the gods, was undercooked and just not cooked right somehow. The foie gras was lacking in the rich buttery flavor it should have and had a texture more like the gelatinous bone marrow fat.

The only other thing I actually enjoyed were the Shrimp with avocado and lardo (the name was something horseman, I dunno) but that's just because I fucking love shrimp. The avocado was so unripe it was literally crunchy. I don't know how they cut the thing into slices.

Obviously, I would be judging the place much less harsh if my bill was under $175 for two people, but it wasn't. I would consider myself ripped off for mediocre food I could have easily made better.
author: Micah S.

description: What can I say, I was seriously impressed. The ambience, the vibe, the people. It was really not typical of San Francisco. I loved that everyone was dressed to impressed. We had the truffle fries, chicken, deviled eggs and Brussel sprout chips. Everything was amazing with an honorable mention to the truffle fries and deviled eggs. The ladies I was dining with were truffle fanatics and they could not stop raving about the fries...they even wanted to order a 2nd round. I highly recommend this restaurant. We will definitely be coming back!!!!!
author: Ben K.

description:
I have such mixed feelings about this place...

I live in the neighborhood, so I badly want to love it, but it's just too inconsistent. 
I've had a decent dinner, a great dinner, a pretty terrible brunch, great snacks + drinks, and awful service. 

Today in particular was a low point: I brought my parents here for a late lunch & cocktails. I requested a table outside and was told it would be about a 30 - 45 minute wait. Ok, cool. So we strolled around the park and Goorin Brothers as we waited for our table. Upon our return, we were told our table indoors was being set up. I reminded the hostess that I had requested an outdoor table. She shrugged her shoulders and told us they didn't have one. If we wanted an outdoor table, we could be put on the list and it would be about 30-45 minutes. I, then, reminded her that I had been on that list and waited 45 minutes. Our hostess than flatly said that there weren't any notes on our reservation and that there must have been a communication error. I told her that if there had been a communication issue, it would have been between us, since it was she I had spoken to 45 minutes prior. She again shrugged. Ridiculous! In the end, they didn't really seem to care that they'd made a mistake nor did they try in any way to make it right. So, we decided not to, again, wait 45 minutes for the outdoor table... instead we walked down the street and into Original Joe's.

I also happen to work by their new sister restaurant The Cavalier, which I actually like much better. Better interior (funnily enough - it used to be Million Dollar Thai), better cocktails, and better service.

I agree with most of the reviews; 
Come here for the smoked deviled eggs, marlowe burger, cocktails, the pt fries.

Better dinner spots in the neighborhood: Capo's, The Square, Don Pisto's or Ferry Plaza Seafood.
author: e v.

description:
On a whim, Danielle M. and I decided to stop by Park Tavern for a few drinks which quickly turned into dinner (and me meeting her new BF!). No tables were available but we snagged 3 spots in the bar area. I think we were really lucky. 
For drinks, I had a washington square which was a bit sweet for me before switching to their mclaren. They have decent wine selections as well.

Waldorf salad was not as filling as I hoped. They really skimped on the toppings. 
Brussel sprout chips are a must try as everyone else has already said. 
I also tried demons on horseback, steak crudo and veggie plate. 

In general serving sizes were small. Next time I'm ordering a burger.
author: Sara P.

description:
The TL;DR Version: AssHat Bartender. Mediocre Fare. The End.

The Full Story (It's a long one):

Early arrival calls for a trip to the bar, where we sit and peruse the house specialties. I inquire with the bartender: "Tell me about this Crème de Violette in the [cocktail_name]" to which I receive a response in the tone of someone speaking to a toddler: "It's a lavender liquor." Really? Wow. Thanks for that enlightening description.

We review the menu some more but opt for traditional drinks. My fiancée opts for her favorite, which she likes to compare across the various venues of the city, and asks: "Do you do a brandy Sidecar?"...and the reply: "Of course, this is San Francisco. Here you can get all sorts of complicated drinks."

What? Are you kidding me? You fucking *AssHat

Allow me instruct you on a few things:

1) I was inquiring about the flavor of the lavender and maybe how it impacts the overall cocktail...as a **mixologist you might want to look into it. It's on YOUR menu and you are serving it to people.

2) The Sidecar cocktail is served in a variety of forms...often with either Brandy or Cognac. Since yours is the ***second worst example I've had the displeasure to experience, you might want to take the time to visit other venues such as Zero Zero, AQ, Lark Creek Steakhouse, Top of the Mark, et. al. where there are bartenders with talent. You have none. Your lemon juice with a twist might pass on a child's roadside lemonade stand, but that's really about it.

3) For some reason you pegged us as tourists. I am personally offended to think that you go about mis-representing our fair city so rudely. 

For the management: It was the big guy...the one who likes to wear watches about the size of his head.

Moments after receiving our fresh squeezed juiceboxes, we are informed our table is ready. 

This bit is extra fun. So it appears that someone is very anxious to pack in as many people as humanly possible into this space. Because that is what top-dollar restaurant goers are looking for, right? And our table? Shoved into the corner where the frame for the restaurant's front sliding doors intrudes fully into the right side of where I'm sitting on the booth. For extra fun I have to sqeeze ever so carefully between the table next to us and ours, so as to not knock over anything on their table (I'm sure they *loved* my ass sliding by over their entrées) and then yoga myself into position...it was...odd. I then re-realized that I was not indeed an amputee, and still have a right arm I typically use to lift my hand so I can eat. Not here. Apparently I'm only permitted to eat left-handed. In order to use my right hand I'd have to sit in the lap of the gentleman at the next table. Awesome.

I brought this to the attention of our server, and indicated that it really wasn't acceptable and that we'd like a different table. She went and spoke to the hostess...and a few minutes later we were moved to a table by the kitchen. Much better. Nice even.

After introductions to our new server, we made our selections and started receiving our food...which is pretty much the punchline: SAUCY.

Yep. Saucy. That is how I would describe the fare. Shrimp with remoulade? (Demons on Horseback) There is more remoulade than shrimp, and they are buried in it. Blech. Something akin to what one would expect at Outback Steakhouse. My fiancée ordered the Herb Crusted Petrale Sole. It should be named "LAKE OF VELOUTE" with fish in it. I'd never seen a veloute fish soup before. She didn't eat it. As for my main dish? I've forgotten what I had. Enough said.

To the credit of the staff and manager, they did inquire about our experience...and I was earnest in my response. The manager offered to give us a gift certificate for a future visit...to which I declined. Yes, our experience was so poor I would not come back and eat here for free. My time and palate deserve better.

To really hammer the point home, we left here and grabbed a quick Uber to Hillstone for dessert and cocktails to try and wash away the crap experience. 

As a final shocking side note: Upon hearing some of the highlights of our evening, do you know what Hillstone did? They comped us a round of drinks. You heard that right. HILLSTONE comped us to make up for PARK TAVERN ruining our evening. 

Wow.

In S.F. we have a huge selection of amazing fare. The differentiators are the overall experience. Sorry Park Tavern, but you are far below par. I think you know where we'll be recommending friends and visitors go.

* I should note that everyone else was quite friendly, in a North Beach sortof way. (This will only make sense to locals)

** I am using the term mixologist ironically here, in case you (the muscle-brained barback-posing-as-a-bartender) happen to be reading this. Clearly your communication skills are lacking and I want to be clear.

*** The worst sidecar I've had came with a salted rim by accident. Yes, your drink made it over this spectacular hurdle.
author: Erich N.

description: This review is for brunch.  I am not a huge traditional breakfast fan, so the brunch menu at Park Tavern appeals to me a lot.  The execution of the creative dishes was excellent.  I ordered the smoked fish cake.  It was so good, I could have eaten another plate.  My table also ordered the polenta cakes, which came with outrageously good mushrooms.  There was also some hash, which was good, but not as good as the other two dishes.  The bloody Mary comes with bacon.  Enough said.  I cannot wait to go back.
author: Amber B.

description:
Sometimes I wish we could rate on the half star because I would've gone 2.5. I will round up to 3 solely because the management was up to par on customer relation skills and because my friend assured me that she had never had such a mediocre experience there before.

Park Tavern is not as outrageously expensive as some other establishments (for the most part), but I do wish that San Franciscans would not tolerate such high prices with low expectations of quality. It is to our collective detriment to get mediocre food at over-priced levels.

A friend and I came for brunch on a Sunday and loved the bright atmosphere. We started off with the smoked deviled eggs since it was on the 7x7 Magazine top 100 list. 7x7 does themselves a discredit here along with the restaurant. For $2.50 (not $2 as reported in other posts), you get HALF a small egg (smaller than the large size you get at the grocery store). Ours were not smokey nor did it have a stand-out flavor that warrants a place on any best-of list, let alone a price of $2.50. And to be clear, it was $2.50 EACH half. My friend found the bacon to be the standout flavor, but for my piece, I didn't get much flavor at all. Please. Even if the expected flavors came through nicely, it is still hard to imagine a half an egg for $2.50. They would do better to leave the smoking process out if that is what raises the price because 1) we can't taste it anyway and 2) there has to be a balance of result vs. price somewhere. Come on San Francisco and 7x7. We can expect better than this.

Next, we had the avocado toast. I would normally not order this at a restaurant because it's so easy to prepare at high quality at home, but my friend had a hankering for it so we ordered it. It did not arrive on one of San Francisco's many famous breads, but on a slice of whole wheat toast that looked amazingly like the loaf I had in my fridge at home. My friend got the side that had an irregularly large hole in it. To look at, it looked nice with beautifully and thinly sliced avocado. On top of that was an oil flavored with what our server said was an African spice. That spice wasn't habanero hot, but it left me with enough tingly sensation on my lips to last into my main course. However, there was too much oil that was unnecessary. Plus, it all covered up the flavor of the avocado. The bread had no flavor at all. For a whopping $10, it was definitely not worth it. Perhaps if it were on a better bread with more balanced flavor...

I had the shrimp and grits ($16). The grits were cooked very nicely and had a nice flavor and creamy texture. It was great to see that they use one of the country's top purveyors of grits! Half of the shrimp were too salty. Luckily, you're meant to eat them together so the aggregate flavor was only a little too salty.

My friend had the crispy polenta cakes ($18), which at first, seemed just right, but ended up giving the feeling of overly-fried by the end. Luckily, one poached egg was just right. The other egg, slightly on the soft-boiled side.

On the whole, perhaps it was the particular line in the kitchen that day that affected the dishes. Either someone wasn't tasting the food or whoever was checking the food had deadened taste buds. The food needed balance of flavors. We got none or too much.

The wait staff confused us. We were seated by one waiter, another took our order, and the food was brought out (and our questions were answered) by the one who seated us. Perhaps they were confused, too, because it took us about an hour to get our food while another table nearby completely turned over while we waited. Also, no one came to check on us or tell us why there was a delay except for the manager on duty who was their saving grace. He took our feedback about the food in stride and with what seemed like sincere appreciation. He also offered us a small token of a make-good to make up for an experience that fell flat and with wishes that we would return to give them another chance. I think I will. Customer service like that (because he really seemed to care about the feedback) when you don't get what you think you're paying for is worth a lot.
author: Maria Y.

description:
I've been to Park Tavern three times now and I'm so pleased that it continues to impress. The atmosphere is always lively, but not too loud that you can't enjoy the group (or person) you're with.  Also the wait staff is immaculate and always caters to your every need. 

The food though, that's the biggest wow.  Most everything I've ate has always been divine, and I think that this spot has the most high quality food in North Beach.  

Details....
Deviled Egg = MUST.  Really unique flavors, and the little crunch of bacon on top is perfection.
Brussel Sprout Chips - delightfully crunchy (brussel sprouts are so "in" these days - ha)
Lemon Chips Burrata - I love the flavor of burrata, so I didn't necessarily enjoy the burrata ON the lemon chips, but thought it was nice to eat on the side. 
PT Waldorf Salad - really fresh, tangy with a hint of sweetness (although my date said it was a little sweet)
Carmelized Onion Mushroom Soup - this was perhaps my least favorite... just wasn't on the top of my list.
Marlowe Burger (ordered medium)  - JUICY and delightful medley of flavors.  The horseradish aioli is such a great addition. I almost had to ask for a 2nd serving of aioli so I could dunk everything in it. It's not particularly large, but still one of my fav burgers. 

Overall I LOVE park tavern.  From ambience, service and most importantly the food, this is the type of place I can count on.
author: Renae K.

description:
Great vibe, great location, great food. 

The new team have done an amazing job in getting this up and running without a hitch. I have no doubt that this will be favorite for those in the neighorhood, but also somewhere to travel to.

Can't wait to return.
author: Richi E.

description: Went here for brunch with friends -- love the attention to detail, the decor, and the service. It's "fancy" without being too formal, and the menu is great. The challah is delicious (just don't think about how guilty you feel for eating it:) and I also got the cod cake which was really good! Overall great experience! Also loved that their water jugs don't spill all over the place when they refill your cup.
author: Betty W.

description:
Park Tavern is one of the best restaurants to open in Northbeach in a very long time. Anna Weinberg's exquisite taste in selecting a menu is unrivaled. I've been there several times since she's opened and can't wait to go back again and again.

The food is incredible and the service is fabulous. Anna makes a personal effort to reach out to all her guests while you're dining, whether she knows you or not. The elegance and class of this restaurant drives in a wide variety of guests from the average foodie to the San Francisco elite. 

Reservations are definitely helpful, but not a must - Because dining at the bar area is just as fun.

Make sure you at least go once a month because the "Birthday Cake" of the month (based on Anna's friends and family) is delicious!

Appetizers to try: Deviled eggs and  fried green tomatoes!

Delish!
author: Chelsea M.

description:
Lotsa reviewers telling you the highlights...just adding a couple of helpful hints if you're going.  
Super friendly, superfast parking valet right out front is a must have in North Beach if you've got $12.
At first was taken to a table near the kitchen.  Place is noisy enough already so asked for different table.  Absolutely no problem.
Halibut was great.
Asked for a wine recommendation and the waiter brought four glasses with tastes.  That's service worth 20%
author: Tyler J.

description:
First Visit for dinner:  Steak... Not so much.  Scallops... Not so much.  Pork belly appetizer... Bad!  

One year later...Second Visit for brunch:  Duck hash... Rad.  Polenta Benedict... Wow.  Bloody Mary... Needs more booze, but spicy.
author: David L.

description:
This place has a vibe that reminds me a lot of uptown Manhattan - at least the ambiance.  I have been here for drinks a few times, dinner and brunch.  All of which were excellent.  Great for large or small parties.

Usually my bf and I share dishes, but these dishes are on the smaller side, so you can order your own.  I had the smoked salmon Benedict for brunch and it was outstanding!  

The menu is unique, but very good.  AND you can make brunch reso's which is perfect as I hate waiting.
author: Sarah Louise H.

description: Food was decent but the service was slow. Highly recommend the short ribs, they were delicious.
author: Joanne G.

description:
Had a wonderful dinner here the other night with my Mom, Grandma, Sister and Aunt. 
The cocktail menu was divine, our service was spectacular and I am still dreaming about those brussels sprout chips! I will definitely be dining here in the future!
author: Lauren H.

description: What a classy brunch to bring in the new year! The food was positively sublime...we ordered the Salmon Benedict w/hollandaise & the Corned Beef Hash...along with some starter smokey deviled eggs! If the atmosphere wasn't quite so elegant we would have licked our plates!!
author: devorah h.

description:
This is one of my new favorite places to eat in San Francisco.  It's big and comfortable, and I really appreciate how the staff is friendly and helpful.

Thoughts on Park Tavern:

1) The "Marlowe Burger" is better here than at Marlowe.  Strange, but convenient for me.

2) The service is much better at Park Tavern than at Marlowe.  Marlowe servers are somewhat unfriendly and sloppy.

3) Must eats:

-Poulet Rouge.  A whole game hen served standing on a cast iron pan.  People will stare.  I actually loved the accompanying spinach the first time, but last night the spinach was too salty!

-Pork Chop:  This is no Nopa pork chop, but the flavor is great and the texture is perfect (if you're ok with pink pork).  The first time we tried to order this, they ran out!  So go on a weeknight.

-Birthday cake: I'm not kidding, their layered cake is perfect.  I got chocolate; next time I want to try coconut.  Not too sweet.  When I ordered this, the bf didn't want dessert....but he ended up eating half of it in 10 seconds!

-NY Steak Crudo: This is the best raw beef I've had.  I like it better than tartare (although I do love Marlowe's spicy tartare!)

-Wild arugula, mushroom conserva, porcini & charred onion vinaigrette.  Yes, this is a salad.  The charred onion vinaigrette is delicious.  It's smoky and pungent and I tried to lick my plate clean.  It's a large portion and shareable.  We split this in 2 and each had a "dinner salad" at some other restaurants. **If I came alone, I would actually order the Steak Crudo and the Arugula salad as my dinner.

-Deviled egg: I thought this would taste too bacony (as in the bacon flavor overpowering everything else), but the bacon, pickle, and egg together are pretty awesome.

-Brussels Sprout Chips: I love these at Marlowe--they're fried perfectly and are lemony.  When we ordered these last night, they came out over-fried and burned-tasting.  Also they were greasier at Park Tavern.  Could just be an off batch.  :(

4) Things I'd Skip:

-Fried Pork Belly Bites: not for me.  You have to really like pork fat to eat these.  They're mostly fat, almost no meat.  And they're coated.  I prefer flash fried and braised pork belly.

-Creamed seasonal greens: When we ordered this, the sauce had a truffled goat cheese in it.  I had not expected this.  I don't like things to be truffled (overpowering taste) and I don't like goat cheese.  I couldn't eat it.

-Twice baked potato.  I also didn't like this one.  It was just OK.  Cheese was a little sharp for me for such a rich dish.  I would have liked some acidity and some more salt on this.
author: Diana C.

description:
Finally made it to Park Tavern. Whew. 

I had brussel sprouts to start and the porkchop and halibut were the entrees we ordered. Brussel Sprout chips were salty, bitter and lemony and as bad as that may sound, it was incredibly yummy. Crunchy and salty, they were definitely hard to stop eating. The porkchop itself was okay but the potatoes that it was served with were a buttery and creamy goodness. The halibut was served with the skin (which was crispy) and I absolutely loved it..because I love crispy fish skin. Teehee. We also ordered the twice baked potatoes as a side dish and the amount of food was perfect for two. 

The cocktail list is filled with unique concoctions so definitely try one out! I don't drink much but the Dolores drink was my fave. Bartenders, servers and floor managers were so hospitable too. 

Coming back! :)
author: Joy A.

description:
I've only eaten brunch and had drinks here, so my review is based simply on that. The food is all delicious, but I think the menu could use a few more options on the savory side. I love my sweets, but about 70% of the menu is sweet brunch food. Adding a few more sandwiches and breakfast items that don't use sugar would be great. With that being said, the French toast was probably one of the best versions I've ever had.  If you like sweet items - you'll love the menu! 

Drinks are also great - my only complaint is that the menu pricing seems to be off. Two separate occasions I've ordered a bottle of wine to be told later the price on the menu is incorrect. No big deal, but maybe change your menu price to reflect that or honor the price the customer already saw. :)
author: Tara T.

description:
Pretty impressed with this new spot from the Marlowe team.

Nice space, well executed food.

We started with the deviled eggs, steak crudo, pork belly bites, and uni.
The only miss was the uni, which we all agreed could do without the butter lettuce.

The fried oysters were okay, not my favorite prep.

For our mains we tried the NY steak, poulet rouge, and the burger. The chicken was fantastic, served whole, upright on a stand. It was moist and perfectly seasoned. Burger was just as good as Marlowe's, and the steak was cooked fine but nothing special.

Cocktail list featured some interesting drinks as well as classics. 

Service was great, would definitely come back.
author: Derrick V.

description: Love this place. Have been many times, always tasty. This is another place I tend to get the same few things. The fries are simply amazing, I tell people about them all the time, served with truffle oil and a soft boiled egg with caviar. Really like their mussels, chicken... it's all very good. Solid cocktails as well. Plus, they have beef jerky on the menu; Beef Jerky! Can't go wrong.
author: Joshua G.

description:
Just spent an evening at the former Moose's space now called Park Tavern. What a fun night! I had many good friends who used to work at Moose's and they all would be very proud of what the new owners are achieving here at Park Tavern. The vibe is lively, the service is attentive and the menu is very tasty. 
Notable items we had were: 
brussels sprout chips
raw, local halibut, avocado & corn appetizer
deviled eggs*** so good!
pork belly bites (very heavy, but sinfully good)
Have yet to try an entree but hear the burgers are great. 

There's a very limited dessert menu- only 2 desserts and a couple of "boozy floats". Since my husband is a teetotaler, we skipped that course. All in all... a great new place in the heart on North Beach!
author: Terry M.

description:
I had one of the best brunch's here by far. I'm not much of a brunch person, but post the Park Tavern experience I think I have to reconsider whether I'm a brunch person or not. First of all their regular brewed coffee is amazing and they have raw sugar cubes, the experience with the coffee was almost as good as on my couch only it got better with the french toast with the fresh berry compote (I'm drooling as I'm writing this review). Me and my friend also ordered the veal, and the polenta, both were exquisite. The staff was friendly, they didn't rush us and when we were torn with the choices their recommendations were spot on.

I have also previously had a dinner experience here, which I can't complain about either, and of course the burger is to die for which I opted out of that evening and got the muscles, which were a bit on the over salted side for my taste, but still delicious nonetheless. This restaurant is definitely a must to dine at.
author: yana Z.

description: Great spot amazingly located on Washington square park in north beach. Dinner was very nice...had the hake which was lovely and the sides of fries and brussell sprouts were really good. A friend had the chicken which is the highly rated dish but thought it was slightly overrated... All in all great dinner though. Tried it for brunch since - even better. Pancakes are a must try, delicious..plus they do an awesome Bloody Mary - love this spot (four and a half stars!)!
author: Kate G.

description: Absolutely delicious! A bit on the pricey side, but if you don't mind spending the money, it's well worth it! Be sure to make a reservation as it's always busy. If you go for brunch, don't forget to order a Hummingbird! Yum.
author: Anne-Marie H.

description:
AMAZING. The 3 variations of duck dish is HIGHLY reccomended. I really, really like duck. This rich dish is served with duck liver pate, duck confit, crispy duck skin pieces and duck breast. There are fava beans and mushrooms as the vegetable, which complimented the richness of the duck very well.

Each type of duck was cooked perfectly and so full of flavor. I will definitely go back. We also had the fried baby artichokes as appetizer, which was great, too. Not overly heavy and served with a tasty aoli. Very good food, highly reccomend.
author: K M.

description:
Nice setting, tough acoustics for conversation and surprisingly tiny portions.

Been to Park Tavern about ten times and I've noticed a slight downward regression in both the service and food quality.  It's disappointing too because the setting is really nice and the vibe usually quite good.

I hosted a business dinner there last night for six people and for 700 bucks we ended up all sharing two pizzas a few hours later.  The lamb and steak entrees are inexcusably small for their 38 and 40 price tags.  Maybe the lamb portion was four ounces, maybe.  There's really no excuse for this other than the restaurant trying to goose its margin.

I think the only item we all really enjoyed was the deviled eggs which are a treat.  The sardines were mediocre, as was the shrimp appetizer. 

The service was also average -- not bad, but not great either.  The staff generally seems disinterested since they take for granted that they'll be busy every night.  Nothing to overtly complain about but the service definitely wouldn't fly in a xl parable restaurant in NYC.  That's for sure.

All in all, I think I am moving on from Park Tavern.
author: LA Kings L.

description:
My first impression of this place: why the heck is it so freaking cold in here? It's a tavern, isn't it? Isn't a tavern the traditional place you go to shelter from the cold? I mean yikes, I never took off my jacket or scarf. I know restaurants make it colder because that makes you want to eat more, but I just felt sort of chilled the whole time I was there. 

I really liked the way their menu was organized (smoked, fried, marinated, tomatoes, etc). And there were lots of choices, whatever your craving was. I especially loved the heirloom tomato and burratta dish, presented on a very cool piece of slate. I thought all the dishes were presented so beautifully, and came out at a great pace. Our server was lovely, and it seemed all the people around us were lovely, too (tables are kind of close together, it got hard not to eavesdrop). Everything was delicious, and I encourage anyone to try their chocolate creme brulee with chili and lime. Very unique, with great flavors. 

Still, I'm not sure I was down with the atmosphere. In addition to being chilly in the front table section, the place was very loud and around 8pm, they dimmed the lights. This might have created a nicer vibe if we hadn't been ordering, as the print on their menu was seriously as small as they could possibly make it and the space was already kind of dark before the mandated dimming. Also, it seems like they went to a lot of trouble to fit their massive wine list on one page of paper, which made it extremely difficult to read (even for the folks at the table with perfect vision).

The location is prime, and it was nice to take a walk around the neighborhood after our meal, so I think I would rather come back here during the day. Maybe it wouldn't be so damn cold inside then, and I would be able to read the menu without the squinting.
author: Rachel A.

description:
NOW OPEN! 

We landed reservations for opening night at Park Tavern and to my surprise, we had one of the best seats in the house.  One would argue that they were not the greatest seats in the house, because we were by the kitchen and in the back - but from the angle I was sitting at, you could see all of the food being served and people watch from a distance. Simply excellent. 

Park Tavern is a sharing kind of a place.  You order and share to maximize your experience.  Here's everything we shared - beware, it's a long list for 2:
- deviled eggs: so amazing. bite size heavenly, deliciousness 
- raw halibut: TASTY! 
- beef carpaccio: perfect seasoning with a hint of mustard! 
- burrata: not my favorite, the lime salt (similar to Marlowe's brussel sprout chips but on deep friend lemons) was too salty for my palate
- pork belly bites: you get a TON... so be prepared
- seared scallops: a trio of perfectly plated scallops
- seasoned creamy greens: just the right size of creamy greens
- fig and apple dessert: the crust, fabulous. if you're an apple/fig fan - a must get. i'm a fan of neither... should have stuck with the cake

Casey, one of the managers, complimented the bottle of wine we had ordered. I think it was the Muscadet on the list - but now it slips my mind.  Crisp and light - just how I like my whites. 

Opening night = packed house.  Looking forward to seeing how the restaurant does in the upcoming months!
author: Lisa L.

description:
So many things delicious things to try! Finally, a great reason to visit North Beach for dinner.

I attended the friends and family dinner and can't wait to become a regular. Similar to sister restaurant Marlowe, the newly opened Park Tavern understands the needs of the neighborhood and delivers.

The menu offers diversity depending on whether you want small bar bites, apps and salads or sides and entrees. It's a large and enticing menu (especially all the apps and starters), and I can't wait to try it all from a perch at the bar. My favorites from the meal- oysters caeser (fried oysters in lettuce wraps with caeser dressing- unique and so delicious), beef carpaccio with fried horseradish, and the pork belly. 

One of my favorite things about the restaurant is how they make the beautiful grand surroundings feel intimate by the delicious food from the same award-winning chef at Marlowe. There's a beautiful sit-down dining room for the impress-your-date-or-out-of-towners meal, a gorgeous bar and communal table for locals that want to drop in for tasty food and a full bar, and cafe-type seating by the windows overlooking washington square park for a more informal bite with a glass of wine. To me, this type of ambiance is part of what makes San Francisco restaurants so special, and Park Tavern nails it.     

Plus, there's valet parking. Yay! 

Welcome to the neighborhood, Park Tavern!
author: Gina W.

description: I love this place. Ambiance is great, staff is warm and friendly, and the cocktails and food are pretty tasty. Check it out. One of the classier joints in North Beach.
author: Kelsey B.

description:
Overhyped. Overpriced. 

*Note: This review is for brunch, not dinner.* 

I freakin love brunch. It's kind of a problem. I think about it during the week, planning for my next brunch fix. There are few breakfast establishments that miss my scavenging eye. So, when I discovered that Park Tavern had recently begun to serve brunch, I was giddy with excitement. I mean, they serve cocktails in PITCHERS for god's sakes! What could go wrong?

Do not be lured in by their pitchers (although their menu insinuates otherwise, only 2 of their cocktails are offered in this form) or the flawless, if sterile, Restoration Hardware decor. This was a highly average brunch experience. Here's a breakdown:

To Start:

-Sourdough, Dungeness crab & green goddess toast:  This could have been fabulous! But what was the deal with the toast? Instead of the crunchy, flavorful Tartine-style slices we were hoping for, we received small doughy triangles, already getting soggy from the crab and green goddess on top - kind of like old lady cucumber sandwich bread. Plus the dungeness crab topping was only so-so. You know it's a fail when you think to yourself, "I could have made this better at home."

To Drink:

-PT Bloody Mary:   I'm really glad they got this right, otherwise I might have cried. However, these bloody maries are made with a beef broth, which was a sad discovery for my vegetarian sister, who loves bloody maries and couldn't get one here. The "veggie alternative" (see below) was such a sad excuse for a cocktail - it should really be taken off the drink menu.

-Bloody Maria:   This is usually made with tequila, but my sister asked for hers with vodka to make it more like a classic bloody mary. Unfortunately, nothing could help this drink. "Grass" is the first thing that comes to mind when drinking this, and not in a good way. It's essentially like drinking watered-down salsa with alcohol. Not good.

-Boozy Smoothie:  Another radical drink. Coffee, banana and bourbon. Amazing. Only sad thing was the tiny glass it came in.

Main Courses:

-Cornmeal Pancakes: These were dry and uninteresting. The lemon curd was good, but they were not even close to Mission Beach Cafe's pancakes with bourbon syrup and vanilla cream.

-Country ham steak & poached farm egg: This dish was an odd combo of cold potatoes, mustard and cabbage with the eggs and ham done in the style of a benedict without the english muffins. It just felt off.  All of the egg dishes at Zazie blow this out of the water.

-"Marlowe" burger: My brother in law is a burger eater. He gets them pretty much everywhere we go. His rating for this one - good, but not on his top 5. (If you're wondering, NOPA's burger is #1 on his list.)

-Crispy polenta cakes: This dish was the best of the batch. The polenta was crunchy on the outside and creamy on the inside, the eggs were perfectly poached. However, even this dish was lacking something. A spice? Another ingredient? Not sure, but it didn't make up for the rest.

If you're going to charge as much as Park Tavern does, your food should be exceptional. Sadly, PT's brunch was really a let down. The hardest thing for these guys will be living up to all of the delicious and reasonably priced competition in this city.
