He was very attentive to my party and made the night an overall success. I would highly recommend Park Tavern for good food, drinks and service if Cristo is working with you!
author: L B.

description:
For Tom's "Choose your own adventure night' or whatever the hell he decided to try and brand it (the name's changed hourly and I still believe they all sucked) started here at the Park.

Okay so it is like Park Place tries to be a Tavern. This place is the exact opposite of anything dark or dank. It is very much bright and trendy and not tavern like in any way shape or form. For starters you don't bring kids to a tavern, there was no dartboard, and they have waaaaay too many kinds of wine to be a real tavern.

That being said it was a nice place with good service. I really liked the menu options but still settled on the well named Marlowe burger. It was a nice piece of beef with bacon and caramelized onions. Fries on the side with a beer up top and I was ready to praise this place as a great new stop. Prices were in the middle of the road but it was a nice place so the $14 for a burger didn't seem too out of line. They did have Speakeasy and IPA on tap after all...

Onward boys!
author: Nick B.

description: Very inventive Sunday brunch menu! Great Mimosa's! Plenty of seating at bar or in bar area with full menu, in cases you don't have reservations on a very crowded Saturday or Sunday morning. We had the Crispy Polenta Cakes with Wild Mushrooms, the Smoked Cod Cake, and the Avocado Toast. All were delicious! The "Toasts" are a great spin on the usual "bread & butter" toast. This restaurant is a fine addition to the Washington Square Area, and we will definitely be back.
author: Ira L.

description: Love the food, atmosphere and service.  First, the food is creative and delicious - we love the brussel sprout chips and deviled eggs.  The cocktails are also yummy.  The place is always buzzing - not a place for an quiet, intimate dinner.  And the wait staff is friendly.  Be prepared - the bill will put a dent in your wallet.
author: Serena S.

description:
I forgive Park Tavern for the five pounds they probably made me gain for serving deliciously captivating food that I couldn't help but gobble up as quickly as they put it down. The food is truly that good. I was going into the evening hoping to spare my waistline a calorie overload, but once I looked at the menu, I knew I'd be throwing those goals out the window. 

This restaurant has a charming, cozy and trendy vibe wrapped into one. Each table is within pretty close proximity of each other but it's so vibrant inside, you don't really pay attention to the table next to you. We began the feast with brussell sprout chips, burrata cheese with lemon basil chips and deviled eggs. I wasn't quite sure what to expect with the burssel sprout chips and my taste buds were pleased with the choice after just one bite. These are the leaves of the sprous basked in olive oil and baked to perfection. They are cirspy, salty and just plain delicious. The deviled eggs are just a perfect little taste and you can order them individually. I'm not typically a deviled egg fan but these were delicious. 

For the entree, I was told they are known for their poulet rouge (rotisserie chicken) so I had to order it. Yes, this chicken actually came out completely whole on the rotisserie skewer and sitting on a bed of potatoes and spinach. It was the most phenomenal presentation I've seen in awhile and the table next to us even made a comment! This is not your ordinary chicken either. No, they do something to this chicken to make it moist with flavor that's spicy and sweet all together. It almost tasted like a gourmet buffalo wing sauce. The spinach complimented the chicken. I didn't really eat the potatoes but mostly because my tummy was already begging me to stop consuming food! However, you can't end the night with chicken, so we shared a piece of birthday cake. Yes, they have birthday cake on the menu and each month has a different flavor. This month (March), they are featuring strawberry birthday cake. It's a heavenly combination of fluffy cake, creamy frosting and fresh strawberry mixed inside. It was a perfectly sweet way to end the meal and I can't wait until I get to visit this foodie's paradise again.
author: Lindsey D.

description: I went to the Park Tavern to give it a second try. As before the staff is exceptional. This time however, the food was great as well. There was almost too much burrata cheese with the lemon chips and I didn't know that concept even existed, too much cheese pah! Then followed up by the salmon which melted in my mouth. The portions look like they are appropriately sized however I was struggling to get the last delicious bites into my mouth.  All in all, a great meal. Thank you!
author: B S.

description: Good service, great food for apps and brunch--have yet to go back for dinner.
author: Ali A.

description:
I recently went to Park Tavern to try both the lunch with is only on Fridays' and for dinner.  

Both times I had the deviled eggs and they are as the tout fabulous.  The presentation is boring on the plate but I think that's on purpose since the egg itself is garnished very well.  

For lunch I shared the crab cakes and the salmon entry.  The service delivered the entry split even though we didn't ask for it. That was nice.  I was very happy with my lunch overall.  The restaurant was decorated very respectably for the holiday.  It wasn't too much or too little. Classy.

As for dinner, I had the game hen, which takes 30 minutes to cook.  It was worth the wait because we occupied ourselves with the wedge salad and the brussel sprouts.  What I liked about the wedge salad was that it was not made with ice berg lettuce but butter lettuce.  It was very nice.    The hen comes with stuffing and even though my friend and I split, I had enough for a light lunch the next day.  I suggest 2 eggs per person as 1 just leaves you wanting. 

I have already suggested this place to friends.  The restaurants starts to get a bit loud at the peek of dinner, but other than that, I have absolutely no complaints.
author: Elaine L.

description: I sat in the bar. I ordered the NY steak with marrow and crispy potatoes. It was really good. I ordered it medium-rare, came out on the rare side (which was fine).
author: Brooks D.

description: I think they should call this place "Salt Tavern." The roasted game hen was good for the first few bites, then it was nearly inedible because it was so salty (and I LIKE salty food!). The deviled egg appetizer was really good though...I could eat a dozen of them.
author: Rich L.

description: Gave me food poisoning.  Too much oil was my first thought.  Ate the oily deviled egg first, which was yummy (but oily).  Then had the Portuguese seafood stew.  It was basically just drowned in oil.  Way too much.  At first I thought I had a headache and no appetite to finish it just because of the oil.  But I was still feeling the effects the next two days, so I think it was more than just oil overdose, I think there was something wrong with the seafood.  My friend got a couple sides for her dinner, thinking to be healthier - and she had the same experience - just drowned in oil.  She had the twice baked potato dish and the brussel sprouts.  She felt sick for two days after as well.  So that's the food.  The wait staff was nice, but a little pushy.  I felt like our waiter twisted our arm to get the deviled eggs.  And for being an upscale place, I was surprised that they had metal chairs that you'd find in an outdoor festival or something for their dining room chairs.
author: David V.

description: Park Tavern is an amazing experience all around.  From the incredibly warm hostesses to the impeccable service, one feels like royalty here.  The food is extraordinary with fun plays on classics like deviled eggs & the wagyu beef jerky & a steak that gives the finest steakhouse a run for its money.   I'd be amiss if I didn't tell you that Park Tavern has the cities best burger hands down.  And if you save room for dessert, the birthday cake is phenomenal.  I have eaten at Park Tavern a few times now and have found it to be the epitome of perfection.
author: Samantha B.

description:
Went to Park Tavern last night (Sunday) after wandering around North Beach a bit trying to avoid all the tourist traps. It is a long weekend and the area wa very busy. Had not checked out this location since the venerable Moose's closed and so wasnt sure what to expect. The place was packed and so we sat at the communal table - fantastic experience and fantastic meal! The menu isn't extensive but very well-rounded and everything sounded great. The recommendations from the people sitting around us made the decisions even more difficult as everyone was raving about what they were eating. I finally decided on the Halibut with fennal and potatoes but was still debating on the sides - either Dungenss Crab Salad or Smoked Pumpkin Soup. The waiter recommended the soup, which I ordered and it was truly spectacular; it had a very smoky flavor, toasted pumpkin seeds and fried sage - outstanding! The Halibut was perfectly seared and roasted and was served with fennel with an excellent creamy-type sauce on it - very nice combination and something I'm going to try to recreate at home. My friend had the short ribs, which were extremely tender and flavorful. I had no expectations of having dessert, but I succumbed to  the "White Russian" Affogato - fabulous! Homemade white russian ice cream with an espresso and rum sauce and homemade marshmallow and cocoa nibs. Really spectacular and not overly large, which for me is actually a good thing in a dessert. My friend had the Almond Joy and raved about it as well. 

The service was very good, although perhaps a tad slow, but really nothing to complain about. The other diners at the communal table were all very social and we had a great time talking with everyone so any slowness really wasn't an issue. The atmosphere is excellent - upscale and a bit trendy, but restrained and tasteful at the same time. Overall a very diverse crowd with a very healthy sampling of the young and beautiful. 

Park Tavern is a great addition to the North Beach dining scene and I will definitely return. I strongly recommend it!
author: Gary A.

description:
Love the location, the ambiance, and the service staff!

I was here last night with 3 of my girl friends to try some of the signature items that were posted on yelp.  We each had the deviled eggs (delish! Who woulda thought to place bacon on top!) then we went to the 'demons on horseback'  prawns (five stars), the twice baked potatoes were great, the squash salad (glad I tried it but wouldn't order it again), brussel sprout chips (LOVE!) and burratta with tomatoes (refreshing and delicious).  Moving on to desert, my friend already had her eye on the fernet milkshake from the online menu, but our server made a recommendation for the coffee ice cream with toffee and a roasted fig.... so good!  it was light, flavorful and satisfying.
I will also give the service staff five stars for their patience with us because we didn't order any entrees this evening yet he never rushed us through the meal and he made excellent recommendations throughout the meal. 
I highly recommend coming here although it is best to make a reservation as the place is always packed.  
I will be back!!
author: Lauren C.

description: Love this place! Park Tavern is easily one of the best restaurants in the neighborhood. It has a really cool, classy vibe with a really big bar area and great drinks. Great date night spot that feels a lot nicer than anything else in the area. The food is really good too - get the brussel sprout chips! Definitely try to make a reservation here, the wait can be really long (or try to find a spot to eat at the bar).
author: Gina C.

description: One of my new favorite spots in the City. Take a date, take your wife or just go get a drink. Food is great and it won't dent your wallet.
author: Eric E.

description:
I loved this restaurant from the ambiance to the service to the food. 

Our waitress and waiter (she switched out halfway through) were both the perfect balance of hands off and speedy service. 

the food: i LOVED the heirloom tomato tart for starters - it was covered with creamy buratta and the dough was a puff pastry - what more could you want? 

my main dish was a delightful mahi mahi and we tried BOTH brussel sprouts (the started chips and the "side").  The starter is basically the outside leaves of brussels fried up into "chips" and the side is the remainder of those brussels cooked to perfection. I took half of them home, the portions were hardy.
author: A H.

description: Great atmosphere and location. Food was good and service was friendly and attentive. Good for a date, but probably not for a business dinner (maybe lunch?)
author: Michael B.

description: Seating is a bit cramped inside but the environment is clean and friendly. Service was good and attentive. The menu is pretty limited to just a handful of choices. I had the burger which was tasty. I can't say I would go back as the selection is too narrow and prices are a bit high for what you get. It's a popular brunch spot and if poached eggs are your thing this would do well.
author: Jonathan N.

description: Park Tavern never disappoints! Their brunch menu is fabulous. I always seem to come back to the polenta and the coconut fritters. You need a reservation on the weekends, it's busy. All in all a great brunch spot. I need to try the dinner menu!
author: Susan G.

description: Sunday brunch here was quite good.  We were seated promptly for our reservation at a nice table looking out onto the park.  Their pastries are delicious, the butter cake was described as five flaky croissants reduced into one yummy treat, and that was a very good description!  I had the crispy polenta cakes with mushrooms.  It was very good, although the polenta was more soft like cornbread than crispy.  But very tasty.  Service was excellent and friendly.  Would definitely like to come and try dinner at some point.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Solid 4 star experience that met my expectations. Burger was very good but nowhere near NOPA's. They split it for me and my friend as an app. We also split the green goddess salad, which was just ok. (Fresh parsley was the only flavor that popped; chicharrones were soggy and one of them way too spicy compared to the rest.)  

Then we split the poulet noir chicken. Cool presentation, moist & delicious. Beware: it comes whole and you carve it yourself. Gasp! I dig that, but imagine a lot of foofy people would balk it. Relax, the pieces come apart easily with a little knife work, and you can impress a date with your skillz.

Good wines by the glass. Hostess and servers had upbeat attitudes without being fake & annoying. Overall reasonably priced. Crowd seemed like mostly locals, which is refreshing in north beach. Packed on a Monday nite is a good sign that this place will last in a notoriously high turnover location.
author: Jon V.

description: The best thing about this restaurant is the outdoor seating facing Washington Square Park. The food is simple but good. I'd recommend the burger and the watermelon salad. The lobster salad was too salty and the small chunks of lobster were disappointing!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
One word: pork. If they have pork tenderloin on the menu, order that. If they have the pork chop, order that. If they have both, flip a coin. Pair with deviled eggs, brussels sprouts, and something fried. You'll leave stuffed and happy.

If they have neither (or you can't have pork), get the burger, maybe the chicken. If you don't eat meat, what are you doing here?
author: Steven L.

description:
Excellent Service! $12 valet a bit pricy but i don't mind paying for convenience. Cash only valet.

Must tries:

1) brussell sprouts chips (tasty and not too salty)
2) deviled eggs (amazing flavor)
3) marlowe burger w fries (juicy burger, perfect fries but prefer w ketchup not the aoli)

Yummmmmmmmm

The halibut was basic. Good but not outstanding. 

Park Tavern is great but I think I still prefer Marlowe.
author: A. Z.

description:
Not the best food, but great service.  I arrived and the valet was super nice.  My friends were at the bar and we were seated right away.  The waiter was able to share which items were gluten-free easily and was happy to do so.  I ordered the burrata w/ lemon chips and that was delicious.  The burrata was incredibly creamy and I liked the lemon chips served with them instead of bread.  The tangy lemon complimented the rich and creamy burrata.  I ordered the scallops for my entree and was less than thrilled.  The scallops were overcooked.  They were served with roasted cauliflower in a creamy curry-like sauce.  The flavors were decent, but the overcooked scallops ruined the dish.
The atmosphere was lively and the space was pretty nice too.  When I left the valet again was super nice and efficient.  I really wish the food had been better.  I'll try this place again, because I think it has potential.
author: Heather S.

description: Across St. Peters is yet another great brunch spot in San Francisco.  An old school bar feel on the inside, with an eclectic selection of brunch items.  The Prawns and grits was delicious.  Large shrimp with creamy flavorful grits really got our morning started out right.  Pricey yes, but well worth it.
author: Kris B.

description: Fabulous food! Everything we had was wonderful. You must try the brussel sprout chips! Service in the restaurant was great but the gentleman who serves drinks in the upstairs lounge is not very motivated. You are better off getting a drink in the bar while you wait, if you can get a seat. You definitely need reservations but it is worth it! I will go back and highly recommend the restaurant.
author: Colleen R.

description: Great Sunday brunch.  Started with the avocado toast and a delicious bloody mary.  Perfect location, friendly staff, and the kitchen was accommodating to special requests.
author: Jason G.

description:
I think we've eating at a ton of top SF restaurants including Gary Danko and the like. This restaurant rates one of the best of SF in my opinion. We had the deviled eggs, smoked crab dip, truffle fries, lobster bisque and the pork chop between my husband and I. Every bite was quite orgasmic in its own sense. The eggs were the perfect balance between creamy with a pickled pepper and a cilantro sauce. (better than Wayfarer Tavern). The smoked crab dip was plentiful and had a great smokiness top with Ikura. The truffles fried were seriously amazing. Shaved truffle, white truffle aioli, then a soft boiled egg with osetra caviar... Can it be any better? Then the lobster bisque was explosive with flavor not with too much cream. It came with a perfect bread pastry stick that made it almost too rich, but really it was perfect.then we had the pork chop which was brined then grilled. This was 3 stars in my book bc it leaned on the salty side and the polenta was overly creamy. I needed something to cut the richness.

The birthday cake was probably the least exciting. But it was birthday cake. Overall we loved our experience here an would come back!
author: Sadie F.

description:
Park Tavern, I like you. A lot.  I like you a lot more for your bites and appetizers than your entrees, but that's still saying a lot. 

Brussel sprout chips: Flaky, crispy, salted goodness with just the right amount of charring.
Lemon chips: Thin and crispy, with a bit of citrus and tang, and good with the burrata cheese, but just as good without. 
Foie gras terrine: I have to taste this one more time before foie gras gets  banned! Here's the thing, my allergies were acting up pretty bad and my nose was clogged, but i could STILL taste the  goodness. I can only imagine what it would taste like if my taste buds were at full capacity. Smoked kumquats were also yummy as well.
Twice baked potato: Dripping with yummy butter and creamy, with big bites of potato skin.
Fish dish: Can't remember what fish, but tender and moist, with a very nice crispy skin. Could have used more salt. Would pass for the next time though.
Marlowe burger: This was a bit of a disappointment and I can't understand the hype. True, the patty was juicy, but I didn't taste anything unique.  Also, I had one small clump of what looked like iceberg lettuce (maybe about an 1.25 inches in diameter placed exactly in the middle of my bun, along with the caramelized onions dead center and the aoili, so there was a pretty uneven distribution. Bites all around the edges only got me meat, bun, and bits of bacon (okay, the bacon was perfectly cooked, so I'll give you that. bacon chips!).  Anyhow, pearl's burgers are much better to me.  Oh, but the french fries were really good. Crispy on the outside and soft on the inside with just the right amount of salt. 
Pork chop: Omg. Looks like a freaking steak. Moist and flavorful, even with a clogged nose.  Great char on the outside too.  My friend (who actually ordered the dish) thought the pork belly was wonderful. Imagine foodgasm face.

Good attentive service as well, and I would definitely return, especially since I still want to check out the truffle fries and the homemade jerky.
author: ML N.

description:
I'm going back for the ambience and location as well as the drinks....and food.

The Poulet Rouge does not disappoint as it is indeed tender and so juicy with that iron cask holding the thing together.  That is one piece of impressive equipment to roast a game hen in.  The only gripe i have about the overall experience is that they love salted everything.  I left with a very dry taste in my mouth and it can only be attributed with salt.  Everything was drenched in salt, but not to the point of disgust, but a little over enough to notice "my, this is kinda salty"

Appetizers
-Lemon chips with burrata - simple, and yet refreshingly indulging
-Foie Gras Terrine with caramelized kumquats - excellent, but whenever is anything with foie gras not?
-NY steak crudo - probably skipable as a simple beef carpaccio would have been better imo and the pieces didn't come out in nice large thin slices, rather they were kind of scattered around in small pockets of the plate.
-Fried Oysters - comes in 4 and came with romaine lettuce and a sort of thousand island sauce.  Surprisingly good
-Chicken Sweetbread - if you didn't know what it was, you probably still wouldn't have figured it out at the end, because this thing is rich and pretty damn amazing.  Deep fried yet retaining a moist rich center.
-Deviled Eggs - needless to say, each person should get one of these 
-Demons on Horseback - but not everyone should get this.  its ok, but that bacon drags on the saltiness.  The prawns are delicious but again, nothing to rave home about.
-Brussel Sprout chips - still on top

Main
-Poulet Rouge - excellent over a bed of kale and potatoes but indeed salty
-Pork Chop - very tasty and moist
-Mussels - probably better as an appetizer for many to share because this monstrosity is so damn rich I my appetite can't afford it

Sides
-Creamed veggies - tasty creamed spinach
-Polenta w/ seville orange and red cabbage relish - very good
-Twice baked potato - kind of too much, but you should anticipate that
-Brussel Sprout hearts - I see where the rest of the brussel sprouts have gone now.  hah, but nothing too great.

My new favorite spot in North Beach.  It's settled.
author: Vincent K.

description: probably most classic place to hangout in the sunset.  grew up in SF and went to high school down the street, never been to this place.  once I walked in, I was like wow very nice and clean.  awesome bar.  reminded me of the harry's bar on fillmore.
author: Kevin L.

description: Amazing customer service! The staff got us a great table for Friday lunch, chilled & served our champagne, and surprised us with a birthday dessert. An altogether classy dining experience that helped facilitate some important business discussions.
author: xmarksthespot y.

description: Great atmosphere at Park Tavern - steakhouse meets Italian living room. The entire menu sounded rich and impressive and the food matched. Only downside was the copious amounts of butter and olive oil used... The lemon chips, red snapper crudo and deviled eggs were very unique.
author: Sandra S.

description: In Chronicle's top 100 so made reservations to take visiting friends out to dinner.  Our meal was a big disappointment.  The salad was over dressed, the pork chop was a lump of fat and gristle not to mention way over salted.  The tuna had no seasoning and had zero taste.  We ordered the creamcicle for dessert and it was five pieces or orange with a dollop of whipped cream.  We had to wait almost 30 minutes until I finally got our waiter's attention to bring us coffee which tasted like tea. Dinner was a $300 mistake
author: Evie F.

description: Love it! Went first for the Marlowe burger. Keep going back for the crazy standing up chicken.
author: Dan N.

description:
This place has really great food. I was so excited when this opened just a block away from my house. So why the low rating? 

Because every single time I've gone here, the prices have gone up. They've been open for less than a year.

Two examples off the top of my head: deviled eggs - from $1.50 each to $2 after they were featured in 7x7's 100 list. That might not sound like a lot, but it comes out to about a 33% increase. Next: the PT fries. I can't remember exactly what they used to be, but it was under $15 (probably more like $12). They're now $20!!! They're just potatoes with some truffle oil and caviar that you can't even taste.

I understand that you have to pay for quality food in San Francisco, but could the owners be any more money grubbing? I guess this is what happens when restaurant owners care more about money than loyal customers. I'm not sure if they think that the locals won't notice the large increases or if they're banking on a tourist crowd that will never know they're getting screwed, but they've definitely turned this local away for good. There are plenty of other great restaurants in North Beach that aren't money gougers.
author: Lele L.

description: My husband, father, stepmother and I enjoyed a terrific dining experience at Park Tavern last Saturday. Right away, all four of us just loved the ambiance and decor. The bar area was very lively and busy. We had a reservation and they seated us right away, although we were about 15 minutes early. We started with some cocktails, I enjoyed a Moscow Mule, my current favorite. Here though, they were a tad heavy with the lime juice and bitters - it was too tart compared to the ones I usually enjoy at other establishments.  My Dad and StepMom enjoyed some sauvignon blanc which they both said was very good.  Dad is serious about wine, and he remarked that their selections were impressive.  We next had the brussels sprout chips - soooo good. I'd had them at Marlowe and they were just as yummy here. I also had the pea soup, it was a summer style soup served at room temperature. It was a tad runny, but had excellent fresh pea flavor. Hubby had the prawns in lardo (sounds gross, I know, but it isn't what you might think) - they were heaven. Best prawns either of us had ever experienced. Dad enjoyed the anchovies and we all loved the fresh bread. I had the halibut on a potato and corn "risotto" and it was one of the best preparations of any fish dish I've had. Portions were perfect.  Hubby and StepMom had the black cod, they loved it. Dad had the Ahi, and also enjoyed it. We finished by sharing the peach cobbler and the dark chocolate creme brûlée...they were very good, cobbler was a tad bland, but it did allow for the flavor of the peaches to dominate, rather than the toppings, I guess.  Husband had a nice espresso and Dad and StepMom had dessert wines - all three were happy with their selections. The people watching was fabulous - a see and be seen sort of vibe.  Lots of very young women wearing clothing that left nothing to the imagination and/or shoes that were two sizes too tall and trying to gracefully navigate their way to their table or the restroom, and plenty of men admiring their efforts.  I think our only constructive criticism would be that every time our plates came out from the kitchen, they were delivered to the wrong person at the table and that the wait between appetizers and main course was every bit of a half hour, maybe more. That's a little too long, but we made the best of it with all that people watching. I would go back, for sure, and wouldn't hesitate to recommend it to others.
author: Rachel H.

description:
I'm going back for the chicken...  I mean the Petit Poulet Rouge...

Enough said right? If chicken is that good to deem a return, there's nothing more to say. But why? Now I would say it's the best damn chicken I've ever eaten, but I'm going to save you the hyperbole (that often exists when people talk about food) and note it's not actually chicken... it's game hen. Yeah same deal, but there is an advantage of using a young chicken that lends itself to being tender and juicy. That being said (and I'll go ahead use the word "best"), it is the best piece of roasted poultry I've had in the city. The fire roasted and perfectly seasoned skin would raise suspicion that the meat could be dry. Not so! As I attacked the wings and legs the meat was, excuse the KFC reference, finger lickin' good! Then as you slice into the breast meat and see the juice seep out you already know it's a winner. It was. Go get it. Stop reading all this hype. I should also mention that its standing at your attention when served to your table! You'll see. Go get it. Damn, I guess I did not save you the hyperbole...

As for everything else, it was above average if not very good. Park Tavern could be just another cookie cutter, urban socialite, new American cuisine with a signature bar program resto that has flooded the restaurant scene. So many of these types of places are just another face in the crowd. The element that hits is the food. And obviously that's the element that brings an establishment up to the high echelon of restaurants that will ensure its longevity. Soon enough it will be mentioned in the same breath as NOPA, Marlowe (its sister restaurant), Zuni Cafe, etc.

And one last piece, Park Tavern's poultry blows the following out of the water: Zuni Cafe's Roasted Chicken on Warm Bread Salad that has a one hour prep time from ordering and NOPA's Rotisserie Herbed Chicken. 

Damn, I really suck at controlling my excitement for food. Yay hyperbole!!!
author: Al L.

description:
LOVE this place!  Great experience through and through. The only reservation we could get was at 9:15 (they are always packed), but we got there early (parking spot right out front... how lucky is that?!) and had a couple cocktails. 
We were seated right at 9:15 at a cute 4-top in the middle of the restaurant. The restaurant has this hip new york feel to it, which I love. The server was super friendly and informative. We started with the Steak Crudo and Brussel Sprout Chips. The Steak was good... but it didn't blow my mind. The Brussel Sprout chips, however, we're out of this world. 
I had the steamed mussels with fennel sausage and leeks, and it was incredible.  The sausage and leeks were minced very finely into the butter sauce, which tasted ohhhh soo good when I spooned it into the mussell. They served it with a crusty crostini, which I used to soak up the remainder of the sauce. Everyone else got the "Marlowe Burger", which was good.. but I wouldn't go that route at Park Tavern personally. Go to Marlowe for it! Park Tavern has much more variety than Marlowe, so I recommend trying something different on the menu.
Will absolutely be back!
author: megan s.

description:
for dinner get:
-any of their special cocktails
-deviled eggs
-waldorf salad (made with housemade pickle juice)
-chicken (comes out standing up, so not for the fowl queasy)

for brunch get:
pancakes (amazing and fluffy, with syrup already in the batter)
any of the special toasts (they are small, so not a meal portion)
latte (comes in a cozy le creuset mug)

can't wait to go back.  everything i've tried there is delicious.
author: Josie M.

description:
Finally made it to Park Tavern this past Saturday for my sister's b-day.  We arrived about 30 mins early hoping to grab a drink at the bar before we sat down to eat.  The lovely hostess, Adrianne, told us our table was ready anytime and that we could either sit immediately or have a drink.  We opted to have a drink first.  The friendly bartender poured a couple of delicious drinks including an Old Fashioned and a Makers Manhattan.  $12 a pop, but that's pretty standard pricing for this type of restaurant.
Soon after we were seated at our table our server came over and poured the champagne that we had brought with us.  I called beforehand to ask about the corkage fee and they said they would waive it if we purchased of their bottles.  Our server recommended a fantastic Spanish white (Albariño Legado del Conde).  He also suggested a few apps that would go well with it including the Demons on Horseback and one of their raw apps.  Both were amazing.  We also ordered the Brussels sprout chips which were equally as good.  for mains we had the steamed mussels, pork cop, and the burger.  My mom said it was the best burger she's ever had and my pork chop was pretty amazing as well.  For dessert we had the apple crisp and the chocolate creme brulee.  Both were very good.  
Service throughout the meal was excellent which included a friendly, attentive, and knowledgeable server and bussers who came to fill water and clear plates at just the right times.
After dinner we had friends meet us at the bar where we stayed the rest of the evening.  The bar area was crowded but not so much that we couldn't find a spot to lean up against.   The bar area also has a long communal (I think) table for drinks and apps.  Not sure if they serve the full menu there, but it's a great spot to wait for your table with a drink if there's no room at the bar.
author: Marco C.

description: Stopped here for dinner with my grand daughter on a Tuesday. Night, this place was packed also the noise level was high, had a burger and frys,burger was great, but a bit pricey 17.00. I prefer a little less noise level , must be getting old. Won't be on my must return list.
author: Patrick Z.

description:
Went there yesterday and the overall experience was nice.  I would have given them 4 stars, however, I have to downgrade it to 2.  I ordered the game hen which was yummy, but I barely touched it because I was too full (being pregnant I get full easily) so I asked if they can put it to go for me.  We had a big party and we gave them a 30% tip.  

Since I had my son with me and he was getting restless I didn't check to see if they gave me the right to go box.  I should've check because this morning when I open the box instead of a whole hen I have  a fully eaten hen with just bones in the box.   Called and left the general manager a message and waiting to see if they call.  

With the amount they charge and the whole atmosphere I get yesterday I am shocked that I have to write this!
author: Helen P.

description:
people must be drinkin' themselves some happy kool-aid, because i can't figure out where they're getting all these 4 and 5 star reviews...

now, to be fair, maybe we went on a bad night.  meaning, we went on a night when the kitchen ran out of almost everything, the server had something more important to do than you know...take our order or check in on us, and then said kitchen refused to accommodate a preparation request (just leaving an egg off of something - super difficult, right?).  and while the bill was given to us hastily BEFORE we finished dessert, the two, young blonde women sitting next to us had their drinks and dessert comped because (as I overheard the same server say), "We're so sorry that we ran out of the things you wanted to order and apologize for the slow service."  W.  T.  F.

this was supposed to be a special night out with the boy in celebration of his birthday, but there was no recognition of this (or us, for that matter) by staff and at the end of our experience here, we felt thoroughly ignored.  there was a point...somewhere within the 30 minutes it took for the server to take our order as we watched him attend to everyone else...when we very melodramatically thought, "if we left, would anyone even notice...or care?"  

anyway, in a nutshell - we wanted to like park tavern, but the service was so piss-poor that i can't even tell you if the food was any good, nor can i remember what we ordered.
author: Nicole E.

description: Superb bartenders, delightful food. Get the pork chop. Unlike any other and better than most steaks.
author: Noah L.

description:
I recently went here for a late dinner. Everything was exceptional. My server was very helpful & knowledgeable. The food was out of this world! 

Between us we ate:

pork chop
halibut
nettle soup
burrata & fried lemon/mint
truffle fries
devilled egg

I couldn't find anything to fault. I love this place! Going in for brunch tomorrow.
author: Victoria C.

description: Reliably awesome yummy food, modern rustic atmosphere and great bar area. Highly recommend having brunch or dinner here if you haven't already.
author: N G.

description:
The waiters here are very nice and attentive. Overall, the food is amazing and although it is a bit pricey it is worth it! Here is a list of the items my friends and I tried in order of my most favorite.
1. PT Fries- Freaken amazing with the truffle oil aioli and soft egg with caviar.  Order this whether or not you are hungry. You will regret it if you walk out without trying it!
2. Crispy Lemon chips- Perfect bite of sourness and crunch to be eaten with a side of buratta.
3. Venison carpaccio and crispy bone marrow- just a small bite is enough.
4. The Bar Steak- I only liked the edge of the steak.
5. Seared Scallop- the scallops were delicious but small and not worth the price.
6. Grilled Pork Chop- I'm not a fan of pork chops so this dish was ok.
7.Banana Bread Pudding- a hybrid of banana bread and a s'more.
8. July's Birthday Cake- I really liked just the cake I could pass on the compote as it made it mushy.
author: Vannie T.

description:
Came back with my girlfriends this time.  It was easy to get reservations and a seat at the bar for drinks.  

I recommended we share a bunch of diff dishes so we can try more and I think it worked out well from my experience last time.  
Duck Liver Mousse - good
Brussel Sprout Chips - always a hit
Crispy lemon chips, fava bean hummus & sorrel - not the same w/ hummus, disappointed
"Demons on horseback" smoked lardo-wrapped prawns, scallion remoulade & celery leaf  - unexpectedly good
PT fries, truffle oil & parmesan, truffle aïoli, soft boiled egg & Osetra caviar - highly recommend if you like fried, delicious, richness.  
Roasted brussels sprout hearts, parmesan, sage & chili - standard
Grilled pork chop, wood fire-roasted yellow peaches, creamy polenta, Nueske's bacon & mustard jus - not a huge pork chop fan so it was ok.  
"Marlowe" burger, caramelized onion, cheddar, bacon, horseradish aïoli & fries - disappointing, not as good as I remember and all the write ups.  Our waiter was really nice to switch out the fries w/ PT fries.  

We ordered way too much food.  We also shared a dessert but I was so stuffed I couldn't even take a bite - unheard of!  All in all everything was good, including service but I don't need to come back for awhile.
author: Meredith K.

description:
I've been here for dinner and liked it so we made a reservation for Father's Day brunch to celebrate my mom's birthday.  To say the least, the brunch offerings were disappointing.  Here's the recap:

We ordered 4 dishes - Veal schnitzel, Line cook lunch, Ham steak & eggs, and Marlowe Burger.

The good: Marlowe burger - they can't mess up their signature dish

The bad: Ham steak  & eggs - nothing beyond what I can whip up at home and that's not saying much at all.

The ugly: Line cook lunch - Pieces of bacon were not cooked through and the cheese was still cold inside the bread.  Feel bad for the line cooks if they eat this for lunch.  Veal schnitzel was soggy (bad frying) and the inside was rubbery - can it get worse than that combination?   

Giving them an additional star only because the dinner was a good one.  Otherwise, this would be a rare 1 star review.
author: Yvonne L.

description: One of the most irrational and unsympathetic management team I've ever met. Not looking to get into details or contexts but do yourself a favor and never ever ever asked to talk to the hostess or the manager!!! They are the worst!!!
author: Ryan B.

description: Office Holiday party at PT tonight-divine. We had "The Cafe", i.e.the front part of the main dining room up against the windows overlooking Washington Square Park. SO fun- you're still in the mix w/ the rest of the restaurant, but it feels like a private space.  Alicja helped me set everything up, and Brian and crew ruled as servers, keeping the wine/cocktails flowing and being super attentive w/out bugging.  The food!!! Standouts were burrata on lemon chips w/pea tendrils, (duh) Brussels sprout chips, (duh again) deviled eggs, poulet rouge and sliced filet in red wine jus. They even did a couple of vegan/gluten free platters for the "special" people in my crew which were delicious and much appreciated.  A total success- Thank You PT!!!!!!
author: David M.

description:
HF:  In the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit. Amen.

ME:  Bless me Father, for I have sinned. My last confession was 11 months ago.  These are my sins.  I secretly hoped Joey & Eddie's would go out of business.  But since we both know the Big Guy is Italian, I'm sure He hated the tasteless food, wasteful portions, and gaudy decor as much as I did.  Do you think he'll hold it against me?

HF:  Say 10 Hail Mary's.  What else?

ME:  I started with a margarita and 6 deviled eggs.  6 Father!  6!!

HF:  Were they delicious?

ME:  Sinfully.

HF:  Say 10 more Hail Mary's, and next time eat 7 pork belly bites.

ME:  7?

HF:  7 my son.  Did you order an entree?

ME:  That's the worst part Father;  I ordered the Marlowe burger, medium-rare.

HF:  Blasphemy my son!  You realize he was an atheist?!

ME:  But I washed it down with a pint of the Monte Python Holy Grail Ale.  That should even things out shouldn't it?  

HF:  Maybe.  Did the burger come with cheese?

ME:  Cheddar.

HF:  Say 1 Our Father and make an Act of Contrition; have dinner at Rose Pistola...or even worse, Bottle Cap.

ME:  Must I?

HF:  Free will my son, free will.  Now, let's hear it.

ME:  I am sorry for my sins with all my heart. In choosing to do wrong and failing to do good, I have sinned against you whom I should love above all things, even those eggs.  I firmly intend, with your help, to do penance, to sin no more, and to avoid whatever leads me to sin.  In your name, have mercy, please don't make me eat at Bottle Cap -- Amen.
author: daily r.

description: I can't believe I've waited so long to come here.  This place is not only an amazing place to come to for a delicious dinner, but you can also enjoy some pretty fantastic drinks in a warm and inviting atmosphere with friendly and attentive service.  Brought my husband here for a celebratory birthday dinner, and we couldn't help but try out some of the dishes that my fellow Yelpers raved about.  Everything you've read about the deviled eggs, brussels sprout chips, and demons on horseback are absolutely true and even better than you can imagine.  For our entrees, I had the halibut and hubby had the steak frites - so well cooked, tender, and so well flavored.  For dessert, they surprised hubby with a huge slice of "birthday cake" on the house! Classy, Park Tavern, really classy.
author: Julie P.

description: have eaten here 4, 5, or 6 times, can't keep track, but never have a bad meal or poor service, whether at the bar by myself eating or with a few friends at a table!  Definitely make a reservation, and KEEP IT, you can never beat this wonderful menu, anything you have will please the palette, smokey devilled eggs and definitely pork chop!!!!!!!!
author: Chantel N Brett W.

description:
Ed and Mary Etta Moose made Washington Square Park the cradle of civilization in North Beach starting in the early 1970's when they brought us The Washington Square Bar & Grill on Powell at Union and later at Moose's across the Park.  Each was a landmark destination that became the hub or portal that unified San Franciscans in dialogue and spirited collaboration that enriched and never eroded the quality of life and spirit in 'The City That Knows How".  I loved Park Tavern before I nibbled a single bite for the tribute table honoring Mary Etta Moose, the artist, gourmand, philanthropist and spirited voice of beautiful North Beach, the community.

I haven't tried the much of the menu yet, but I can attest to the quality and scrumptiousness of their burger, my heart's true calling.  I first tried Marlowe's after it first opened and loved it, especially the burger and fries.  Kinship to Marlowe's becomes harder to see the deeper you explore the eclectic, electric and exciting menu, and the more you take in the design that marry's so many warm and comfortable elements, remembered and wanted, that simply aren't in evidence elsewhere in the city.  The place is crowded like Moose's was, and the crowd is a melting pot like Moose's so it's got the feel of a place you want to be a regular at and be known by name and your unique peculiarities by the staff and your fellow regulars.  Former Mayor Brown has dubbed the place a success and a must stop on his weekly rounds, so maybe it arrived before the delivery.

The exposed kitchen that Ed and Mary Etta created is spiffed up and is the anchoring element of the well executed restaurant.  It's amazing how good the 'bones' of Moose's remain, because I still feel Ed's warmth and big personality greeting one and all in the space he so lovingly created.  I said the menu is exciting and that may be an understatement because although the focus appears to be on small plates and the unusual, the food is stylish and uber sophisticated.  It's also a little on the pricy side, but that isn't hindering anyone from making their way here and back so I'd say they're doing a lot of things right and their customers think so too.  The bar is wonderful and drinks are inspired and delicious, the staff are well trained and well chosen.  Beer and Wine lists are well thought out, and the whole place is clean and inviting, masculine and powerful, a real testament to North Beach and Ed Moose, this place is a compelling winner.
author: Stu S.

description: One of the best meals I've had in a long time. Impressed by everything:  country lawyer, deviled eggs, brussel sprouts chips, tuna and poulet. Love.
author: m t.

description: Great atmosphere and very cool space!  I am so sad to say it because we wanted so badly to love it, but the food wasn't great and execution was poor.
author: Jen N.

description:
Came here with a friend after SFGate alerted me to absolutely nothing going on in the City. It was a Monday after all. I heard Park Tavern was popular, and thought if anything was going on at Washington Square, it would center around the tavern. I had 9pm reservations, but we showed up early and found a spot at the bar. Jake, our bartender, greeted us like we were regulars... his charm and skillful mixology was enough that I abandoned my reservation of an outdoor table in favor on eating on the old Moose's bartop. I thought Gary Danko made a great blood and sand, but this one - served neat with an aromatic orange peel kiss to the sides of the glass - was tops. We had the obligatory deviled eggs and brussels sprout chips (YUM!), and while I ordered the only beef entree on the menu (NY Kobe Steak) my friend ordered the Poulette Noir. One note: it's best to sit at the bar when you order the Poulette Noir, it really does take 30 minutes, and you'll need at least one drink refill before it arrives.

The food was outstanding, but what made the night was Jake. He was soft spoken and cheerful, joining in on jokes and telling us stories about the bar and his travels. We were having so much fun, we actually closed the bar after an impromptu grappa tasting and a particularly tasty bit of cheddar. 

For my experience, Park tavern is a place to go alone or with a good friend. Belly up to the bar and find Jake or one of the other skilled bartenders to guide your night.
author: Sean-Franc S.

description:
Came here on the suggestion of a friend of a friend. With the name, I wasn't really expecting much. I thought it wouldn't be much more than an upscale pub! Ok, not quite... way, way better than that (and I'm not dissing upscale pub food... there is a time and a place for yuppie sauce and garlic/sweet potato fries... there were Fried Sunchokes instead! A yummy alternative...so maybe some of it does classify as upscale pub food) As a vegetarian, such places can present me with the problem of: what the eff do I eat that isn't a carb bomb?! Not so, here. Thank goodness. Though I would have been happy with a glass of wine and three courses of dessert at this place, I'm not ashamed to say it. 

I was so excited to see that they had Brooks Pinot from Oregon! The sight of it on the menu made me gushy. I believe their wine director is an Oregonian. I nearly passed out from pleasure. My favorite non-California purveyor: organic vineyards, reasonably priced, amazing light, true pinot noir. I should have gotten a whole bottle. (To share, of course.) My sommelier friend who was having dinner with our party was very impressed by their wine list, too, s it had a great range of reasonably priced-and-also-delightful wines and the impress-your-business-associates-or-your-date fancy pants French bottles, too. She knows a lot more about California wines than I do by about 30 years of experience, having lived and worked in the industry in Napa for the better part of two decades, so that's a good sign, too. 

We arrived party of five, pre-dinner rush on a Saturday night without a reservation, so we weren't expecting prime seating, or anything. We were seated outside, which was fine, (fun people watching is always the appeal of San Francisco for me, there's a beautiful park across the street, and it's not an exceptionally loud or busy street, so just fine with me. Interesting to see all the fancily dressed folks arriving and popping out for the valet) since we didn't call ahead and it was a beautiful San Francisco spring evening, perfectly warm with the sun still shining and the heat lamps on us.Sometimes being seated outside can mean you get ignored by the wait staff/the somm, but not so here. We had a wonderful waiter. I unfortunately can't remember her name... attentive, and always seemed to be there when we needed her, without being overbearing. I never once felt rushed. 

The food. Oh my gawd. Let me preface with... I was here with fellow chef friends, so we were not just some pile of neophyte tourists with travel/wine goggles on, oh mah! Ok, so I was starving, but I also didn't have any expectations. My favorite way to approach any old thing, so I'm even more delighted when the food is really damn good. Which it was. 

The Parissienne Gnocchi... melt in your mouth. The English Peas with a creamy pea... sauce. Ugh... I'm sure it had some prettier name I'm not remembering, but it was so delightful, I could have licked the plate (I didn't. I have a few manners, at least). I wanted seconds, but my stomach would not have been happy with me. I definitely ate more than I should have, but I wanted to try it all. Fortunately for my waistline, I didn't. Wheel me away in a cart...

The place doesn't stand out to me aesthetically, at least from the outside, so I was just thinking it would be another California bistro. Blah blah blah. I didn't spend the time checking out the interior much, because I was more focused on eating and drinking and hanging out with my group of friends, because that is why we are here, no? So that's not a part of my review. Thank goodness the app plates are on the smaller side (but still, very generous, enough to share, but share several) and so I got to try a little bit of everything, so long as it didn't have meat on it. (My friend got The Demons on Horseback, which looked so delicious that I briefly considered breaking my 20 year streak of no meat...). The presentation was pleasing, beautiful, but not overly fussy. The flavors spoke for themselves. No need to gussy things up to an OTT level, to take away from the fact that your food is just so so like some not-to-be-named-here other supposed hot spots on the SF restaurant scene. 

I do wish there had been some sort of vegetarian main, in case you're not in the mood for sampling all the sides (I was. I usually am. That way I get to try a variety) though the meat dishes actually made me drool (seriously I haven't eaten red meat since before middle school, so that's something) and want to take a closer bite... I mean, look. It seems like they change up their menu though, so I'll be excited to go back in a few months when I'm in the city again for work, and maybe they will have a whole new slew of amazing to investigate. 

One thing: thank goodness I got to put this on a business account, because the tab was in the $400 plus range, and one of our party was a small child who only had a lemonade. 

Spendy, but worth it, especially if someone else is paying.
author: WildCowsofBoont A.

description: Had plans to go to Mama's for breakfast but the line up the street was about a two hour wait in cold drizzly weather so we quickly changed destination and landed at Park Tavern, a stone throw from Mama's.  What a delicious surprise! Our  brunch food was extraordinary.  The pancakes with rosemary infused blueberry compote were delish.  The pancetta cakes topped with poached eggs out of this world and the wheat avocado chili and lemon oil was a hit with our vegan in the group.  Overall, this place offers amazing food, great service in a very beautiful, comfortable setting.  Don't miss it when in SF!
author: Adriana P.

description:
Oh Park Tavern I want to love you and have been waiting patiently for you to open in my hood, but after my meal last night you have simply left me sad and confused. I arrived on time for my reservation and was told to wait in the bar. Fifteen minutes later my party was seated. Our waitress greeted us and was a little off from the start. She gave two of the three people at the table water and walked away. She then returned to announce that bread and pork fat butter would arrive soon with great enthusiasm. The bread and butter shortly arrived and I was less than impressed with the fancy hawaiian bread and butter that tasted simply like butter. We ordered a bottle of wine and our food. The pork bites arrived first. What the hell is this restaurant doing serving fancy pork rinds?!? I was so confused when they were placed on the table. These are the pork bites I have been reading about?!?! On a better note the deviled eggs came next, the highlight of my meal. I wish we ordered more than one per person for the table, because these are keepers. For my entree I ordered the famous Marlowe burger. A burger I have enjoyed many times at Marlowe, a burger I only ate half of at Park Tavern. The burger was simply OK, nothing like the Marlowe burger and nothing to write home about. We also ordered the twice baked potato side to share for the table, my first bite was amazing, my second was just OK and the third just sucked.

I know Park Tavern just opened, so I will give you a second chance. Please don't let me down again.
author: Kathleen E.

description: Grabbed a late night dinner reservation on a Friday night. We had the brussel sprout chips (great) the demons on horseback (great) and the fondue which had a lot of bread and not a lot of actual fondue unfortunately. Then we split the braised beef short ribs which were amazingly tender and delicious. The meal was very good overall.
author: Rachel W.

description: Absolutely delicious! My friend and I started with the banana and coconut fritters that came with raspberry and chocolate sauce for dipping. AMAZING! They were so good and crispy and the sauces were fantastic. I had the burger with fries with horseradish aioli on the side - extremely yummy. My friend had the corned beef hash which was also good. We finished with the bread buddying which was probably the best I've ever had...Pretty affordable, great location, and good service! Only problem was finding a place to park but the food was totally worth it. I will be back!
author: Julia M.

description: wonderful restaurant and great service! The staff was great, which was surprising with how busy they were. the food was delicious and atmosphere was perfect. I would recommend this place, however the parking was somewhat of an issue and valet was not complimentary.
author: Sheena P.

description: Last night I was a bit disappointed. Overall I still love the ambiance & decor as well as the fabulous service... But everything was so salty. I had the arugula salad and their special: grilled seafood- scallops & calamari... Both dishes were super salty. I was too lazy or too hungry to complain since it was getting late...  So unfortunately I doubt I will come back here to eat... perhaps if I do, it would only be to meet friends for drinks.
author: Myra M.

description: Can't speak for the food since I've never eaten here but a great place to sit at the bar and have a glass of whiskey or scotch near Washington Square Park. Bartenders are nice and quick. Not too crowded but never dead.
author: Binh D.

description: A little over priced, fun fancy brunch spot and really good bloody marys! Sometimes the wait is pretty long at popular brunch hours too
author: Jill G.

description: Went there for dinner on Friday night.  Fun crowd but very noisy, to the point that the conversation was impossible.  Hip surroundings and people.  There were 6 of us and all three of those that ordered hamburgers, said they were over-cooked and dry.  What good restaurant that has a hamburger on the menu, wouldn't know how to cook it properly? Waitress offered to redo them but since we had already waited an extra 30 minutes to order, they declined.  As compensation, they provided free desserts......TWICE!  They had forgotten they already served it!  Four out of 6 would not return, 1 would and 1 was unsure......
author: Paula S.

description:
Hot spot, but it's overated, by far. But some good things to go along with the poor or average items.
Great menu, not alway executed well. We were a four top, and spent $240 on wine, 3 apps, and main courses for four. Hard to talk across the table with the noise.
LOTS of looking going on, attractive people.
Waiter acted like he was sure we knew he was good, but couldn't get bread on the table, candle lit, silverware didn't make sense, all done by rote, timing was very off, and no thought applied.
But the food... must try the brussel sprout chips, fabulous. The "Demons on Horseback" are heavily sold, but honestly, shrimp with a little fat and veges, didn't impress me. Deviled eggs are hard NOT to like, these were actually good. Two of us had the pork chop, a disaster of odd misses. Oversalted, HIGHLY oversalted,  long leaf spinach, mixed in with turnips that were rubbery, (honestly, couldn't cut them with the knife), and chunks of bacon, square cut, but TOUGH, along with a butterflied pork chop, (really, the only reason to do that is to hurry up the cooking). But the meat WAS tasty, mostly due to the high level of fat on the chop,  in a delicious reduction.
Rubbery scallops, (same word 2x), but in a nice sauce on as skewer. The other entree was the tuna, not memorable.
Chef friend of mine, also said he had a terrible meal, accented by really lacking service. 
When restaurants get hot, they just get frantic, and forget how to keep up the ideas and effort that all DO work, and they go for the turnover, and hope to be successful being formulaic without good management. This is one of those spots.
You have to go to see the buzz, but PLEASE, rate it right, forget the hype!
author: Peter C.

description:
First time we dined at this place were couple years ago and they were good - both the food and the service.
As we go to SF at least once a year, this time, we decided to dine there again as it's next door to our Bed and Breakfast, and we remembered the food was good.
Unfortunately, we were disappointed this time - both the service AND the food.

For drinks, we opted to have cocktails in lieu of wine - hubby had Treasure Island (Barrel-aged gin, fennel syrup, Dolin Genepy des Alps & lemon); and I had Duboce (Bank Note scotch, yellow chartreuse, Benedictine & bitters) -- they were good and very strong - straight to your head strong.

We started our meals with Crispy Soft Shell Crab, it was good, it had very good crispy coating that's not oily at all - we were happy.  We also had Brussels Sprout Chip - pretty good but they were very oily.
For dinner, I had The Bar Steak while hubby had Grass Fed Ribeye; ordered medium rare for both.  For mine, with description of grass fed bisto filet - I expected the filet to have nice flavor.  To my surprise, it came sliced and I already knew I would only going to have my first bite as the juicy bite as I saw the juice from the meat was on the bottom of my meat.  I'm sorry, but. . . I had better meat from regular market.  It was not taste good at all, overcooked (more like medium toward well done), and super dry due to the slicing - which they possibly not let the meat rest first as well. 
Hubby's ribeye had better taste and cooked perfectly as medium rare; his was also served sliced, but his was not dry like mine - possibly because lots of fat on the meat.

To cap off the night, hubby had May's "Birthday" Cake while I had the TCHO Chocolate Creme Brûlée.  The "Birthday" Cake was plain yellow chiffon cake with plain cream cheese frosting - couldn't taste any of the brandied apricot coulis & peach cream cheese frosting as they detailed on their menu.  As for my Creme Brûlée, it was not as good as I remembered I had it couple years ago; plus the chocolate biscotti that came with it were soggy and old tasting.

As for the service, our waiter was pretty ignorant - she only came by to take our order after I gave her the look as we were sitting for 20 minutes or so waiting while she was too busy "entertaining" 2 other tables next to us that were bigger parties (6-people table).  The bus-boy was much more attentive as he asked if we wanted some bread and never failed to fill up our water glasses.

We definitely will skip this place on our future annual visit to SF.  There are so many other restaurants that offer much much better food and services - sorry Park Tavern, you definitely failed us.
author: Ivy S.

description: Brunch double date at Park Tavern. Food was beautifully presented and taste as good as it looks. Between the four of us, we ordered three different items (the walnut and raisin pancakes, two orders of the crispy polenta, and the smoked salmon benedict). The pancakes were huge and hearty, but I could have eaten another smoked salmon benedict as it wasn't very filling. Service was friendly and professional.
author: Jess L.

description: We sat up at the bar and ate. The food was great. The bartender was awesome and gave us some great recommendations. I would have given a 5 star rating however I had a bad experience with the valet and management wasn't very helpful. Valet service seemed very friendly. I even gave the guy an extra big tip. Unfortunately when I got home and remove items from my trunk I noticed a huge gash in my brand new car. I contacted the the restaurant the next day and spoke with Peter. He was very apologetic and said that he would contact the valet company. The Murat from the valet company told me that he would not pay for any damages unless it was reported before I left and told me "This is why you have insurance". Peter offered to send me gift certificates to make amens for my bad experience however he never came through with it.
author: Thuy K.

description:
If you haven't been, Park Tavern is a must. Great food, great service, and a great time. If you can't get a table because of short notice, try the bar. They have a waiting list, but it only took us 15 minutes to get seated (the long public table is first come first serve). We returned within two weeks of our first visit - my girlfriends 30th Birthday. On that note, it is a great spot for a special occasion. I dropped by early to drop off a special bottle of wine that we love, and to make several small arraignments.  The hostess was extremely nice and very helpful.

The main courses are great, but my girlfriend and I also like to dine on a number of appetizers, which are all amazing: burrata w/lemon chips, carpaccio, salads, gnocchi, deviled eggs (I normally do not particularly care for these, however I love them here), etc. They also have a great wine, beer, and speciality cocktail list.  I will be returning in the very near future.
author: Will R.

description:
Thoroughly enjoyed our dinner at Park Tavern last night! Everyone we encountered there was warm and friendly. It was an upscale environment without a shred of snobbery. Not always easy to come by!

Here's a run down of what we had: 

Deviled eggs. Yum! A crisp and crunchy piece of bacon atop the light whipped yolks, just a touch of heat in the back of your throat from the pickled jalapenos!

Compressed Watermelon and goat cheese salad with olives. Perfect salty and sweet combo. The watermelon was sooooo good!

Brussel sprout chips. A great munchie app. Nice touch of citrus. Not overpowering but just right. 

My friend had the seafood special. I tried her scallop and fried oyster. Both very tasty. She cleaned her plate so I imagine the other sea creatures were also delicious.

I had the roast chicken. It was insanely good! I would say better than Zuni! They poured fresh au jus with lemon over the chicken when it was served which sizzled in the skillet and blended beautifully with the spinach. My friend was eating my spinach before I even took a bite! 

A-Mazing waiter. So fun. He didn't rush us along and was very helpful in explaining different items on the menu. He gave us a free dessert on top of the dessert we ordered. Chocolate creme brûlée with sea salt and then he brought us chocolate ice cream on cocoa nibs which was light and sweet. They apparently do whipped egg whites with whipping cream. So light and fluffy! Heaven. 

Will def be coming back here!
author: Carol W.

description: Went to the friends and family tasting last night.... AMAZING!!!! Well done Anna. Particular highlights: deviled eggs, burrata, and the cornish game hen.
author: James R.

description: I had the iron skillet farm eggs for brunch. Great ambience! The service and prices could have been a bit better :)
author: Alexis C.

description: Love Park Tavern and I order the roasted chicken the minute I sit down. My fav is the stuffing...literally thanksgiving on a plate, but for summer they decide to NOT do stuffing. I want my stuffing back!! Service was exceptional, as always. Special shout out to the new hire from Boulder! He's great!
author: Vivian F.

description: I was pleasantly surprised to secure reservations for two on such short notice. I was expecting a line around the block? This was the best brunch that I've eaten in a long time. The polenta cake with truffled shrooms and poached egg was amazing!!! The Confit Chicken was a plate of amazing textures with shards of crispy chicken skin. YES YES YES. It was clear that happy people work here. I love to see that. This will be my first dinner destination next time I visit SF. The space felt warm, unfussy, and classy... the holiday decorations compliment it well.
author: Staci W.

description: Had dinner (again) here on Saturday night. Great vibe and energy. Bar was packed. Can't get enough of the deviled eggs. It's always hard to get newbies to believe that they can be that good!
author: mickey w.

description: I can't say enough great things about this place. I adore Park Tavern. Love the location, love the interior, love the vibe, the service, the food, the drinks... everything. The Poulet Rouge - a MUST. The mussels are fantastic. The cocktails are great. I can't wait to go back again.
author: Courtney E.

description: Ate here last month and I really had a good time. Great service, food was excellent. I had the scallops, which were great and my dinner date had the tuna, which was really amazing. I liked the atmosphere and I thought that the menu was priced just right and I honestly had a really great time there. Well done! Oh and P.S. the truffle fries are out of control!
author: campbell b.

description: I really wanted to like this place since its only a 15 minute walk from my place.  The restaurant is set up nicely.  The food was just ok.  This place is always busy.  Its tough to get a reservation during normal eating times.  Usually only 5 and 9 are available.  If you have eaten at wayfare tavern you have therefore eaten here.  I thought their other restaurant Marlowe was better.
author: Fatty A.

description: Wow!  What a beautiful job they did making this place look lovely!  Very inviting and nice people!  The food is delicious!  Everything that I tried I loved!  My favorite...fried green tomatoes, fig W/deep fried polenta & the scallop W/grapefruit.  Oh & they make beef jerky that is wonderful!  Great service!  Welcome to North Beach!!!!!
author: Lynnet S.

description: Went to Park Tavern for a girls night and we loved it! We got there at 7:30pm Friday night without a reservation, but, with a little team work, were able to snag a table at the bar in no time and it was the best seat in the house! We had an awesome waiter who anticipated our every need and when we hesitated on the wine decision we got some much appreciated guidance from their wine guy and ended up with an amazing cava we were all raving about, until he brought us the next bottle which was even better. The pork belly bites were sinfully, melt-in-your-mouth delicious and I highly recommend the brussel sprout chips, just to keep it healthy. Totally relaxed environment, but you're totally taken care of. Best of all worlds!
author: Bri K.

description: I would not consider myself a "fine diner" and the menu scared me because I didn't know what anything was! But the waiter was so helpful and knowledgeable about the menu. I ordered the Malowe Burger. IT WAS AMAZING!! The others I was with order pork chops, scallops, chicken and the filet. Everything was great! It's also a beautiful place inside with a cool bar on the other side. Highly recommend this place to try something different and delicious.
author: Alex S.

description: We were invited to the friends and family pre opening and were so impressed with the decor and food, even though this restaurant has only been open a few days I am sure it will be one of the top restaurants in the city. There have been a few other restauurants in this space since Ed Moose that have not done well but these folks are pro's and it shows.Better make your reservations soon the opening is on the 1st.
author: daniel l.

description: Great food,great drinks,great service.A little pricey but I don't mind when everything is good.I'll go back.A bit of a New York feel which is a nice change after 100's of times eating in the area.
author: Julian C.

description: A bit pricey but they do deliver a great product and experience. The thing that stands out the most is how the management takes initiative and strives to succeed.
author: Kyle C.

description:
I have to update my review and since my last write up we have returned to Park Tavern at the request of their General Manager Ileah. We were kindly contacted by the Maitre'd (Adrianne you're awesome) inviting us back. They expressed their utmost concern to rectify the situation with us since we left defeated last time. (I greatly appreciate them taking the time to read the reviews and having an open line of communication to their customers.) So, please know that they do see all the comments. With that said, I was still a skeptic and was hesitant about returning.

When we went back at to Park Tavern I decided seeing the place in the light of day may change my outlook. So, we went for brunch. My fiance and i both were blown away by the level of excellent customer service and professionalism. Adrianne was extremely professional and greeted us at the door. Ileah was sincere in her concern to make our experience wonderful and changed my whole outlook on the establishment entirely. (She is amazing!) Our waiter Bo was funny, amazingly knowledgeable and extremely kind. I'd come back just for his recommendations. Love him! It was honestly the most pleasant meal I've ever had, point blank and the period.

 The food was fresh, flavorful, and filling. Everything we had that morning was good! Forgive me if I do not recall the names of the dishes. We started off with the caramelized grapefruit brulee with creme fresh. Tart, sweet, and fresh! The butter cake is a must order! Described by our waiter as 6 butter croissants mashed into a hockey puck. Lol crazy good! The cinnamon sugar challah was soft, warm and heaven. My fiance ordered the special - an open faced chicken sandwich with apple smoked bacon, chili pepper, and special sauce concoction that left him completely silent for a couple of minutes. I ordered the french toast with fresh blackberries. It was enjoyable and I am not partial to french toast. 

The chocolate mousse brulee was delicious and neither of us had ever had a chocolate that was spiked with a kick of chili pepper. It was off putting at first but some how it brought out the flavor of the chocolate. If you are a chocolate lover I totally recommend! 

After this experience we agreed that we had forgotten what good service was and we needed to come back to park tavern to be reminded. We really did feel VIP for a day. The staff is kind and they really do care about great food and customer service and integrity. It's nice to see in a sea full of below par restaurants. I am going to chalk up our previous experience to an off day. I now have full confidence in Park Tavern and as long as the staff and food doesn't change I am looking forward to booking my wedding reception here :)

THANKS GUYS!
Tiffany
author: Kipani K.

description: The evening began with running late - spent 30 minutes looking for parking in the area. Called to let them know and they were gracious and had a table waiting. Oaxaca cocktail was good...a little smokey. Appetizer demons on horseback [shrimp] arrived cool not at temperature, which killed the flavor. Scallops good, not great. Too much going on with the plate to experience the true flavor of the East Coast Diver Scallops. Broccolini, good but smoke dominated the flavor. Stopped there, not enticed by the desert menu. Check came to over $100 pp.  Overall, the hospitality was warm, but just another expensive, unmemorable meal prepared in volume by line cooks... Absolutely nothing memorable except the check.
author: Abe S.

description:
I will start by saying our server was awesome! I wish I could remember her name.  :(

We made reservations and were seated right on time. (I hate it when you make reservations and still have to wait 30 minutes. It's like....hello? Why did I make a reservations?!)

I was with 5 girlfriends for a girls night out. We ordered 5 appetizers and hung-out and chatted for a bit before order our entrees. Everyone LOVED the DEVILED EGG and BRUSSELS SPROUT CHIPS. I guess those are the two most popular small plates. I ordered the HAWAIIAN AHI TUNA with squash & eggplant. It was pretty good. The tuna was seared on the outside and raw on the inside. There was a thin slices of eggplant. I believe it was Japanese eggplant because they were very small. The only problem was the the eggplant was burnt black. Not exaggeration, most of the slices were cooked past the point of tasting any eggplant. The squash however was cooked nicely and seemed fresh. The plate was filled with greens and a bell pepper dressing.

Two of the girls ordered the CRAB, MUSSEL & SOLE BOUILLABAISSE. Neither girl was a big fan of the dish. The felt like the broth was not as good as they would have expected. It was "just okay" according to them both.

However, the MARLOWE BURGER was a big hit with another friend. She said it was cooked just as she wanted and the meat was delicious.

Over all....the experience was okay. The waitress was great and the food was "good enough" but not my favorite.
author: Yelper S F.

description: Pearl took me here for my birthday.  Beautiful ambience, interesting and tasty food, warm service...in my favorite part of town.
author: Eric C.

description: Great new restaurant!  Location off the park is charming, the decor inside was really cool...very well done...and there are a number of sidewalk tables for outdoor dining...if the SF summer ever ends...the food was excellent...top items from our table were the lamb, NY steak, Marlowe burger and polenta.  We will go back.
author: Greg A.

description:
2nd time here on Friday night. Cannot go wrong with this place. Absolutely love their brussel sprout chips, I always order them. 

Probably the best deviled egg I've ever had... will be thinking about that one for a while.

This time I got their Country Line Harvest salad (LOVED the dressing) and leek and broccoli soup. The soup was wonderfully flavored and had depth, but I wish there was more texture - it was almost like water, although it tasted amazing (the lardons did add a nice touch, but you only get 1 every few bites b/c of the quantity... which is enough, but that leaves the rest of the spoonfuls too liquid-y)!
author: Sarah K.

description:
Thank goodness some joint has finally figured out how to actually charge a bunch of schmucks $20 for an order of fries!  Truffle fries that is.  Oh, but they have a poached egg and caviar that comes with it so it must be worth it!  My review is based on a pretty great client dinner we had there, but I am also going to disclose some pitfalls.  The truffle fries are amazing, even for $20, but the egg/caviar part is completely unnecessary.  For my entree I ordered the lobster bisque which came out luke warm at best so that completely ruined it.  I didn't send it back because I didn't want to upset the tempo of the business meal, but from a food perspective it was almost inedible.  People at the table who ordered the pork chop or steak were blown away by how good they were.  The seafood orderers seemedd just satisfied.  The table also ordered one of the giant slices of birthday cake, which was surprisingly delicious -- and I don't even like cake.  Great ambiance, pretty good service.
If I'd paid for my dinner, considering the bisque situation, I'd have been pissed.  Since I didn't, I'm willing to go back and try again with another client dinner in two weeks.  I think I'll stick with the good stuff:  fries and meats.
author: e w.

description: I had burger and grapefruit mimosa, husband had Bloody Mary. Everything was exceptipnally good.
